Posts.Title: Dads biopsy was positive

Posts.Content: I really dont want to travel into Manhattan every day for SRT for 8 weeks, so i contacted the local "suburban" treatment center of MSKCC on Long Island and asked them about the equipment they use. Curious if anyone can offer input/info They have 2 machines. one is a Varian True Beam. The second is a Varian EX-1. The woman i spoke with told me that she believes that the EX-1 is what they use for Prostate Cancer specifically, most of the time. It was installed about 3 years ago. The True Beam was installed a bit longer than 3 years ago. She's not a clinician but seemed pretty knowledgeable Anybody have any knowledge about whether these are good, most up to date machines that will offer lowest chance of permanent side effects in SRT? I was also told that if i decided to do the treatments out on Long Island, i could have everything done up to and including the simulation, in Manhattan, with Dr Zelefsky, then when i am ready to start treatment, i would get transferred out to the island for my daily sessions. The RO there has a primary focus on Prostate Cancer, almost exclusively. So that gives me some more confidence. Anyway, if anyone has knowledge about the machines, much appreciated. Garyi, no wiseass comments please.

Posts.Title: Radiation Equipment

Posts.Content: Haven't been around the last 10 days or so, was in Florida enjoying new home. But while there we got results of wifes ct scan taken 5 weeks after end of chemo for Ovarian Cancer. Abdomen and Pelvic scans were completely clean. 2 days later we get results of chest ct. CT Scans done 2 weeks ago, 5 weeks after chemo ended. Pelvic and Abdominal CT showed no sign of residual or recurrent disease, all clean. 2 days later, get an email, ct scan of chest report is available in the portal. It showed 1. 3 mm nodule in lung, referred to as "tiny" recommended monitoring 2. 21x17mm enlarged INTERNAL MAMMARY LYMPH NODE, which is on the same side as mastectomy 28 years ago. I'd be curious if anyone has any thoughts, comments, or similar experiences. I'm thinking it makes no sense that Frontline treatment for OC would clean everything up and drive down ca 125 to almost zero, except that 1 lymph node would be recurrence. So that leads me to think, maybe its BC recurrence? But does it make sense that after 28 years, there would be a LOCAL recurrence? She had Mastectomy 28 years ago, no recurrence since, although marker has been rising very slowly from low 30's to 50 over 8-9 years, dr said its just her new normal. I'm confused, a little scared, hoping its just lymph node inflamation resulting from lung collapse, and hoping the 3mm nodule on lung is nothing, i know they are pretty common and that is very small. Or maybe its just wishful thinking. Seeing Dr later this week, guessing he might want to biopsy lymph node if its reachable. Any thoughts appreciated. We've been through so much, and thought we were done for a while. now this. I know this isnt a breast or Ovarian cancer forum, but the BC and OC forums here are pretty inactive, and we've all had experiences. PS. AT this point, i dont even care to retest my PSA which was wrongly tested with standard test.

Posts.Title: new worries

Posts.Content: I would speak with a medical oncologist for a second opinion. NYU Perlmutter Cancer Center is a great place, I'm sure there are some good MOs that are experienced in PC there. Thinking about what i might do in your place, (which i may soon be, having lost my "<" in January), i would reach out to Prostate Oncology in Marina Del Rey, California, and get an opinion. I did that before i decided on surgery, and spoke with Mark Scholz, the Medical Director of the practice. They are MOs totally focused on PC, and they do phone consults. I sent them all of my records, and then we did a 45 minute phone consult, they charged me $675. After that, follow up calls are $75 for a 15 minute call. I know a number of guys with advanced cases that travel out there to be treated and/or advised by them

Posts.Content: Thanks guys. The lung nodule doesn't scar me much, I've read that over 50% of chest Ct scans show lung nodules and most under 3 cm are benign. It's the lymph node I worry about, but yeah, got to just wait to speak to Dr at visit on Wednesday. Of course he's a gyn onc so I'm guessing he'll either want to biopsy it or send us to a breast specialist. But who knows. I guess I just have to wait. The lymph node apparently was there on the last scan, about 5 or 6 months ago (wasn't mentioned to us till now) and back then it was 19 mm by 17 mm, now it is 21mm x 17 mm. 2 mm is tiny, so I don't know if that's considered stable or not but the report stated "not largely changed from prior image"

Posts.Title: The waiting game... (long)

Posts.Content: Mark, congratulations on making a decision, it’s always a weight off the shoulders when you get to that point. I can understand that the waiting 2 months could be annoying and nerve wracking. But PC grows slower than other cancers, even G8, and with only one core positive, it sounds like there isn’t any great danger. I just want to make one comment, with some hesitation. This is just me...I would not be real comfortable with a surgeon that’s only done 240 RALPS. Studies, as u probably know, show that the learning curve flattens at 300. Nevertheless, I’d want more than even 300. But it’s a very personal decision, just something to consider.

Posts.Title: new worries

Posts.Content: I think you just follow your current Drs advice, thats what we pay them for. As long as you have reason to believe he is good. But also worth looking up the guidelines yourself via google. FWIW, my surgeon, Ash Tewari, has told me that after one year of 3 month PSA tests, assuming they continue undetectable, he will move me to 6 months for the next year, then to annual. This is with a G7 (3+4) SO WIth a G6, you should be comfortable with annuals, i would think. On the other hand, if you prefer to be cautious, get it done at six month intervals

Posts.Content: Dave i agree with the others, go easy on the physical activity, its too soon, and not worth the risk. Re the coffee, immediately after my cath came out, i went to decaf, didnt cause problems. So after a week or two, i switched to caffinated, and i noticed the leakage increased in frequency. So i went to half caf keurig cups and have been fine ever since. Just my experience

Posts.Title: Doing great.

Posts.Content: Dave its great that you have 1. a uro you trust 2. an RO you trust and that you can hit the ground running with once the time comes 3. a clear plan that gives you some relief from the tortorous question of what to do. I have to say, your Uro's explanation is counterintuitive, but makes sense on some level. And yet, i have what all indications are, an UNagressive cancer, g7(3+4) and a low risk Decipher score (.37), but my PSA is rising very slowly. (.068 after starting to rise 18 months ago) So who knows. Since the medical profession doesn't have black and white answers in a recurrence setting, we just have to make decisions based on 1. what facts we know 2. how aggressive we are by nature 3. how lucky we feel. Its great that you made yours and have a clear path forward. It must be a relief, just like the feeling of having made a firm decision on primary therapy

Posts.Title: The waiting game... (long)

Posts.Content: I'm not a doctor and so I hesitate to give advice. As I'm sure you know, any grade 5 cells, are nasty. But it looks like you got a negative margin at the site of the grade 5, so it could be all out. You might need SRT. BUT THE LONGER YOU WAIT THE LESS CHANCE OF LASTING INCONTINENCE, and ED. So give yourself as much time To heal as possible. Any improvement of incontinence and erectile function, is frozen once you start radiation. For me, I'd want to see what my post op PSA is and if it's undetectable then I'd not be inclined to rush into salvage radiation.

I would consider sending ALL the cores taken, to Johns Hopkins , Dr Jonathan Epstein, or Boatwick Labs, Dr David Bostwick, for a second opinion.

Posts.Title: Pathology in: Gleason 7/3+4 with tertiary Gleason Grade 5, Lymphovascular Invasion

Posts.Content: Dave its great that you have 1. a uro you trust 2. an RO you trust and that you can hit the ground running with once the time comes 3. a clear plan that gives you some relief from the tortorous question of what to do. I have to say, your Uro's explanation is counterintuitive, but makes sense on some level. And yet, i have what all indications are, an UNagressive cancer, g7(3+4) and a low risk Decipher score (.37), but my PSA is rising very slowly. (.068 after starting to rise 18 months ago) So who knows. Since the medical profession doesn't have black and white answers in a recurrence setting, we just have to make decisions based on 1. what facts we know 2. how aggressive we are by nature 3. how lucky we feel. Its great that you made yours and have a clear path forward. It must be a relief, just like the feeling of having made a firm decision on primary therapy

Posts.Title: I was diagnosed 3 weeks ago with prostate cancer. Type of surgery.

Posts.Content: CIL. Sorry to hear you are having these issues. What you are referring to, voiding on orgasm, is more common than you may think, among men who've gone through Prostatectomy. You should discuss it with your surgeon. From what I know, which ain't much, the best thing you can do is make sure to empty your bladder just before sex.

Posts.Title: do i have pc?

Posts.Content: This is the scan I would get - I think it’s already approved and standard of care in Germany, check me on that, or Allmo will. The trial is being run at multiple locations, it might be at Cleveland Clinic, the link I included shows it’s being run at Case Comprehensive Cancer Center/Case Western. https://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT02978586 It’s more sensitive than Auxumin tracer. I don’t remember the limit if detectionfir Auxumin, but I think i recall reading it to be 1.0 or 5.0, either way, it would work for you at least inregards to your PSA. With that said, and I’m no expert, itvwould seem to me, that with a PSA of 10, it’s unlikely that it’s a node or two, or a spot or two, that could be radiated, it would probably be multiple mets that would require systemic therapy. But others, like Djin Tonic, Another, Allmo, Micheal F et al, will probably chime in, they know more

Posts.Content: This is the same task force that years ago, recommended that mammograms for the general population are not necessary. Because of family history on Breast Cancer, I’ve got a hard on for the task force. With that said, I get where they are coming from. But I wouldn’t want to be that one guy in a thousand (I’m not sure I buy into those stats). As Djin alluded to, this falls on the Doctors. They need to be responsible in their decisions to biopsy, using the more advanced tests like PHI, and educating patients in the nature of the disease, in an unbiased way.

Posts.Content: I really dont want to travel into Manhattan every day for SRT for 8 weeks, so i contacted the local "suburban" treatment center of MSKCC on Long Island and asked them about the equipment they use. Curious if anyone can offer input/info They have 2 machines. one is a Varian True Beam. The second is a Varian EX-1. The woman i spoke with told me that she believes that the EX-1 is what they use for Prostate Cancer specifically, most of the time. It was installed about 3 years ago. The True Beam was installed a bit longer than 3 years ago. She's not a clinician but seemed pretty knowledgeable Anybody have any knowledge about whether these are good, most up to date machines that will offer lowest chance of permanent side effects in SRT? I was also told that if i decided to do the treatments out on Long Island, i could have everything done up to and including the simulation, in Manhattan, with Dr Zelefsky, then when i am ready to start treatment, i would get transferred out to the island for my daily sessions. The RO there has a primary focus on Prostate Cancer, almost exclusively. So that gives me some more confidence. Anyway, if anyone has knowledge about the machines, much appreciated. Garyi, no wiseass comments please.

Posts.Title: 2018 US Preventative Task force recommendation on Psa screening

Posts.Content: This is the same task force that years ago, recommended that mammograms for the general population are not necessary. Because of family history on Breast Cancer, I’ve got a hard on for the task force. With that said, I get where they are coming from. But I wouldn’t want to be that one guy in a thousand (I’m not sure I buy into those stats). As Djin alluded to, this falls on the Doctors. They need to be responsible in their decisions to biopsy, using the more advanced tests like PHI, and educating patients in the nature of the disease, in an unbiased way.

Posts.Title: I was diagnosed 3 weeks ago with prostate cancer. Type of surgery.

Posts.Content: I would speak with a medical oncologist for a second opinion. NYU Perlmutter Cancer Center is a great place, I'm sure there are some good MOs that are experienced in PC there. Thinking about what i might do in your place, (which i may soon be, having lost my "<" in January), i would reach out to Prostate Oncology in Marina Del Rey, California, and get an opinion. I did that before i decided on surgery, and spoke with Mark Scholz, the Medical Director of the practice. They are MOs totally focused on PC, and they do phone consults. I sent them all of my records, and then we did a 45 minute phone consult, they charged me $675. After that, follow up calls are $75 for a 15 minute call. I know a number of guys with advanced cases that travel out there to be treated and/or advised by them

Posts.Title: Finasteride prescribed for early PSA rise following prostatectomy

Posts.Content: Haven't been around the last 10 days or so, was in Florida enjoying new home. But while there we got results of wifes ct scan taken 5 weeks after end of chemo for Ovarian Cancer. Abdomen and Pelvic scans were completely clean. 2 days later we get results of chest ct. CT Scans done 2 weeks ago, 5 weeks after chemo ended. Pelvic and Abdominal CT showed no sign of residual or recurrent disease, all clean. 2 days later, get an email, ct scan of chest report is available in the portal. It showed 1. 3 mm nodule in lung, referred to as "tiny" recommended monitoring 2. 21x17mm enlarged INTERNAL MAMMARY LYMPH NODE, which is on the same side as mastectomy 28 years ago. I'd be curious if anyone has any thoughts, comments, or similar experiences. I'm thinking it makes no sense that Frontline treatment for OC would clean everything up and drive down ca 125 to almost zero, except that 1 lymph node would be recurrence. So that leads me to think, maybe its BC recurrence? But does it make sense that after 28 years, there would be a LOCAL recurrence? She had Mastectomy 28 years ago, no recurrence since, although marker has been rising very slowly from low 30's to 50 over 8-9 years, dr said its just her new normal. I'm confused, a little scared, hoping its just lymph node inflamation resulting from lung collapse, and hoping the 3mm nodule on lung is nothing, i know they are pretty common and that is very small. Or maybe its just wishful thinking. Seeing Dr later this week, guessing he might want to biopsy lymph node if its reachable. Any thoughts appreciated. We've been through so much, and thought we were done for a while. now this. I know this isnt a breast or Ovarian cancer forum, but the BC and OC forums here are pretty inactive, and we've all had experiences. PS. AT this point, i dont even care to retest my PSA which was wrongly tested with standard test.

Posts.Title: new worries

Posts.Content: Thanks guys. The lung nodule doesn't scar me much, I've read that over 50% of chest Ct scans show lung nodules and most under 3 cm are benign. It's the lymph node I worry about, but yeah, got to just wait to speak to Dr at visit on Wednesday. Of course he's a gyn onc so I'm guessing he'll either want to biopsy it or send us to a breast specialist. But who knows. I guess I just have to wait. The lymph node apparently was there on the last scan, about 5 or 6 months ago (wasn't mentioned to us till now) and back then it was 19 mm by 17 mm, now it is 21mm x 17 mm. 2 mm is tiny, so I don't know if that's considered stable or not but the report stated "not largely changed from prior image"

Posts.Title: new worries

Posts.Content: I would like to correct a fallacy that's been stated here a number of times.. It is incorrect to say that surgery cannot be done after radiation. There are surgeons who do it, and some specialize in it. For example. The surgeons at MSKCC do it. Specifically, Dr James Eastham, you can go to his website and see that it's an area that he specializes in. It is clearly more difficult after radiation, and side effects Alan be more severe, but it can be done. Called Salvage surgery. I discussed this with my RO, in our consult. Also, there are other alternatives if brachybor EBRT fail, such as cryosurgery, and other treatments . So to say surgery is not an option after radiation is not correct. It's not as straightforward , but can be and is, done. Also, in my consult with the RO at MSKCC, he explained that salvage radiation, after failed surgery, is only successful 50% of the time.

Posts.Title: New patient in the box

Posts.Content: Thanks for your comments Jim. Regarding having to travel for salvage surgery, that's probably correct. I would think though, that it's done at all of the major NCCN Cancer Centers like MSKCC, Cleveland Clinic, etc, so probably available within 500-1000 miles of most. Being in the NYC area, I know of at least 3 surgeons who do it. Like I said though, it's no fun, very complicated and SEs are more severe Regarding the 5o% success rate, I have not researched this, as I said, it's a stat that was told to me by the RO at MSKCC, chief of RAd Oncology, at one of their suburban complexes. He could be wrong, and frankly, I sure hope he is. I should probably mention, that while I've learned so much in the last few weeks (not by choice) from this and other forums, reading studies n pubmed, and reading 2 going on 3 books, I'm far from an expert. So everything I say should be taken as opinion, not fact

Posts.Title: Someone ask me how my weekend has been...

Posts.Content: Mark, congratulations on making a decision, it’s always a weight off the shoulders when you get to that point. I can understand that the waiting 2 months could be annoying and nerve wracking. But PC grows slower than other cancers, even G8, and with only one core positive, it sounds like there isn’t any great danger. I just want to make one comment, with some hesitation. This is just me...I would not be real comfortable with a surgeon that’s only done 240 RALPS. Studies, as u probably know, show that the learning curve flattens at 300. Nevertheless, I’d want more than even 300. But it’s a very personal decision, just something to consider.

Posts.Title: Finally Made Treatment Choice - Waiting for Surgery Scheduling.

Posts.Content: Mark, congratulations on making a decision, it’s always a weight off the shoulders when you get to that point. I can understand that the waiting 2 months could be annoying and nerve wracking. But PC grows slower than other cancers, even G8, and with only one core positive, it sounds like there isn’t any great danger. I just want to make one comment, with some hesitation. This is just me...I would not be real comfortable with a surgeon that’s only done 240 RALPS. Studies, as u probably know, show that the learning curve flattens at 300. Nevertheless, I’d want more than even 300. But it’s a very personal decision, just something to consider.

Posts.Title: Finally Made Treatment Choice - Waiting for Surgery Scheduling.

Posts.Content: Haven't been around the last 10 days or so, was in Florida enjoying new home. But while there we got results of wifes ct scan taken 5 weeks after end of chemo for Ovarian Cancer. Abdomen and Pelvic scans were completely clean. 2 days later we get results of chest ct. CT Scans done 2 weeks ago, 5 weeks after chemo ended. Pelvic and Abdominal CT showed no sign of residual or recurrent disease, all clean. 2 days later, get an email, ct scan of chest report is available in the portal. It showed 1. 3 mm nodule in lung, referred to as "tiny" recommended monitoring 2. 21x17mm enlarged INTERNAL MAMMARY LYMPH NODE, which is on the same side as mastectomy 28 years ago. I'd be curious if anyone has any thoughts, comments, or similar experiences. I'm thinking it makes no sense that Frontline treatment for OC would clean everything up and drive down ca 125 to almost zero, except that 1 lymph node would be recurrence. So that leads me to think, maybe its BC recurrence? But does it make sense that after 28 years, there would be a LOCAL recurrence? She had Mastectomy 28 years ago, no recurrence since, although marker has been rising very slowly from low 30's to 50 over 8-9 years, dr said its just her new normal. I'm confused, a little scared, hoping its just lymph node inflamation resulting from lung collapse, and hoping the 3mm nodule on lung is nothing, i know they are pretty common and that is very small. Or maybe its just wishful thinking. Seeing Dr later this week, guessing he might want to biopsy lymph node if its reachable. Any thoughts appreciated. We've been through so much, and thought we were done for a while. now this. I know this isnt a breast or Ovarian cancer forum, but the BC and OC forums here are pretty inactive, and we've all had experiences. PS. AT this point, i dont even care to retest my PSA which was wrongly tested with standard test.

Posts.Title: new worries

Posts.Content: Dave its great that you have 1. a uro you trust 2. an RO you trust and that you can hit the ground running with once the time comes 3. a clear plan that gives you some relief from the tortorous question of what to do. I have to say, your Uro's explanation is counterintuitive, but makes sense on some level. And yet, i have what all indications are, an UNagressive cancer, g7(3+4) and a low risk Decipher score (.37), but my PSA is rising very slowly. (.068 after starting to rise 18 months ago) So who knows. Since the medical profession doesn't have black and white answers in a recurrence setting, we just have to make decisions based on 1. what facts we know 2. how aggressive we are by nature 3. how lucky we feel. Its great that you made yours and have a clear path forward. It must be a relief, just like the feeling of having made a firm decision on primary therapy

Posts.Title: do i have pc?

Posts.Content: This is the scan I would get - I think it’s already approved and standard of care in Germany, check me on that, or Allmo will. The trial is being run at multiple locations, it might be at Cleveland Clinic, the link I included shows it’s being run at Case Comprehensive Cancer Center/Case Western. https://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT02978586 It’s more sensitive than Auxumin tracer. I don’t remember the limit if detectionfir Auxumin, but I think i recall reading it to be 1.0 or 5.0, either way, it would work for you at least inregards to your PSA. With that said, and I’m no expert, itvwould seem to me, that with a PSA of 10, it’s unlikely that it’s a node or two, or a spot or two, that could be radiated, it would probably be multiple mets that would require systemic therapy. But others, like Djin Tonic, Another, Allmo, Micheal F et al, will probably chime in, they know more

Posts.Title: Need advice - PSA nuts again and what about PET/CT F-18 Fluciclovine (Axumin) scan

Posts.Content: I think you just follow your current Drs advice, thats what we pay them for. As long as you have reason to believe he is good. But also worth looking up the guidelines yourself via google. FWIW, my surgeon, Ash Tewari, has told me that after one year of 3 month PSA tests, assuming they continue undetectable, he will move me to 6 months for the next year, then to annual. This is with a G7 (3+4) SO WIth a G6, you should be comfortable with annuals, i would think. On the other hand, if you prefer to be cautious, get it done at six month intervals

Posts.Title: I was diagnosed 3 weeks ago with prostate cancer. Type of surgery.

Posts.Content: This is the same task force that years ago, recommended that mammograms for the general population are not necessary. Because of family history on Breast Cancer, I’ve got a hard on for the task force. With that said, I get where they are coming from. But I wouldn’t want to be that one guy in a thousand (I’m not sure I buy into those stats). As Djin alluded to, this falls on the Doctors. They need to be responsible in their decisions to biopsy, using the more advanced tests like PHI, and educating patients in the nature of the disease, in an unbiased way.

Posts.Title: One Year Result - No Man's Land Followup - Part 2

Posts.Content: Thanks for your comments Jim. Regarding having to travel for salvage surgery, that's probably correct. I would think though, that it's done at all of the major NCCN Cancer Centers like MSKCC, Cleveland Clinic, etc, so probably available within 500-1000 miles of most. Being in the NYC area, I know of at least 3 surgeons who do it. Like I said though, it's no fun, very complicated and SEs are more severe Regarding the 5o% success rate, I have not researched this, as I said, it's a stat that was told to me by the RO at MSKCC, chief of RAd Oncology, at one of their suburban complexes. He could be wrong, and frankly, I sure hope he is. I should probably mention, that while I've learned so much in the last few weeks (not by choice) from this and other forums, reading studies n pubmed, and reading 2 going on 3 books, I'm far from an expert. So everything I say should be taken as opinion, not fact

Posts.Title: 2018 US Preventative Task force recommendation on Psa screening

Posts.Content: I would like to correct a fallacy that's been stated here a number of times.. It is incorrect to say that surgery cannot be done after radiation. There are surgeons who do it, and some specialize in it. For example. The surgeons at MSKCC do it. Specifically, Dr James Eastham, you can go to his website and see that it's an area that he specializes in. It is clearly more difficult after radiation, and side effects Alan be more severe, but it can be done. Called Salvage surgery. I discussed this with my RO, in our consult. Also, there are other alternatives if brachybor EBRT fail, such as cryosurgery, and other treatments . So to say surgery is not an option after radiation is not correct. It's not as straightforward , but can be and is, done. Also, in my consult with the RO at MSKCC, he explained that salvage radiation, after failed surgery, is only successful 50% of the time.

Posts.Content: This is the scan I would get - I think it’s already approved and standard of care in Germany, check me on that, or Allmo will. The trial is being run at multiple locations, it might be at Cleveland Clinic, the link I included shows it’s being run at Case Comprehensive Cancer Center/Case Western. https://clinicaltrials.gov/ct2/show/NCT02978586 It’s more sensitive than Auxumin tracer. I don’t remember the limit if detectionfir Auxumin, but I think i recall reading it to be 1.0 or 5.0, either way, it would work for you at least inregards to your PSA. With that said, and I’m no expert, itvwould seem to me, that with a PSA of 10, it’s unlikely that it’s a node or two, or a spot or two, that could be radiated, it would probably be multiple mets that would require systemic therapy. But others, like Djin Tonic, Another, Allmo, Micheal F et al, will probably chime in, they know more

Posts.Title: Need advice - PSA nuts again and what about PET/CT F-18 Fluciclovine (Axumin) scan

Posts.Content: I'm not a doctor and so I hesitate to give advice. As I'm sure you know, any grade 5 cells, are nasty. But it looks like you got a negative margin at the site of the grade 5, so it could be all out. You might need SRT. BUT THE LONGER YOU WAIT THE LESS CHANCE OF LASTING INCONTINENCE, and ED. So give yourself as much time To heal as possible. Any improvement of incontinence and erectile function, is frozen once you start radiation. For me, I'd want to see what my post op PSA is and if it's undetectable then I'd not be inclined to rush into salvage radiation.

Posts.Title: New patient in the box

Posts.Content: Thanks for your comments Jim. Regarding having to travel for salvage surgery, that's probably correct. I would think though, that it's done at all of the major NCCN Cancer Centers like MSKCC, Cleveland Clinic, etc, so probably available within 500-1000 miles of most. Being in the NYC area, I know of at least 3 surgeons who do it. Like I said though, it's no fun, very complicated and SEs are more severe Regarding the 5o% success rate, I have not researched this, as I said, it's a stat that was told to me by the RO at MSKCC, chief of RAd Oncology, at one of their suburban complexes. He could be wrong, and frankly, I sure hope he is. I should probably mention, that while I've learned so much in the last few weeks (not by choice) from this and other forums, reading studies n pubmed, and reading 2 going on 3 books, I'm far from an expert. So everything I say should be taken as opinion, not fact

Posts.Title: New patient in the box

Posts.Content: Mike I think you are spot on. Most, not all, guys who've had a good outcome, with no recurrence, no side effects, tend to hang around for a few months, or a year or two, after treatment, then they move on. There are those however, and I've seen a number of them, do hang around for a long time, or at least drop in every now and then, to pay it forward, and help the new guys. This is something I've brought up, and has been discussed, on another forum I am on. And it's funny you brought this up, I was on that forum last night and saying to myself, how is it that PC is so often referred to as the "good" cancer (which I hate), when there re so many guys here who have or are recurring? But I knew the answer, and you just gave it. Selective bias.

It is clearly more difficult after radiation, and side effects Alan be more severe, but it can be done. Called Salvage surgery. I discussed this with my RO, in our consult. Also, there are other alternatives if brachybor EBRT fail, such as cryosurgery, and other treatments . So to say surgery is not an option after radiation is not correct. It's not as straightforward , but can be and is, done. Also, in my consult with the RO at MSKCC, he explained that salvage radiation, after failed surgery, is only successful 50% of the time.

Posts.Title: Rise in PSA with last positive biopsy 3 years ago

Posts.Content: Last night I had the most realistic dream, when I first woke up it was about a minute before I finally realized it was a dream I went for my one year follow up with the Surgeon (which happens to be considered Ming up in January) and he told me I need RT. With no sign of recurrence. In my dream I didn't have a result of the January upcoming PSA, but my readings up till now have all been zero's, and the Dr has told me I've gotten a less than 5% chance of needing any additional treatments. And even if I did have a rise in PSA in January, he would want a retest before recommending treatment. In my dream, I started looking for a Medical Oncologist for a second opinion. It was so realistic, that it spooked me. I remember that yesterday, in another forum, I read of 2 guys with my post surgical Gleason and negative margins, that had a recurrence. I'm sure that's what precipitated this. I'm stating to think I'm spending too much time on prostate cancer Internet forums.

Posts.Content: DD You are right. I do find myself seeking out cases like mine to see the outcome, I guess it's a natural thing for us guys to do. And yup, when it's not a good outcome, it sticks in my craw. I notice them much more than I notice the good outcomes. I guess another thing to keep in mind is that larger percentage of the good outcomes tend to disappear from the forums, while the ones who have less favorable outcomes are the ones that tend to stick around. It's a tough mind game that we tend to play with our own brains.

Posts.Content: T.hanks Lil Guy, and a speedy recovery for you. Chuck, thank you, no doubt you are correct. I spoke with a family member yesterday who is 6 years out and said he doesn't even think about it anymore. I wonder sometimes, if i was not upgraded fro G6 to G7(3+4), if I would have an easier time forgetting about it. I try to tell myself that. Then I have a dream like the one I mentioned and, well.... It makes me nervous. not logical, I know.

Posts.Title: Odd Dreams

Posts.Content: Saw new Uro. PSA has been slowly trending up last few years, from .7 in 2006 to 2.8 today. 6 months ago, at 2.2, biopsy was done and negative for PCa but positive for HI Grade PIN, in one core of 14. At todays visit, i was told of the 2.8 PSA, which Doc said he wouldn;t consider a significant rise (although it seems to me that it reconfirms the trend). But i was also told that Free PSA was 11 (i assume 11%). So my question is - how much do i need to worry? What are the chances that this is the beginning of my joining the club? Doc did a PCa3 today and ordered an MRI of prostate. Ugh. Here we go again.
Posts.Title: Psa/free psa

Posts.Content: BJW, I became very depressed when I was diagnosed a few weeks ago. I went to see my primary Care dr and he prescribed Lexapro, very small dose. I've been taking it every other day, but I am probably going to stop as I think I'm getting a grip. Some depression is common even after surgery, depending on a persons makeup. I am a glass half empty type, but I am going to try to fight it off by speaking with others who've gone thru it. I don't think anti depressant drugs can be good for you, but would take them if absolutely necessary. I'd rather take an occasional Xanax as needed. JMHO

Posts.Title: Depression issues

Posts.Content: Welcome lismil . You've gotten good advice above, and your question has been answered. I'll add that in the case of gynelogic cancers, it's different. Gynecologists are not as experienced in radical surgeries, and treating gyn cancers is very complex surgery, my wife just recently finished frontline treatment and surgery for ovarian cancer with a gyn onc, which has shown to have better outcomes than being treated by a gynecologist. Re your husband... I would normally say, first thing is to send the biopsy slides for a second opinion. But with so many positive cores, even if it's downgraded to Gleason 6, he'd still need treatment, so i don't think is necessary to do that. Chuck is correct, if you do surgery, 300 is about where the learning curve flattens out, according to studies. Still, I would want more experience. At the time of my surgery, my Dr had done about 4000 robotic prostatectomies. Among your list of questions for interviewing Surgeons, are How many ops have you done (using the method you recommend) What is your rate of positive surgical margins What is your rate of full recovery of continence? And erectile function? What are my chances of ACHIEVING THOSE TWO GOALS Do you do frozen section of intra-operative margins during surgery, to increase the chance of attaining negative margins? Should I hve n MRI to determine the chances that the OC might hve escaped the capsule? You should also interview MULTIPLE RO's who specialize in different forms of radiation therapy as primary treatment. Brachytherapy, both LDR (seeds) and HDR, the newer form of Brachy that is showing good results. And take a close look at SBRT, AKA Cyberknife, which is showing excellent results 9 years after it became approved. The more you know, the better informed decision you will make. And it's up to you guys to be your own advocate. Never forget that this is big business , and urologists like to cut, while radiation oncologists like to burn. If you do your due diligence, you'll never look back and say woulda shoulda coulda, because you'll know you've made an informed decision. Good luck and keep us posted

Posts.Title: Surgeon vs. Oncology Surgeon

Posts.Content: There have been studies that have shown that SRT is more effective when begun at a PSA of .03, IN CERTAIN SITUATIONS. Don't remember what those situations were, but if you believe in hitting it early as possible, that's where US PSA makes the most sense. I do the US, even though my surgeon has told me that he wouldn't recommend any action as long as PSA remains below .1, and even then the first step,would be imaging yo try to determine if they could find evidence of location of a recurrence. But for whatever reason, he uses the US test, and I trust him so I haven't questioned it. I might, after a year goes by, if I am still undetectable.

Posts.Title: Ultra-sensitive PSA test?

Posts.Content: Mike I think you are spot on. Most, not all, guys who've had a good outcome, with no recurrence, no side effects, tend to hang around for a few months, or a year or two, after treatment, then they move on. There are those however, and I've seen a number of them, do hang around for a long time, or at least drop in every now and then, to pay it forward, and help the new guys. This is something I've brought up, and has been discussed, on another forum I am on. And it's funny you brought this up, I was on that forum last night and saying to myself, how is it that PC is so often referred to as the "good" cancer (which I hate), when there re so many guys here who have or are recurring? But I knew the answer, and you just gave it. Selective bias.

Posts.Title: Any need for second opinion on negative biopsy?

Posts.Content: Mikla, am I reading correctly that your pathology showed Cancer I. The right Apex? That is one of my concerns , the apex is where there is the highest chance of positive margins and escape from capsule, as well as making it difficult to save the nerves. So if I am reading your signature block correctly that's fantastic. I have one core in the apex which is 80% G6. Worries me, although the pathologist at Johns Hopkins who I spoke with, told me it doesn't mean much.

Posts.Title: Choosing Surgeon in NYC

Posts.Content: There have been studies that have shown that SRT is more effective when begun at a PSA of .03, IN CERTAIN SITUATIONS. Don't remember what those situations were, but if you believe in hitting it early as possible, that's where US PSA makes the most sense. I do the US, even though my surgeon has told me that he wouldn't recommend any action as long as PSA remains below .1, and even then the first step,would be imaging yo try to determine if they could find evidence of location of a recurrence. But for whatever reason, he uses the US test, and I trust him so I haven't questioned it. I might, after a year goes by, if I am still undetectable.

When they retested, it came back at 0.00 Just a thought.

Posts.Title: PSA 5.0 at age 30. Very worried.

Posts.Content: My biopsy was pretty painless. Just annoying, as others have said. I didn't have any IV sedation. But i did take a Xanax before i left the house to go to the dr. and then another when i got to the waiting room, no doubt that helped. But as was already stated, the waiting was the harder part for me. I was a basket case for a week leading up to the biopsy, not knowing what to expect, and then after about a day or two of feeling relieved that it was over, i was a basket case again for 10 days waiting for the results.

Posts.Title: Odd Dreams

Posts.Content: There is so much talk of overtreatment, and unfortunately it does exist. The best way to avoid it, is to be educated, and seek out the best, most up to date, urologists and RO'S. Not to follow the guidelines of the USPSTF. The some group that advocated not doing mammograms for most women. Had I listened to those irresponsible a holes, my wife would be dead. And I'd be in a heap of trouble by now. It gets me so mad.

I think what we all need to remember is that these are broad statistics and doesn't mean a lot in the context of an individual case. I would go with your doctors prognosis

Posts.Content: T.hanks Lil Guy, and a speedy recovery for you. Chuck, thank you, no doubt you are correct. I spoke with a family member yesterday who is 6 years out and said he doesn't even think about it anymore. I wonder sometimes, if i was not upgraded fro G6 to G7(3+4), if I would have an easier time forgetting about it. I also wonder if, and my guess is that, (3+4) in general being considered LOW intermediate risk, means that (3+4) with negative margins , no EPE, ETC, would be considered VERY LOW intermediate risk. I try to tell myself that. Then I have a dream like the one I mentioned and, well.... It makes me nervous. not logical, I know.

Posts.Title: Odd Dreams

Posts.Content: Last night I had the most realistic dream, when I first woke up it was about a minute before I finally realized it was a dream I went for my one year follow up with the Surgeon (which happens to be considered Ming up in January) and he told me I need RT. With no sign of recurrence. In my dream I didn't have a result of the January upcoming PSA, but my readings up till now have all been zero's, and the Dr has told me I've gotten a less than 5% chance of needing any additional treatments. And even if I did have a rise in PSA in January, he would want a retest before recommending treatment. In my dream, I started looking for a Medical Oncologist for a second opinion. It was so realistic, that it spooked me. I remember that yesterday, in another forum, I read of 2 guys with my post surgical Gleason and negative margins, that had a recurrence. I'm sure that's what precipitated this. I'm stating to think I'm spending too much time on prostate cancer Internet forums.

Posts.Title: Odd Dreams

Posts.Content: DD You are right. I do find myself seeking out cases like mine to see the outcome, I guess it's a natural thing for us guys to do. And yup, when it's not a good outcome, it sticks in my craw. I notice them much more than I notice the good outcomes. I guess another thing to keep in mind is that larger percentage of the good outcomes tend to disappear from the forums, while the ones who have less favorable outcomes are the ones that tend to stick around. It's a tough mind game that we tend to play with our own brains.

Posts.Title: Odd Dreams

Posts.Content: Hi Chuck - thanks for the reply. Not meaning to be redundant posting on both forums but i am sure there are some folks that are on one forum or another and trying to get as much perspective as I can, being the worry wart that i am..... To answer your Q's, I am age 62, never had anything but a normal DRE. On this visit, the doc did what i would call the most vigorous DRE that i have ever had, i almost pee'd. I believe this was partly because he was doing the PCA3 right after that, which required such a DRE. After the DRE, he told me that it was totally normal, no nodules, no firmness. As far as BPH, in my TRUS biopsy 5 months ago they measured the prostate and it was 38 CCs, the biopsy report said there was some BPH, the Doc said there was, but it wasn't very bad, pretty much "normal for my age". Thanks for the info and article. i know the slow rise in Total PSA could be caused by mild BPH its the 11% Free PSA that is making me nervous.

Posts.Title: Finally some good news

Posts.Content: More good news. I had my slides sent to Johns Hopkins/Dr Epstein for a second opinion. He downgraded my G8 to a G6. So I am now G6 10%, G6 20% AND G6 80%. Changes things quite a bit. I actually got to speak to Dr Epstein, and he was very emphatic that it was a G6 and that I had months to decide on how to proceed. He also commented that I would be a very good candidate for surgery. So all in all, in the context of my "new world" I finally had a great day. I am still bummed that I have PC, but its now something I an handle. BTW the call of the G8 being a G6, was not based on a subjective eyeballing of the cells. It was based on his disagreeing with the premise noted in the original path report, used in the g8 call. Complicated to expain, but clear to me. I asked Dr Epstein to confirm that my understanding of this was correct, and he agreed.

Posts.Title: Finally some good news

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by lzicc That is great news. Please keep us updated. What is the next step now? Izicc, next step is final decision on treatment. I am heavily leaning towards surgery, but will meet with all disciplines and listen with an open mind. Unfortunately everyone is a salesman and I've learned that PC is a big business, so I will listen more to other patients that I speak to (I know a lot of people who've had the surgery, and also do my own research on the numbers. I've met with one surgeon, have an appointment with another this week. Both high profile guys. The one I met with was very arrogant, but at the same time seemed confident and caring, and his staff seems terrific, called me back when I had additional questions. Also meeting this week with my Uro whom I have not spoken to since he called me on the biopsy results, to discuss all options. Pretty sure he is going to push me towards Cyberknife, and meeting with his RO. I will meet with his RO BUT ALSO WANT TO SEE if I can get an appointment with a surgeon and an RO at MSKCC, as well as a surgeon that was recommended to me at Cornell-Weill, who I was told will give me an honest assessment of what my best option is, even if he thinks it's not surgery. As you can see I'm very skeptical of them all. I need to find on I trust. I have an appointment with a surgeon in my suburban area as well, but may cancel. He did a friend of mine who was very happy with him, but I don't know, I feel like I want to be in a major Manhattan hospital setting, don't know if that has any validity.

Posts.Title: Looking back after one year

Posts.Content: Mikla, am I reading correctly that your pathology showed Cancer I. The right Apex? That is one of my concerns , the apex is where there is the highest chance of positive margins and escape from capsule, as well as making it difficult to save the nerves. So if I am reading your signature block correctly that's fantastic. I have one core in the apex which is 80% G6. Worries me, although the pathologist at Johns Hopkins who I spoke with, told me it doesn't mean much.

Posts.Content: I would agree with Chuck, dont wait. Most important, you need to get to the bottom of what caused all that blood to come from your Urethra. Prostate cancer isnt usually a rush to treat kind of situation. But with that said, there is no reason to delay and find yourself behind the 8 ball. Those tests will give you a better idea of whether you are dealing with PC. I have a feeling you are not. But what do i know. As far as the wedding, i empathize. My wife was diagnosed in September with Ovarian Cancer, and my daughter is getting married a week from tomorrow. She had to go through surgery and 18 weeks of chemo (which she has 4 weeks left) but shes doing well, and feeling great, ready to party. These things have a way of working themselves out. And there is no doubt, that your son would not want you to delay, because you need to be around to see his grandchildren

Posts.Content: With a result reported at <.03, it just means that the lowest level of PSA that the machine can detect, is .03. And the machine couldn’t detect any PSA. So based on that assay, you are undetectable. With your good pathology, you should be happy with that result. Especially after only 6bweeks.

Posts.Title: Elevated and rising PSA, what should I do?

Posts.Content: Since the surgery is next week, id Say the one thing he should do if he hasnt done it already, is start kegels. As far as after surgery First make sure you have all the supplies you need. If you have a recliner, position it in front of the tv. And if you dont, rent one. Get an oval bucket to Carry the catheter around in, depends briefs, get a chuck to cover the bed just in case he leaks while sleeping. Get some ky jelly to keep the tip of his penis lubricayed where the catheter goes in. Gauze and surgical tape, for changing the dressing where the drain was. Get some sweatpants that have button down sides if you can find them, to accommodate the leg bag/catheter. Youll need a laxative, like Dolcolax, but the Drs office will tell you what kind they prefer. The hospital will probably have him up and walking the day or night if the surgery. If they dont then bug them. Its important to start moving ASAP. Laps around the hospital floor. And when he gets home, walk as much as possible, even if its just around the house. Its the most important thing. Walk walk walk. They will pump gas/air into his abdomen to widen the field in which they work. For this reason, he may have gas pains. I had it really bad for a week, if I wasnt told to expect it, I would have thought I was having a heart attack. But many others have less of a problem. Anyway, the way to get rid of the gas AND get his bowls moving or at least get him farting again, is to walk as much as possible. I was doing a mile a day on the treadmill with the catheter still in at the end of the first week (walking slowly, not running lol) Others will be along with all the things I forgot. Good luck, keep us posted.

Posts.Title: Husband scheduled to undergo RP next week

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by lzicc That is great news. Please keep us updated. What is the next step now? Izicc, next step is final decision on treatment. I am heavily leaning towards surgery, but will meet with all disciplines and listen with an open mind. Unfortunately everyone is a salesman and I've learned that PC is a big business, so I will listen more to other patients that I speak to (I know a lot of people who've had the surgery, and also do my own research on the numbers. I've met with one surgeon, have an appointment with another this week. Both high profile guys. The one I met with was very arrogant, but at the same time seemed confident and caring, and his staff seems terrific, called me back when I had additional questions. Also meeting this week with my Uro whom I have not spoken to since he called me on the biopsy results, to discuss all options. Pretty sure he is going to push me towards Cyberknife, and meeting with his RO. I will meet with his RO BUT ALSO WANT TO SEE if I can get an appointment with a surgeon and an RO at MSKCC, as well as a surgeon that was recommended to me at Cornell-Weill, who I was told will give me an honest assessment of what my best option is, even if he thinks it's not surgery. As you can see I'm very skeptical of them all. I need to find on I trust. I have an appointment with a surgeon in my suburban area as well, but may cancel. He did a friend of mine who was very happy with him, but I don't know, I feel like I want to be in a major Manhattan hospital setting, don't know if that has any validity.

Posts.Title: Finally some good news

Posts.Content: More good news. I had my slides sent to Johns Hopkins/Dr Epstein for a second opinion. He downgraded my G8 to a G6. So I am now G6 10%, G6 20% AND G6 80%. Changes things quite a bit. I actually got to speak to Dr Epstein, and he was very emphatic that it was a G6 and that I had months to decide on how to proceed. He also commented that I would be a very good candidate for surgery. So all in all, in the context of my "new world" I finally had a great day. I am still bummed that I have PC, but its now something I an handle. BTW the call of the G8 being a G6, was not based on a subjective eyeballing of the cells. It was based on his disagreeing with the premise noted in the original path report, used in the g8 call. Complicated to expain, but clear to me. I asked Dr Epstein to confirm that my understanding of this was correct, and he agreed.

Posts.Title: 3T MRI Question

Posts.Content: Today I had my MRI with contrast done at MSKCC. They are very thorough. They gave me a shot of something-or-other that is used to quiet the bowel, to minimize movement. And just before I went into the room, they took a wand and moved it over my body, to make sure I didn't have any metal inside me besides the 2 stents that I told them about. After the test was done, the technician who was a friendly dude made a comment that really surprised me. He said "in all the years I've been working here, I don't recall ever seeing a recurrence of prostate cancer." I'm like, "WHAT?" But I didn't respond or persue it, I just chose to believe it because we all believe what we want to believe. Now I wait for the results. With a PSA of .03 as of end of May, I'd be shocked if it picked up any prostate cancer. But I figure, exactly for the fact that I'm not worried about it, they will probably find some collateral unexpected thing that is worse, like bladder cancer, or some other disaster. But if I didn't think that, I wouldn't be me. One thing I know, if they do find that, I'm not having a cystoscope. No matter what. Ever. The MRI was done only because the RO wanted a baseline, just in case I continue to see PSA rising. Guess I'll call next week for the results. I'm too scared to sign up for the MSKCC patient portal

Posts.Title: Should I suggest a saturation biopsy...and how to prepare for the results

Posts.Content: Hi Chuck, I probably mis-stated what I intended to mean. I think they would be equally effective at finding any high grade cancer. My understanding is that a saturation biopsy is still a blind biopsy, but with many more cores, so we are playing with and increasing our odds. Vs an MRI guided which, from my understanding will give you a 90% + chance of finding anything that is hi gleason cancer. Which is more of a concern that G6. So why go through the (I assume) added pain of a saturation biopsy if you can accomplish at least the same thing with an MRI guided and less cores. anyone PLEASE CORRECT ME IF I AM WRONG, OR MISINFORMED.

Posts.Title: Newly Diagnosed & Taking the DaVinci Plunge (6/26/2017)

Posts.Content: I would agree with Chuck, dont wait. Most important, you need to get to the bottom of what caused all that blood to come from your Urethra. Prostate cancer isnt usually a rush to treat kind of situation. But with that said, there is no reason to delay and find yourself behind the 8 ball. At the very least, ask your urologist to do a PHI Blood test which is a more advanced and better test than PSA. Or ask for a free psa and PCA3. Then go from there. Those tests will give you a better idea of whether you are dealing with PC. I have a feeling you are not. But what do i know. As far as the wedding, i empathize. My wife was diagnosed in September with Ovarian Cancer, and my daughter is getting married a week from tomorrow. She had to go through surgery and 18 weeks of chemo (which she has 4 weeks left) but shes doing well, and feeling great, ready to party. These things have a way of working themselves out. And there is no doubt, that your son would not want you to delay, because you need to be around to see his grandchildren

Posts.Title: Cialis, Viagra or Sildenafil for Penile Rehabilitation

Posts.Content: If you post your general location others may be able to recommend a surgeon. I used Dr Ash Tewari in NYC, who has done iver 6000 Robotic Prostatectomies, and is world renowned, very well published, and trained under Dr Menon in Detroit, the father of Robotic Prst. Highlander had an excellent surgeon at Mayo whose name I'm sure he will chime in on. I'd like to make three key suggestions.... 1. Get a second opinion on the slides. From an expert in Prostate Pathology, either Jonothan Epstein at Johns Hopkins, or David Bostwick at Boatwick labs. The local pathologists look at all kinds of slides every day, lung Breast colon Prostate, etc. Prostate cell diagnosis is very peculiar and somewhat subjective. And it's very important to get it right, it could effect treatment options. I was originally diagnosed GLeason 8, but 2nd opinion, with dr Epatein, confirmed by pathologists at Memotial Sloan Kettering, downgraded me to GLeason 6. Big difference 2. Consider meeting with a Radiation Oncologist. I'm not recommending radiation,momma surgery guy.. But you should , as I was encouraged to , explore and be educated on, all options, so that when you make your final decision, you do so with confidence that you've done your due dilligence, and never look back and say shoulda woulda coulda. 3. Prostate cancer is big business. You must be your own advocate because many of the experts u meet with will have an agenda. So whether you want to or not, you should learn all you can.

Posts.Title: Should I suggest a saturation biopsy...and how to prepare for the results

Posts.Content: Felix, I think the second part for your statement is sort of correct, getting an immediate drop (hopefully) in PSA is a big reason that people choose surgery. It was a consideration for me. The first part though, is not so. If the Cancer has a high chance of not being organ confined, (which is blessed assessed with a 3 Tesla mpMRI ) then it might steer many away from surgery. On the other hand , if there is evidence of a lot of Cancer in the Prostate, there are some who think surgery is worthwhile, not to cure the Cancer but yo debulk it. This would be followed by additional therapy, hormone therapy, radiation etc, depending on the specific circumstances. There are many factors that go into deciding on surgery, including age and physical health, how the patient feels about side effects, which are different, sometimes more severe with surgery vs radiation., etc Did you get a second opinion on the slides? This is something you should do as a first step, with a lab / that specializes in Prostate cell pathology, like dr Epatein and Johns Hopkins , or David Bostwick, at bostwic laboratories. I don't knwo of any website that posts collectively, the data you are looking for.

Posts.Title: Treatment decision week- couple of questions

Posts.Content: Wishbone, welcome to the reluctant brotherhood that nobody wants to be a part of. But glad you found us. Michael has given you good advice. Everyone is different but one thing is quite common among us, the road to continence will be one of fits and starts. One step forward two steps back. Not linear. If you are prepared for that, you will handle the mental aspect much easier. One thing I did that helped measure my progress was, rather than just log the # of pads I used, I weighed and logged the pads. So I know how much I was leaking in any 24 hour period. As long as I looked at it week to week, not day to day, it gave me encouragement. I used a Weight Watchers scale to weigh them, a postage scale that you can buy at staples will work just as well. Good luck and keep us posted.

Posts.Title: New Member/Maiden Voyage

Posts.Content: My biopsy was done this afternoon, now the waiting. No pain just a little annoying during the procedure, and after the procedure i had some discomfort up my butt, but that seems to be subsiding. I am confused about something, and it is concerning me, i am hoping someone can shed some light. He did a DRE, before he started the procedure, that was fine. I asked him about the ultrasound, if it showed anything, and he said no, everything looked 'pretty much" normal. Of course i asked him what pretty much meant and he just said it looked fine, no abnormalities. But what i forgot to ask, was the size. So i called his office on the way home, and got a call back from the nurse. She told me the size was 22. I assume she meant CCs. She said he marked the report "normal size". This concerns me for two reasons. 1. if its normal size, that lowers the chance of BPH raising my PSA. (although with a %fPSA of 12 and a Total of 4.3 and PCA3 of 26, maybe thats irrelevant) 2. AND THIS IS WHATS REALLY CONCERNING AND CONFUSING - I looked at my path report from my last biopsy 2 years ago, and it showed a size of 38 CCs. How can this hapen? Can a prostate shrink by 40% from age 62, to 64, with no medication? 3. I read that studies have been done showing that smaller prostates tend to have higher gleason scores and higher chances of being out of the prostate, on post RP inspection. Can anyone comment on these issues? Especially the 2nd? Its just made me more frantic The other thing is, he told me to call him in a week for results. After thinking about it, with a high possibility of cancer (he told me, north of 50%, in response to my asking him) i think i would rather get the results in a face to face meeting. Would it be inappropriate to call tomorrow and ask for a meeting to get the results despite what he told me?

Posts.Content: My biopsy was done this afternoon, now the waiting. No pain just a little annoying during the procedure, and after the procedure i had some discomfort up my butt, but that seems to be subsiding. I am confused about something, and it is concerning me, i am hoping someone can shed some light. He did a DRE, before he started the procedure, that was fine. I asked him about the ultrasound, if it showed anything, and he said no, everything looked 'pretty much" normal. Of course i asked him what pretty much meant and he just said it looked fine, no abnormalities. But what i forgot to ask, was the size. Posts.Title: Second Post-op PSA

Posts.Content: I remember how frustrated I was when I had a bad day early in. But over time, I got to where I needed to be, and what I would call ful, continence. I still have an occasional squirt sometimes for no reason, but most of the time it just feels like a squirt but when I feel my underwear down there it's dry. One thing that's weird is that 3 times in the last 7 months (which is how long I've been fully continent) I've woken up to find I seriously pissed while sleeping. Last time it happened was about 7 weeks ago. Don't understand why that happens. Last night I slept 7 straight hours. My bladder felt like it was about to burst when I woke up, but I had no problem. Re kegels, I'm still doing them 4-5 sets a day, 10 reps per set. This thread is making me wonder whether I should just slack off a bit, either cut down to 3 sets a day, or maybe every other day

Posts.Title: 1 step forward, 2 steps back - incontinence

Posts.Content: Welcome FLA, you've gotten some good advice here, not much for me to add. I'd agree with the suggestion to get a second opinion on the slides. I can tell you that I had surgery 8 months ago, and all is well, and while some are not as lucky when it comes to side effects, but these days the odds are with you, as long as you have a competent, experienced surgeon. As far as the cance goes, with a G6 the odds ore OVERWHELMINGLY with you. I know of many guys who've had great results with the various modern forms of radiation as well. So the best thing I can tell you, is there is life after Prostate Cancer. You'll get through this fine, and at some point, it will likely be a distant memory. Educate yourself, look at all of your options, including Active Surviellance, and make an educated decision as to how to move forward. Then don't look back. And stick around here, it's a great group, you'll get plenty of support.

Posts.Title: Crossed over into the "normal" zone...

Posts.Content: I would agree with Chuck, dont wait. Most important, you need to get to the bottom of what caused all that blood to come from your Urethra. Prostate cancer isnt usually a rush to treat kind of situation. But with that said, there is no reason to delay and find yourself behind the 8 ball. At the very least, ask your urologist to do a PHI Blood test which is a more advanced and better test than PSA. Or ask for a free psa and PCA3. Then go from there. Those tests will give you a better idea of whether you are dealing with PC. I have a feeling you are not. But what do i know. As far as the wedding, i empathize. My wife was diagnosed in September with Ovarian Cancer, and my daughter is getting married a week from tomorrow. She had to go through surgery and 18 weeks of chemo (which she has 4 weeks left) but shes doing well, and feeling great, ready to party. These things have a way of working themselves out. And there is no doubt, that your son would not want you to delay, because you need to be around to see his grandchildren

Posts.Title: Elevated and rising PSA, what should I do?

Posts.Content: You are 32 as in 32 years old? Highly unlikely THT you have PC. Possible, yes, but highly unlikely. More likely that it's just a tough to treat prostate infection. Roblee is on the money, there is no way to know you didn't get a false negative. The answer might be a saturation biopsy, where they take something like 25-40 cores and it's done under anesthesia.but I don't know if I'd go that route considering your age. Maybe wait and just keep an eye on your PSA. If it was cancer, it would probably show a slow steady rise. Good luck, keep us posted

Posts.Title: Dad PCa recently diagnosed (data inside)

Posts.Content: I remember how frustrated I was when I had a bad day early in. But over time, I got to where I needed to be, and what I would call ful, continence. I still have an occasional squirt sometimes for no reason, but most of the time it just feels like a squirt but when I feel my underwear down there it's dry. One thing that's weird is that 3 times in the last 7 months (which is how long I've been fully continent) I've woken up to find I seriously pissed while sleeping. Last time it happened was about 7 weeks ago. Don't understand why that happens. Last night I slept 7 straight hours. My bladder felt like it was about to burst when I woke up, but I had no problem. Re kegels, I'm still doing them 4-5 sets a day, 10 reps per set. This thread is making me wonder whether I should just slack off a bit, either cut down to 3 sets a day, or maybe every other day

Posts.Title: Big day tomorrow

Posts.Content: You are 32 as in 32 years old? Highly unlikely THT you have PC. Possible, yes, but highly unlikely. More likely that it's just a tough to treat prostate infection. Roblee is on the money, there is no way to know you didn't get a false negative. The answer might be a saturation biopsy, where they take something like 25-40 cores and it's done under anesthesia.but I don't know if I'd go that route considering your age. Maybe wait and just keep an eye on your PSA. If it was cancer, it would probably show a slow steady rise. Good luck, keep us posted

Posts.Title: awaiting biopsy results, looking for RAP surgeon recco in Jax, Fla and NYC

Posts.Content: Welcome FLA, you've gotten some good advice here, not much for me to add. I'd agree with the suggestion to get a second opinion on the slides. I can tell you that I had surgery 8 months ago, and all is well, and while some are not as lucky when it comes to side effects, but these days the odds are with you, as long as you have a competent, experienced surgeon. As far as the cance goes, with a G6 the odds ore OVERWHELMINGLY with you. I know of many guys who've had great results with the various modern forms of radiation as well. So the best thing I can tell you, is there is life after Prostate Cancer. You'll get through this fine, and at some point, it will likely be a distant memory. Educate yourself, look at all of your options, including Active Surviellance, and make an educated decision as to how to move forward. Then don't look back. And stick around here, it's a great group, you'll get plenty of support.

Posts.Title: Editorial: Bad Prostate Cancer Advice

Posts.Content: I would second the comments that you need to get the biopsy done, and also to ease your mind, that the anticipation was way worse than the procedure. I was a basket case for the two weeks leading up to the procedure. The doc gave me 2 xanax, i took one before leaving the house, and another when i got to the hospital waiting room. So i was pretty looped by the time i got on the table. I also made sure the doc knew how nervous i was (my own idiosyncracy, it makes me feel better to verbalize it) and he assured me it wouldn't be bad. He was right. Also told me everything that was going on as the procedure progressed. The procedure was nothing more than an annoyance. So don't sweat it. I know i have another one in my future, as i was not diagnosed with PCa, but one core out of 14 showed Hi Grade PIN. But had another PSA and free PSA and PCA3 a month ago. THe PSA was 2.8, up from previous readings of 2.2, and 1.7 (all 6 months apart), 1.1 and .7 (2 years apart). My FPSA was low (not good) and my PCa3, was high (good). So no doubt i have another PSA coming, he told me to come back and re-take in 4 months (August). No doubt if PSA is up again, (which i have no reason to believe it won't be, because the trend just continues on and on,) I will have to have another biopsy. This time i will not be nearly as nervous from anticipation, but won't be exactly jumping for joy waiting for results. Get the biopsy. Good luck. Don't worry (i know, easy for us to say). And if its positive, keep remembering you are on top of it, likely very early, so at the end of the day, everything will work out ok. PS. - I'M 62, so more or less same age.

Posts.Title: Do I need a biopsy?

Posts.Content: Mikek - yes you are definitely getting ahead of yourself. Wait for the biopsy. And if it does come back positive (which i believe it very possibly WILL NOT, considering your almost non existent PSA), you should look at all options, surgery, Brachytherapy (seeds), and other possible treatment options, like SBRT ,Proton, etc. Do this so that you can go into whatever treatment you decide on, with a clear head, knowing that you did your homework, this way, you will never look back and wonder if you made a good decision With that said, if you do end up needing a surgeon, in NYC, i used Dr Ash Tewari. Very well known, highly regarded, Chief of Urology at Mount Sinai, and has done over 6000 RALP's. My results were very good, no ED, no incontinence after week 4 or 5 (dont remember exactly, but it was def within that time frame), negative margins, no escape from Prostate, and so far, undetectable PSA. But seriously, wait for the biopsy results, you are way ahead of yourself. Good luck

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Michael F Prato: Chill way down........this stress will be bad for your overall health. Stay focussed on the fact that you are in the care of a top URO Surgeon and have seen a top RO. Regardless of 0.1 or 0.07, you are not near that level. The 0.033 from a different lab may well be an outlier data value. A friend of mine (intact prostate) recently had his annual MD exam. All was well EXCEPT his PSA (run at LabCorp) came back 10.0 It had never been > 2.0 His MD had it retested at Quest and it was < 2.0. (Not sure why his MD didn't ask LabCorp to re-run the sample?!?!?) Anyway, he had some unnecessary anxiety for a few days due to lab error. Enjoy the summer and don't even think about uPSAs until after Labor Day! MF Michael, I'm with you, as i said, i am not as frazzled as it may appear. It will be on my mind, can't help that, but I'm not crazed about it. I will be the week of my next PSA but not until then. Re lab error, i know, i had a similar situation. After being undetectable <.02 for a year, i had my 3 month test and it came back 3.8 !!!!! They wouldn't retest without the request coming from the Dr, but i just went to the Drs office and had him test at his lab, it came back <.02. I contacted Quest and made a lot of noise. I got a call from the Senior VP of Oncology Testing and Development, who told me they redid the test multiple times, all came back undetectable they couldn';t reproduce the 3.8 result. They checked the machines, they spoke to the technicians and he told me he was sorry but they could not come up with an explanation for the error. I know what the explanation was, some idiot doing input gave me some poor shmucks results and he got mine. So he was walking around thinking he was undetectable, and i was ready to jump off the Brooklyn Bridge. Never went to Quest again for PSA, since then

Posts.Content: PDV, I did ok, but did not have your experience. At my worst, i went through 2 pads a day, that lasted about a week or two (dont remember, and i'm happy about that), and was wearing nothing within 5 weeks. But i do have a friend who was fully continent from almost the moment that the catheter was pulled out, so indeed, its possible, and congratulations to you. Re the golf thing - i was worried about the same thing. I played golf for the first time about 5 months after surgery. Lo and behold, i gripped it, and ripped it, but i didnt drip it at all. I thought about wearing a shield just in case, but decided to be brave and i walked off the 18th green dry as a bone. I didnt even pee until the 5th hole, then went into the woods twice after that. That was truly a great day for me.

Would you trust your gut instinct in a decision like this? or would you trust the data, the science.

Posts.Content: My Uro suggested Cyberknife because (in my opinion ) his hospital has a big investment in it and he's the chairman of the department. I didn't like the way he handled things when he called me with a diagnosis, instead of telling me why don't you make an appointment to come in and we'll discuss your options he just said if you want I can set you up an appointmentwith our radiation oncologist who does cyber knife. After that I went to see him told him I want to explore all my optionsat which time he told me they were equally good I cure stage and it was just a matter of what I felt let comfortable with in terms of side effects and quick or gradual drop in psa

Posts.Title: Surgery vs Brachy

Posts.Content: I am on so many damn forums i dont remember what i post from one forum to the next any more, so i'll start from the beginning here.... So after 2 years of undetectable <.02, at my two year mark last January i got a .02 result, without the <. Then on May 26th, i got a .033 (different lab). My Uro/Surgeon, Dr Tewari, said not to worry, they dont do anything until it hits .1, and i may just be seeing noise Being the nutjob that i am, i couldn't leave it alone, so i made an appointment with Dr Zelefsky at MSKCC, the rock star RO for Prostate Cancer. I just wanted his take. so i'll paste below what i posted elsewhere, just to save time. Apologies to those who've seen this elsewhere. So i had my meeting with Dr Zelefsky, it was pretty much what i expected. I think the most important thing that i accomplished was establishing myself as a patient in his office, so that if and when i do need SRT, i will hit the ground running. So his basic comment on my situation was that he thinks its possible that i am recurring (nothing i didnt know) but he wouldn't go so far as to say that its probable, YET. He wants to see a series of rises, and right now my PSA is too low, and only one rise, after the first one. He said that he is not a believer in the magic number being .1 for starting treatment. If he sees 3-4 rises in a row, and I'm .07, he will likely recommend we get started. Regarding my "How the F does this happen with my pathology?" rant, he commented that while i had negative margins, the fact that i had a positive frozen section, that was then turned into a negative FINAL margin, tells him that my negative margins could be "questionable" Regarding HT in conjunction with SRT, my impression was, probably not, but that could change. He was sort of non commital, he said that generally they use HT with SRT with higher PSA's (Not sure if he was referring to my presurgery PSA of 4.3, or the fact that we are on it currently and would hit it early, if it kept going up. But he also said, there are ongoing studies in this regard. I told him i was surprised that the nomograms showed that my chance of success was 53% without HT, but 73% with HT. He commented that he doesnt put a lot of faith in the nomograms, because for example, its only a small number of men in the database that have the same exact stats as me, same G, same pathology, same PSA, etc. So its not that meaningfrul to an individual The one action item he suggested is that i get an MRI in the next month or so, to have as a baseline . Which i will do. Aside from that , he suggested i continue to be followed by Dr Tewari, my surgeon, who he spoke very highly of, and that we keep an eye on things, and another couple of rises, i should come back and see him. Oh, and he did a DRE, which he said felt "smooth" and unremarkable (my word). Dayum, i thoughti was done with that SH!T!!!!! He didnt do a PSA though. So i guess nothing more to do but retest as scheduled in August, and otherwise just sit back and relax. And continue to worry I'm nervous that at the current rate, two more PSA's take me to November and if they both rise, i will need treatment in January, which will screw up my plan to spend the winter at my new home in Florida. That would REALLY SUCK. Ok, now i'm just venting, so I'll stop.

Posts.Title: RO Meeting

Posts.Content: Struggling with this decision. G 6 3/12 cores positive, one or two (not sure) in right apex, all pos cores on 1 side. Age64, good physical condition. Very nervous type. All scientific data shows results are same both ways, 95% cure rate in my situation, either tx. SEs less with Brachy, although some show up years later in small %. But clearly less trauma to body. Advantage of surgery, quick drop in PSA vs slow fall with Brachy,along with possible bounces along the way (remember I'm nervous type of personality). Other advantage is final pathology? That would be good for me mentally, if it's good news, but either way, would it affect my Tx? I don't buy into the idea that surgery not an option if Brachy fails. You can do salvage surgery, it's done at MSKCC m although I probably wouldn't do it, too difficult. But there is Cryo ablation, HT, Chemo, and other types of radiation. So logically it seems Brachy might make more sense, but my gut tells me cut it out. With either option, I have Drs lined up whom I've consulted on surgery and one who I would be referred to on Brachy, who are both rock stars in their worlds. I've read all the studies. I've talked to patients who've gone thru both. It seems not only are Drs biased towards their own specialty, but so are patients biased towards what the chose. I'm Very conflicted. Any feedback appreciated

Posts.Title: Surgery vs Brachy

Posts.Content: Otago, interesting perspective. Regarding the SE of ED... I was told by both the surgeon and the RO THAT I HAD ABOUT A 60-65%. Chance of maintaining full function, with surgery being after anywhere from 6 months to two years and surgery being with drugs, but Brachy being without drugs and if I fall into the 40% unlucky group, then 50% chance that would be resolved with drugs. Honestly, as much as I would like to maintain that function, it pales by comparison to my desire to come outfit this disease free. REGARDING Incontinence, I am going to admit that I believe I will be one of the lucky ones that gets it resolved, within a few months. This is based on my full continence pre treatment, my doing the Kegels now, pre treatment, and most important, having a highly skilled surgeon, Ash Tewari But I realize there is a small risk I might not be so lucky. So y, I guess I need to decide if I want to gomble with that. I think I am
