Posts.Content: Sarg, this is a good, fourth, and much needed post There are three ingredients to a good outcome in surgery both oncologically, and regarding side effects. First is a great surgeon. Second followed instructions that he gives you including doing Kegels before surgery and third i and regarding side effects. First is a great surgeon. Second following all the instructions that he gives you including doing Kegels before surgery and third is a lot of luck The point is it's not up for bunco The point is it's not A foregone conclusion that the surgery will end badly but it's also clear that there are risks quality of life. I think that's not very different then radiation her other treatments there is no risk freeway to treat this so it's a matter of pick your poison

Posts.Content: The numbers by themselves dont look so great, fPSA of 12% is not a good number, neither is PSA 8.3. With that said, the jump from 3.9 to 8.3 in a short time (ignoring the first reading of 8.4) leads me to ask - has he been given a course of Cipro - antibiotic to see if it brings the the PSA down, which would be a sign that the problem might be a prostate infection, a fairly common cause of elevated PSA. Another thought - if you dont ignore the first reading of 8.4, and compare it to the current 8.3, you could consider his PSA stable. On the other hand, the meds he is taking for BPH might, i mean MIGHT, be lowering, i.e. masking, his PSA, so in reality it might be higher. I'm not that sure about the last point on meds, but others more knowledgeable will surely chime in, so keep checking back. At the end of the day though, i think you have to go with the Drs suggestion that due to the recent colonoscopy, hemmerroid repair, etc, he should wait. The biopsy needles go through the colon wall, so i am sure there is good reason for the Drs suggestion. You might want to let him know that you guys want the biopsy done as soon as is safely possible (assuming your husband agrees). Good luck, and keep us posted.

Posts.Content: Carmel, sorry to hear this. First thing you need to know - your husband is not going to die of Prostate Cancer any time soon. Focus on that. Second thing, get a copy of the pathology report. It would help us help you (as layman, but as guys who've been there, and done the research), if you could create a signature in your profile with the pathology facts... Gleason score, PSA, , # of positive cores, % of each core positive, etc Third- depending on the Gleason score, more often than not, you should send the slides to a prostate pathology expert for a second opinion. Most of us use DR Jonathan Epstein, at Johns Hopkins, he is one of the foremost pathology experts in the world. THE COST IS AROUND $250. Fourth, this is a very manageable disease. Even when it has spread, even when it's aggressive. There are many treatments available, surgery, and different types of radiation. You will want to start reading and learning as much as possible. Do a consult with an expert in the different types of treatment, radiation (SBRT, IMRT, LDR and HDR brachytherapy), and surgery. Don't listen to advice from an expert in one type of treatment , about a different type. They all prefer their own treatment, naturally. It's up to the patient to be there own advocate. Hang in there the initial shock will wear off. And your husband is going to be ok. Getting educated will give you and your husband a sense of control.

Posts.Title: Surgery vs Brachy

Posts.Content: Struggling with this decision. G 6 3/12 cores positive, one or two (not sure) in right apex, all pos cores on 1 side. Age64, good physical condition. Very nervous type. All scientific data shows results are same both ways, 95% cure rate in my situation, either tx. SEs less with Brachy, although some show up years later in small %. But clearly less trauma to body. Advantage of surgery, quick drop in PSA vs slow fall with Brachy,along with possible bounces along the way (remember I'm nervous type of personality). Other advantage is final pathology? That would be good for me mentally, if it's good news, but either way, would it affect my Tx? I don't buy into the idea that surgery not an option if Brachy fails. You can do salvage surgery, it's done at MSKCC m although I probably wouldn't do it, too difficult. But there is Cryo ablation, HT, Chemo, and other types of radiation. So logically it seems Brachy might make more sense, but my gut tells me cut it out. With either option, I have Drs lined up whom I've consulted on surgery and one who I would be referred to on Brachy, who are both rock stars in their worlds. I've read all the studies. I've talked to patients who've gone thru both. It seems not only are Drs biased towards their own specialty, but so are patients biased towards what the chose. I'm Very conflicted. Any feedback appreciated

Posts.Title: My husband was diagnosed last night. This doesn't feel real. What should I do?

Posts.Content: WW, I am a little hesitant to answer, as I'm no expert on Chemo. But I'll take a stab at it with that understanding. My understanding is that Hormone Therapy can easily put one into remission, and wipe out all evidence of cancer on. bone scan. However two things to keep in mind 1. Unfortunately, even if the scan shows nothing it does not rule out the possibility, that there are PC cells circulating in the blood or lymph system, or that there could be mets too small to be seen on the scan (micro mets) that are being controlled by the HT (and Chemo) 2. PC cells can, over time, become Hormone Resistant. I think, but I'm not sure, that it's the same thing for Chemo. It could be months before that happens, BUT it can also be many many years. So I would take the great news for what it is, great news. Hopefully it lasts a long long time, and allows for a really good quality of life for a decade or more. If something changes, deal with it then. (I know, easy to say, hard to do) Someone please correct me if I'm wrong, as I said, I'm not an expert in treatments beyond primary treatment.

Posts.Content: My Uro suggested Cyberknife because (in my opinion ) his hospital has a big investment in it and he's the chairman of the department. I didn't like the way he handled things when he called me with a diagnosis, instead of telling me why don't you make an appointment to come in and we'll discuss your options he just said if you want I can set you up an appointmentwith our radiation oncologist who does cyber knife. After that I went to see him told him I want to explore all my optionsat which time he told me they were equally good I cure stage and it was just a matter of what I felt let comfortable with in terms of side effects and quick or gradual drop in psa

Posts.Title: I'm Confused by Han and Partin Table Stats

Posts.Content: Maverick, sorry you need to be here, but welcome. With 2 of 12 cores positive, and both Gleason 6, with low volume %, there is no "have to If you are truly a Gleason 6, you are a good candidate for Active Surviellance, which means regular testing, biopsies, etc. In this way, your disease is monitored so that if it ever does turn more aggressive, you can do something more about treatment at that time. This is accepted protocol, and has been very effective, proven in peer reviewed studies. Has your urologist mentioned this option? The first thing you should do is have your pathology slides sent to Johns Hopkins, Dr Jonathan Epstein, for their second opinion service. If he still calls them Gleason 6, then i would ask for a 3T MRI, which would probably identify anything more aggressive that might have been missed. After that, if you are still diagnosed as G6, consider active surviellance. Worst case scenario, you put off treatment for a few years, and have that time to ahve fun with your sexy wife. And in a few years, if your disease does progress, requiring treatment, there may be better treatets available. Progress is being made at a rapid rate. Good luck and keep us posted.

Posts.Title: Decisions, decisions. Surgery or remain on AS with Gleason 3+4

Posts.Content: Carmel, sorry to hear this. First thing you need to know - your husband is not going to die of Prostate Cancer any time soon. Focus on that. Second thing, get a copy of the pathology report. It would help us help you (as layman, but as guys who've been there, and done the research), if you could create a signature in your profile with the pathology facts... Gleason score, PSA, , # of positive cores, % of each core positive, etc Third- depending on the Gleason score, more often than not, you should send the slides to a prostate pathology expert for a second opinion. Most of us use DR Jonathan Epstein, at Johns Hopkins, he is one of the foremost pathology experts in the world. THE COST IS AROUND $250. Fourth, this is a very manageable disease. Even when it has spread, even when it's aggressive. There are many treatments available, surgery, and different types of radiation. You will want to start reading and learning as much as possible. Do a consult with an expert in the different types of treatment, radiation (SBRT, IMRT, LDR and HDR brachytherapy), and surgery. Don't listen to advice from an expert in one type of treatment , about a different type. They all prefer their own treatment, naturally. It's up to the patient to be there own advocate. Hang in there the initial shock will wear off. And your husband is going to be ok. Getting educated will give you and your husband a sense of control.

Posts.Title: Getting ready for recovery

Posts.Content: I had an issue with my Uro, in terms of communications, after a biopsy (issue in my mind, not his) that has been resolved, in that i had the conversation i needed to have, but after more time had passed than i wanted to. Spoke to a friend who is the head administrator at a major cancer center. Asked him his opinion. His response was that not getting to a doc when you felt you needed to have a conversation was very common at major centers, particularly teaching hospitals, as they are always busy, not only with patients, but with research, teaching, etc. But that the quality of the docs and care, often superior. So if you think you have a doc who knows his stuff, you have to weigh that with your lack of satisfaction on the service/communications side. Curious to get others thoughts on this. I think the guy is good, all i have to go on is credentials, the hospital he is associated with and practices in (he works at the hospital, not private practice), and the good experience i had in him doing the biopsy (very little blood afterwards, careful about respecting my fear of pain, and not causing a lot of pain). So i assume he is top notch. But like i said, it was hard to get to him after the (negative) biopsy, which when i spoke to him i found out, showed 1 core of HG PIN. Sometimes i think maybe i should find a more local practice, via a referral (someone i have in mind, who a friend had RP DaVinci with and was very happy). Like i said, i would be curious to hear what approach some of you would take to this decision.
Posts.Title: Quality of service/care at major centers

Posts.Title: Thought I was doing great!

Posts.Content: Sorry about your dad. G10 is tough, but he can manage this disease as chronic for many many years. Established treatments can put him into remission, and as others have said, there are new treatments being approved very frequently. An example is Erleada, which has shown much promise in men who have developed a resistance to standard hormone therapy, which itself could work for years. Re PSA, 400 - yeah thats pretty high. But we've seen much higher. There is a member here who shows up once in a while, Todd1963, who was diagnosed 12 years ago with a PSA of 3200, (No typo) and he is, last i heard (very recently) in remission with a PSA that is undetectable. And he is enjoying life. He didnt have a g10 gleason score, it was g7 i think, but still it shows that even advanced cancer of the Prostate can be managed for years. Just make sure he gets to the right doctors, hopefully at a major Teaching Hospital . Regarding life insurance - doubt anyone will underwrite him now. The important thing thats already been mentioned by Michael, is that he have good health insurance. Good luck keep us posted.

Posts.Title: Stepdad diagnosed with Aggressive Cancer but have questions

Posts.Content: I think you are doing the right thing. Everyone is different, but I'm aggressive with my health, and particularly with prostate issues, if it is cancer, even though most prostate cancers grow slowly, you want to catch it early for the best shot at a one and done treatment. The fact that your PSA has actually trended down is a good sign. But better safe than sorry. And the fusion targeted biopsy is state of the art, shows you've got a very competent urologist, rrust his judgement. Hope you are just passing through here and don't have a need to become a permanent resident and member of our club.

Posts.Title: Biopsy upcoming. Hope I'm doing the right thing.

Posts.Content: Wilde, I'm going in the day before you, surgery Jan 6th. Like you guys, I think about Cancer every waking moment. It's the first word in my head when I wake in the morning, and the last word before I go to bed. I think I spend way too much time thinking reading and worrying about the outcome. We have to remember, focus on what we can control, not what we have no control over. I try to keep busy, and exercise almost every day, that helps a lot. I wouldn't call it depression, I'd call it anxiety. And for some odd reason, today I'm pretty calm, sort of weird and eery I guess I'm just resolved that it is what it i, has to be done, I believe in my surgeon, am pretty sure I'll be continent, not as sure about the ED issue, but if I can get a cure, I'll be happy to deal with ED if I have to. For now I'm just trying to have a lot of sex, exercise, and letting myself eat whatever I want today which is not how I normally operate. Of course tomorrow, after a light early morning breakfast, no more solid food for a few days, so what the heck.

Posts.Title: Prostate Questions Answered

Posts.Content: I think you are doing the right thing. Everyone is different, but I'm aggressive with my health, and particularly with prostate issues, if it is cancer, even though most prostate cancers grow slowly, you want to catch it early for the best shot at a one and done treatment. The fact that your PSA has actually trended down is a good sign. But better safe than sorry. And the fusion targeted biopsy is state of the art, shows you've got a very competent urologist, rrust his judgement. Hope you are just passing through here and don't have a need to become a permanent resident and member of our club.

Posts.Title: Biopsy upcoming. Hope I'm doing the right thing.

Posts.Content: I've been on Lovaza which is a prescription drug, an dis purified fish oil/omega 3, for 4 years now, due to high triglycerides. I have had low but rising trend of PSA, for about 5 years, and was diagnosed with high grade pin last year, after a biopsy. So now i am left to wonder if there is a connections. I lost a lot of weight over the last year, and my trigycerides (Tgl) got under control. 5 MONTHS ago, i convinced doc to cut the Lovaza dose in half from 2000 to 1000 mg a day. I retested 3 months later, and my Tgl was lower still. But he wouldn;t change the medication. I am also on 2 other meds for Tgl. I've never done this before, but after this new study, I am not asking the doc, i am taking myself off the Lovaza altogether. I'll maintain my better eating habits and then go re-test the Tgl in 3 months. If its up I'll deal with it, but I'm not playing with fire if i dont have to. I dont know if this study is convincing enough or valid from a scientific point of view, but I dont want to take any chances.

Posts.Title: Depressions, do you guys get them?

Posts.Content: chiguy, welcome to the forum, sorry about your diagnosis. First of all, yes, getting a second opinion is one of the most important things you can do. Make sure the slides are sent to a pathology dept that specializes in prostate cells. You should use either Dr JOn Epstein at Johns Hopkins or David Boatwick, at Bostwick Labs. Prostate is all they do and they are the foremost experts. If the G6 holds, you can possibly do AS. This doesn't mean just watch and wait. It means what it says ACTIVE Surveillance. YOU WANT TO GET Ainto a structured program, with preset protocols for regular PSA checks, biopsies, and MRI. I could be wrong, but I think Johns Hopkins which is one of the more stringent as to guidelines for AS, would not accept you into their program due to cancer in both lobes. I could be wrong, if I am, someone will correct me Besides seeds, there is other type of radiation. SBRT and its cousin Cyberknife, HDR Brachytherapy (like seeds/LDR but implants are temporary, high dose for only a few hours. And other options. Make sure you explore them all, Surgery and radiation will both likely cure you. One thing to be aware if, the advantage of surgery is confirmation of your Gleason scores. In 20-49% of cases, Gleason score is upgraded after surgery. Mine was G6 then after surgery upgraded to G7(3+4). You don't have to rush, sounds like your case is not serious. It's always scary to get a cancer diagnosis, but MOST PC is easily curable or manageable, especially G6 and g7(3+4). So the urge to "do something" or "get it out" quickly, is PROBABLY misguided although understandable. One more thing... (In before Highlander LOL). Do yourself a favor, go to Amazon and buy the book "Surviving Prostate Cancer" by Patrick Walsh. Make sure you get the third edition.although adbpvancements are coming so fast. That even that is outdated a bit. Also, for a different perspective (Dr Walsh is a surgeon), by the book "Invasion of the Prostate Snatcherz" by Dr Mark Scholz. He's a big fan of AS when appropriate. These two books will give you a balanced view. Above all, educate yourself thoroughly.Be your own advocTe. Most Drs, with good intentions , are biased towards their own specialty. Surgeons want to cut, radiation oncologists want to burn. So you need to make the decision on what's best for you Good luck, you will be ok, breathe. Ken

Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed - Gleason 6

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Michael F Hi Pratoman! At least be very pleased with the fact that your missing "<" has returned!!! Now a decimal point has gone AWOL! Try to loosen up & laugh at this crazy situation! You simply can't win at getting a correct post RP uPSA. I recall the horrible scare you had when the Quest uPSA was erroneously reported to be "3.something" Sorry for this latest SNAFU but remain confident that you will get is straightened out. I'm sure that my Forum Family is tired of my constant "Same Lab Same uPSA Methodology" & "Get a Copy of The Original Lab Report" mantras! But yours is a case where your Lab switched from Quest to LabCorp and you would have never known this except for the fact that your latest PSA result was from a "Standard" PSA Assay. Had they run a uPSA, your LabCorp result could not be compared (to detect a change) to your previous Quest uPSA result. Double check if your Jan & Feb uPSAs were done by LabCorp (or ask when LabCorp bought your current lab). Same thing happened at my local hospital lab where I have my uPSAs drawn. I always ask the phlebotomist to show me the Lab requisition sheet that has my name and the "exact" uPSA test before I'll allow them to draw the blood sample. LabCorp picks up from the hospital and the sample is run in their Birmingham, AL facility each time. FYI: I am "permanently married" to: LabCorp Test Number: 140731 = Prostate-specific Antigen (PSA), Ultrasensitive This must be on my requisition sheet. My "co-pay" is $12. Good luck in quickly getting back BOTH your missing < & your 2nd Decimal! I am certain that you will find both of them huddled closely together on your next uPSA Lab report! Hang in there & Good Luck my friend! MF Michael, just to claify. I haven't had my PSA done at Quest since that one time tht they screwed it up and it came back at 3.8. I'll never use them for PSA again unless I have no choice. My test since then has always been done at the hospital lab itself. Now, the hospital lab has been bought by labcorp. And what's messed up, to your point, is no matter what I do, I'm going to have to start all over again, with a new lab, probably new assay. So none of my future tests will relate to my past tests. UGH! my first few tests after surgery all came back at 0.00. Then, the next few came back at <.02. Yup, you guessed it, they changed the assay, I looked at the reports and compared them. Then I got the .02 three months ago, but it was the same assay. Now I get to start all over again. Oh crap

Posts.Content: chiguy, welcome to the forum, sorry about your diagnosis. First of all, yes, getting a second opinion is one of the most important things you can do. Make sure the slides are sent to a pathology dept that specializes in prostate cells. You should use either Dr JOn Epstein at Johns Hopkins or David Boatwick, at Bostwick Labs. Prostate is all they do and they are the foremost experts. If the G6 holds, you can possibly do AS. This doesn't mean just watch and wait. It means what it says ACTIVE Surveillance. YOU WANT TO GET Ainto a structured program, with preset protocols for regular PSA checks, biopsies, and MRI. I could be wrong, but I think Johns Hopkins which is one of the more stringent as to guidelines for AS, would not accept you into their program due to cancer in both lobes. I could be wrong, if I am, someone will correct me Besides seeds, there is other type of radiation. SBRT and its cousin Cyberknife, HDR Brachytherapy (like seeds/LDR but implants are temporary, high dose for only a few hours. And other options. Make sure you explore them all, Surgery and radiation will both likely cure you. One thing to be aware if, the advantage of surgery is confirmation of your Gleason scores. In 20-49% of cases, Gleason score is upgraded after surgery. Mine was G6 then after surgery upgraded to G7(3+4). You don't have to rush, sounds like your case is not serious. It's always scary to get a cancer diagnosis, but MOST PC is easily curable or manageable, especially G6 and g7(3+4). So the urge to "do something" or "get it out" quickly, is PROBABLY misguided although understandable. One more thing... (In before Highlander LOL). Do yourself a favor, go to Amazon and buy the book "Surviving Prostate Cancer" by Patrick Walsh. Make sure you get the third edition.although adbpvancements are coming so fast. That even that is outdated a bit. Also, for a different perspective (Dr Walsh is a surgeon), by the book "Invasion of the Prostate Snatcherz" by Dr Mark Scholz. He's a big fan of AS when appropriate. These two books will give you a balanced view. Above all, educate yourself thoroughly.Be your own advocTe. Most Drs, with good intentions , are biased towards their own specialty. Surgeons want to cut, radiation oncologists want to burn. So you need to make the decision on what's best for you Good luck, you will be ok, breathe. Ken

Posts.Title: Newly diagnosed - Gleason 6

Posts.Content: The business of medicine, is a clown show. We are all just numbers. I got the result. They always call between 9am and 9:45AM, this time i didnt hear from them, and my mind was running wild, so i called them at 11:30AM, and didnt hear back until 2PM. So, after losing my "<" and going from <.02 to .02 three months ago, my test today came back and <.1.... Thats right, <.1, without any zeros. They proceed to explain to me that they did the standard test, not the uPSA this time. Why, i asked. Well, because our lab at the hospital was bought by LabCorp and they changed it. OK, I responded, but i know LabCorp does uPSA and in fact goes to 3 decimal places. The NP responds by telling me that i am correct, but the uPSA is not on their requisition list. Are you f***ing kidding me? They are working on getting the uPSA, and in the meantime, if i'd like, they can send me a scrip for a uPSA that i can get on my own from Quest (no thank you) or a local Labcorp facility. So bottom line, i know nothing, its like i never got the test. All i know is that i'm less than .1 . I could be <.02 again, or i could be stable at .02. Or i could be unstable, at .03, .05, .08 or .09. What a joke. NP said it doesnt really matter, because they wouldnt do anything till it hit .1 anyway. Guess what. I would. If it hits .05, i'm interviewing RO's. I'm sure the guys that rail against the uPSA to begin with, are gonna have a field day with this. It doesn't matter to me. Now that i've had the uPSA, and lost my <, the cats out of the bag. And i need to know. So i will discuss with the Dr (Tewari) tomorrow, after telling him i think what they did to me is idiotic because there was no reason to do the test in the first place, except to get some billing in for the month.

Posts.Title: Got my PSA Results

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Michael F Hi Pratoman! At least be very pleased with the fact that your missing "<" has returned!!! Now a decimal point has gone AWOL! Try to loosen up & laugh at this crazy situation! You simply can't win at getting a correct post RP uPSA. I recall the horrible scare you had when the Quest uPSA was erroneously reported to be "3.something" Sorry for this latest SNAFU but remain confident that you will get is straightened out. I'm sure that my Forum Family is tired of my constant "Same Lab Same uPSA Methodology" & "Get a Copy of The Original Lab Report" mantras! But yours is a case where your Lab switched from Quest to LabCorp and you would have never known this except for the fact that your latest PSA result was from a "Standard" PSA Assay. Had they run a uPSA, your LabCorp result could not be compared (to detect a change) to your previous Quest uPSA result. Double check if your Jan & Feb uPSAs were done by LabCorp (or ask when LabCorp bought your current lab). Same thing happened at my local hospital lab where I have my uPSAs drawn. I always ask the phlebotomist to show me the Lab requisition sheet that has my name and the "exact" uPSA test before I'll allow them to draw the blood sample. LabCorp picks up from the hospital and the sample is run in their Birmingham, AL facility each time. FYI: I am "permanently married" to: LabCorp Test Number: 140731 = Prostate-specific Antigen (PSA), Ultrasensitive This must be on my requisition sheet. My "co-pay" is $12. Good luck in quickly getting back BOTH your missing < & your 2nd Decimal! I am certain that you will find both of them huddled closely together on your next uPSA Lab report! Hang in there & Good Luck my friend! MF Michael, just to claify. I haven't had my PSA done at Quest since that one time tht they screwed it up and it came back at 3.8. I'll never use them for PSA again unless I have no choice. My test since then has always been done at the hospital lab itself. Now, the hospital lab has been bought by labcorp. And what's messed up, to your point, is no matter what I do, I'm going to have to start all over again, with a new lab, probably new assay. So none of my future tests will relate to my past tests. UGH! my first few tests after surgery all came back at 0.00. Then, the next few came back at <.02. Yup, you guessed it, they changed the assay, I looked at the reports and compared them. Then I got the .02 three months ago, but it was the same assay. Now I get to start all over again. Oh crap

Posts.Content: I'll echo what the others have said. It's wayyyy too early. Everyone is different. From what I've read only about 3% never regain full continence. The other 97% vary, everyone is different. I went without pads at about the 6bweek mark, (6 weeks from Cathy removal). I know others who regained full continence but it took months. Hang in there, don't be discouraged.

Posts.Content: Rooster, I'm not that knowledgeable bout advanced cases, but I think that is not the case. Stage 4 is spread to distant organs or distant parts of the body. Stage 3 means it's escaped the capsule. If the Eligard stops working and your PSA goes up and that's the only sign, another treatment, like chemo (taxotere?) can often stop the cancer from progressing And I may be wrong, but isn't it possible that eligard could be effective for more than 2 years?

At the same time, the more walking you can do the quicker you will get back to yourself Dont expect too much too soon. I was a little depressed for a month or two after surgery, and i tired very easiy. But over time it all subsided and now i am working harder than ever, not sure if thats a good thing or not LOL. Good luck and stick around.

Posts.Title: Got my PSA Results

Posts.Content: The business of medicine, is a clown show. We are all just numbers. I got the result. They always call between 9am and 9:45AM, this time i didnt hear from them, and my mind was running wild, so i called them at 11:30AM, and didnt hear back until 2PM. So, after losing my "<" and going from <.02 to .02 three months ago, my test today came back and <.1.... Thats right, <.1, without any zeros. They proceed to explain to me that they did the standard test, not the uPSA this time. Why, i asked. Well, because our lab at the hospital was bought by LabCorp and they changed it. OK, I responded, but i know LabCorp does uPSA and in fact goes to 3 decimal places. The NP responds by telling me that i am correct, but the uPSA is not on their requisition list. Are you f***ing kidding me? They are working on getting the uPSA, and in the meantime, if i'd like, they can send me a scrip for a uPSA that i can get on my own from Quest (no thank you) or a local Labcorp facility. So bottom line, i know nothing, its like i never got the test. All i know is that i'm less than .1 . I could be <.02 again, or i could be stable at .02. Or i could be unstable, at .03, .05, .08 or .09. What a joke. NP said it doesnt really matter, because they wouldnt do anything till it hit .1 anyway. Guess what. I would. If it hits .05, i'm interviewing RO's. I'm sure the guys that rail against the uPSA to begin with, are gonna have a field day with this. It doesn't matter to me. Now that i've had the uPSA, and lost my <, the cats out of the bag. And i need to know. So i will discuss with the Dr (Tewari) tomorrow, after telling him i think what they did to me is idiotic because there was no reason to do the test in the first place, except to get some billing in for the month.

Posts.Title: Got my PSA Results

Posts.Content: chiguy, welcome to the forum, sorry about your diagnosis. First of all, yes, getting a second opinion is one of the most important things you can do. Make sure the slides are sent to a pathology dept that specializes in prostate cells. You should use either Dr JOn Epstein at Johns Hopkins or David Boatwick, at Bostwick Labs. Prostate is all they do and they are the foremost experts. If the G6 holds, you can possibly do AS. This doesn't mean just watch and wait. It means what it says ACTIVE Surveillance. YOU WANT TO GET Ainto a structured program, with preset protocols for regular PSA checks, biopsies, and MRI. I could be wrong, but I think Johns Hopkins which is one of the more stringent as to guidelines for AS, would not accept you into their program due to cancer in both lobes. I could be wrong, if I am, someone will correct me Besides seeds, there is other type of radiation. SBRT and its cousin Cyberknife, HDR Brachytherapy (like seeds/LDR but implants are temporary, high dose for only a few hours. And other options. Make sure you explore them all, Surgery and radiation will both likely cure you. One thing to be aware if, the advantage of surgery is confirmation of your Gleason scores. In 20-49% of cases, Gleason score is upgraded after surgery. Mine was G6 then after surgery upgraded to G7(3+4). You don't have to rush, sounds like your case is not serious. It's always scary to get a cancer diagnosis, but MOST PC is easily curable or manageable, especially G6 and g7(3+4). So the urge to "do something" or "get it out" quickly, is PROBABLY misguided although understandable. One more thing... (In before Highlander LOL). Do yourself a favor, go to Amazon and buy the book "Surviving Prostate Cancer" by Patrick Walsh. Make sure you get the third edition.although adbpvancements are coming so fast. That even that is outdated a bit. Also, for a different perspective (Dr Walsh is a surgeon), by the book "Invasion of the Prostate Snatcherz" by Dr Mark Scholz. He's a big fan of AS when appropriate. These two books will give you a balanced view. Above all, educate yourself thoroughly.Be your own advocTe. Most Drs, with good intentions , are biased towards their own specialty. Surgeons want to cut, radiation oncologists want to burn. So you need to make the decision on what's best for you Good luck, you will be ok, breathe. Ken

Posts.Content: Rooster, I'm not that knowledgeable bout advanced cases, but I think that is not the case. Stage 4 is spread to distant organs or distant parts of the body. Stage 3 means it's escaped the capsule. If the Eligard stops working and your PSA goes up and that's the only sign, another treatment, like chemo (taxotere?) can often stop the cancer from progressing And I may be wrong, but isn't it possible that eligard could be effective for more than 2 years?

Posts.Title: Stage 3 progression??

Posts.Content: I'll echo what the others have said. It's wayyyy too early. Everyone is different. From what I've read only about 3% never regain full continence. The other 97% vary, everyone is different. I went without pads at about the 6bweek mark, (6 weeks from Cathy removal). I know others who regained full continence but it took months. Hang in there, don't be discouraged.

Posts.Content: Nicole, there are so many available treatments for advanced prostate cancer. Can you give us more data? What specific treatments has he been on so far, that have either failed, or worked for a time, then failed? Are you at a major cancer center or with a local medical oncologist? Does he specialize in prostate cancer? Depending on the answers, might it be a good idea to get a second opinion from a major cancer hospital, or teaching/research hospital?

Posts.Title: Stage 4 prostate cancer

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Michael F Hi Pratoman! At least be very pleased with the fact that your missing "<" has returned!!! Now a decimal point has gone AWOL! Try to loosen up & laugh at this crazy situation! You simply can't win at getting a correct post RP uPSA. I recall the horrible scare you had when the Quest uPSA was erroneously reported to be "3.something" Sorry for this latest SNAFU but remain confident that you will get is straightened out. I'm sure that my Forum Family is tired of my constant "Same Lab Same uPSA Methodology" & "Get a Copy of The Original Lab Report" mantras! But yours is a case where your Lab switched from Quest to LabCorp and you would have never known this except for the fact that your latest PSA result was from a "Standard" PSA Assay. Had they run a uPSA, your LabCorp result could not be compared (to detect a change) to your previous Quest uPSA result. Double check if your Jan & Feb uPSAs were done by LabCorp (or ask when LabCorp bought your current lab). Same thing happened at my local hospital lab where I have my uPSAs drawn. I always ask the phlebotomist to show me the Lab requisition sheet that has my name and the "exact" uPSA test before I'll allow them to draw the blood sample. LabCorp picks up from the hospital and the sample is run in their Birmingham, AL facility each time. FYI: I am "permanently married" to: LabCorp Test Number: 140731 = Prostate-specific Antigen (PSA), Ultrasensitive This must be on my requisition sheet. My "co-pay" is $12. Good luck in quickly getting back BOTH your missing < & your 2nd Decimal! I am certain that you will find both of them huddled closely together on your next uPSA Lab report! Hang in there & Good Luck my friend! MF Michael, just to claify. I haven't had my PSA done at Quest since that one time tht they screwed it up and it came back at 3.8. I'll never use them for PSA again unless I have no choice. My test since then has always been done at the hospital lab itself. Now, the hospital lab has been bought by labcorp. And what's messed up, to your point, is no matter what I do, I'm going to have to start all over again, with a new lab, probably new assay. So none of my future tests will relate to my past tests. UGH! my first few tests after surgery all came back at 0.00. Then, the next few came back at <.02. Yup, you guessed it, they changed the assay, I looked at the reports and compared them. Then I got the .02 three months ago, but it was the same assay. Now I get to start all over again. Oh crap

But yours is a case where your Lab switched from Quest to LabCorp and you would have never known this except for the fact that your latest PSA result was from a "Standard" PSA Assay. Had they run a uPSA, your LabCorp result could not be compared (to detect a change) to your previous Quest uPSA result. Double check if your Jan & Feb uPSAs were done by LabCorp (or ask when LabCorp bought your current lab). Same thing happened at my local hospital lab where I have my uPSAs drawn. I always ask the phlebotomist to show me the Lab requisition sheet that has my name and the "exact" uPSA test before I'll allow them to draw the blood sample. LabCorp picks up from the hospital and the sample is run in their Birmingham, AL facility each time. FYI: I am "permanently married" to: LabCorp Test Number: 140731 = Prostate-specific Antigen (PSA), Ultrasensitive This must be on my requisition sheet. My "co-pay" is $12. Good luck in quickly getting back BOTH your missing < & your 2nd Decimal! I am certain that you will find both of them huddled closely together on your next uPSA Lab report! Hang in there & Good Luck my friend! MF Michael, just to claify. I haven't had my PSA done at Quest since that one time tht they screwed it up and it came back at 3.8. I'll never use them for PSA again unless I have no choice. My test since then has always been done at the hospital lab itself. Now, the hospital lab has been bought by labcorp. And what's messed up, to your point, is no matter what I do, I'm going to have to start all over again, with a new lab, probably new assay. So none of my future tests will relate to my past tests. UGH! my first few tests after surgery all came back at 0.00. Then, the next few came back at <.02. Yup, you guessed it, they changed the assay, I looked at the reports and compared them. Then I got the .02 three months ago, but it was the same assay. Now I get to start all over again. Oh crap

Posts.Title: Got my PSA Results

Posts.Content: Gsteve....funny you should ask. I saw my Uro/surgeon today. My PSA after surgery was <.02, than at the two year mark it was .02. Retested two weeks later , .02. Then retested 4 months later, DIFFERENT LAB. .033. Because of differences in testing, .033 at this lab, could be the same as .02 at the previous lab. I'll never know. Retested last week, again, .033. Today I asked my urologist, the big question, which I'm sure you will be interested in.... "If not recurrence, what the hell is causing this admittedly small amount of PSA in my blood." His response was, that it could be cancer cells. But it could also be the fact that the Cowpers Gland, which is left in, is producing some PSA. And male breasts are also known to produce PSA. So it could be a sign of approaching recurrence. Or it could be nothing. He said he sees pops,in PSA that end up just leveling off and becoming the new normal all the time. So chill. Or try to. I'm going to post in another thread about today's Dr visit, so I don't hijack yours....good luck. As we used to say in Brooklyn, fuggetaboutit, just retest in 3 months.

Posts.Content: Newporter - so here is the story - The nurse didnt give me details, she just said the report looks great, no EPE, negative Margins, SV, LN, Upgrade from G6 to G7 (3+4) but since its organ confined, no big deal. and positive PNI which almost every one has. 5 % of organ involved by tumor. She did not tell me about the original Apex margin being positive. I learned this from my wife. The Surgeon (Dr Ash Tewari, great surgeon) called my wife during the surgery, and told her that they got the results of the frozen section and it showed positive margin, so he had to take off some more, and then got negative margin. I also read the path report, and it clearly said, referring to that sample "right apex positive margin, see notes", then underneath the note said right apex, final margin negative for carcinoma" So thats what it is. But still, as you said, I'm a worrier, and i need a couple of zero PSAs, before i can stop worrying about my damn Apex! So it sounds like you are saying that i probably dont need to worry about it if the case is that i have stated?

Posts.Title: Cancer at the Apex

Posts.Content: My attention had been diverted for a while so i have been MIA from here for a few days. Figured i would post an update.... Today is three weeks since my first Firmagon shot. So far no troubling side effects. Some "warm flashes" that make me sweat, not profusely, maybe just a few times a day, but today seems to be less, nothing troubling. And it seems that my Erectile Function is suddenly about 30% of what it was. Not sure if thats the Firmagon, i know a lot of guys on ADT that dont have erectile disfunction ,just a lack of interest. Today i had my simulation. MRI, CT Scan they will fuse the two images together and use the result to plan the treatments. They made a mold of my body from my abdomen to my junk, that will fit over me and secure me to the gurney, so i dont move when they are zapping me. For some reason they also did an EKG. It all went smoothly. Then they scheduled me for my 40 treatments. Starting on Sept 24th, and ending on Nov 16th, a day that i hope will make me very happy. Just in time for thanksgiving, followed by, hopefully, if i am in decent shape, the drive down to Florida for the winter. I'll keep you guys posted in this thread, for any new guys that might follow me (i hope none).

Posts.Title: Hopefully not a major issue

Posts.Content: My PC, dominant tumor was in the right Apex. My surgical pathology was negative for EPE, as well as negative, LN, SV, and Margins. My initial margin at the Apex was positive, this was the frozen section done while I was still on the Operating Table. When it came back positive, the Surgeon cut more, and sent it for Frozen Section and it came back Negative. So they stopped cutting. They didn't take any of my nerve bundles (near the Apex, I believe). I always knew that PC at the Apex produced more + margins than any other area (51% of all + margins are at the Apex). But the more I read and find out other stuff, like there is no capsule at the Apex, so its the easiest place for escape, etc, the more nervous I get. In two weeks I have my first post surgery PSA test (6 weeks after surgery) And my mind is starting to race. Anybody have any insight on this. Is my chance of biochemical recurrence a lot higher with cancer at the Apex, even if I had negative final margins and no Extra Prostatic Extension? Or does all the good stuff in the path report balance it out? My final Gleason was 7 (3+4). My PSA when I was diagnosed was 4.3. Very nervous about the first PSA, and this Apex issue.

Posts.Title: Update on Secondary Treatment

Posts.Content: Thanks all. MM, yes, it’s interesting, they do things a little differently at MSKCC. I don’t have to arrive with a full bladder, but I do have to arrive 1 hour before my appointment each day. When I arrive, they have me empty my bladder fully, and they give me one cup of water to drink. Wait 45 minutes and start treatment, This assures, they say, that the bladder will be in the exact same state, and I assume, position, each day. They still look at it though daily, with a ct scan before zapping commences, to be sure. Getting there an hour earlier than my 7:20am appointment will be a PITA for sure. But I like the approach, relieves me of one headache (no pun intended)

Posts.Title: 6 month checkup today

Posts.Content: NRHK, sorry for your dads diagnosis, I'm not sure what value the second opinion would have since he's already had primary treatment of some sort, although I might be wrong about that. But To get a second opinion you would need to have the biopsy slides sent to Epstein or Bostwick. I used Epstein and after I got the results, I tried to call him, he actually got on the phone and spent 10 minutes talking to me. He also was very good about answering a few questions that came up afterwards, via email. I was not covered for insurance for the second opinion service. The total cost was just $250.00. Lot less than $30,000 LOL. But a different kind of service. I'm not sure of the mechanics of getting the slides from India specifically. But here is a link to Dr Epsteins web page. If you scroll down, you will see phone numbers, and address where to send the slides, all the information you need to proceed... http://pathology.jhu.edu/department/...s/urologic.cfm Also, another thing you might consider, which I did.... In Marina Del Rey, Calufornia, there is an oncology practice that is focused solely on prostate cancer. They are highly regarded Medical Oncologists, with no ax to grind. In other words they don't do surgery, or radiation, they manage and treat prostate cancer mostly when it advances. They will do a telephone consultation with you, after they receive all the records, that lasts about 1 hour, and give you their thoughts on the best way to proceed. It lasts about 1 hour ( at least in my case) and the cost is $600. They will do follow ups for $75 for a $15 minute call. I did a consult with Dr Scholz, the medical director, who also wrote a well known book titled "invasion of the Prostate Snatchers" (basically about over treatment, Scholz is a big advocate of Active Surviellance, but obviously not in your dads case). The other Drs, Dr Lam and Turner, are also very excellent from my understanding. To access their info, go to their website at http://www.prostateoncology.com Good luck to you and your dad. He is very lucky to have you as his advocate.

Posts.Title: Newbie.

Posts.Content: My PC, dominant tumor was in the right Apex. My surgical pathology was negative for EPE, as well as negative, LN, SV, and Margins. My initial margin at the Apex was positive, this was the frozen section done while I was still on the Operating Table. When it came back positive, the Surgeon cut more, and sent it for Frozen Section and it came back Negative. So they stopped cutting. They didn't take any of my nerve bundles (near the Apex, I believe). I always knew that PC at the Apex produced more + margins than any other area (51% of all + margins are at the Apex). But the more I read and find out other stuff, like there is no capsule at the Apex, so its the easiest place for escape, etc, the more nervous I get. In two weeks I have my first post surgery PSA test (6 weeks after surgery) And my mind is starting to race. Anybody have any insight on this. Is my chance of biochemical recurrence a lot higher with cancer at the Apex, even if I had negative final margins and no Extra Prostatic Extension? Or does all the good stuff in the path report balance it out? My final Gleason was 7 (3+4). My PSA when I was diagnosed was 4.3. Very nervous about the first PSA, and this Apex issue.

Posts.Title: Hopefully not a major issue

Posts.Content: Thanks all. MM, yes, it’s interesting, they do things a little differently at MSKCC. I don’t have to arrive with a full bladder, but I do have to arrive 1 hour before my appointment each day. When I arrive, they have me empty my bladder fully, and they give me one cup of water to drink. Wait 45 minutes and start treatment, This assures, they say, that the bladder will be in the exact same state, and I assume, position, each day. They still look at it though daily, with a ct scan before zapping commences, to be sure. Getting there an hour earlier than my 7:20am appointment will be a PITA for sure. But I like the approach, relieves me of one headache (no pun intended)

Posts.Title: Groin pain one year after prostate cancer surgery

Posts.Content: PCD, i'll add my welcome, and just say, remember, even if it is advanced, it can be beaten back for many years. pc, is a highly treatable disease, unlike many other cancers and with todays medical technology, and new treatments coming on line regularly, its likely your dad will be around for a long time. Whats also different about PC is that there are a number of primary treatments, radiation and surgery, with or without hormone treatments, etc, and there is not necessarily one treatment that is the right treatment. In certain situations they all work equally well. So make sure you get a number of opinions, see a surgeon, a radiation oncologist, and probably a medical oncologist, to give you different points of view on your dads best course of action And do get the book, as Chuck suggested. Good luck

Posts.Title: Good Luck Tomorrow MM16

Posts.Content: Gsteve....funny you should ask. I saw my Uro/surgeon today. My PSA after surgery was <.02, than at the two year mark it was .02. Retested two weeks later , .02. Then retested 4 months later, DIFFERENT LAB. .033. Because of differences in testing, .033 at this lab, could be the same as .02 at the previous lab. I'll never know. Retested last week, again, .033. Today I asked my urologist, the big question, which I'm sure you will be interested in.... "If not recurrence, what the hell is causing this admittedly small amount of PSA in my blood." His response was, that it could be cancer cells. But it could also be the fact that the Cowpers Gland, which is left in, is producing some PSA. And male breasts are also known to produce PSA. So it could be a sign of approaching recurrence. Or it could be nothing. He said he sees pops,in PSA that end up just leveling off and becoming the new normal all the time. So chill. Or try to. I'm going to post in another thread about today's Dr visit, so I don't hijack yours....good luck. As we used to say in Brooklyn, fuggetaboutit, just retest in 3 months.

Posts.Title: slight increase in psa 4 years post robotic

Posts.Content: I'm no expert, and not a doctor, just a guy on the Internet, but I'll venture a guess that some Gleason grade 4 cells had already left the prostate and taken up residence in a distant place away from the prostate. PSA of 23 is pretty high, pre treatment. We're bone scan and Ct scans done at time of diagnosis? If they were negative, he could still have had mets that were too small to detect. He should not have a PSA of 100 after treatment. I'm a bit surprised that his doc was only checking PSA once a year so soon after treatment. Not what you wanted to hear, I know. But there are many treatment options available after fails BRachytherapy, if that's what this is, that can control the cancer for a long time. If I were your dad, I would find a good MEDICAL ONCOLOGIST that has a focus on Prostate Cancer, and make him or her a part of your dads team. Don't depend on just the urologist. Good luck and keep us posted

Posts.Title: Hopefully not a major issue

Posts.Content: Mary, welcome, and hope you are just passing through, and that you get a negative result on the biopsy. Its a big plus that the DRE/physical exam, seemed unremarkable. Keep in mind, that PSA is not really a test for cancer, certainly not a conclusive one. A high PSA just means that more investigation is warranted. If it does come back positive, there will be steps you will want to take, before making any decisions, first of which will probably be getting a second opinion on thte biopsy slides. But thats getting way ahead of ourselves, so for now, lets keep our fingers crossed that the result is negative.

Posts.Title: Cancer at the Apex

Posts.Content: Rocky, great synopsis I'm three weeks out of surgery, today is my three week "anniversary" I still have some blood in urine, but very little, if I don't look for it at the end of the stream I wouldn't notice it. One or two drops of pink. But I do have mini blood clots, little black flecks coming out with my piss. But getting better, and I think its just a sign of healing. My pain after surgery was almost exclusively from the gas they pump in you. That took a week to dissipate, and it was only because I did my walking. Currently walking 2 miles a day on the treadmill at a pace of 3.2-3.3 mph. Its a big help The catheter, as you said, wasn't painful, just annoying. And seeing blood come out was disturbing. But knew it was normal. I'm down to 1-2 guards per day, no more full Depends briefs. Usually only 1 guard, I weigh my pads, and am leaking about 1-1.2 ounces per 24 hour period. I'm not up and about all day, but I do spend 34-40 minutes a day on the treadmill, that's when I leak more. Good luck with your continued recovery.

Posts.Title: Cancer at the Apex

Posts.Content: Newporter - so here is the story - The nurse didnt give me details, she just said the report looks great, no EPE, negative Margins, SV, LN, Upgrade from G6 to G7 (3+4) but since its organ confined, no big deal. and positive PNI which almost every one has. 5 % of organ involved by tumor. She did not tell me about the original Apex margin being positive. I learned this from my wife. The Surgeon (Dr Ash Tewari, great surgeon) called my wife during the surgery, and told her that they got the results of the frozen section and it showed positive margin, so he had to take off some more, and then got negative margin. I also read the path report, and it clearly said, referring to that sample "right apex positive margin, see notes", then underneath the note said right apex, final margin negative for carcinoma" So thats what it is. But still, as you said, I'm a worrier, and i need a couple of zero PSAs, before i can stop worrying about my damn Apex! So it sounds like you are saying that i probably dont need to worry about it if the case is that i have stated?

Posts.Title: Cancer at the Apex

Posts.Content: Mary, welcome, and hope you are just passing through, and that you get a negative result on the biopsy. Its a big plus that the DRE/physical exam, seemed unremarkable. Keep in mind, that PSA is not really a test for cancer, certainly not a conclusive one. A high PSA just means that more investigation is warranted. If it does come back positive, there will be steps you will want to take, before making any decisions, first of which will probably be getting a second opinion on thte biopsy slides. But thats getting way ahead of ourselves, so for now, lets keep our fingers crossed that the result is negative.

Posts.Title: Fifteen hours to go....

Posts.Content: Mrs GG, this will all work out and eventually be a distant memory. I too had what turned out to be a G7 (3+4) and I was concerned because it was at the Apex. Last week I got results of my 3rd PSA test, since surgery, at the 6 month post op mark. And it was undetectable. It will be a tough two weeks or So, after surgery, but manageable. And after two weeks things will improve very rapidly. I still can't believe how good I feel now, it's like I never had surgery. So try to relax, it will be manageable, and likely will all turn out well. Get a 5 gallon oval shaped bucket for him to carry the catch bag in. Recliner if you don't have one you can rent it,for a week. Get an inflatable donut for him to sit on for the ride home from the hospital. Hang in there, keep the faith

Posts.Title: Lupron Depot price shocker

Posts.Content: Totally different, but since you don't know what your treatment plan will be yet.....a good friend of mine was diagnosed a year ago, and he had Davinci Robotic Surgery. I was speaking with him last week about his experience. He had the cath out in i think 6 days, and was back at work in 8 days (from date of surgery) which i found amazing. Said he was a bit tired as the day wore on, but was able to handle it. He is in an office type of environment.

Posts.Title: Lupron Depot price shocker

Posts.Content: Welcome to the forum, sorry you need to be here. But you will get a lot of support and education here. I am not the most knowledgeable guy here, but I've been through it and educated myself with the help of guys here and elsewhere. First thing I would say is its clear that he needs treatment and probably shouldn't wait too long, with the G8 cores. But with that said don't rush, or get pushed, into anything. I would get a second opinion on the biopsy slides from a highly respected lab. The two always mentioned are Johns Hopkins, Dr Jonathan Epstein, and Bostwick Labs/David Bostwick. But I would imagine if you are going to MD Anderson, they will look at the slides and they are world class. Surgery may well be the right option, but keep in mind there are other alternatives. And Prostate Cancer is unfortunately, big business. Talk to a surgeon, (like your urologist) they will want to cut. Talk to a Radiation Oncologist, they will want to radiate. At MD Anderson you will probably be referred to a team that will together help you make a decision. If the cancer has escaped the prostate capsule, surgery may not be the best option. You can never know for sure, but you can get a good idea, by asking for a 3 tesla, multiparametric MRI, (think Hi Def MRI). I'm sure MD Anderson will recommend that. Armed with the information it will yield, you can make an intelligent decision. Whatever you choose, make sure you hire a doctor who has a good track record and is highly experienced in whatever treatment he does. Last thing - buy the book - How To Survive Prostate Cancer by Dr Patrick Walsh. Its the definitive guide, and will give you a good education. Just keep in mind Walsh is a surgeon, and so his POV is a bit biased, naturally. But its a great easy read. Make sure you purchase the 3rd edition. You can buy it here.... http://www.amazon.com/Patrick-Walshs...+patrick+walsh Good luck, it sounds like your husband has a good advocate.

Posts.Content: Anything is possible. The lupron is not given with curative intent, it's given with the purpose of making the cancer more susceptible to radiation, which, as Highlander said, if contained, could cure the disease. G10 is tough though, so it depends highly on how early in the game you are being treated Good luck, and as highlander said, providing us with your PSA, and other data would help us help you

Posts.Title: Wheelar

Posts.Content: Wam, After re-reading your original post, I have to say this.... If your dad had a PSA OF 3 a year after treatments after reaching a nadir of 1 (not even sure 1 is considered a nadir) he should have been re-tested in a month. To wait a year, and then save a 7, and still do nothing? For another year? Do I understand correctly that this is what happened? I hesitate to say this under most circumstances, but in this case, I feel compelled - I think this borders (or maybe not borders but is) on the verge of malpractice. I would be asking that doctor a lot of hard questions. Your dad is in a tough spot, but he can be helped, the disease can likely be managed. Just keep that in mind. But again I can't stress enough for the sake of other men who see this doc, I would be asking some really hard questions about now.

Posts.Title: Worried About My Dad - PSA Level 100

Posts.Content: PCD, i'll add my welcome, and just say, remember, even if it is advanced, it can be beaten back for many years. pc, is a highly treatable disease, unlike many other cancers and with todays medical technology, and new treatments coming on line regularly, its likely your dad will be around for a long time. Whats also different about PC is that there are a number of primary treatments, radiation and surgery, with or without hormone treatments, etc, and there is not necessarily one treatment that is the right treatment. In certain situations they all work equally well. So make sure you get a number of opinions, see a surgeon, a radiation oncologist, and probably a medical oncologist, to give you different points of view on your dads best course of action And do get the book, as Chuck suggested. Good luck

Posts.Title: Viagra insurance issues?

Posts.Content: Daughter, so sorry for your dads diagnosis. I’m not very well versed in advanced prostate cancer, but I can tell you, it’s not likely to be months, unless he has a poor response to the Lupron, which is unlikely. I’m going to leave the rest to other more knowledgeable guys. But I just want to relate to you, a case that might give you hope. There is a member of another forum (he shows up here occasionally too), screen name is Todd1963. He was diagnosed at age 42, with a PSA of 3200, and had multiple bone mets. That was 11-12 years ago, and last time I saw him post, within the last few months, his PSA was undetectable. Sure he’s gone through a lot. But he is living large. If you are interested, here is a link to his blog... http://toddseals63.blogspot.com Again, I am not as knowledgeable technically as guys like DjinTonic and Another, Micheal, and others here, but I hope Todd’s story takes you at least a step away from panic mode.

Posts.Title: Fifteen hours to go....

Posts.Content: Mrs GG, this will all work out and eventually be a distant memory. I too had what turned out to be a G7 (3+4) and I was concerned because it was at the Apex. Last week I got results of my 3rd PSA test, since surgery, at the 6 month post op mark. And it was undetectable. It will be a tough two weeks or So, after surgery, but manageable. And after two weeks things will improve very rapidly. I still can't believe how good I feel now, it's like I never had surgery. So try to relax, it will be manageable, and likely will all turn out well. Get a 5 gallon oval shaped bucket for him to carry the catch bag in. Recliner if you don't have one you can rent it,for a week. Get an inflatable donut for him to sit on for the ride home from the hospital. Hang in there, keep the faith

Posts.Title: A wife with questions

Posts.Content: My former urologist, who diagnosed me, is Dr Aaron Katz. He's very well known for holistic approach with diet, wrote a few books and has published numerous studies. He put me on Broccolli extract after my first biopsy which was negative, when my PSA was 2.9. 6 months later , PSA was 2.7, first decrease in over 3 years. Then 6 m0nths later it went to 3.1. And continued to rise, for another year, when at 4.3, I had another biopsy. The rest is history, I had surgery 2 months later. Just anectdotal. But still, Reading this thread, I wonder if I should start taking it again, with my PSA now detectable at .033. I eat a lot of broccoli and cauliflower though.

Posts.Title: Merry Christmas

Posts.Content: Mary, welcome, and hope you are just passing through, and that you get a negative result on the biopsy. Its a big plus that the DRE/physical exam, seemed unremarkable. Keep in mind, that PSA is not really a test for cancer, certainly not a conclusive one. A high PSA just means that more investigation is warranted. If it does come back positive, there will be steps you will want to take, before making any decisions, first of which will probably be getting a second opinion on thte biopsy slides. But thats getting way ahead of ourselves, so for now, lets keep our fingers crossed that the result is negative.

Posts.Title: Glad tidings to all

Posts.Content: Ive not traveled, but from others experiences that I've read, you should get a hotel room to stay it for a week or 10 days, until the catheter comes out. I have read of others who traveled home with the cath, I personally wouldn't want to do it. But that's me. You should talk to your surgeon about follow ups. You won't want to drive 4-5 hours ape very few months, so you should probably find a local urologist with experience who is willing to take your partner on as a patient, monitor his PSA, and deal with any issues that might come up.

Posts.Title: Good for my Prostate Health

Posts.Content: Red bull, for the constipation, my surgeon had me on 3 Colace a day and I continued that for about 2-3 weeks, then cut back to two a day. Then a week later, I cut it back to one every evening. I am six weeks post op (tomorrow) and a couple of days ago I cut back to 1 every other day, so far so good. As far as recovery, my experience was things started to speed up after the catheter came out (10 days post op), but there was enough bothering me, like leakage, and just not feeling right, for the next 10 days or so that I was feeling better but frustrated. Probably a result of my impatient nature. But then at about week4, things really started getting better fast. When I look back now to three weeks ago, I can't believe the difference Good luck, it gets better from here for you.

Posts.Title: Newcomer

Posts.Content: a few days ago, I read a great poem on another PC forum. One of the lines was " I wish to be normal again" . It hit me right between the eyes. I got past the PC and then got hit with Coronary Artery Disease. A punch in the stomach. My research in how to stop progression led me to a new Cardioogist who practices integrative medicine and he did advanced blood tests on me, one of which was off the charts and indicates very high risk for a cardiac event in the next one to six months, according to the research I've read. Needless to say, I didn't take this well. The Dr wants me to retest and said if it comes back with the same result it may or may not be heart related, it could be something else. I have no knowledge of what he is thinking and I don't think I want to know. I am hoping it's just a lab error, and that I'm just presisposed to labs screwing with my head. Not counting on it though, since I'm such an "optimist" Anyway, the point is, back to that poem, I really just want to be normal again. I wake up each morning and go to my iPad to log on here, and to another PC forum, then to a heart health forum. I listen to Doctor Radio on Sirius XM in ten car on my way to work. I think about my health 24/7. I doubt I'll ever be normal again, but I gotta try. I know a lot of folks especially many here, have it way worse than I do. That's not lost on me. But I still ain't a happy camper these days, and I need to change it up. So I'm gonna take a break from posting here for a while. And on the other cancer forum. Might be a week, might be a month, I dunno. Just a break with no plan. (But I'm sure I'll be back a few weeks before my next PSA test LOL )

Posts.Content: Ive not traveled, but from others experiences that I've read, you should get a hotel room to stay it for a week or 10 days, until the catheter comes out. I have read of others who traveled home with the cath, I personally wouldn't want to do it. But that's me. You should talk to your surgeon about follow ups. You won't want to drive 4-5 hours ape very few months, so you should probably find a local urologist with experience who is willing to take your partner on as a patient, monitor his PSA, and deal with any issues that might come up.

Posts.Title: 5 years post RALP

Posts.Content: I have been going to Aruba every summer for the last 15 years, and on and off for 38 years. This summer i skipped it, as i wanted to do Alaska (cant do that in the winter) so i went last week. First time since my surgery. It was truly, GFMPH. I never appreciated this trip mre than this year. The day before i left, i was walking down the aisle of the drug store. It was a year ago, that i was shopping for supplies before my January 2015 surgery. It occured to me...here i am, shopping for suntan lotion. A year ago, i was walking down the aisles of this same drugstore, with tears, shopping for diapers. What a difference a year makes. I've been very lucky SO FAR. (Dont want to jinx myself before my 1 year PSA next month). Zero PSA, no incontinence, and a bonus, no issues with ED. Of course, i have been taking Cialis, so never knew if i was good on the ED without drugs. I did switch from daily Cialis to every other day this past summer and everything seemed fine. So i decided, on my vacation, when i was pretty relaxed, to take a shot. I stopped Cialis altogether. After three days, i did the deed, and everything worked fine. Mrs Pratoman makes me take her on vacation if i want sex, so this was my opportunity LOLOL. As the week progressed, all was good. On the 8th day, i still had no problem, and did the deed. Not only effortless, but it was probably the best orgasm i've had since surgery. Hopefully this continues. I do find, that even WITH Cialis, at times when i need to "take care of my own business" it is often not as easy to maintain an erection. But otherwise, I'm grateful. Now i just need to get a zero on my 1 year PSA test. Keeping my fingers crossed

I am sure there are highly skilled surgeons in your area. With that said, Dr Tewari performed surgery on me and I had a great result, besides zero PSA (so far) I had no ED problems from the beginning (5mg Cialis daily), and continence issues resolved at 5 weeks. Of course every case is different

Posts.Title: Radical Questions

Posts.Content: Not much to add, other than welcome, Roblee gave you a great overview and i agree with MichiganMan, if you could get to a major NCCN comprehensive cancer center like Mermorial Sloan Kettering, MD Anderson, etc, it would be ideal. This is not gonna be fun, but you will get through it, and as MM said, it can be managed for years, or decades. And new treatments are being approved very regularly. One more thing. At the very least, your husbands previous Doctor should be made aware of whats going on, and that it was his lack of proper care that put your husband in this position. Because if he is not aware, he will do the same thing to the next guy. At the very least.

Posts.Title: Overload of info, trying to understand

Posts.Content: Water i agree with Chuck. A jump that big, that quickly, could well be an infection. So you should probably go on a regimen of Cipro, or some other anti biotic then retest. Of course, the MRI (i assume 3T?) could tell you alot. And BTW, if it IS cancer, just be aware, I've seen guys with PSA at diagnosis in the THOUSANDS, as i high as 5200, that have been treated successfully, and while undergoing continuous treatment, are living long and enjoyable lives. But that conversation is getting ahead of ourselves. Good luck and keep us posted

Posts.Content: Cyndyrd, great advice above, the only thing I'd like to add is this... I don't like it when doctors say things like 3-5 years. It's just opinion. It might be true.it might not. Statistics are applicable to large groups. The larger the group, the more true the stats. Your dad is a group of 1. Don't pay attention to that statement.

Posts.Title: Did they perform a junk transplant?

Posts.Content: Sorry you found your way to this place, but u will get good information from others that have gone thru it. You were staged T2c due to the fact that they found Cancer lesions on both lobes of the Prostate. g6. , however, is a slow growing cancer type, many studies have shown that it does nit spread to other parts of the body. 30-40% of patients have their GLeason scores upgraded to a more aggressive score after surgery when they examine the entire Prostate after it's been removed. One of the first things you should do is request that your Dr arrange to have your pathology slides sent out for a second opinion, to either Drs john Epstein at Johns Hopkins , or Davd Bostwick at Bostwick labs, two of the leading pThologists on Prostate cells. This is done routinely it's very simple, and you should get that second opinion. If you provide more details, it will help others possibly give you more detailed information, but remember nobody here is a doctor we are patients and you need to be writing do questions for your doctors.

Posts.Title: First time diagnosis with Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: Water i agree with Chuck. A jump that big, that quickly, could well be an infection. So you should probably go on a regimen of Cipro, or some other anti biotic then retest. Of course, the MRI (i assume 3T?) could tell you alot. And BTW, if it IS cancer, just be aware, I've seen guys with PSA at diagnosis in the THOUSANDS, as i high as 5200, that have been treated successfully, and while undergoing continuous treatment, are living long and enjoyable lives. But that conversation is getting ahead of ourselves. Good luck and keep us posted

Posts.Title: Big PSA jump. What does it mean?

Posts.Content: Paul, I am with you, I was just diagnosed on Nov 10th and am scheduled for surgery jan 6th. Learn all you can. Don't depend on your Dr no matter how good he may be. Knowledge is power. This Cancer is different than other cancers, where they have a protocol, and tell you what it is. With PCa, there are options , as you were told. And you're given the options then told to choose one. So it's imperative that you are educated. You should buy Dr Patrick Walsh's book "Guide to Surviving Prostate Cancer" and Dr Marc Scholz book "Invasion of the Prostate Snatchers" . This will give you a broad understanding and help you with the right questions to ask. Also stay on this forum, frequent it often and in addition visit Healingwell.com, Prostate cancer section. There is a wealth of information and it's helped me tremendously. I was in a fog for weeks. Don't get me wrong, I'm still nervous and upset, but I learned enough to know I am not going to die or even get really sick any time soon and I can think with a clear head. Take your docs advice and meet with both surgeons and radiation oncologists. Good luck and keep us posted

Posts.Title: New Member, Wife

Posts.Content: Ron, good luck. The good news is that after a couple of months, and more so as some time passes, you are going to be surprised at how the "new" normal, is really not a whole lot different than the old normal. Especially with your pathology. Re the prep - i was told that i could have a light breakfast the day before surgery, if i did so early in the morning, like 8AM. After that, i was restricted to liquids, took some prep drink at about 4pm, (forgot what it was, probably because i want to) then the fleet enema in the morning.

Posts.Title: My first post-surgery PSA report is in

Posts.Content: Stevie, Bravehardon is 100% correct. One week is nothing. I was going thru 2 - 3 pads a day at one week out of surgery. At 4 weeks I was just wearing a shield, one a day, and at 5 or 6 weeks I wasn't wearing anything. At 5 montHs, I still have an occasional squirt at odd times, like when I grab my wife's ass (serious) but not enough to show, and not enough tO have to wear any pads. Some guys recover slower, some faster. But my doc said I will continue to see improvement. So don't cheat yourself out of what might be months of enjoying life. You are so early in the game that you shouldn't even be thinking about being dry yet. Just keep doing your Kegels, it works, and you will eventually be dry.

Posts.Content: Was diagnosed yesterday. Today I saw dr David Samadi, and scheduled surgery for mid December, exactly 6 weeks after the biopsy. If there is a reason, I can always cancel what I scheduled, if one of the other doctors says something that makes me want to do so. But I liked Samadi a lot. He seems very positive, and easy to talk to, and I know his reputation as a top guy Next step is to get the scans done.

Posts.Title: Thought I had a plan

Posts.Content: Thanks guys for the comments. Seems to be no real consensus. My concern with Calcium supplementation is how it might affect my coronary artery disease, that’s something I plan on asking my RO, or maybe my cardiologist would be a better choice. For now, I’m eating cheese for calcium. I know, there’s a theory about cheese being bad for PC. I’m afraid that I’m beyond all that stuff now. I need science otherwise I’m going to eat what I want. There are no prospective studies though on diet, only retrospective, so I’ll just keep on eating, try to keep it heart healthy, and leave my pc to the ADT and SRT

Posts.Title: PSA results in

Posts.Content: H60, I agree with the others, there is no reason to think hope is waning, by any stretch of the imagination. I put your numbers, as best I could, into the MSKCC Nomograms, a database, based on 10,000 patients histories. I assumed a PSA at time of surgery o 3.0, and negative margins (not clear). Here are the results.... PROBABILITY OF REMAINING RECURRENCE-FREE AFTER SURGERY 2 YR97% 5 YR92% 7 YR90% 10 YR86% 15-YEAR PROSTATE CANCER-SPECIFIC SURVIVAL 98% When I changed the input to POSITIVE margins, the 15 year PC specific survival rate was STILL 98%. What is interesting to note is that angiolymphatic Invasion was NOT one of the input criteria. Which means it's not considered a major determining factor. As I mentioned in another post, I'm waiting for a PSA result 2 1/2 years after surgery, after having a slight rise at 2 years. I'm nervous about it, sure, but when I find myself getting down, I remind myself that no matter what, the odds of PC getting me in the next 15 years, are infinitesimal. Try to stay positive, you've got every reason to.

Posts.Title: Angiolymphatic Invasion question

Posts.Content: Mark, it doesn’t matter if it’s a single tumor or not, as to which procedure you choose, and in fact, PC is usually multi-focal so when they get the prostate out they may well find it’s more than one tumor. Obviously robotic will provide an easier recovery than open. However, nothing is more important than the skill and experience of the surgeon you choose. That’s the most important factor to focus on.

Posts.Title: Best Surgical Options Still Seems Unclear

Posts.Content: Walsh's book is outdated. But for a good understanding of the basics of PC and primary treatment, I think it's still a terrific resource. And it's not written for surgeons. It's written for us. While diet, as has already been pointed out, cannot cure cancer, there is a large body of collective knowledge that believes that in some cases, it can slow progression, or even help avoid or delay recurrence. The basics art, limit dairy, red meat, sugar. Lots of plant based foods. No egg yolks. Here is a publication bu USCF on diet and prostate cancer, that you will find very useful...and it includes references to hundreds of studies as cites that you can look at to make your own judgements.... http://cancer.ucsf.edu/_docs/crc/nutrition_prostate.pdf Also, if you go to ancan.org, you can access a replay of a webinar done a few weeks ago, on diet and prostate cancer. Good luck in your decision making process. It sounds like you are going about this the right way, being informed and deliberate.

Posts.Title: Some questions about PSA

Posts.Content: Thanks Frenchy. My experience has been the fluctuations are more about the 3rd digit. I had 3 PSA tests in 3 weeks, with the last one being a 2 digit at MSKCC, they came back t .082, .078, and .08. I wouldn’t m9nd a test that detects down to say .02. .05 seems high to me. But that’s MSKCC’s protocol. I guess, they figure if the SRT doesn’t work, they wouldn’t act at .05 anyway, they’d probably wait till 5.0 or something, unless something showed on a scan

I tested Blood sugar today, and its alraedy up
