Posts.Title: Taking care of yourself while on ADT

Posts.Content: Mark, it doesn’t matter if it’s a single tumor or not, as to which procedure you choose, and in fact, PC is usually multi-focal so when they get the prostate out they may well find it’s more than one tumor. Obviously robotic will provide an easier recovery than open. However, nothing is more important than the skill and experience of the surgeon you choose. That’s the most important factor to focus on.

Posts.Title: Best Surgical Options Still Seems Unclear

Posts.Content: Bit of a tough pathology report. Nevertheless, 2 comments. 1. I’d wait until PSA became detectable and then rose 2 more times (assuming it was very low detectable). Then I’d jump in it. And I’d use an ultrsensitive assay. 2. I’d try to give it at least 3-4 m0nths to heal, after surgery. Wherever you are in recovery, you’ll likely not make more progress once radiation starts.

Posts.Title: Double Whammy

Posts.Content: Welcome to the club. If you can handle it mentally, Active Surviellance is a great option for you with 2 cores gleason 6, low tumor volume, both on 1 side, and low PSA. One thing though - you mentioned the words "wait and see". That implies do nothing for now and see what happens. Maybe an occasional PSA test. Which seems to be what your Urologist is implying. DONT DO THAT!!!! Get into a solid, structured, program of Active Surviellance. This means regular DRE's and PSA's at specific intervals, and regular MRIs, probably annually, with Biopsies every few years. And a pre-determined metric that will mean you take action. i.e. treatment. If you get into a structured program like this, it will give you a very high likelihood of taking action before its too late to cure, if and when the time comes. Active Surviellance is not for everyone, but if you can handle it mentally, its probably your best option. You'd be cured in all probability with surgery or radiation. But neither of those is a hell of a lot of fun.

Posts.Title: Just Received Diagnosis Active Sur Route I Think

Posts.Content: Dave, I'm on Medicare. I know it's probably not what you meant. But effectively, it is a single payer system, md a form of socialized medicine. I would imagine, that if we ever got to a point in the US, where we went to a single payer system, it would be modeled on the Medicare system. In fact, we've all heard the campaign phrase in the past (Bernie Sanders) , "Medicare for all" So in my experience, as stated in another thread, it's been terrific. I've not been refused any treatments, and no payment has been declined with me held responsible. I've had a few instances where a service was declined as not covered with the notation "because you were not made aware that this service is not covered, you re not responsible to pay anything. However if this service is rendered agin, it will be your responsibility". But nothing major. The big question I would have, is how quick and efficiently does Medicare add newly (FDA) approved treatments to the list of covered expenses. I haven't gotten to that stage. Yet.

Posts.Title: Curious About treatment choices for those with socialized medicine

Posts.Content: One PSA test by itself doesn’t mean much. I would retest in 2 months or so. Also ask your Uro for anPHI Index, it’s a blood test that looks at not only PSA bug other factors and is a more reliable indicator of whether a biopsy is indicated. This could be PC. Or it could be Prostatitis. PSA is just an indication that something is going on, it’s not an indication of cancer.

Posts.Title: Surgery on Wednesday

Posts.Content: I do notice a correlation between bowel and urinary function. And when I am emptying my bowels, I find that if I just relax, I am emptying my bladder at the same time (sorry, not to sound disgusting). Which is a good thing. I did not find myself to be extra gassy in the mornings with rumblings. However I did find some pain on bowel movement, in my lower abdominal area, feeling like it was near my bladder or somehow related to it. But that seems to have, for the most part, subsided.

Posts.Title: Forum as reality?

Posts.Content: Two questions - started Firmagon 2 weeks ago today, next shot is in two weeks. When I started, they tested PSA and Teststosterone before giving me the shot, and will test again every month when I get each ahot. 1. If my PSA on the day of my first Firmagon shot was .08, and Firmagon should drop my T down to castrate levels within 3 days (it’s been two weeks and I’ve got no side effects), then a month later they retest PSA, which they will just before my second shot, what should I expect/hope for? Should my PSA be undetectable? If it’s not (MSKCC tests down to .05) does that mean I’ve got a problem ? 2. I’m not sure how much <.05 means to me, being accustomed to the 3 digit Labcorp uPSA. Would anyone suggest testing simultaneously at Labcorp to be sure it’s really I undetectable, if that’s what it’s supposed to be, at my expense of course? If say, my PSA went down to .03, or .04, this showed undetectable with the MSKCC Test that only measures down to .05, should I know if it’s not truly undetectable, I.e. <.006? With ADT?

Posts.Title: Just diagnosed, many questions

Posts.Content: One PSA test by itself doesn’t mean much. I would retest in 2 months or so. Also ask your Uro for anPHI Index, it’s a blood test that looks at not only PSA bug other factors and is a more reliable indicator of whether a biopsy is indicated. This could be PC. Or it could be Prostatitis. PSA is just an indication that something is going on, it’s not an indication of cancer.

Posts.Content: Thanks guys for the comments. Seems to be no real consensus. My concern with Calcium supplementation is how it might affect my coronary artery disease, that’s something I plan on asking my RO, or maybe my cardiologist would be a better choice. For now, I’m eating cheese for calcium. I know, there’s a theory about cheese being bad for PC. I’m afraid that I’m beyond all that stuff now. I need science otherwise I’m going to eat what I want. There are no prospective studies though on diet, only retrospective, so I’ll just keep on eating, try to keep it heart healthy, and leave my pc to the ADT and SRT

Posts.Title: Hello from the Other Side (of Surgery)

Posts.Content: Dave, I'm on Medicare. I know it's probably not what you meant. But effectively, it is a single payer system, md a form of socialized medicine. I would imagine, that if we ever got to a point in the US, where we went to a single payer system, it would be modeled on the Medicare system. In fact, we've all heard the campaign phrase in the past (Bernie Sanders) , "Medicare for all" So in my experience, as stated in another thread, it's been terrific. I've not been refused any treatments, and no payment has been declined with me held responsible. I've had a few instances where a service was declined as not covered with the notation "because you were not made aware that this service is not covered, you re not responsible to pay anything. However if this service is rendered agin, it will be your responsibility". But nothing major. The big question I would have, is how quick and efficiently does Medicare add newly (FDA) approved treatments to the list of covered expenses. I haven't gotten to that stage. Yet.

Posts.Title: Hello from the Other Side (of Surgery)

Posts.Content: Welcome to the club. If you can handle it mentally, Active Surviellance is a great option for you with 2 cores gleason 6, low tumor volume, both on 1 side, and low PSA. One thing though - you mentioned the words "wait and see". That implies do nothing for now and see what happens. Maybe an occasional PSA test. Which seems to be what your Urologist is implying. DONT DO THAT!!!! Get into a solid, structured, program of Active Surviellance. This means regular DRE's and PSA's at specific intervals, and regular MRIs, probably annually, with Biopsies every few years. And a pre-determined metric that will mean you take action. i.e. treatment. If you get into a structured program like this, it will give you a very high likelihood of taking action before its too late to cure, if and when the time comes. Active Surviellance is not for everyone, but if you can handle it mentally, its probably your best option. You'd be cured in all probability with surgery or radiation. But neither of those is a hell of a lot of fun.

Posts.Title: Nail-biting wait for PSA results....11 month post-op

Posts.Content: I am a member of another PC forum, in addition to this one. It's striking to me that while all I hear in real life is that people seldom die of PC, and that pRimary treatment usually cures (except of course for G8+) it doesn't seem to be the case on the forums. I see What seems like a lot of men with G7 (3+4) that have BCR/rise in PSA after surgery, even with pathology that says organ confined disease. And it just serves to make me nervous. Do you think this represents reality? Or is it that most men with G7 and no ECE, negative margins, are cured, don't have a recurrence, and eventually leave the forums and move on. This makes me so frustrated that I was upgraded from g6 to g7, after surgery, the only fly in the ointment in my pathology. I am having a tough time mentally, getting back to myself, and I think that worrying about this has a lot to do with it.

Posts.Title: Forum as reality?

Posts.Content: One PSA test by itself doesn’t mean much. I would retest in 2 months or so. Also ask your Uro for anPHI Index, it’s a blood test that looks at not only PSA bug other factors and is a more reliable indicator of whether a biopsy is indicated. This could be PC. Or it could be Prostatitis. PSA is just an indication that something is going on, it’s not an indication of cancer.

Posts.Title: Path report today?

Posts.Content: Searcher, welcome and sorry to hear about you joining our club. Your biopsy results are relatively good, you are in the low risk group. You could go on active Surviellance, but it sounds like you are wanting to treat and that’s ok. I had surgery, it wasn’t as bad as it sounds. A rough 10mdays but then recovered quickly. Chance of incontinence is small. As far as ED, everyone is different so it’s hard to say. Your best bet is to find an experienced surgery who has done at least (in my opinion) 1000 surgeries (some say 300, it’s just me). And make sure it’s someone who is current ask how many they currently do a month on average, As far as radiation, there are 2ntypes of Brachytherapy, LDR (permanent seeds) and HDR (newer, temporary radiation inserted). But there is also SBRT sometimes known as Cyberknife. In Gleason 6 and 7 it’s got a great 10myear track record. Make sure you speak to a specialist in each of these methods. As far as radiation or surgery, either one will likely cure you. The side effects tend to be more immediate with surgery, and ED is more of a possibility On the other hand with surgery, you will know for sure what your Final Gleason score is. 30% of the time, Gleason can be upgraded when the pathologist examines the entire prostate. And with surgery, you should see your PSA drop to undetectable within a couple of months, where with radiation it is a gradual drop, with some bounces along the way, and it can take up to a couple of years to reach nadir (low point, it willl usually not go to undetectable, because you will still have a prostate. It’s a tough decision that only you can make. But the good news is whatever you decide, it won’t be a wrong decision, as long as u educate yourself about each option p,uses and minuses. Good luck and keep us posted

Posts.Title: Just diagnosed, many questions

Posts.Content: Asa , interesting video to watc, even though it was a commercial for the radiation oncologist who did the interview. I think the perils of Robituc Surgery were greatly exaggerated by Curtis Sliwa, it was only his personal experience. With today’s technology, and a skilled surgeon, it’s a small percentage of men who have permanent incontinence. With that said, I (and probably many here) have a pretty good idea who the surgeon was, that he had operate on him. And if it’s who I think it was, I have no doubt he was told what he says he was told. I saw that surgeon 3 days after my diagnosis, he had me booked for surgery 5 weeks later, before I walked out the door. Thank goodness I came to my senses and cancelled, a week later after I saw Dr Tewari, who finally did the surgery. Aside from that, Sliwa’s case seems like a classic case of overtreatment.

Posts.Title: Just diagnosed, many questions

Posts.Content: Chasisme - I too was diagnosed in November - November 10th. I am scheduled for Surgery Jan 6th . My understanding is that you cant do the surgery till at least 6 weeks after biopsy anyway. I don't know about how long you can wait, but I do know that if you were a gleason 8 or higher, the urgency would be a lot higher. With that said, the fact that you had all 12 cores positive, indicates you shouldn't wait TOO long, but still, slow down just a bit and get your facts and due diligence done. The only bad decision is one made without knowing all the relevant facts - about your pathology, about side effects and cure rates of various treatment options, about the experience of the surgeon or radiation oncologist that you choose to treat you, etc. The first thing I think you should do is send your biopsy slides for a second opinion to a high level pathology lab that has pathologists who look at prostate slides all day long. The local Pathologist might look at your slides, but also the same day looked at breast slides, colon slides, and who else knows what. And prostate grading (gleason) is a very subjective thing. So call your urologist on Friday, and tell them (don't take any pushback) that you want your slides sent to Jonathan Epstein at Johns Hopkins or David Bostwick at Bostwick Labs. They will know these people, they get this request all the time. And just so you know, my biopsy was graded 3 cores positive, Gleason 6, gleason 6, and gleason 8. When I sent the slides to Epstein, they downgraded me to Gleason 6 x 3. And that was later reconfirmed by pathologists at Memorial Sloan Kettering. So do it. Then with the facts, make sure you see at least a few surgeons and a few Radiation Oncologists and one medical oncologist, with no skin in the game. What I mean by that is that Surgeons will recommend surgery, Radtiation oncologists will generally recommend radiation, and Oncologists don't have any dog in that fight. Learn all you can about side effects, upside and downside of all treatment options available to you, and only then, should you make a decision. If you are near a major cancer center of great repute, like Johns Hopkins, Mayo, Cleveland Clinic, MSKCC, all the better, because to me at least, those guys seem to be above the fray, and you can arrange to consult with a team, whom together, will probably give you a joint assessment. If you tell us what major city you are closest to, perhaps someone here will be able to recommend a Dr or Center. Good luck

Posts.Title: Options aside from a biopsy?

Posts.Content: Searcher, welcome and sorry to hear about you joining our club. Your biopsy results are relatively good, you are in the low risk group. You could go on active Surviellance, but it sounds like you are wanting to treat and that’s ok. I had surgery, it wasn’t as bad as it sounds. A rough 10mdays but then recovered quickly. Chance of incontinence is small. As far as ED, everyone is different so it’s hard to say. Your best bet is to find an experienced surgery who has done at least (in my opinion) 1000 surgeries (some say 300, it’s just me). And make sure it’s someone who is current ask how many they currently do a month on average, As far as radiation, there are 2ntypes of Brachytherapy, LDR (permanent seeds) and HDR (newer, temporary radiation inserted). But there is also SBRT sometimes known as Cyberknife. In Gleason 6 and 7 it’s got a great 10myear track record. Make sure you speak to a specialist in each of these methods. As far as radiation or surgery, either one will likely cure you. The side effects tend to be more immediate with surgery, and ED is more of a possibility On the other hand with surgery, you will know for sure what your Final Gleason score is. 30% of the time, Gleason can be upgraded when the pathologist examines the entire prostate. And with surgery, you should see your PSA drop to undetectable within a couple of months, where with radiation it is a gradual drop, with some bounces along the way, and it can take up to a couple of years to reach nadir (low point, it willl usually not go to undetectable, because you will still have a prostate. It’s a tough decision that only you can make. But the good news is whatever you decide, it won’t be a wrong decision, as long as u educate yourself about each option p,uses and minuses. Good luck and keep us posted

Posts.Title: Torn between Brachy or Surgery: Input Requested

Posts.Content: @DT - yup I’m planning on wonrking on my list of questions. The biggest question I have of the RO is, “how confident are you that it’s in the prostate bed” @Michael - I’ve mentioned this before but to refresh your memory, my Surgeon does frozen sections intraoperatively. In my case I had a positive margin, I believe at the Apex, that was 3+4. When that came back positive, the surgeon went back and did further resection of the tissue, and obtained what the pathologist referred to as a negative “FINAL” margin. When I consulted with an RO at Cleveland Clinic he said that the surgeon probably got everything he could see but left a few cells that were cancerous, that was missed on the final pathology, and they’ve now grown to put out PSA. In addition, Dr Zelefsky, the RO at MSKCC, who o am seeing on Tuesday, when I saw him last July, referred to my negative margin status as “questionable” which he thinks may be the source of the PSA. So while on the surface my pathology is pristine, it’s a bit of an odd situation. We shall see what Zelefsky says on Tuesday.

Posts.Title: PSA results are in, not great news, but totally expected

Posts.Content: Yesterday’s blood draw came back at .068. Just for context, my first detectable PSA first was in January 2017, which was 2 years post op and at that point it was .02. That was followed by .033, .033 (again), .046, .060, and now today’s .068 (this last one was 2 1/2 months since last test, before that it was always 3-3 1/2 months. Now I have appointment with RO on Tuesday, who is going to tell me time to act, then August 3rd with surgeon Uro, who says don’t do anything till .2, based on my pathology, unless velocity starts to ramp up. RO probably holds more weight with me at this point, but I am going to try and have them talk to each other.

Posts.Content: Asa , interesting video to watc, even though it was a commercial for the radiation oncologist who did the interview. I think the perils of Robituc Surgery were greatly exaggerated by Curtis Sliwa, it was only his personal experience. With today’s technology, and a skilled surgeon, it’s a small percentage of men who have permanent incontinence. With that said, I (and probably many here) have a pretty good idea who the surgeon was, that he had operate on him. And if it’s who I think it was, I have no doubt he was told what he says he was told. I saw that surgeon 3 days after my diagnosis, he had me booked for surgery 5 weeks later, before I walked out the door. Thank goodness I came to my senses and cancelled, a week later after I saw Dr Tewari, who finally did the surgery. Aside from that, Sliwa’s case seems like a classic case of overtreatment.

Posts.Content: Chasisme - I too was diagnosed in November - November 10th. I am scheduled for Surgery Jan 6th . My understanding is that you cant do the surgery till at least 6 weeks after biopsy anyway. I don't know about how long you can wait, but I do know that if you were a gleason 8 or higher, the urgency would be a lot higher. With that said, the fact that you had all 12 cores positive, indicates you shouldn't wait TOO long, but still, slow down just a bit and get your facts and due diligence done. The only bad decision is one made without knowing all the relevant facts - about your pathology, about side effects and cure rates of various treatment options, about the experience of the surgeon or radiation oncologist that you choose to treat you, etc. The first thing I think you should do is send your biopsy slides for a second opinion to a high level pathology lab that has pathologists who look at prostate slides all day long. The local Pathologist might look at your slides, but also the same day looked at breast slides, colon slides, and who else knows what. And prostate grading (gleason) is a very subjective thing. So call your urologist on Friday, and tell them (don't take any pushback) that you want your slides sent to Jonathan Epstein at Johns Hopkins or David Bostwick at Bostwick Labs. They will know these people, they get this request all the time. And just so you know, my biopsy was graded 3 cores positive, Gleason 6, gleason 6, and gleason 8. When I sent the slides to Epstein, they downgraded me to Gleason 6 x 3. And that was later reconfirmed by pathologists at Memorial Sloan Kettering. So do it. Then with the facts, make sure you see at least a few surgeons and a few Radiation Oncologists and one medical oncologist, with no skin in the game. What I mean by that is that Surgeons will recommend surgery, Radtiation oncologists will generally recommend radiation, and Oncologists don't have any dog in that fight. Learn all you can about side effects, upside and downside of all treatment options available to you, and only then, should you make a decision. If you are near a major cancer center of great repute, like Johns Hopkins, Mayo, Cleveland Clinic, MSKCC, all the better, because to me at least, those guys seem to be above the fray, and you can arrange to consult with a team, whom together, will probably give you a joint assessment. If you tell us what major city you are closest to, perhaps someone here will be able to recommend a Dr or Center. Good luck

Posts.Title: Recently diagnosed with prostate cancer

Posts.Content: Asa , interesting video to watc, even though it was a commercial for the radiation oncologist who did the interview. I think the perils of Robituc Surgery were greatly exaggerated by Curtis Sliwa, it was only his personal experience. With today’s technology, and a skilled surgeon, it’s a small percentage of men who have permanent incontinence. With that said, I (and probably many here) have a pretty good idea who the surgeon was, that he had operate on him. And if it’s who I think it was, I have no doubt he was told what he says he was told. I saw that surgeon 3 days after my diagnosis, he had me booked for surgery 5 weeks later, before I walked out the door. Thank goodness I came to my senses and cancelled, a week later after I saw Dr Tewari, who finally did the surgery. Aside from that, Sliwa’s case seems like a classic case of overtreatment.

Posts.Title: 12 years

Posts.Content: Searcher, welcome and sorry to hear about you joining our club. Your biopsy results are relatively good, you are in the low risk group. You could go on active Surviellance, but it sounds like you are wanting to treat and that’s ok. I had surgery, it wasn’t as bad as it sounds. A rough 10mdays but then recovered quickly. Chance of incontinence is small. As far as ED, everyone is different so it’s hard to say. Your best bet is to find an experienced surgery who has done at least (in my opinion) 1000 surgeries (some say 300, it’s just me). And make sure it’s someone who is current ask how many they currently do a month on average, As far as radiation, there are 2ntypes of Brachytherapy, LDR (permanent seeds) and HDR (newer, temporary radiation inserted). But there is also SBRT sometimes known as Cyberknife. In Gleason 6 and 7 it’s got a great 10myear track record. Make sure you speak to a specialist in each of these methods. As far as radiation or surgery, either one will likely cure you. The side effects tend to be more immediate with surgery, and ED is more of a possibility On the other hand with surgery, you will know for sure what your Final Gleason score is. 30% of the time, Gleason can be upgraded when the pathologist examines the entire prostate. And with surgery, you should see your PSA drop to undetectable within a couple of months, where with radiation it is a gradual drop, with some bounces along the way, and it can take up to a couple of years to reach nadir (low point, it willl usually not go to undetectable, because you will still have a prostate. It’s a tough decision that only you can make. But the good news is whatever you decide, it won’t be a wrong decision, as long as u educate yourself about each option p,uses and minuses. Good luck and keep us posted

Posts.Content: None of this seems to me like its earth shattering news that we've never heard before. They have been talking about nitrates as carcinogenic forever. The only thing new, might be the language is a bit stronger. For my part, i've all but give up red meat, haven't had a good steak in about 6 months or more. I really miss it, but i can live without it. Better safe than sorry, for cardiac as well as cancer. The problem comes up is the question of "so what the hell CAN i eat?" No meat, dairy is bad for you, no fats, no sugar, no nuttin. Might as well die and come back as a Giraffe and just eat leaves. Seriously its very frustrating. My wife goes shopping and asks me what i want her to buy, and i tell her i have no f'n clue.

Posts.Title: Off Topic but still...

Posts.Content: Barry, is that your diagnosis? I don't have an answer, i just don't know. But if you are in fact a gleason 10, i wouldn't even bother to go searching for survival rates. It doesn't matter, you know you will find things to depress you, but they are just statistics, and they dont apply to indivduals. Your survival could be shorter, but it could be much much longer. Have you confirmed the G10 with a second opinion? If not it would be worth doing. Check out the second opinion service at Johns Hopkins, Dr Jonathan Epstein. He is one of the worlds formost experts on Prostate Pathology. Gleason 10 is rare. It might just be a 9, or even an 8. Still aggressive but manageable. I would think G10 MIGHT be manageable as well, if caught at a relatively early stage. Have you determined with an MRI if there is escape from the capsule? If you could post your stats in a signature (create it in your profile) it would help others come up with some more specific information.

Posts.Title: Sex after RP

Posts.Content: Joe, while I dont think, as Another does, that this means you need help, or that its a reflection of your own insecurities, I do think that you are overthinking this. Unless your friend is living under a rock, or is a total moron, he realizes that prostate Cancer that shows no sign of mets (which it seems from your signature you havent even been diagnosed with yet, maybe Im missing something?) is totally different than metastatic kidney cancer. Its likely that hes made a choice to forgo a treatment that many think is worse than the disease. Or it may just be a reflection of his philosophy on life. Or maybe hes been told that even with treatment, its so advanced that hes onlygot 6 months, and he just wants quality of life for that time. If you are really that close, why not just ask him/ On another note, Im curious, have you had a biopsy? With a high PSA and a pirads4 MRI result, I would think you should? As I said, maybe Im missing something. This si not a judgement , just genuinely curious

Posts.Title: A reflection...

Posts.Content: I believe most DRs won't call it a recurrence until it hits .2 with another rise after that. But some may call it sooner. Even if it is, with no symptoms, it's considered a biochemical recurrence, and nothing that a scan will pick up, and with salvage radiation treatment for mop up, there is still a chance for a cure

Posts.Title: Hopefully this thread will help others

Posts.Content: The new data you refer to is not new data, but a new opinion. The AUA announced that they no longer recommend testing for all men over 50 (i think 50). They are now recommending that under 50 and above 70 should not be tested except for under 50 with high risk factors like family history. And i think they said that between 50 and 70 should be tested every two years, rather than ever year, in the absence of any test results that indicate otherwise. My numbers may be off a little, but thats the gist of it. I think its ridiculous. Sure, testing causes unnecessary biopsies, but it also saves lives. I do not understand the motivation for this decision. Maybe if the Urologists that the AUA represents would take care to look at the PSA test in perspective and along with other tests and observations, to make biopsy decisions, it would be a better solution to the problem, rather than throwing the baby out with the bathwater.
Posts.Title: To test or not to

Posts.Content: None of this seems to me like its earth shattering news that we've never heard before. They have been talking about nitrates as carcinogenic forever. The only thing new, might be the language is a bit stronger. For my part, i've all but give up red meat, haven't had a good steak in about 6 months or more. I really miss it, but i can live without it. Better safe than sorry, for cardiac as well as cancer. The problem comes up is the question of "so what the hell CAN i eat?" No meat, dairy is bad for you, no fats, no sugar, no nuttin. Might as well die and come back as a Giraffe and just eat leaves. Seriously its very frustrating. My wife goes shopping and asks me what i want her to buy, and i tell her i have no f'n clue.

Posts.Title: Catheter is out!

Posts.Content: Osh, the positive margin isnt the optimal news you wanted, but what Newporter says does make sense so you probably have good reason to be optimistic. Also remember that SOMETIMES, at 6 weeks, there might still be a trace of PSA remaining in the blood. Probably won't happen, but if it does, its not reason to flip out. Re your science project - awesome news. I had the same experience and asked the same question, how is this possible. The answer is 'dont look a gift horse in the mouth". Its a great sign, that Johnny will be soon actively engaged in fun and games, not for the sake of science, but for the sake of fun and games. Yeah, the continence issue can be frustrating. But within the first year, i think something like 97% of guys with a good surgeon, and you obviously had one, regain full continence. Just remember, it takes time, and its none linear, there will be good days and bad days, two steps forward one step back. What i did was i weighed my pads (used an old Weight Watchers food scale, so i had to buy a new one) and logged them every 24 hour period. This helped me track my progress week to week, month to month, rather than day to day, which will only frustrate the hell out of you. Welcome to life post surgery, and good luck with a continued speedy recovery. Oh, and i too, worried about blowing up my junk if i started the fun and games too soon. I waited until about 8 weeks after the cath came out, only because i was scared. And i took care of business myself the first one or two times, i ddint want it to blow up inside someone.

Posts.Title: Pathology report received, not what I wanted

Posts.Content: @DT - yup I’m planning on wonrking on my list of questions. The biggest question I have of the RO is, “how confident are you that it’s in the prostate bed” @Michael - I’ve mentioned this before but to refresh your memory, my Surgeon does frozen sections intraoperatively. In my case I had a positive margin, I believe at the Apex, that was 3+4. When that came back positive, the surgeon went back and did further resection of the tissue, and obtained what the pathologist referred to as a negative “FINAL” margin. When I consulted with an RO at Cleveland Clinic he said that the surgeon probably got everything he could see but left a few cells that were cancerous, that was missed on the final pathology, and they’ve now grown to put out PSA. In addition, Dr Zelefsky, the RO at MSKCC, who o am seeing on Tuesday, when I saw him last July, referred to my negative margin status as “questionable” which he thinks may be the source of the PSA. So while on the surface my pathology is pristine, it’s a bit of an odd situation. We shall see what Zelefsky says on Tuesday.

The biggest question I have of the RO is, “how confident are you that it’s in the prostate bed” @Michael - I’ve mentioned this before but to refresh your memory, my Surgeon does frozen sections intraoperatively. In my case I had a positive margin, I believe at the Apex, that was 3+4. When that came back positive, the surgeon went back and did further resection of the tissue, and obtained what the pathologist referred to as a negative “FINAL” margin. When I consulted with an RO at Cleveland Clinic he said that the surgeon probably got everything he could see but left a few cells that were cancerous, that was missed on the final pathology, and they’ve now grown to put out PSA. In addition, Dr Zelefsky, the RO at MSKCC, who o am seeing on Tuesday, when I saw him last July, referred to my negative margin status as “questionable” which he thinks may be the source of the PSA. So while on the surface my pathology is pristine, it’s a bit of an odd situation. We shall see what Zelefsky says on Tuesday.
Posts.Signature: Diagnosed at age 64 (in November, 2014), PSA 4.3 Nov 2014 BX 3 of 12 cores positive original pathology G6 10%, G6 20%, G8 (3+5), 70%. Johns Hopkins second opinion, G6, G6, G6 Surgery with Dr Ash Tewari Jan 6, 2015 Post surgical pathology, stage T2c, bilateral disease, upstaged to G7(3+4) 5% of Prostate involved in Tumor. Organ confined, Margins, SV, lymph nodes (9) all negative, PNI positive PSA <.02 until (uh-oh), 2/17 .02. Then 5/17-.033, 8/17-.033, 11/17-.046, 4/18-.060, 6/18-.068, 7/18- .082, 8/18-. 078. Decipher score low risk, .37 ADT/Firmagon started August 2018. SRT to start SEPT 2018

Posts.Title: ED Meds and side effects

Posts.Content: Dogdollar, I had the surgery January 6th, and yes, I would do the same thing again. No ED, no Incontinence, so problems. But I was lucky and you should understand that everyone is different. If I were you, I would send the slides for a second opinion to an expert who on,y reads prostate slides. dr Jon Epstein at Johns Hopkins is who I used. Also, seek out a great, not good, but great surgeon. Even if you have to travel. You only get one shot at this. DaVinci is great but if you find a solid great surgeon that does open, then remember the skill of the surgeon, rather than the method, is paramount. You should also meet with a good Radiation oncologist or two. Explore Brachytherapy (seeds) both LDRR and HDR (2 different methods) and SBRT, (sometimes goes under the brand name Cyberknife) Explore all of your options even if you decide you are more or less set on surgery, so that when it's over, you will not have any regrets, knowing that you did your due diligence. Good luck and keep us posted. This is a treatable disease that in all likelihood, won't kill you.

Posts.Title: Just got great news!

Posts.Content: I believe most DRs won't call it a recurrence until it hits .2 with another rise after that. But some may call it sooner. Even if it is, with no symptoms, it's considered a biochemical recurrence, and nothing that a scan will pick up, and with salvage radiation treatment for mop up, there is still a chance for a cure

Posts.Title: ED Meds and side effects

Posts.Content: Narnar, progress will continue, it just won't be linear. Patience is key with this issue. I used to weigh my pads on a food scale so i knew how much I leaked each day. I'd log it in a notebook, then check my progress week to week, rather than day to day, to avoid frustration. When you are tired, you will tend to leak. Revthe coffee, I need my coffee in the morning too. After surgery, I switched to half caf in the mornings, try that. Cafienne effect is the same.

Posts.Title: Sex after RP

Posts.Content: Tara, sorry you and your family are going through this. PSA of 400 is not what you want to hear. You are right, I would think (and keep in mind I'm not a doctor, just a guy on the Internet) there is a high chance of metastasis. Best thing you can do is 1. Don't anticipate. Wait for the results, we all know it's agonizing, 2. learn as much as possible about various treatments in case it is a positive diagnosis 3. Try to keep your dads mind ff it with talk about other things, while waiting. Also keep in mind, HIGH PSA is not a sign of. Cancer, per se, but a sign that something is going on, it could be something else. But with a PSA of 400, yeah there is a good chance.... Assuming it is advanced cancer, keep in mind it's still highly treatable, and he will likely live many years with proper treatment. There is another forum I am on, and a guy there was diagnosed. At age 42 with PSA of 3200 and multiple mets. A few months ago he celebrated his 51st birthday, with I believe, undetectable PSA SO KEEP CALM AND KEEP THE FAITH

Posts.Title: My story, currently.

Posts.Content: Congrats on the incontinence issue thats great. I had surgery in early January, have an occasional leak or squirt, mostly on stress, but sometimes for now reason. Not enough to bother me or even to need to wear a pad, but i'd sure like it to stop.Still doing kegels Re the ED issue - i'm surprised your doc didnt put you on 5 mg daily cialis from the start, and you should ask him about it. My understanding is that most docs do that, as a matter of standard practice, and the reason is not just to get you an erection, but it promotes blood flow to the pecker, which is needed to keep the tissues healthy while waiting for the nerves to wake up. I've been on it, since 3 days after the catheter came out, and from the beginning i was getting erections. I have more sex now than before the surgery because i play the cancer card and tell my wife that its important to keep things going, and also to "make sure i can still do it. ))

Posts.Title: Just got great news!

Posts.Content: I would get a second opinion, and the genomic test, if money is not an issue. The more information the better. But f you've already made up your mind on surgery, then don't bother with a second opinion, save it for the surgical pathology There are Drs who will advocate for AS with 3 cores and a 3+4. Personally I wouldn't do it. But some believe that it is viable with low volume, and you do have low volume. But yes, surgery or rad is probably inevitable eventually , so if your mindset is to get it over with on view of that, ....

Posts.Title: I've been pad free now for a month or so

Posts.Content: Congrats on the incontinence issue thats great. I had surgery in early January, have an occasional leak or squirt, mostly on stress, but sometimes for now reason. Not enough to bother me or even to need to wear a pad, but i'd sure like it to stop.Still doing kegels Re the ED issue - i'm surprised your doc didnt put you on 5 mg daily cialis from the start, and you should ask him about it. My understanding is that most docs do that, as a matter of standard practice, and the reason is not just to get you an erection, but it promotes blood flow to the pecker, which is needed to keep the tissues healthy while waiting for the nerves to wake up. I've been on it, since 3 days after the catheter came out, and from the beginning i was getting erections. I have more sex now than before the surgery because i play the cancer card and tell my wife that its important to keep things going, and also to "make sure i can still do it. ))

Posts.Title: Hopefully this thread will help others

Posts.Content: The new data you refer to is not new data, but a new opinion. The AUA announced that they no longer recommend testing for all men over 50 (i think 50). They are now recommending that under 50 and above 70 should not be tested except for under 50 with high risk factors like family history. And i think they said that between 50 and 70 should be tested every two years, rather than ever year, in the absence of any test results that indicate otherwise. My numbers may be off a little, but thats the gist of it. I think its ridiculous. Sure, testing causes unnecessary biopsies, but it also saves lives. I do not understand the motivation for this decision. Maybe if the Urologists that the AUA represents would take care to look at the PSA test in perspective and along with other tests and observations, to make biopsy decisions, it would be a better solution to the problem, rather than throwing the baby out with the bathwater.
Posts.Title: To test or not to

Posts.Content: Tara, sorry you and your family are going through this. PSA of 400 is not what you want to hear. You are right, I would think (and keep in mind I'm not a doctor, just a guy on the Internet) there is a high chance of metastasis. Best thing you can do is 1. Don't anticipate. Wait for the results, we all know it's agonizing, 2. learn as much as possible about various treatments in case it is a positive diagnosis 3. Try to keep your dads mind ff it with talk about other things, while waiting. Also keep in mind, HIGH PSA is not a sign of. Cancer, per se, but a sign that something is going on, it could be something else. But with a PSA of 400, yeah there is a good chance.... Assuming it is advanced cancer, keep in mind it's still highly treatable, and he will likely live many years with proper treatment. There is another forum I am on, and a guy there was diagnosed. At age 42 with PSA of 3200 and multiple mets. A few months ago he celebrated his 51st birthday, with I believe, undetectable PSA SO KEEP CALM AND KEEP THE FAITH

Posts.Title: new diagnosis, questions

Posts.Content: Yesterday’s blood draw came back at .068. Just for context, my first detectable PSA first was in January 2017, which was 2 years post op and at that point it was .02. That was followed by .033, .033 (again), .046, .060, and now today’s .068 (this last one was 2 1/2 months since last test, before that it was always 3-3 1/2 months. Now I have appointment with RO on Tuesday, who is going to tell me time to act, then August 3rd with surgeon Uro, who says don’t do anything till .2, based on my pathology, unless velocity starts to ramp up. RO probably holds more weight with me at this point, but I am going to try and have them talk to each other.

Posts.Title: PSA results are in, not great news, but totally expected

Posts.Content: Hi guys, I'm back. I seem to wander back here whenever i get close to my next PSA test and URO visit, i guess because i assume the worst, even though i have not been diagnosed or "joined the club" (yet), as you can see from my stats. I'm very curious about something. For those of you in your early sixties (even mid and late sixties), I'm sure a lot of you feel the way i do, that 60 today, isn't what 60 was when our parents turned 60. I feel much younger, and i live as though i was younger. My mindset is that i am not old. If you feel this way, or felt this way, and then you got diagnosed, did it change? Did your mindset change as a result of diagnosis? Or after surgery, if you had surgery, as a result of having to deal with side effects. Hope i am not out of line asking this question. If so, i apologize. I am very afraid of losing that younger mindset, and the ability to lead as active a life as i do now.

Posts.Title: The Mental Part

Posts.Content: Thanks Ed. I am in NY and when this all first started and a biopsy was recommended, I decided to leave my local urologist and go t a doc at Columbia Presbyterian, which is a top 5 ranked urology center. That's where I had the biopsy. The one thing I wasn't thrilled about was that when he took blood for PSA he did a DRE first and when I asked about it he said that their group doesn't believe it makes that much diffence. S that it me thinking. So when it was time for a follow up, I found that Dr Aron Katz who was one of the top docs at Columbia, had left to become chairman of Urology at Winthrop, a hospital much closer to me. I believe that it's not just the hospital or departments rep, but also the doc, and Katz , has an excellent rep as a top urologist, from everyone I've spoken to So now I am under his care. And believe me, I WILL be staying close to him, and on top of this. If I am diagnosed, ll do everything possible to get it early. One other point, I am thinking if and when the time comes, and I do get DX, I would probably look to go to Johns Hopkins, or Mayo. If I can Sorry, I realize now that I'm all over the place and probably hijacking my own thread

Posts.Title: The Mental Part

Posts.Content: If you look at the data, Cyberknife has had good success as primary treatment for PC, particularly in low risk cases. It seems to be as effective as other radiation forms SO FAR, with similar or less toxicity. http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/25426447 http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/25389521 The problem I have with it, and I did meet with an RO who does it, is that it is still relatively new as a primary PCa treatment. The data only goes back 7 years. And I want more than 7 years of data before deciding that a treatment is right for me. I met with 2 ROs one who does almost exclusively Cyberknife (which is just a brand name for SBRT) and another, at MSKCC, who recommended LDR Brachy as my best option, primarily for the reason I mentioned. His comments to me were that he has been very impressed with the data published so far and thinks that over time it will become treatment of choice for many, but there is not enough data available yet for him to make it his best option recommendation. BTW, at his facility he does not do Brachy, he would refer me to an RO at MSKCC'S main campus. (I saw him at a suburban campus) and yet he still recommended it, which impressed me as no agenda, other than what was best for the patient.

Posts.Content: LOLOL at Michael, thanks for the laugh. Another. You may be right about the horse being out of the barn. But I dunno. Recurrence occurs at the cellular level. And I think if it's very early on in the process, good diet and low inflammation can help the immune system fight off the changes. But if course, I don't know for sure, it's just a layman opinion. Groom, thanks. That's quite an upgrade you got after surgery. But the fact that you were <.01 after surgery, and I assume, since then, bodes well for you. I agree though, if I were you, I would want to test more often tan every 6 mo this with a g9. Maybe every 3, or 4. Just to keep an eye on things.

Posts.Content: Thanks all for your comments. Very encouraging. I know I'm a bit of a head case, but with hi grade pin in one core in my biopsy, and a slowly rising albeit low, PSA, I put those two together and think its just a matter of time before I am diagnosed, as Fairwind implied as being possible. @Walt - low as dirt, but consistently rising, which I have been told Is an important factor. Plus a not so great Free PSA of 11. i don't let it get in the way of enjoying my life, except for the worry that starts to appear in the weeks leading up to my Psa trs/appointments. @WJW- amazing. Thanks again all, your comments make me realize that even if I came across a worst case scenario, the world would not end.

Posts.Title: I need a Glass-Half-Full session here:

Posts.Content: After being told no cancer, but one core high grade pin, i asked for a copy of the path report to be sent to me. 14 samples taken from Prostate, as they told me all normal except the one with high grade PIN in the left base. Also there was a comment, which wasnt mentioned by uro when i spoke with him, that said "each slide contained a single needle core biopsy of prostate. Major feature is benign hyperplasia. There are scattered small foci of atrophy and acute and chronic inflammation. " It also noted volume of prostate at 38 CC My PSA was 2.2 a month prior to the biopsy, although the doc that did the biopsy took his own blood test a week before the biopsy and it was 2.7. I dont think that matters it was a different lab. Curious if any of the more expert guys here have any thoughts. Apparently i have BPH, which could be the reason for the psa rising over the last three years. But then again, they found a HGPIN. Not sure what to make of it.
Posts.Title: Recieved Path Report in the mail

Posts.Content: Yes, Highlander, i am going to do PSA every 6 months. Next one is in May. I just have to decide where to do it. I have been doing it at Quest, having the tests sent to my local Uro, but the last one was done at NY Presbyterian, where the Uro is who did my biopsy. I have to decide if i will continue seeing him, or find someone local. Probably stay with him. BTW, i senT you a PM.
Posts.Title: Recieved Path Report in the mail

Posts.Content: Rivtrail - i am about 4 weeks out past my negative biopsy. Had blood for a couple of weeks, now its almost normal, but still looks like the color of slightly dirty water. So i wouldn't freak out about that, its normal Enjoy the fact that you had a negative biopsy (listen to me, do as i say, not as i do) and don't stress too much. There will be plenty of time to stress if and when you have a reason to. (i'm laughing at myself, i was a wreck for 3 weeks after the biopsy, have calmed down now, without drugs). But be vigilant, and stay on top of it.
Posts.Title: blood after biopsy

Posts.Content: Thanks all for your comments. Very encouraging. I know I'm a bit of a head case, but with hi grade pin in one core in my biopsy, and a slowly rising albeit low, PSA, I put those two together and think its just a matter of time before I am diagnosed, as Fairwind implied as being possible. @Walt - low as dirt, but consistently rising, which I have been told Is an important factor. Plus a not so great Free PSA of 11. i don't let it get in the way of enjoying my life, except for the worry that starts to appear in the weeks leading up to my Psa trs/appointments. @WJW- amazing. Thanks again all, your comments make me realize that even if I came across a worst case scenario, the world would not end.

Posts.Title: The Mental Part

Posts.Content: Hi guys, I'm back. I seem to wander back here whenever i get close to my next PSA test and URO visit, i guess because i assume the worst, even though i have not been diagnosed or "joined the club" (yet), as you can see from my stats. I'm very curious about something. For those of you in your early sixties (even mid and late sixties), I'm sure a lot of you feel the way i do, that 60 today, isn't what 60 was when our parents turned 60. I feel much younger, and i live as though i was younger. My mindset is that i am not old. If you feel this way, or felt this way, and then you got diagnosed, did it change? Did your mindset change as a result of diagnosis? Or after surgery, if you had surgery, as a result of having to deal with side effects. Hope i am not out of line asking this question. If so, i apologize. I am very afraid of losing that younger mindset, and the ability to lead as active a life as i do now.

Posts.Title: blood after biopsy

Posts.Content: Thanks Ed. I am in NY and when this all first started and a biopsy was recommended, I decided to leave my local urologist and go t a doc at Columbia Presbyterian, which is a top 5 ranked urology center. That's where I had the biopsy. The one thing I wasn't thrilled about was that when he took blood for PSA he did a DRE first and when I asked about it he said that their group doesn't believe it makes that much diffence. S that it me thinking. So when it was time for a follow up, I found that Dr Aron Katz who was one of the top docs at Columbia, had left to become chairman of Urology at Winthrop, a hospital much closer to me. I believe that it's not just the hospital or departments rep, but also the doc, and Katz , has an excellent rep as a top urologist, from everyone I've spoken to So now I am under his care. And believe me, I WILL be staying close to him, and on top of this. If I am diagnosed, ll do everything possible to get it early. One other point, I am thinking if and when the time comes, and I do get DX, I would probably look to go to Johns Hopkins, or Mayo. If I can Sorry, I realize now that I'm all over the place and probably hijacking my own thread

Posts.Title: The Mental Part

Posts.Content: I would get a second opinion, and the genomic test, if money is not an issue. The more information the better. But f you've already made up your mind on surgery, then don't bother with a second opinion, save it for the surgical pathology There are Drs who will advocate for AS with 3 cores and a 3+4. Personally I wouldn't do it. But some believe that it is viable with low volume, and you do have low volume. But yes, surgery or rad is probably inevitable eventually , so if your mindset is to get it over with on view of that, ....

Posts.Title: One Year Result, No longer zero, but in No Man's Land

Posts.Content: Valar, Very sorry you need to be here, with such news. It clearly sounds as though your husbands situation needs to be dealt with sooner rather than later. Some important points, with an understanding that I, and everyone else here, are not doctors, we are just a bunch of guys on the Internet who have out of necessity, educated ourselves as best as possible 1. There is some controversy as to whether surgery is the best option when the Cancer has already escaped the Prostate capsule. 2. A big reason for that is that if its escaped, there is a good chance that surgery won't offer a cure 3. If he needs radiation after surgery, why not have radiation as the primary treatment (not saying that is what he should do, just something to consider) the side effects can be worse after both treatments vs radiation or surgery alone) 4. He should request a 3tesla MUltiparametric MRI which may be more definitive as to whether the Cancer escaped the capsule. Which leads me to ask, how did the urologist come to the conclusion that it's escaped. 5 you should probably ask that the slides be sent to a lab that focuses on PC for a second opinion. Either dr Jonathan Epstein at Johns Hopkins, orDavid Boatwick at Bostwick Labs. Others may want to chime in here, as I'm not sure if it would change treatment options. 6. Meet with other surgeons who have done at least 500-1000 radical prostatectomies, and get familiar with the various types of surgery (open,robotic, etc) 7. Also meet with a good radiation Oncologist to learn about alternatives to surgery as primary treatment. 8. Read "Surviving Prostate Cancer" by Dr Patrick Walsh which you can buy or download here....I would get a hard copy , easier to use as a reference. http://www.amazon.com/Patrick-Walshs.../dp/1455504181 We've all been where you and your husband are right now, that panicky dark place. The way to get out if it is to educate yourself and take charge, and not just depend on the DRs. Surgeons will want to cut, and radiation oncologists will want to radiate. You have to ask the right questions to come to the best conclusion, which may be different for you guys than for others, depending on your preferences and priorities. And please understand that Prostate cancer is usually a slow growing Cancer, unlike lung, breast and colon cancers, and your husband will likely live many years with proper treatment, even decades. Good luck and stick with us there is a lot of knowledge AND support here.

Posts.Title: Sex after DaVinci--Houston, we have liftoff!

Posts.Content: Congrats on a great report Davis, thats a big step, getting that first zero. I never heard of Stendra, but googled it. Apparently its a relatively new PDE5 inhibitor, like the more well known ED drugs. The advantage of it is that it is very fast acting, like within 15 minutes. I also, have no problem getting getting it up, even having gone off daily Cialis about 10 days ago But i like you, sometimes have trouble maintaining it. I never thought to mention it to the Doc because i can keep it long enough to do the deed. But might be worth mentioning.

Posts.Title: Ramblings first week post Catheter

Posts.Content: Apologies to those who may have seen this posted in another forum, I know there is some overlap...... So,I had my meeting with my surgeon/urologist, today. (Post op PSA's in my signature). Takeaways... He still calls recurrence at .2! He is aware of the studies that point to .03, which I printed out and brought with me. But his comment was there is no evidence that starting earlier, affects final the outcome (meaning survival). The fact that my PSA is up doesn't concern him right now, but based on that, AND based on the fact that my final negative margin was preceded by a positive intra-operative margin, is why he wants to have me back in three months. Even if I had a slight rise at the next visit , he would not call it a clear trend He thinks it was a smart thing that I went to see Zelefsky, (RO at MSKCC) on my own, and that a baseline MRI was done. He still thinks there is a good chance that I don't recur, ever. His best advice to me for now is to eat healthy, watch weight, exercise, and calm my brain (I'm actually reading a book by that title right now) He said he is a big believer that inflammation in the body can produce increase in PSA. (I think he meant can produce recurrence.) and he is also a big believer that anxiety will cause inflammation. And my big picture question.... if not from cancer recurrence, where is this minute (.033) amount of PSA coming from? His answer was it could be cancer cells, or could be produced by the cowpers gland or male breasts. Lastly, he told me about a 2 day symposium at Mt Sinai (his hospital and that he put together), that takes place next week. Said speakers will be The Who's who of prostate cancer from all over the world. Suggested I register and gave me a brochure. It is targeted to medical professionals. But he clearly saw that I was more knowledgeable than his average Joe patient, and that I was hungry for knowledge and answers. I'm tempted, but I think I'm gonna pass. I really and truly need a mental health break from cancer. Too much of it going on between me and others in my family (which means I might disappear for a while, this time for real lol) Anyway that's what I got. It was a fruitful meeting. But I'm thinking that AS LONG AS MY PSA REMAINS STABLE, assuming it does, I might just get the tests done and not keep going back for visits unless I have more specific questions. Oh, just an aside... Had a new PA today. Very hot. Short skirt, heels . Comes in before the doc. Sits on the examining table, and does "the pose" you know, the one where they lean to one side, with arm supporting them, and crossed legs. No effort to pull down skirt. And starts asking me about my erections. I'm like what the FLUCK? But whatever. It was the bright spot of my day ������������

Posts.Content: I was doing 5 sets of 10, each day. About 5-6 weeks ago, I cut down to two sets, then about a week later I just stopped doing gem. After a week or two, I sensed that I would leak once in a while, even though my briefs were dry. So I started up again, 3 sets a day. I think everyone is different, but I also think most people need to do them forever, maybe just not as many sets a day after a while. I'm 8 months out of surgery

Posts.Title: newbie from Vancouver

Posts.Content: Hi Dave, sorry to see you’ve joined me in no mans land. It seems that that’s exactly where the ultra sensitive test takes us more often than not. I am also at .06 but have been having ultrasensitive tests all along and at the two-year mark I started a steady rise from .02. You might want to take a look at My post in the thread I started yesterday titled “early salvage radiation“. In the thread I mentioned that the chairman of radiation oncology at Cleveland clinic in Florida recommended that I treat now and he cited this study… https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jam...?redirect=true It showed a significant improvement in outcome for patients with adverse pathology who treated below .1. I also saw Michael Zelefsky at MSKCC who said he does not believe in waiting for some target number, he prefers to treat when he sees a clear trend. I’m seeing him again next month and think he will say time to treat, You are right, the data is all over the place. IMO if I hear “time to treat” from 2 highly respected RO’s at major research institutions, I believe it’s time to treat. I think you need another couple of uPSA’s before making that decision, you don’t know if it’s been .06 all along (which can and does happen). Good luck, keep us posted.

Posts.Title: Kegels for how long?

Posts.Content: Valar, Very sorry you need to be here, with such news. It clearly sounds as though your husbands situation needs to be dealt with sooner rather than later. Some important points, with an understanding that I, and everyone else here, are not doctors, we are just a bunch of guys on the Internet who have out of necessity, educated ourselves as best as possible 1. There is some controversy as to whether surgery is the best option when the Cancer has already escaped the Prostate capsule. 2. A big reason for that is that if its escaped, there is a good chance that surgery won't offer a cure 3. If he needs radiation after surgery, why not have radiation as the primary treatment (not saying that is what he should do, just something to consider) the side effects can be worse after both treatments vs radiation or surgery alone) 4. He should request a 3tesla MUltiparametric MRI which may be more definitive as to whether the Cancer escaped the capsule. Which leads me to ask, how did the urologist come to the conclusion that it's escaped. 5 you should probably ask that the slides be sent to a lab that focuses on PC for a second opinion. Either dr Jonathan Epstein at Johns Hopkins, orDavid Boatwick at Bostwick Labs. Others may want to chime in here, as I'm not sure if it would change treatment options. 6. Meet with other surgeons who have done at least 500-1000 radical prostatectomies, and get familiar with the various types of surgery (open,robotic, etc) 7. Also meet with a good radiation Oncologist to learn about alternatives to surgery as primary treatment. 8. Read "Surviving Prostate Cancer" by Dr Patrick Walsh which you can buy or download here....I would get a hard copy , easier to use as a reference. http://www.amazon.com/Patrick-Walshs.../dp/1455504181 We've all been where you and your husband are right now, that panicky dark place. The way to get out if it is to educate yourself and take charge, and not just depend on the DRs. Surgeons will want to cut, and radiation oncologists will want to radiate. You have to ask the right questions to come to the best conclusion, which may be different for you guys than for others, depending on your preferences and priorities. And please understand that Prostate cancer is usually a slow growing Cancer, unlike lung, breast and colon cancers, and your husband will likely live many years with proper treatment, even decades. Good luck and stick with us there is a lot of knowledge AND support here.

Posts.Title: Ramblings first week post Catheter

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Southsider The book says that salvage radiation is considerably less successful once the PSA gets past 0.5 What book? There hve been studies that show that a cutoff of .03 WHEN ADVERSE PATHOLOGY EXISTS is advantageous. We don't know if he has adverse pathology, unless I missed something. The AUA standard of care is still SRT when PSA gets to .2. I think most Drs today, will hit it at .1. That's what my surgeon tells me. Unless diverse pathology exists. Plus the extenuating circumstances need to,be considered in Steves case.(but he is obviously,y way past .1, or .2. Stage, I would agree that your Uro is dragging his feet. But the final decision is up to you. I'd fight. I'm the more or less the same age as you,. No bypass, but two stents and heavy plaque load. (CAC score of 937) But we are all different. It's a very personal decision OH, AND LAST BUT NOT LEAST, CONGRATS ON KICKING THAT BOURBON HABIT. THAT IS SOME FEAT. YOU ARE ONE TOUGH DUDE. BE PROUD.

Posts.Content: Derk - the two books that came highly recommended to me (i have not been diagnosed (yet), getting biopsy results next week) are Dr Patrick Walsh's Guide to Surviving Prostate Cancer and The Prostate Book by Dr Peter Scardino. Both are avail on Amazon. I read through Dr Walsh's book and it was easy reading and easily understood. I get what you are saying about how difficult it must be to actually get the news. My friends who have been diagnosed said the same thing. I am trying to temper my optimism, (due to low psa) with caution, and brace myself for whatever comes, but i know it will be a knockdown blow if i get the call and its positive. Good luck to you, the one thing we can all take solace in, from all I've read is that this cancer is usually not a killer, and no matter what, everything will work out.

Posts.Title: Diagnosed 5 days ago. Still in the fog stage. Could use some support.

Posts.Content: Idmeanl, sorry for your troubles. While there are never guarantees, prostate cancer usually causes a slow and steady rise in PSA, not a big jump like yours, especially 5 points in 6 weeks. Most of the time, with a jump like that, its due to Prostatitis. The biopsy will tell you more. Prostatitis is sometimes hard to treat, but you might want to try a round of antibiotics first to see if it drops the PSA. If it does, its probably Prostatitis and a biopsy might not Ben necessary. Also, you could ask your Uro for a PHI (prostate Health Index)test (its a blood test), it incorporates PSA and other factors as well and has been shown to be more accurate than PSA alone. If these measures could help you avoid a biopsy, that would be a good thing

Posts.Title: OK, now I'm REALLY depressed

Posts.Content: Hi Dave, sorry to see you’ve joined me in no mans land. It seems that that’s exactly where the ultra sensitive test takes us more often than not. I am also at .06 but have been having ultrasensitive tests all along and at the two-year mark I started a steady rise from .02. You might want to take a look at My post in the thread I started yesterday titled “early salvage radiation“. In the thread I mentioned that the chairman of radiation oncology at Cleveland clinic in Florida recommended that I treat now and he cited this study… https://jamanetwork.com/journals/jam...?redirect=true It showed a significant improvement in outcome for patients with adverse pathology who treated below .1. I also saw Michael Zelefsky at MSKCC who said he does not believe in waiting for some target number, he prefers to treat when he sees a clear trend. I’m seeing him again next month and think he will say time to treat, You are right, the data is all over the place. IMO if I hear “time to treat” from 2 highly respected RO’s at major research institutions, I believe it’s time to treat. I think you need another couple of uPSA’s before making that decision, you don’t know if it’s been .06 all along (which can and does happen). Good luck, keep us posted.

Posts.Title: Saying "Hello"

Posts.Content: Technically, you can do Active Surveillance . I had 3 of 12 G6 as well, but one of my cores was 80%. I had most doctors including my urologists, that it needs to be treated. I had one, very well know, tell me i could do AS. I wouldn't, i'm not wired to go through tests and worry that its still in me, so I'm likely getting surgery done next month. But everyone is different At the very least, if you want to do AS, you should get a Parametric 3T MRI which will show with some reliability whether there is something more lurking that was not picked up by the biopsy. If there is, then you should not do AS.

Posts.Title: RP the day before yesterday

Posts.Content: PDV, great news on the PSA. Sicks that you've got all this other crap,going on, I hope it all turns out to be nothing. You're right, getting old is an adventure. I've got a PSA check coming up end of this month, after 2 small rises this year. Then a few weeks later, see my PCP, Who is also my cardiologist. 6 months after RP, I was blindsided by the need for 2 stents, and a diagnosis of coronary artery disease, so seeing the cardio guy is always an adventure. And week after next, my wife has her second checkup at 6 weeks, and now at 3 m0nths, since finishing surgery and chemo for ovarian cancer. So I know how you feel. Lots that can go south in the next month. Let's hope we both have all good news when we are done. We both need to get in shape for the Patriots and the Jets. As for my boys, #tanktheseason

Posts.Title: My story so far...

Posts.Content: Welcome to the forum, looking forward to seeing your stats. You've gotten good info above. I'll just add a couple of NYC Reco's... For surgery, Dr Ash Tewari at Mt Sinai (he did my surgery, he's world reknowned, has done over 6000 robotics) also Dr James Eastham at MSKCC has a solid rep. For Brachytherapy, Dr Michael Zelefsky, without a doubt, at MSKCC. Yout should also look at SBRT, (aka Cyberknife) which has built a good track record over 9 or 10myears in low and intermediate risk cases.

Posts.Title: 72 hours... Homina, Homina

Posts.Content: I have read about this on another forum. I believe the purpose is to reduce the emotional attachment and resulting emotional decisions that come with being told "you have cancer" if followed, it should help a lot of newly diagnosed grade 1 and 2 guys, to not panic, and go into unemotional fact finding mode. And hopefully reduce over treatment. But at the same time, hopefully the Drs using it will take care to not lead patients yo decisions that result in under treatment either

Posts.Title: Robotic prostatectomy in two days - Some questions

Posts.Content: Technically, you can do Active Surveillance . I had 3 of 12 G6 as well, but one of my cores was 80%. I had most doctors including my urologists, that it needs to be treated. I had one, very well know, tell me i could do AS. I wouldn't, i'm not wired to go through tests and worry that its still in me, so I'm likely getting surgery done next month. But everyone is different At the very least, if you want to do AS, you should get a Parametric 3T MRI which will show with some reliability whether there is something more lurking that was not picked up by the biopsy. If there is, then you should not do AS.

Posts.Title: Biopsy Positive

Posts.Content: I've been gone for a while, and for that I apologize. But something had to give. I'm a member of 3 other forums, and it just became overwhelming and I had to make some changes. Feel bad about it, but it is what it is. I'm still spending to much time on forums, so I may cut back more. But I miss you guys, and I hope everyone here is doing well. On a positive note, I got results this week n my 18 month post Davinci PSA, and the answer IS.....<.02. So that's a good thing. I wanted to post to encourage any new guys here. And repeat what is often said...there is life after PC, and it can be good. I've got no incontinence issues, and while little Johnny doesn't play as hard and fast as he used to, without meds, he's been a more than adequate tool, and I'm enjoying sex as much as I always did. With meds, he's still playing hard and fast. Same without, but it just takes a little more time and effort. So all good on my end, and again, hope it's the same for you guys. Ken

Posts.Title: Robotic prostatectomy in two days - Some questions

Posts.Content: Welcome to the forum, looking forward to seeing your stats. You've gotten good info above. I'll just add a couple of NYC Reco's... For surgery, Dr Ash Tewari at Mt Sinai (he did my surgery, he's world reknowned, has done over 6000 robotics) also Dr James Eastham at MSKCC has a solid rep. For Brachytherapy, Dr Michael Zelefsky, without a doubt, at MSKCC. Yout should also look at SBRT, (aka Cyberknife) which has built a good track record over 9 or 10myears in low and intermediate risk cases.

Posts.Title: Dribble, dribble

Posts.Content: Dave, we are in a similar boat, as you likely realize (actually its uncanny how similar our circumstances are). 2 YEARS undetectable followed by a slowly rising PSA which now at 3 1/2 years post op is .068. I met with the Rad Onc last week, he said that at G7(3+4) (which describes us both) he would be ok with no HT, as long as my PSA was under .1. Once it got close to .1, he would rather I do HT, but if i didnt want it, it would be my choice. This was Zelefsky, top RO at MSKCC. I also, last month, met with Chairman of Rad Onc at Cleveland Clinic in Florida. He told me that he would not recommend HT, and that is based on my Gleason, more than on the PSA. FWIW, while i had a negative final margin (positive frozen section, which led to the surgeon cutting more tissue to get negative finaL) they both think that my negative margin is not really negative, but that a few cells were left behind. So i dont think there is one answer. I hope this experience i have had helps you, since our situations are really similar.

Posts.Title: Looking for advice from any who have been through salvage radiation

Posts.Content: PDV, great news on the PSA. Sicks that you've got all this other crap,going on, I hope it all turns out to be nothing. You're right, getting old is an adventure. I've got a PSA check coming up end of this month, after 2 small rises this year. Then a few weeks later, see my PCP, Who is also my cardiologist. 6 months after RP, I was blindsided by the need for 2 stents, and a diagnosis of coronary artery disease, so seeing the cardio guy is always an adventure. And week after next, my wife has her second checkup at 6 weeks, and now at 3 m0nths, since finishing surgery and chemo for ovarian cancer. So I know how you feel. Lots that can go south in the next month. Let's hope we both have all good news when we are done. We both need to get in shape for the Patriots and the Jets. As for my boys, #tanktheseason

Posts.Title: Dribble, dribble

Posts.Content: With your low PSA it's highly likely this is not Cancer. Can't ever say never, but highly likely you are good. It would be good if you could ask the Uro about a 3Tesla mpMRI, rather than biopsy. It may help you avoid a biopsy altogether, and if not it would help the URO target certain areas of the Prostate iif they look suspicious, for more accuracy. But seriously, it's not time to sweat, at this point

Posts.Content: When I chose to have the surgery performed by another urologist, and told my original urologist, he volunteered, that, " after your surgery, if you'd like to continue to see me, I'd be happy to continue our relationship, some urologists would not do that, but I'm not of that school of thought" I appreciated it, but I have no plans to see him again, for unrelated reasons. So apparently, it's not all that unusual. Nevertheless, after THAT conversation, I'd be done with him, and seek out someone else.

Posts.Title: My story so far...

Posts.Content: SW, its noted in your first post that he has already started treatment, based on the spot on his pelvic bone being a met. That does NOT mean its too late for him to get the slides reread and possibly the spot on the scan biopsied. I would at least ask the uro why the spot was NOT biopsied. If the comments here turn out to be prescient, you an change course (and urologist) on the treatment that was started. Think about it, even though its a tough and awkward position to be in. Its that important to your husband.

Posts.Title: Looking for advice from any who have been through salvage radiation

Posts.Content: Dave, we are in a similar boat, as you likely realize (actually its uncanny how similar our circumstances are). 2 YEARS undetectable followed by a slowly rising PSA which now at 3 1/2 years post op is .068. I met with the Rad Onc last week, he said that at G7(3+4) (which describes us both) he would be ok with no HT, as long as my PSA was under .1. Once it got close to .1, he would rather I do HT, but if i didnt want it, it would be my choice. This was Zelefsky, top RO at MSKCC. I also, last month, met with Chairman of Rad Onc at Cleveland Clinic in Florida. He told me that he would not recommend HT, and that is based on my Gleason, more than on the PSA. FWIW, while i had a negative final margin (positive frozen section, which led to the surgeon cutting more tissue to get negative finaL) they both think that my negative margin is not really negative, but that a few cells were left behind. So i dont think there is one answer. I hope this experience i have had helps you, since our situations are really similar.

Posts.Title: Looking for advice from any who have been through salvage radiation

Posts.Content: My understanding is that the standard PSA test measures down to .1. The uPSA measures lower, but it depends on the lab. Quest measures down to .02, labcorp down to .006. I’m now being tested at MSKCC, their in house lab tests down to .05, with anything less being reported as <.05. I THINK this too is considered ultra sensitive. I sometimes wonder if they measure lower but don’t report that unless it’s .05 or higher, thinking that anything below .05 is meaningless. Doesn’t really matter, I think, but I might ask my RO when I meet with him next

When it comes to chance of recurrence, mortality etc, those nomograms will give you a good idea of your odds. But as others have said, the odds dont matter to the individual.

Posts.Content: Sort of what i was wondering. He has to be a good doc, to be Chairman of the dept of a major hospital. But i dont love the fact that he sent me to a specific website. I had a previous urologist, who I started with about 7 years ago, who did the same thing. At that time PCa was not really on my mind, and he sent me to a website to purchase a supplement (might have been the same website, don't remember) but i didnt do it, because i felt i was taking enough pills. (meds for lipids, etc). Can't believe a top doc would want to profit from me spending $300 a year on pills, but i guess they are like everyone else. On the other hand, there must be some valid theory behind some of these supplements. Probably worth doing some reading on it, which i will google.
