Posts.Title: Looking for advice from any who have been through salvage radiation

Posts.Content: Yes Lancepeace, he is integrative. He ran the Holistic Center for Prostate Cancer at Columbia which is one of the top ranked hospitals in Urology, nationally, i believe #5. He is still associated with Columbia Presbyterian, and teaches there. There is no doubt in my mind that he is a legitimate Doc, i did not mean to give the impression otherwise. My curiosity is in the efficacy of these herbal supplements, and dietary changes. This Docs traditional specialty, is, i believe Cryosurgery. As i said, i have not been diagnosed as yet, but signs are pointing to a storm possibly brewing, so i have been spending time on this forum, and another, to start educating myself. And i felt, going to this doc, perhaps there would be something available that he was onto, tha might at least lessen my chances of being diagnosed. I know that having high grade PIN, even though it was only in one core, is not a good sign, nor is the slow steady rise in PSA, even though it is still low in absolute numbers. Thank you, i appreciate the feedback
Posts.Title: Diet and Alternative Medicine

Posts.Content: Warning and apology: this turned into a long post. Didn't know how to do it otherwise, wanted to explain my whole story. The thread by Skizman, on his pathology report, took a turn towards dietary issues near the end, and made me think, i would just like to get others take on this. Not to repeat myself, some of you may recall, but just in case, i had my first biopsy in November and it was negative for PCa, but one core out of 14 showed HI Grade PIN. Leading up to the biopsy, i had a steadily rising PSA that went from .7 in 2008 (or 2009, dont remember) to 1.1, to 1.7, then 6 months later 2.2, then 6 months after that (just last month) 2.8. The last time around, in April, i also had a FPSA, which came in at 11, (NOT so good) and a PCA3, of 15 (not so bad) I may have the numbers mixed up on the FPSA & PCA3, but they were definitely not so bad and not so good respectively. All negative DREs and the prostate at time of biopsy was 38 CCs . I'm 62 years old, father had PC. Based on the test results he wanted to do an MRI but the insurance co wouldnt authorize it. I told him i would pay for it if he thought it was critical, but he said no, just come back for follow up and retest in 4 months instead of 6. So i will go back to him in August. Anyway, to the point, this last set of tests, i decided to see another Urologist. He is Chairman of Urology at Winthrop University Hospital on Long Island, joined them 2 years ago, formerly with Columbia Presbyterian, so very good cred. The reason i wanted to see him, is that he is known for his approach of combining traditional medicine with herbal and alternatives. He asked me if i had changed my diet at all. Gave me a cheat sheet with dietary suggestions. The usual stuff, stay away from red meat, lots of vegetables, protein, exercise, etc. He also, and this is what i am curious about, told me to purchase two supplements online - from a company called Designs for Health. I had to apply for a password, with the name of my doc, then wait a few days to get an email with a password. The two supplements are "Brocco-Protect" and Inflammatone. The Brocco is a Broccoli extract of some sort, and the inflammatone, i dont know really. Also, on my own, i upped my Vitamin D from 2000 ius daily to 5000. (just from my reading) The thing that peaked my interest in all this is that i know someone who was diagnosed 11 years ago with gleason 9, had the surgery, it had escaped the capsule and he was given a very poor prognosis. He started taking supplements on his own, and has been fine for the last 11 years. Just now, his PSA has started to rise. Anyway, do you guys have any opinions on this stuff? No doubt there will be another biopsy in my future. The slow steady rise in PSA is troubling to me, and tells me something is brewing. But I'm hoping some of these supplements might prevent the hi grade pin or anything else from becoming PCa
Posts.Title: Diet and Alternative Medicine

Posts.Content: Is there any consensus as to whether this type of approach could prevent PCa from developing in the first place?, or prevent hi grade PIN from developing into PCa?
Posts.Title: Diet and Alternative Medicine

Posts.Content: SW, its noted in your first post that he has already started treatment, based on the spot on his pelvic bone being a met. That does NOT mean its too late for him to get the slides reread and possibly the spot on the scan biopsied. I would at least ask the uro why the spot was NOT biopsied. If the comments here turn out to be prescient, you an change course (and urologist) on the treatment that was started. Think about it, even though its a tough and awkward position to be in. Its that important to your husband.

Posts.Content: This goes to the fact that once you have been diagnosed with PCa, (or any cancer), your life will never be quite the same. Not that it will suck. It will just be different. Think Hotel California. You can check out any time, but you can never leave. No matter how unlikely, there is always that slim but real chance that it can come back next year. Or ten years from now. Enjoy every day. Believe the Dr. but don’t stop testing. At least not till you are 80.

Posts.Title: PSA angst....

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ASAdvocate Pratoman, That calculator has Dr. Tewari's photo on its cover page, and says that it is based on his research. It would seem to me that there should not be such a great difference in what he, as your surgeon, told you, and what this calculator gave you. You might want to ask him about the calculator. Meanwhile, it doesn't appear that credible. I didn't notice that, interesting. I will ask him at my next follow up in 3 months. Now I'm nervous again. Edit: I took a closer look at that page, it refers to Dr Tewari as being with Cornell - Weill , which he left 3 years ago. So I'm thinking while it's sloppy, it's probably a site owned by the hospital that a they never took down or updated. More important, it states that the data was taken from a cohort of patients that had surgery between 1992-1999. That was a loooonnngggg time ago, and there have been huge advances made. There was no robotic surgery back then, and I'm sure results were very different. In addition, Dr Tewari himself didn't have the experience he has now. I'm surprised the calculator is still online.

Posts.Title: Question!

Posts.Content: Mary, I ran my numbers in that calculator. The first thing that struck me is it does not differentiate between G7 (3+4) and G7(4+3). Studies have shown there is a big difference. The second thing I noticed is that the PSA range you (and I) have to choose is 4-9.9. Your husbands PSA is 5.27, mine is 4.3 (pre surgery) . That's a lot different than 9.9. If you notice, the part in tables have much narrower ranges. So before I even ran the numbers, I felt a lack of credibility Secondly, it showed I , like your husband, have a 58% chance of treatment success, in other. Words, no PSA failure. My surgeon told me that my chance of no further treatment needed is 95%. So I then went to the MSKCC Nomograms (link provided above by George) and it showed chance of no PSA failure at 97, 92, 88 and 83%, for w, 5, 7 and 10 years respectively. Basically a lot closer to my surgeons comment, than that other calculator. So if I were you I wouldn't get to freaked out over the results of that calculator

Posts.Title: Is this calculator accurate????

Posts.Content: JLynn, you've gotten some good insight here. I will say, that if your husbands experience is anything like mine, you will both be surprised at how manageable the recovery is, considering the extent and seriousness of the surgery. The worst part for me was the gas pains from the CO2 they use to blow up your abdominal cavity. i had it in my chest and shoulders, and for the first few days, or maybe a week, it hurt like hell, and I'm glad i knew to expect it, or i might have thought it was a heart attack. Aside from that, it was fairly easy. Catheter was a PIA, but not nearly as bad as i anticipated. I had somewhat low energy levels which took time to come back. Had blood clots in my urine for about 6 or 8 weeks. Other than that, uneventful, i was walking on the treadmill (slowly) the first week (i live in the Northeast and with the surgery in January, the treadmill was a godsend.) Just be prepared, read the stickies, make sure you stock up on depends, get a bucket to hold the catheter, think about renting a recliner for a week (easier to sleep in, than getting in and out of bed), lubricant for the tip of the penis where the catheter goes in (i used lidocaine, given to me by the hospital.) It will be nowhere near as bad as what you are anticipating.

Posts.Title: Diet and Alternative Medicine

Posts.Content: I'll try to give the short version of my source of annoyance...... Biopsy 2 and a half weeks ago. Got results via email from the nurse (negative, no cancer found). Doc was traveling, i was told to expect a call from him this past week, if not, to call him. Didn't hear. I called Wednesday, didn't get callback. Emailed the nurse Thursday, no response. Emailed the nurse Friday morning, no response. Called the nurse Friday afternoon, was told to call him Monday, he was very busy this week. I know the results are no cancer, thats good. But i should be able to speak to the Dr about follow up. No? If i dont get a call Monday, i am done, i'll figure out how to get the path report and bring it to someone else (no idea who) This is at a major medical center, nationally ranked for uroology.

Posts.Title: my husband diagnosed-even with thorough checking

Posts.Content: This goes to the fact that once you have been diagnosed with PCa, (or any cancer), your life will never be quite the same. Not that it will suck. It will just be different. Think Hotel California. You can check out any time, but you can never leave. No matter how unlikely, there is always that slim but real chance that it can come back next year. Or ten years from now. Enjoy every day. Believe the Dr. but don’t stop testing. At least not till you are 80.

Posts.Title: 3+ 4 and 4+3 - Is there REALLY a Difference?

Posts.Content: So I had my blood draw Friday for PSA, and now, once again, I wait. Ugh. Backstory is 2 years of <.02, then at the two year mark I lost the < and was .02. Retest 3 weeks later came back the same, .02. Waited 3 months and at the beginning of May, retested, and turns out the idiots at my Drs office ordered a standard PSA, not ultra sensitive, so it came back <.1. I guess you could say I got my < back, but the reality is, it could be anywhere from .02 to .099. So now I wait, and am real nervous, that it will come back at .03, or .06 or even .09. Next few days will be long Only thing that gives me comfort is my Decipher (genomics) test came back with a score of .37, with anything below .45 being low risk of recurrence. I'd feel better if it was deeper into low risk territory, like .2. Anyway, just venting, I woke up this morning very nervous about it for some reason.

Posts.Title: What's the opposite of shortening?

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by ASAdvocate Pratoman, That calculator has Dr. Tewari's photo on its cover page, and says that it is based on his research. It would seem to me that there should not be such a great difference in what he, as your surgeon, told you, and what this calculator gave you. You might want to ask him about the calculator. Meanwhile, it doesn't appear that credible. I didn't notice that, interesting. I will ask him at my next follow up in 3 months. Now I'm nervous again. Edit: I took a closer look at that page, it refers to Dr Tewari as being with Cornell - Weill , which he left 3 years ago. So I'm thinking while it's sloppy, it's probably a site owned by the hospital that a they never took down or updated. More important, it states that the data was taken from a cohort of patients that had surgery between 1992-1999. That was a loooonnngggg time ago, and there have been huge advances made. There was no robotic surgery back then, and I'm sure results were very different. In addition, Dr Tewari himself didn't have the experience he has now. I'm surprised the calculator is still online.

Posts.Content: Joe1, dont you think its lack of education, rather than PSA tests, that cause overtreatment? I know there are those that think PSA testing is the beginning of a slippery slope. But it seems to me that testing is not the issue. Its the Doctors that dont take the time to educate their patients about the test, what it means and what it doesnt mean, and same thing when it comes to biopsy results. That right there, i think, is the real problem. I wouldn't want to be that one guy in a thousand, whose life was lost, or whose quality of life was ruined, because my doctor read the recommendations of the U.S. Post Office, or whatever the name of that group of morons (in my humble opinion) calls themselves. No disrespect meant to you or your opinion. (or to the postal workers union )

Posts.Title: 3+ 4 and 4+3 - Is there REALLY a Difference?

Posts.Content: My understanding is that the standard PSA test measures down to .1. The uPSA measures lower, but it depends on the lab. Quest measures down to .02, labcorp down to .006. I’m now being tested at MSKCC, their in house lab tests down to .05, with anything less being reported as <.05. I THINK this too is considered ultra sensitive. I sometimes wonder if they measure lower but don’t report that unless it’s .05 or higher, thinking that anything below .05 is meaningless. Doesn’t really matter, I think, but I might ask my RO when I meet with him next

The other thing, which is probably ridiculous on my part, but i have always been a mental case about health issues, is this....i just want to hear in person or on the phone, from the Dr, the same thing that i read in an email from the nurse. Posts.Content: What Chuck said. And specifically to the issue of getting up at night to pee, i had the same issue. I had never gotten up at night before surgery. Afterwards, i had to go every night a couple of times, then every three hours. Over time, it improved. At 10 weeks out, i am not where i was, but last two nights i slept 6 and 5 hours respectively, so its improving, as you will too.

Posts.Content: Thanks guys... Michael , I doubt my Cardiologist will be much help, my guess is he'd prefer I not get my info from the Internet. He doesn't love the idea that all the labs have patient portals, so we can get our own results before he reviews them (not ego, he's a good guy, he just knows people misinterpret info sometimes and can get the wrong idea) Octagon, thank you. Yes, the HW forum is quite useless when it comes to the heart disease section Chuck thank you. The medhelp forum doesn't seem active, I posted there a week ago, and bumped it up yesterday, I got no responses other than an email from some nutjob recommending that I pray, and that I see an African Doctor. I'll check out the webmd forum. As I said it amazes me that an active forum doesn't exist. I'm sick over this. Ina way, more so than when I was diagnosed with PC, because this is something that can't be cured, only held at bay, with MAYBE a slight regression, but I'll always be high risk.im having a tough time dealing with it, I guess it's also the trauma of first PC followed swiftly by heart disease, after never having been sick Beiderbecke in my 64 years. It's been a miserable weekend for me, I'm a basket case.

Posts.Content: Whatever is the opposite of penis shortening, I think I have it. Has anyone experienced this? Please don't laugh, this is a serious post. I have noticed it for a while. I always assumed it was just fullness due to the 5mg Daily Cialis. But I had to go off the Cialis 5 weeks ago, and after a few weeks it got MORE noticeable. I thought maybe it was tissue dying to to lack of blood flow without the Cialis, maybe causing the tissue to drop down (makes no sense I know). But I can still get an erection so that can't be it. I went back on Cialis this week, but every other day, rather than daily. Everything works fine. It's just bigger, when soft.. (Same size when hard) I'm not complaining or worried, or anything like that. Just puzzled. Anybody ever hear of this

Posts.Title: Small step for mankind big step for me...

Posts.Content: there is a lot of good support here for PC patients, especially newbies. I've been looking for a place like this for Heart Disease, and while Otago and others have been very helpful, I really could use a dedicated ACTIVE heart disease forum right now. But while I've found multiple forums on the subject, none of them are active. That's crazy to me, considering how widespread Heart disease is in the developed world. There are lots of guys here in our 60s and 70s, and I would imagine lots who have some type of heart disease, like me. So I just want to put it out there and ask if anyone happens to know of a site that provides the same kind of support, and quick response that we do here. It might be against the TOS to post the link, if that's the case, which I hope it isn't, just shoot me a PM THANKS IN ADVANCE Back to Top

Posts.Title: Small step for mankind big step for me...

Posts.Content: Thanks guys... Michael , I doubt my Cardiologist will be much help, my guess is he'd prefer I not get my info from the Internet. He doesn't love the idea that all the labs have patient portals, so we can get our own results before he reviews them (not ego, he's a good guy, he just knows people misinterpret info sometimes and can get the wrong idea) Octagon, thank you. Yes, the HW forum is quite useless when it comes to the heart disease section Chuck thank you. The medhelp forum doesn't seem active, I posted there a week ago, and bumped it up yesterday, I got no responses other than an email from some nutjob recommending that I pray, and that I see an African Doctor. I'll check out the webmd forum. As I said it amazes me that an active forum doesn't exist. I'm sick over this. Ina way, more so than when I was diagnosed with PC, because this is something that can't be cured, only held at bay, with MAYBE a slight regression, but I'll always be high risk.im having a tough time dealing with it, I guess it's also the trauma of first PC followed swiftly by heart disease, after never having been sick Beiderbecke in my 64 years. It's been a miserable weekend for me, I'm a basket case.

Posts.Title: Need a Resource

Posts.Content: there is a lot of good support here for PC patients, especially newbies. I've been looking for a place like this for Heart Disease, and while Otago and others have been very helpful, I really could use a dedicated ACTIVE heart disease forum right now. But while I've found multiple forums on the subject, none of them are active. That's crazy to me, considering how widespread Heart disease is in the developed world. There are lots of guys here in our 60s and 70s, and I would imagine lots who have some type of heart disease, like me. So I just want to put it out there and ask if anyone happens to know of a site that provides the same kind of support, and quick response that we do here. It might be against the TOS to post the link, if that's the case, which I hope it isn't, just shoot me a PM THANKS IN ADVANCE Back to Top

Posts.Content: Davis, i thought i remember that the reason for the difficulty at the apex is because there is no capsule at the apex, its an open area. I had intra-operative positive margin at the apex, and so the surgeon cut more, and ended up with negative FINAL margins. Sometimes though its not possible. Yes i think (i'm not an expert) you could have undetectable PSA. You probably need to be rather vigilant though in regular PSA testing.

Posts.Content: Samie, unfortunately i agree with you. 12 days is way to soon to be doing any kind of shoveling or other hard work. You really should not worry about nagging him, be insistent that he could do some serious damage if he doesn't pull back a bit. At least until he sees the doc. And make the doc aware of whats going on, when he goes to get the cath out, so the Doc can kick his butt. I was told not to lift more than 10 pounds for 6 weeks.

Posts.Title: Post op...how much activity is too much?

Posts.Content: So I had my blood draw Friday for PSA, and now, once again, I wait. Ugh. Backstory is 2 years of <.02, then at the two year mark I lost the < and was .02. Retest 3 weeks later came back the same, .02. Waited 3 months and at the beginning of May, retested, and turns out the idiots at my Drs office ordered a standard PSA, not ultra sensitive, so it came back <.1. I guess you could say I got my < back, but the reality is, it could be anywhere from .02 to .099. So now I wait, and am real nervous, that it will come back at .03, or .06 or even .09. Next few days will be long Only thing that gives me comfort is my Decipher (genomics) test came back with a score of .37, with anything below .45 being low risk of recurrence. I'd feel better if it was deeper into low risk territory, like .2. Anyway, just venting, I woke up this morning very nervous about it for some reason.

Posts.Title: Waiting is the hardest part

Posts.Content: Sarge, sounds weird to say, but congratulations. You dodged a second bullet. You are blessed. My dad also had bypass (triple), he never really recovered, so its good to see that you are already at a point where you are posting here. He was never coherent after the surgery, something happened. So yeah, it scares the crap out of me. I had 2 stents inserted last June, just as i was getting over the idea of having PC. It scared the crap out of me, and i am really taking care of myself now, including complete diet change. I am low carb, low sugar, and moving slowly towards more of a vegan style diet. If you are interested, google Dr Dean Ornish . Good luck in your recovery, sounds like you are on your way, please keep us posted. Its too bad, but i have not found a forum as good as this one, for Heart Disease.

Posts.Content: Gleason 9 and 10 sometimes doesn’t put out a lot of PSA, from what I’ve read. Nevertheless. As Fairwind said, you’ll likely be around for many years. Even in a worst case scenario, if mets are found, there are many many treatments available and more coming every year. PC is treated as a chronic disease these days.

Even in a worst case scenario, if mets are found, there are many many treatments available and more coming every year. PC is treated as a chronic disease these days.

Posts.Content: All good advice, and wise words. I do intend to distract myself (the why the hell am I here on the forumLol) from the PC thoughts. I also am not really expecting to get the results till mid or later in the week, because the test was done at Labcorp (first time I've used them), and with the holiday, by the time the results are faxed to the Drs office and they call me, who knows. Posts.Title: Waiting is the hardest part

Posts.Content: Sorry you need to be here, but welcome. The g7 (4+3) isn't ideal, but it's also not terrible. It's considered intermediate risk. G8-10is what's considered aggressive. The negative lymph nodes is SUPER GOOD NEWS!!! I'm not sure what Equivocal margins means, but after googling, I thing it means tumor was found up to the edge of the gland just at the margins , so positive,, nut just barely. Again, I am not sure, maybe someone more knowledgeable will,chime in. The comment about extra capsular extension was also vague, it seems to say it wa sun determined if the tumor had escaped the capsule. Seminal vesicles invasion is not so great but they took it out, again , I'm not sure, sorry. I've not seen a path report with so many vague comments, but as I said I'm not that knowledgeable, maybe some one else can give more info I think overall, it's not the path report you would wish for, but not terrible either, and. The G7 is way better than G 8 or higher. Gleason score is one of the most important factors. For now, focus on helping your husband heal, and be very patient. He may be depressed for a while, maybe not. The next couple of weeks will,be a little tough, but now that the cath is out, he will improve quickly. In a couple of months you and he won't believe how much better he feels. He should be doing a lot of walking, 3-4 even 5 miles a day (not necessarily in one session. And he should do Kegels (see the sticky above, although I'm sure the surgeon went over that with him. The continence will improve (if it's a problem for him, which it is for most men just out of surgery), but it will not be a linear improvement. He will have good days and bad days, measure progress week to week, not day to day. I used a food scale to weigh my pads and kept a daily log, so I could compare and measure progress, it kept me positive . I am 4 months out of surgery, I feel like nothing even happened. I hit some golf balls ltwo weeks ago and am playing in an outing next week. I just returned from a week In Vegas. There is life after prostate cancer. Even if he has a rise in PSA, and ends up needing some radiation treatments,he has a good chance for cure, with clean lymph nodes. Just try to reassure him,be patient, and show him posts that you find encouraging. He will be fine. A Gleason7 rarely takes a life, Tell us a but more, how old is your husband, where did he have surgery? Stick around here there is plenty of support. I was crazed when I was diagnosed, but Chuck and this forum and another really helped me get perspective.

Posts.Title: What happens after DaVinci surgery?

Posts.Content: If I understand your signature correctly, your husband had one biopsy, and it was 3 years ago, and since then his PSA has slowly crept up, then jumped from 3 to 7 (throwing out the 12). If I were you I’d be asking, no, insisting on, another biopsy. Preferably an mri guided biopsy. I’m no expert on AS, but my understanding is a good AS program requires a biopsy, or at least an MRI, every 2 years, at least. And I’d be extra vigilant with a tumor at the Apex.

Posts.Title: Am I a dead man walking? New member

Posts.Content: If you are going to go to the trouble of getting a second opinion, which in most cases you should, have it done by the best. As good as UWM Pathology probably is they do not specialize in prostate cancer. And PC grading is very subjective. The two foremost experts in the WORLD in Prostate pathology are Jonathan Epstein at Johns Hopkins and David Bostwick, at Bostwick Labs. They both have second opinion services. I used Epstein, and in addition to being reasonably timely in getting me the report, he is extremely responsive. I actually got him on the phone and had a detailed conversation with him. I followed that up with an additional question via email and he got back to me the same day. So again, I'm sure UMW is good, but use one of the world famous PC pathology specialists, as long as they are available to you, which they are.

Posts.Title: Positive experience 8 days post-op

Posts.Content: Just my opinion, but seems to me, with no large scale studies to prove the efficacy of these alternative treatments, i would not be interested in potentially betting my life on diet and healthy living. I would rather go along with modern science, and bet on treatments that have large scale data pointing to positive results. Particularly at your age, i would go for the most aggressive cure attempt available. I realize some of you guys, with more knowledge than me, will disagree with that, especially with a Gleason 6 (see, you've taught me well)because i think it implies surgery. But everyone is different. Note regarding aggressive/surgery; I have to qualify this by saying, regarding surgery, if i was in the position of having a positive biopsy, and it was Gleason 6, maybe i would feel differently. I realize i can't walk in the shoes of the members who have been diagnosed, since i have not been. So i don't mean to be flip, and dont please dont think that i am. As an aside, think Steve Jobs. Can't say for sure that he would still be around had he opted for medical treatment from the beginning. But clearly his multi year attempt at a cure through healthy living and diet (to an extreme) did not help him. Just my humble opinion.

Posts.Title: Prostate Cancer Biopsy Negative

Posts.Content: Bees wife, It's highly doubtful that the surgeon, any surgeon, would preserve the nerve bundles if it lessened the chance of a cure, or heightened the chance of recurrence. As I mentioned earlier, being a little depressed after surgery is totally normal, I experienced that and many others do. I think a lot of it is a sense that before surgery, you feel ok, I'm doing something, doing my research, creating a plan of attack, I'm taking control. Then after the surgery, you spend more time waiting and hoping. The depression will likely subside over time, he needs to work thru the fact that he had to go thru this . I haven't had radiation and am no expert, but from what I've read, when you start radiation treatments, your progress on the continence issue pretty much freezes most of the time. Whatever progress you've made, is pretty much it. So you want him to be as close to continent as possible, before starting radiation. From most people's experiences that I've read about, the big side effect of radiation is fatigue, which can set in about half way thru treatments. Others who've gone thru it will come in soon with more first hand knowledge and experience. But hey, you guys are not there yet. Wait for the first PSA test, he may not need it for a while. Or maybe never. Keep the faith.

Posts.Title: Oh, glorious day!

Posts.Content: Sarge, sounds weird to say, but congratulations. You dodged a second bullet. You are blessed. My dad also had bypass (triple), he never really recovered, so its good to see that you are already at a point where you are posting here. He was never coherent after the surgery, something happened. So yeah, it scares the crap out of me. I had 2 stents inserted last June, just as i was getting over the idea of having PC. It scared the crap out of me, and i am really taking care of myself now, including complete diet change. I am low carb, low sugar, and moving slowly towards more of a vegan style diet. If you are interested, google Dr Dean Ornish . Good luck in your recovery, sounds like you are on your way, please keep us posted. Its too bad, but i have not found a forum as good as this one, for Heart Disease.

Posts.Title: PSA rising (38.5 from 5 in 4 weeks)

Posts.Content: Now What, good luck to you and your husband on the surgery. Note that you can rent a recliner for a week from many hospital supply stores for about $175. It will come in useful, as it's very hard to get in and out of bed the first few days and also easier to sleep in with the catheter. In addition, it's a good change of pace since he'll be home fr a while Also, push him(if you have to) to walk. And then walk kore. And more. And more. It will help speed his recovery. Also, having Robotic, they will pump CO2 into his abdominal area to give the surgeon room to work. As a result, he will possibly have pain in his abdomen , shoulders, chest. Some have it bad others not. Just be prepared so if he does have it bad, you don't freak out. I had it so bad, that if the guys here didn't warn me about it, I would have thought I was having aheartattack. The walking will help a lot as moving around moves the gas, and when he passes it he will feel better. It took me about a week which I think is longer than most. Have some Gasx in the house it will help.

Posts.Title: Advice for after care

Posts.Content: Lowlight - welcome. Was your MRI a 3tesla multiparametricMRI ? Those things are, from what I understand , about 90% accurate in picking up more aggressive tumors.if you have it done by a skilled radiologist. So it's a good sign that it picked up nothing You should talk to your URO about getting a saturation biopsy which takes many more samples with lower chance of missing something. Don't be too lax on this, being vigilant can make the difference between catching something in time, or not. But again, negative MRI is a good sign. More accurate than a CT scan

Posts.Title: Sustained relatively high PSA confirming next steps

Posts.Content: In the spirit of looking for something new to worry about when it doesn't yet exist, I went to the various nomogram tools on the MSKCC, Johns Hopkins, and Cleveland Clinic websites, and input my pathology stats. What I found was all three showing a 99% 15 year PC specific survival rate. However when it came to 2, 5, 7, and 10 year Biochemical recurrence free rate, the numbers for 10 year where in the low 90% range, on the CC and JH Nomograms, but 81% on the MSKCC website. Anybody have any thoughts on this? As good as my pathology report was, with no ECE, positive margins, or lymph nodes, it is bothering and concerning me that the GLeason was upgraded to a G 7 (3+4) , and it was at the apex. I know it's the "good" g7, but having those pattern 4 cells near the apex is making me nervous and thinking too much.

Posts.Title: The topic of perineural invasion and low grade disease.

Posts.Content: Options ▼ http://ascopubs.org/doi/full/10.1200/jco.18.00606 This article basically is an endorsement by the American Society of Clinical Oncologists, of Guidelines put out in 2017 jointly by the American Urological Association, American Society of Radiation Oncology, and the Society for Clinical Oncology, in all but two of the recommendations. They did NOT endorse 2 guidelines on Cryotherapy. What prompted me to post this, is Table 1, https://ascopubs.org/na101/home/lite...8.00606t1.jpeg which is a list of all of the endorsed guidelines, covering primary treatment for low, intermediate and high risk disease, including Active Surviellance. This could be super useful to any new guys coming here, in that it will help them ask the right questions, and PUSH BACK on any questionable statements made by surgeons, as well as radiation Oncologists as newly diagnosed patients go through their decision making process.

Posts.Title: ASCO Endorsement of Guidelines

Posts.Content: nrhk, i dont think even a Doctor can answer that question. Everyone reacts differently to treatment, and this cancer is a wierd cancer that acts differently in different patients. Besides which if you did get an answer, its just based on statistics, and niether your dad, nor any of us, is a statistics. There are all kinds of variations from the mean when it comes to numbers, averages etc. I know of one patient, diagnosed at Stage 4, Gleason 9, with extensisve mets, and a PSA of 5100. He was 41 years old. He will soon be celebrating his 52nd birthday, and last i heard, just a few months ago, his PSA was undetectable. So keep up your hopes, your dad may have a fight on his hands, and nobody can predict how it will turn out. But its quite possible that he could be around for a long time, with a decent QOL.

Posts.Title: Surgery wait time

Posts.Content: I don't have an answer to your question nrkh, it seems to me it would make sense. I think that surgery is usually looked on as a curative option and in your dads case, what they are saying is that since the cancer has already escaped, there is no chance for cure. But there is a chance for managing the disease for a very long time. I HAVE read of cases, don't remember where, like your dads, where they do surgery to "debulk" the tumor, and I would think that would slow the spread to distant areas. But I'm not a doctor. I would ask the treating physician.

Posts.Title: Why not remove the prostate in the case of Stage 4 PCA

Posts.Content: First thought is that i would tell the nurse, if she had a prostate, you would consider .06 a reasonable but for your own prostate, you'd rather not. Jimbow, just a guess, but i wonder if that <.01 was a lab error. Not to make you nervous, but i'd consider it suspect. And i would NOT wait 6 months I'd want a retest in 2 months, and if its up again, start looking for a good RO, to at least start a conversation. Probably, you wont begin SRT at .06, but probably around .1, not .2. And you dont want to first start looking for someone at .1, you want to have someone lined up so you can spring into action. I too was G(3+4) after surgery. I had negative FINAL margins, but margin was positive at the apex intra-operativly, so they cut more to get negative final margin. So my understanding is, that is better than positive margin, but not quite as good as intra operative positive, FINAL negative. I was <.02 till my 2 year PSA in Jan, when it was .02, and that was reconfirmed in February. I should know more in May, when i retest, Dr told me to retest in 3 months. He told me that at .1 is when they start talking about treatment. But i dont know that i will want to wait that long. Lets hope this is a false alarm for both of us.

Posts.Title: Started Treatment

Posts.Content: I've never had that. It could be something inconsequential, like a broken blood vessel from the DRE. But I would get it checked, if at least call the Dr and ask. Many years ago, in my 40's way before I dealt with PCa, I had an episode of bloody ejaculate and it really freaked me out. My PCP sent me to a urologist, who examined me and told me that it was likely a broken blood vessel from a particularly strong orgasm (which I did have). It only happened once. Call the Doc to be safe, but I'm guessing it's nothing, especially if it doesn't continue.

Posts.Content: Wishbone, congrats on back to work, i think going back to work is good for the soul. @PDV - I think everyone is different - not to mention your complicating lymphocele. I have a friend, who had the catheter out on day 8 and went back to work on day 9 post surgery. He just couldn't stand staying home, so he started going back i think about 5 hours a day. Works in Manhattan so was taking the train. Me on the other hand, i have a 15 minute drive to my office and i do no physical labor, all computer and phone work. Andi didnt go back until week 4, and that was part time. And the reality is, i was somewhat fatigued until about 2-2 1/2 months out of surgery. So everyone is different.

Posts.Title: My PSA is 'undetectable' :)

Posts.Content: Lowlight - welcome. Was your MRI a 3tesla multiparametricMRI ? Those things are, from what I understand , about 90% accurate in picking up more aggressive tumors.if you have it done by a skilled radiologist. So it's a good sign that it picked up nothing You should talk to your URO about getting a saturation biopsy which takes many more samples with lower chance of missing something. Don't be too lax on this, being vigilant can make the difference between catching something in time, or not. But again, negative MRI is a good sign. More accurate than a CT scan

Posts.Title: Back to work

Posts.Content: Rick congrats on the downgrade to g6, thats the best news you could have received. As far as incontinenc,e as others have said, weigh the pads, and journal your results every day. but dont look at it day to day, look week to week. Expect good days and bad days, it will be two steps forward one step back for a while, but as long as the trend is improving over weeks you will be encouraged, by having the log.

Posts.Title: Started Treatment

Posts.Content: Now What, good luck to you and your husband on the surgery. Note that you can rent a recliner for a week from many hospital supply stores for about $175. It will come in useful, as it's very hard to get in and out of bed the first few days and also easier to sleep in with the catheter. In addition, it's a good change of pace since he'll be home fr a while Also, push him(if you have to) to walk. And then walk kore. And more. And more. It will help speed his recovery. Also, having Robotic, they will pump CO2 into his abdominal area to give the surgeon room to work. As a result, he will possibly have pain in his abdomen , shoulders, chest. Some have it bad others not. Just be prepared so if he does have it bad, you don't freak out. I had it so bad, that if the guys here didn't warn me about it, I would have thought I was having aheartattack. The walking will help a lot as moving around moves the gas, and when he passes it he will feel better. It took me about a week which I think is longer than most. Have some Gasx in the house it will help.

Posts.Title: Advice for after care

Posts.Content: Tomorrow will be a fun day NOT. 6:30pm - 2nd Firmagon shot, hope its easier to take than the first, which wrecked me for three days, that was a triple dose, now i am on single dose. 6:45pm - Labwork - i guess we'll see what the first Firmagon shot has done. PSA was .08, before i started, so not sure if i should expect much of a drop. T was 332. If hot flashes are any indication, then T is probably in the neighborhood of 10. 9:10PM - Setup and first of 40 SRT Treatments. Haven't seen my RO (Zelefsky at MSKCC) since before my decision was made to move forward. No mention has been made of when my first appointment with him will be. I have a feeling i might be meeting with his Radiation Nurse weekly, rather than him, Just a feeling. For all i know, it could be a resident taking care of my treatment plan, not him. , Nobody has talked to me about whether to continue supplements - Magnesium, D3. Whenever i have a question, i just sign on to the portal, and i get a response from a nurse the same day. Not sure if i like this, i feel a little bit like i'm out at sea, by myself. But whatever. I'm a little uptight. But i know I'll get through it. I still have a nagging thought though, about whether i'm doing the right thing. I could have just left it alone and it might not have been a problem for 5 or 10 years, my surgeon said, probably closer to 10 with my pathology and Decipher result. But i made my decision, so just time to move forward and hope for the best (and a cure) I'll use this thread to keep everyone updated, maybe it will help somebody in the future.

Posts.Title: Starting SRT

Posts.Content: Rob, thanks for the response, and definitely we will try to get together. I can’t wait to get down there. Btw, I saw your response elsewhere, thanks for that. I eliminated a lot of my supplements, I only take the magnesium and d3 now because when I test for those the labs come back low, once I started taking them, I got into the normal range. I stopped taking a multi vitamin two years ago, my nutritionist said with the amount of vegetables I consume, I really don’t need it. I love onions, (as my breath shows is evident LOL) , so I hope I don’t have a problem with that. I’m probably ok with magnesium and d3, but I’ll ask the question in the MSKCC patient portal and a radiation nurse will get back to me tomorrow. Thanks again for the response. Good luck with the scans, and Moffit. I’ll be thinking of you. Gotta go, need a towel, hot flash is coming

I have a feeling i might be meeting with his Radiation Nurse weekly, rather than him, Just a feeling. For all i know, it could be a resident taking care of my treatment plan, not him. , Nobody has talked to me about whether to continue supplements - Magnesium, D3. Whenever i have a question, i just sign on to the portal, and i get a response from a nurse the same day. Not sure if i like this, i feel a little bit like i'm out at sea, by myself. But whatever. I'm a little uptight. But i know I'll get through it. I still have a nagging thought though, about whether i'm doing the right thing. I could have just left it alone and it might not have been a problem for 5 or 10 years, my surgeon said, probably closer to 10 with my pathology and Decipher result. But i made my decision, so just time to move forward and hope for the best (and a cure) I'll use this thread to keep everyone updated, maybe it will help somebody in the future.

Posts.Title: Started Treatment

Posts.Content: 7Seas, welcome to,the forum. Like Michigan Man, and probably like you. I too was a mental wreck when I got my G6 diagnosis. But as I educated myself, I came to realize that in all likelihood, this would be a treatable, curable disease. I got my diagnosis 1 year ago this week. I had surgery in January. And I'm happy to report, that so far there is no sign of cancer, I don't pee in my pants, and I can still bother my wife for sex on a regular basis. So don't worry, things may look dark now, but you WILL get your life back. One suggestion.... It would be worthwhile, for you to request that your slides be sent to Dr Jonathan Epstein at Kohns Hopkins, (or David Bostwick, at Bostwick Labs) for a second look. The reading of prostate cells, and Gleason grading, can be very subjective, and usually local pathologists read all kinds f slides. Epstein and Bostwick are the acknowledged foremost e parts in prostate pathology, and it would be worth getting their opinion, so you have a better chance f knowing that you are dealing with Gleason 6. (Although even if it was G7, it wouldn't mean that you don't have a high chance of cure). Your job now is to get educated, take Chucks (highlander) advice and read the book, it's excellent, and meet with Drs from the various radiation treatments as well as surgeons. Getting educated will make you feel like you are back on firm footing. And when you finally make a decision on a treatment, it will be a big relief. Good luck, hang in there, and keep,us posted.

Posts.Title: Surgery scheduled...

Posts.Content: Now What, good luck to you and your husband on the surgery. Note that you can rent a recliner for a week from many hospital supply stores for about $175. It will come in useful, as it's very hard to get in and out of bed the first few days and also easier to sleep in with the catheter. In addition, it's a good change of pace since he'll be home fr a while Also, push him(if you have to) to walk. And then walk kore. And more. And more. It will help speed his recovery. Also, having Robotic, they will pump CO2 into his abdominal area to give the surgeon room to work. As a result, he will possibly have pain in his abdomen , shoulders, chest. Some have it bad others not. Just be prepared so if he does have it bad, you don't freak out. I had it so bad, that if the guys here didn't warn me about it, I would have thought I was having aheartattack. The walking will help a lot as moving around moves the gas, and when he passes it he will feel better. It took me about a week which I think is longer than most. Have some Gasx in the house it will help.

Posts.Title: 2nd. Zero report!!!

Posts.Content: Moss, for what its worth, i waited to tell my children, both in their early, mid 30's. I wanted to know exactly what the pathology was, second opinion and all, what the initial prognosis was, and i wanted to wait till i decided exactly what treatment i would go with. Once i had that information and all the facts, i waited for the opportunity to tell them face to face (which i realize might be difficult for you in your situation.) I wanted to tell them while they looked at me and saw my (fake) positivity, and saw that i was not afraid. (i was, but we do anything for your kids, dont we?) After i told my son, i had to tell my daughter, but when i was ready, she was a few days away from leaving for a Carribean vacation, and i didnt want to ruin it for her. So i waited until she returned, and told her on Thanksgiving Day. Hardest conversation i've ever had to have with both of them. But they drew strength from seeing my attitude. And it all worked out. Just my opinion, and my approach, we are all different, as are all of our family dynamics.

Posts.Title: Meeting Mr Da vinci Friday

Posts.Content: Question for the surgery guys. How did or do you feel 2-3 months past RALP.Aside from feeling fine, do you feel like everything is "the same down there" ? The more I think about it, I don't. It's hard to describe, but I feel different For one, I always feel something in my penis like there is urine collecting, or like I just pissed, even if I didn't. For another, at the end of a pee, I get a little pain just below the pubic bone. Maybe not pain, maybe a straining feeling, Also, and this is not a bad thing, except it doesn't make much sense - whereas I used to be semi constipated, having hard bowel movements and not always regular, since the surgery I have a large bowel movement pretty much every morning, and it is no longer hard. Like when I was in my 20s. I've been off Colace for 2 months. I don't think I'm fully explaining this feeling, I don't know how, I just know everything feels different down there, not bad, but not YHE same, and it's making me nervous . thinking about it. So I'm curious to know if others have somewhat different sensations in the area, both front and back a few months out. I would think, after 10 weeks, I'm pretty much healed by now, inside.

Posts.Title: biopsy results

Posts.Content: 1. No, the cancerous cells are looked at under. Microscope and identified at a cellular level. With that said, it is somewhat subjective, which is why a second opinion from a prostate specialist is so important in these cases 2. I don't think urologists generally request it, patients (knowledgeable ones) do 3. Never heard of Cytoscopy as routine pre surgical procedure. MRI more suitable I think. I'd run the other way, honestly, it's a needless painful invasive procedure in my opinion, (but I'm not a Dr) 4. Not sure about what % of second opinions are contrary to the first opinions. It's customary I believe , to send only the slides that were identified as containing cancer. That's what my pathology dept did as well. 5. Probably not first line automatically, although you could request it 6. Not sure. Just a guess. The first pathologist will defer to Epstein. Epstien is the Gold Standard. 7. Surgery that results in a final pathology does happen, but it's VERY rare. 8. I also got two opinions - from two urologists. Is the RO one who specializes in treating prostate cancer? If not, I'd go with urologist opinion. 9.just my opinion, but under the circumstances, I think 6 months is prudent. Maybe even 3. It's just a blood test Good luck, it's good that you are Ming slowly and deliberately on this. Stay on top of it though

Posts.Title: Taking Control - Questions

Posts.Content: Moss, for what its worth, i waited to tell my children, both in their early, mid 30's. I wanted to know exactly what the pathology was, second opinion and all, what the initial prognosis was, and i wanted to wait till i decided exactly what treatment i would go with. Once i had that information and all the facts, i waited for the opportunity to tell them face to face (which i realize might be difficult for you in your situation.) I wanted to tell them while they looked at me and saw my (fake) positivity, and saw that i was not afraid. (i was, but we do anything for your kids, dont we?) After i told my son, i had to tell my daughter, but when i was ready, she was a few days away from leaving for a Carribean vacation, and i didnt want to ruin it for her. So i waited until she returned, and told her on Thanksgiving Day. Hardest conversation i've ever had to have with both of them. But they drew strength from seeing my attitude. And it all worked out. Just my opinion, and my approach, we are all different, as are all of our family dynamics.

Posts.Title: Back again, Dad PSA levels rising again

Posts.Content: Joe, i dont think Jim meant his comment as it might have sounded to you, or as you took it. I think he meant it constructively. He makes a point, you seem to have already made up your mind not to treat, in which case, there is no real advice that is actionable, that we can offer. You are in a tough situation. I think a positive mindset might help you however tough that might be. And the point made, of WHAT IF they come up with advances that can prolong quality of life in dementia patients, or even reverse the effects of dementia, is a good one. The advances being made today in modern medicine are astounding, and its quite possible that you will live with a good QUALITY OF LIFE for a much longer time than you susptect. Wouldn't it be a shame, if you decided not to treat your Prostate Cancer, and you remained fully competent mentally, but ended up dying a miserable death from PC that could have been prevented? I suggest that asking you, to ask yourself that question, is probably the best advice we can offer here. Unless and until you decide to treat In whatever you decide, I'm sure i speak for all here in wishing you the best of luck, and we hope you decide to get the biopsy done at the very least, and stick around here for help, advice and support.

Posts.Title: Biopsy/Treatment if in early stages of Dementia

Posts.Content: I got my PCa3 results today and it came back at a 26. The nurse told me, as a different nurse did 2 years ago, that the cutoff is 25, so i am on the cusp. Two years ago, it was 13. She also told me its not necessarily an indication of cancer, its a test that shows whether i have inherited the PC gene, much like the gene for Breast Cancer . I thought it was a test for presence of a genetic material given off by cancer cells, WHEN THEY ARE PRESENT. So i am confused. Because 1. i was pretty sure that i was right regarding what it showed, but the nurse seems pretty knowledgeable 2. from what i've read online, and what i got from a member of another forum, the normal cutoff is 35 not 25, but two nurses told me it was 25. Anybody know the right answers? If this is high, combined with a jump in my PSA from 3.1 to 4.3 over 6 months and a %fPSA of 12, i think i am screwed. Biopsy is tomorrow. I already have it in my mind to get appointments with Samadi and Tewari. UGH

Posts.Title: PCA3 question

Posts.Content: @NYC Gman - (i should have taken that screenname - i'm from NYUC and G is my second initial) - one thing i found out is that the cutoff varies by Dr. Some use 35. Others use 25. Weird its a big range. But the FDA recommended cutoff is 25 But yes, regarding the meaning of PCA3 you are correct. Originally Posted by NYC GMAN Time to get a new nurse! Pca3 measures a prostate cancer gene found in urine. BRCA2, a breast cancer gene thought to be related to prostate cancer is measured in a blood test. The typical cutoff is 35. Scores greater than 35 indicate an increased risk of PC.

Posts.Title: How soon is too soon for sexual activity after prostatectomy?

Posts.Content: Thanks Denis, I appreciate it. Testosterone result came back, at 5 ng/dl down from 322 a month ago. No wonder I feel like garbage. It was accompanied by this comment.... “For Testosterone values less than 20 ng/dL by immunoassay a more accurate and sensitive Mass Spectrometric method is used. This test was developed and its performance characteristics determined by the MSKCC Department of Laboratory Medicine. It has not been cleared or approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration. The FDA has determined that such clearance or approval is not necessary. This test is for clinical purposes” Had my first weekly meeting with the RO today, the day of my second treatment. Waste of time. First PA comes in, asks if I’m having urination issues, bowel issues, mentions the results of my ALT liver enzyme test as high and it needs to be kept an eye on. Asks me if I drink alcohol (I don’t aside from an occasional drink when I go out to dinner, but almost never). You know it’s my second day of treatment. Why are you asking me about urinary issues? Then the RO Comes in. First time I’ve met him, my RO is on vacation. this guy really had nothing to say and seemed totally disinterested. They had me drinking one 8 ounce cup of water before treatment. That had my bladder 2/3 full yesterday, which the tech said is fine but they don’t want it to be less full than that. So today they upped me to 1 1/4 cups. They said it was a good result.

Posts.Title: Mayo Kegel Instructions

Posts.Content: OTS, At about a week or two out, I was pretty much the same as you. In fact, I asked the exact same question on another forum. Will I get to a point where clamping off leaks comes without thinking, as a natural reflex, rather than feeling I have to make a conscious effort; the answers, and there were many, were a resounding yes, and they proved to be accurate. There are occasions where I leak a bit, but not enough to bother me and certainly not so much that I need to wear a pad. In fact, proud to say, I wear boxers LOL. I was 90% at about 8-10 weeks, but I continuously improved incrementally, for about 10-12 months. I tell you my experience, only to give you an idea what to expect, and to reassure you that indeed, you re doing great and ultimately, you will find yourself thinking less and less about this issue.

Posts.Title: Getting ready for chemo on Saturday

Posts.Content: Jerry, two questions.... 1. Where do,you live 2. Are you willing/able to travel. With those two answers no doubt you'll get many recommendations While I have seen the studies showing that after 250 surgeries the learning curve flattens, I believe that in this case, more is better. I would look for 1000 plus. I would highly recommend the surgeon I used, Dr Ash Tewari, in NYC. He's done over 6000 RALPS, and is highly regarded by his peers in PC world. He is not just a surgeon,he is , to use a fellow members words to me, a scientist. And he is not only highly skilled, he is compassionate and has a terrific staff (very important when working with a high volume surgeon as a lot of your post op interaction will be with the staff, I.e. RN, NP, PA. Also, there are fine surgeons at Mayo, Chuck can give you a name, and Cleveland Clinic. And Johns Hopkins is highly regarded as one of the best centers of care for Prostate Cancer. I'm sure others will follow. But seriously post your general location, and folks will Ero in. How to find the right surgeon? I used this and another forum to decide on the right guys to talk to before making my decision. Good luck

Posts.Content: Joe, i dont think Jim meant his comment as it might have sounded to you, or as you took it. I think he meant it constructively. He makes a point, you seem to have already made up your mind not to treat, in which case, there is no real advice that is actionable, that we can offer. You are in a tough situation. I think a positive mindset might help you however tough that might be. And the point made, of WHAT IF they come up with advances that can prolong quality of life in dementia patients, or even reverse the effects of dementia, is a good one. The advances being made today in modern medicine are astounding, and its quite possible that you will live with a good QUALITY OF LIFE for a much longer time than you susptect. Wouldn't it be a shame, if you decided not to treat your Prostate Cancer, and you remained fully competent mentally, but ended up dying a miserable death from PC that could have been prevented? I suggest that asking you, to ask yourself that question, is probably the best advice we can offer here. Unless and until you decide to treat In whatever you decide, I'm sure i speak for all here in wishing you the best of luck, and we hope you decide to get the biopsy done at the very least, and stick around here for help, advice and support.

Posts.Title: Mayo Kegel Instructions

Posts.Content: Illek, I put your data into the MSKCC post surgery nomograms. You dont mention margin status, so first I used negative margins,the result showed that you chance of no recurrence at 2 years is 55%, 5, 7 and 10 years - 33, 26 and 20% respectively. If you had positive margins, the numbers are lower. But in both cases, youve got a 75% chance of NOT dying of PCa in 15 years. So its a bet on whether you want to take the risk. If you want to run the numbers yourself, heres the link... https://www.mskcc.org/nomograms/prostate/post_op Keep in mind the nomograms are not perfect. But theyre all weve got, at least as far as pure numbers go) I would discuss this with your doc, and maybe see an RO its better to discuss with an RO than a surgeon. Ask questions like, how much added risk am I taking if I am undetectable and decide to wait.

Posts.Title: RALP Pathology Stage T3b, Gleason 9, Invasion of Seminal Vesticles. How bad is it?

Posts.Content: Jerry, two questions.... 1. Where do,you live 2. Are you willing/able to travel. With those two answers no doubt you'll get many recommendations While I have seen the studies showing that after 250 surgeries the learning curve flattens, I believe that in this case, more is better. I would look for 1000 plus. I would highly recommend the surgeon I used, Dr Ash Tewari, in NYC. He's done over 6000 RALPS, and is highly regarded by his peers in PC world. He is not just a surgeon,he is , to use a fellow members words to me, a scientist. And he is not only highly skilled, he is compassionate and has a terrific staff (very important when working with a high volume surgeon as a lot of your post op interaction will be with the staff, I.e. RN, NP, PA. Also, there are fine surgeons at Mayo, Chuck can give you a name, and Cleveland Clinic. And Johns Hopkins is highly regarded as one of the best centers of care for Prostate Cancer. I'm sure others will follow. But seriously post your general location, and folks will Ero in. How to find the right surgeon? I used this and another forum to decide on the right guys to talk to before making my decision. Good luck

Posts.Content: I agree, find another Uro. Whether your journey is long and you ultimately learn that you have cancer (Not a super high probability right now but you need to follow this), or it’s short and you find that you just needed to go through the process to eliminate that possibility, you don’t need to take this trip with a guy who has an attitude, and sounds like he’s been doing this for too long (from the tone of your description). You need a partner, who is willing to inform you and engage in shared decision making.

Posts.Content: Dan, I agree with everything Michael said. If you haven't already, it would be worth exploring your non surgery options. Just so that no matter what happens in the future you'll know you made the best decision and it was an informed one. Like Michael, I'm a surgery guy too. But I did take advantage of the time I had to wait between biopsy and treatment, to look at both brachytherapy and SBRT. On the second opinion, I hear you. My biopsy was originally g8(3+5). Second opinion from Epstein called it a g6. But if you feel it won't change your treatment decision and you have reason to be confident with your pathologist, then yes, maybe money not well spent. Good luck today, looking forward to hearing how the appointment goes

Posts.Title: Choosing surgeon

Posts.Content: Welcome Dan. Sounds like you are in a good position all things considered. You've gotten great advice above. Two things I would add... 1. Ask that your slides be sent for a second opinion, preferably to Dr Jonathan Epstein at Johns Hopkins. Reading prostate slides is. Tricky thing, very subjective and you want them read by a pathologist who only looks at prostate slides. Your local pathologist likely looks at all kinds of cells. 2. Chucks suggestion of 300 procedures is a minimum. Science backs up the fact that the learning curve starts to flatten after 250 procedures. But IMO, and it's only my opinion, is I want A recognized expert to do the surgery with at least 1000 surgeries under his belt. My surgeon, in NY had done over 6000 robotic surgeries at the time I had mine. Also, that 15 year survival doesn't mean much. If you are a true Gleason 6, you'll likely live way longer than that if something els doesn't kill you. I think thy might not even track stats after 15 years.

Posts.Content: This has made me feel a lot better. What you guys are describing is pretty much what I feel . NYCGman, tender on bowel movements - exactly. JnIght your description of the sensation after peeing. And softer BMs. Exactly. One thing, I have always consumed huge amounts of water. I. Witha water bottle all day. Now I believe I am consuming less, at night at least. GMan, dr Yewaris nurse told me the day the cath came out, that I should try to reduce the amount of water I drink. So I don't think it's that. And I wonder why the softer more regular BMs. I haven't seen my surgeon since surgery, only his staff, but I am seeing him for my 3 month visit in April and will ask. I wonder if the surgery softens an area of the colon or rectum near the prostate. As I said earlier, I had this huge night wetting incident last night while sleeping and it freaked me out, so I guess that's wy I've been so focused on this today. Good to know others haven exprienced this. I'm just a bit nervous that I ight piss in my sleep again tonight, but hopefully it was a one off incident. I hate this crap

Posts.Title: How Do You Feel After Surgery

Posts.Content: Question for the surgery guys. How did or do you feel 2-3 months past RALP.Aside from feeling fine, do you feel like everything is "the same down there" ? The more I think about it, I don't. It's hard to describe, but I feel different For one, I always feel something in my penis like there is urine collecting, or like I just pissed, even if I didn't. For another, at the end of a pee, I get a little pain just below the pubic bone. Maybe not pain, maybe a straining feeling, Also, and this is not a bad thing, except it doesn't make much sense - whereas I used to be semi constipated, having hard bowel movements and not always regular, since the surgery I have a large bowel movement pretty much every morning, and it is no longer hard. Like when I was in my 20s. I've been off Colace for 2 months. I don't think I'm fully explaining this feeling, I don't know how, I just know everything feels different down there, not bad, but not YHE same, and it's making me nervous . thinking about it. So I'm curious to know if others have somewhat different sensations in the area, both front and back a few months out. I would think, after 10 weeks, I'm pretty much healed by now, inside.

Posts.Title: How Can Uro Know I'm Only Stage 2?

Posts.Content: EaScott, staging from. Biopsy is called clinical staging, vs staging after all tests and surgery if you have it, which is more definitive and called pathological staging. I assume he is ordering bone and CT scans? Which would be standard. Probably will show nothing, in which caseyoeuatage would remain T1, and I assume that's based on negative DRE, In other words, nothing felt on the digital rectal exam. If they find a spread outside the area, it old be upgraded (if that's the right word) to Stage t2a, assuming no lymph node involvement. You should request that your slides from BIopsy be sent to another lab that specializes in PC. Either Dr JOn Epatein at Johns Hopkins or David Bostwick at Bostwick laboratories. Also, that G8 (3+5) is unusual. I had one core labeled that way and it was downgraded to g6(3+3) by Epstein at Johns Hopkins Second opinion is almost a must, and it's easy, your Urologist gets these requests all the time, just tell them where you want it sent. If you say Epstein r Bostwick, that's all they will need, they have the information. Start doing your own research, the docs will usually oush their specialty, surgeons red SURGER Radiation Oncologists rec radiation. Your age might lean you towards surgery though, I think , not sure, that 70 is sort of borderline for SURGER. Others might know better than I. Sorry you need to be here dealing with this, but stick around and ask a lot of questions,you will learn plenty. Good luck

Posts.Title: 10/12 month anniversary & update

Posts.Content: Joe, i dont think Jim meant his comment as it might have sounded to you, or as you took it. I think he meant it constructively. He makes a point, you seem to have already made up your mind not to treat, in which case, there is no real advice that is actionable, that we can offer. You are in a tough situation. I think a positive mindset might help you however tough that might be. And the point made, of WHAT IF they come up with advances that can prolong quality of life in dementia patients, or even reverse the effects of dementia, is a good one. The advances being made today in modern medicine are astounding, and its quite possible that you will live with a good QUALITY OF LIFE for a much longer time than you susptect. Wouldn't it be a shame, if you decided not to treat your Prostate Cancer, and you remained fully competent mentally, but ended up dying a miserable death from PC that could have been prevented? I suggest that asking you, to ask yourself that question, is probably the best advice we can offer here. Unless and until you decide to treat In whatever you decide, I'm sure i speak for all here in wishing you the best of luck, and we hope you decide to get the biopsy done at the very least, and stick around here for help, advice and support.

Posts.Title: Injected/Full Body Bone Scan

Posts.Content: Jim, I had the 2.1 reading, with the local Uro i had been seeing all along. When it went to 2.1 he recommended biopsy. I decded to seek a second opinion, and 2 weeks later, i saw a doc in Manhattan at Columbia Presbyterian. He retook the PSA which got me to 2.7 but it was a different lab The PSAs were all 1 year (approx) apart, until it got to 2.7. At that point i had the biopsy, then changed doctors agai, because a prominent doc from Columbia moved to Long Island to become chairman of Winthrop Urology. , and the rest of the PSAs were all 6 months apart. The reason i had the biopsy at 2.7 was due to 1. consistent rise, EVERY time i had the test, and 2, family history (MY DAD). Did this after getting the same reco from 2 docs.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Walnut First of all, maybe your family history is a positive thing. If your dad was old enough to have dementia when he was diagnosed he must have been pretty old. Doesn't that give you hope that your cancer may be a non-aggressive type that may not require treatment? In my case, as I was in my late sixties, my doctor said that at my age I probably had prostate cancer because so many men have it at that age (this was early in the process, before I was diagnosed). The only question was......does it need treatment or is it better left alone because it will never impact your life? That's the question for you, I think. Treatment surely will impact your life.....perhaps severely. I suggest a LOT of research before doing anything you can't take back. My dad had dementia which was a result of something going wrong with anesthesia in open heart surgery, and passed in his mid 70's Question (for anyone): PSA GOING FROM 2.7 TO 3.1, TO 4.3 IN 18 MONTHS -Is that considered a rapid rise that might be a sign of AGGRESSIVE DISEASE? This is a big worry i have Thanks in advance

Posts.Content: I agree, find another Uro. Whether your journey is long and you ultimately learn that you have cancer (Not a super high probability right now but you need to follow this), or it’s short and you find that you just needed to go through the process to eliminate that possibility, you don’t need to take this trip with a guy who has an attitude, and sounds like he’s been doing this for too long (from the tone of your description). You need a partner, who is willing to inform you and engage in shared decision making.

Posts.Title: elevated PSA at age 52

Posts.Content: Thanks for responding, Otago.... I think that the reason he is wanting to do a biopsy now is 1. the free psa of 12, 2. the bigger jump than in the past, and 3. t he hi grade pin, found in my first biopsy. The latter is probably the more important reason. As far as my dad is concerned, i am ashamed to say, i do not know his psa or gleason. I left it to his wife, although i did go to some of the appointments with him, i just didnt know anything and didnt even know what questions to ask. But i do know that he died of prostate cancer. His situation at diagnosis was that he was not healthy, had dementia, had recently had triple bypass and serious kidney problems, and was not a candidate for surgery, so he went right to shots (hormone therapy i believe). At that point he was already in a nursing home, and they just did the best they could. I regret to this day that i did not get more involved in his care

Posts.Title: I'm back, and freakout time again

Posts.Content: ddayglo, thanks for responding. I have Walshs book, I bought it (and read much of it) at the time of my first biopsy two years ago. It was recommended to me by a family member who had the surgery done, by Dr Walsh. Re Vitamin D, I did have a vitamin D deficiency, which was resolved a few years ago with taking Vit D pills daily. Re MRI, my Uro mentioned it last visit, but for whatever reason this time he felt a biopsy was called for. So I'm going with it. He's pretty well known with good crews, and is Chairman of Urology at a major hospital Center, am Nd also clinical professor at Columbia Prysbetrian. So I've got to ask some questions, but have faith in what he thinks. So, anyone know, are the odds pretty high in my situation, that biopsy will be positive?

Posts.Title: I'm back, and freakout time again

Posts.Content: PSA has been steadily rising over the last 5 years or so, startingat .7, (age 5, to 3.1 six months ago (age 64 -about to turn 64). The rises have been slow, .7, 1.1, 1.7, 2.1, 2.7, 2.9,2.7, then 3.1 six months ago. Went to uro doc today, got results - 4.3. Seems like a bigger jump than in the past. Also my fPSA was 12. and free to total ratio was 8.6. Had biopsy two year ago, which was negative for PC but showed Hi Grade Pin, in one of 14 cores. So between the large jump, the hi grade pin, and the low free psa, combined with my family history of PC (father), i am pretty much convinced that bad news is on the way. I am scheduled for biopsy next week. UGH. Am i wrong to think the odds of a negative biopsy are very much stacked against me here?

Posts.Content: Jazz, I don't have a lot to offer as I'm no expert on HT. but if you feel that badly , and the Drs say you are past the point where the Lupron should affect you (I.e. The Lupron effects should be out of your system by now), then I would press the Drs to get to the bottom of it, and if they don't , find Drs who will. This is your life, don't take "I don't know " for an answer

Posts.Title: Injected/Full Body Bone Scan

Posts.Content: Jim, I had the 2.1 reading, with the local Uro i had been seeing all along. When it went to 2.1 he recommended biopsy. I decded to seek a second opinion, and 2 weeks later, i saw a doc in Manhattan at Columbia Presbyterian. He retook the PSA which got me to 2.7 but it was a different lab The PSAs were all 1 year (approx) apart, until it got to 2.7. At that point i had the biopsy, then changed doctors agai, because a prominent doc from Columbia moved to Long Island to become chairman of Winthrop Urology. , and the rest of the PSAs were all 6 months apart. The reason i had the biopsy at 2.7 was due to 1. consistent rise, EVERY time i had the test, and 2, family history (MY DAD). Did this after getting the same reco from 2 docs.

Posts.Title: How Can Uro Know I'm Only Stage 2?

Posts.Content: EaScott, staging from. Biopsy is called clinical staging, vs staging after all tests and surgery if you have it, which is more definitive and called pathological staging. I assume he is ordering bone and CT scans? Which would be standard. Probably will show nothing, in which caseyoeuatage would remain T1, and I assume that's based on negative DRE, In other words, nothing felt on the digital rectal exam. If they find a spread outside the area, it old be upgraded (if that's the right word) to Stage t2a, assuming no lymph node involvement. You should request that your slides from BIopsy be sent to another lab that specializes in PC. Either Dr JOn Epatein at Johns Hopkins or David Bostwick at Bostwick laboratories. Also, that G8 (3+5) is unusual. I had one core labeled that way and it was downgraded to g6(3+3) by Epstein at Johns Hopkins Second opinion is almost a must, and it's easy, your Urologist gets these requests all the time, just tell them where you want it sent. If you say Epstein r Bostwick, that's all they will need, they have the information. Start doing your own research, the docs will usually oush their specialty, surgeons red SURGER Radiation Oncologists rec radiation. Your age might lean you towards surgery though, I think , not sure, that 70 is sort of borderline for SURGER. Others might know better than I. Sorry you need to be here dealing with this, but stick around and ask a lot of questions,you will learn plenty. Good luck

Posts.Title: How Can Uro Know I'm Only Stage 2?

Posts.Content: NW - I Have a question....Did he have nerve sparing surgery? (you may have posted about that i dont remember). Even if he did not, it is possible (less likely, but possible) that he may get back some function. And even if he doesn't, many couples find other ways of enjoying each other, ways that include orgasm by both parties. If he did have nerve sparing surgery, How do you know, 3 weeks post op, that your sex life wont be the same? It is way too early to come to such a conclusion. Most guys dont have Erectile Function right away. Sure, some guys dont get it back. Many though get it back in 6 months to a year. In fact, i read a post in another forum yesterday, about a guy who finally, without pills, injections or anything, suddenly experienced a return to somewhat normal function, 2 years after surgery. I think now is a good time to take one day at a time. Its way too early. And if he doesn't get it back, there are choices.

Good luck keep us posted

Posts.Content: On another forum there is a robust discussion about test sensitivity, and it was mentioned by one poster that his Dr told him that lately, they have seen a lot of guys coming back wh were formerly undetectable, with.1 readings, specifically from Quest Diagnostics. In the posters caw, I think he said he came back with .1, then tested at Labcorp, and it came back undetectable. I'm curious if guys here have either experienced this or heard anything about it. Obviously there are variations from lab to lab. But uPSA fluctuations between <.01 and .1 is more than noise. I'm concerned about this, because I had my 9 month blood draw today at Quest labs, and will now be on edge for a week, waiting for results. If it comes back detectable, let alone .1, I'll likely fall down and break my skull

Posts.Title: Six-week post-op progress report

Posts.Content: NW - I Have a question....Did he have nerve sparing surgery? (you may have posted about that i dont remember). Even if he did not, it is possible (less likely, but possible) that he may get back some function. And even if he doesn't, many couples find other ways of enjoying each other, ways that include orgasm by both parties. If he did have nerve sparing surgery, How do you know, 3 weeks post op, that your sex life wont be the same? It is way too early to come to such a conclusion. Most guys dont have Erectile Function right away. Sure, some guys dont get it back. Many though get it back in 6 months to a year. In fact, i read a post in another forum yesterday, about a guy who finally, without pills, injections or anything, suddenly experienced a return to somewhat normal function, 2 years after surgery. I think now is a good time to take one day at a time. Its way too early. And if he doesn't get it back, there are choices.

This is your life, don't take "I don't know " for an answer
