Posts.Title: Stress is over for another 6 months

Posts.Content: Lantz - most people who know such things will tell you that prostate cancer doesnt usually kill people. Unless its aggressive and is not treated. You had 7 lymph nodes positive. The cancer is very possibly swimming around your body right now. Your PSA after surgery should be undetectable. Most people get nervous if it is .1, or .2. Yours is 4.7. And doing just a rough calculation in my head, from only the two post op tests, the doubling time seems to be around 4-5 months. These are all signs of failed surgery and aggressive cancer. Dead people cant work. So i would call your new job an important, but secondary consideration, second only to your health. I'm sorry to be so blunt. But unless i completely misunderstood your original post, its really important that you VERY QUICKLY find a good Medical Oncologist, preferably one whose main focus is Prostate Cancer, and if possible, at a major NCCN Cancer Center. Good luck and please keep us posted.

But the side effects from death are the only alternative

Posts.Title: Am I waiting too long?

Posts.Content: I don't know if Cancered is a word, but i mean, I'm burnt out from thinking about this. This last round of seeing the RO with a new PSA and discussing the actual probability of needing treatment, has really gotten to me. Pretty much the first thing i think about in the morning, the last thing i think about in the evening, and the only thing i read about in between. I'm really sick of it. I'm not complaining about my situation, a lot of guys here have it way worse than me, and even with a probable recurrence, i know i am in a decent position. Its just taking a mental toll on me. Maybe its a cumulative effe ct. Never sick a day in my life, then... Nov 2014 PC DX Jan 15 RALP June 15 Cardiac Cath 2 stents CT Heart Scan, Heavy Coronary Artery Plaque Sept 16 Wife rushed to ER, couldn't breath, DX Cancer 3 months chemo major surgery 3 more months chem Jan 17 - BCR begins March 17 - Daughter gets married, great guy - YAY something good Dec 17 - great guy son in law has surgery, high likelyhood of Thyroid cancer - thank God benign, still it was traumatic June 18 - daughter had traumatic event (she's ok thank God but i dont wanna talk about it. I think i have Medical PTSD. I need to find a way to rip it out of my brain at least for a while. Not healthy. I have a fitbit. It tracks a lot of things, including heartbeat, which i have tested, its very accurate. My resting HR is usually around 50-54, Since my visit with the Rad Onc on Tuesday, its risen to 60. The graph is amazing to look at (the app creates a graph, no, I'm not charting it. Not good for my already shitty health. Just blowing off some steam. Thanks for letting me do it.

Posts.Title: psa

Posts.Content: The 4 year timeline of average time from Mets to bones, till death, is, I believe, WITH treatment (Chuck, correct me if I'm mistaken). Without treatment it likely will be quicker. And yes, as Micheal stated, Hormone therapy could stop the cancer, even make it regress, possibly for a long period of time, giving your dad not only more years, but better quality of life. (But not without side effects of its own) I would urge your dad to seek medical attention. There is no reason for him to suffer in pain, and live a shorter life than necessary.

Posts.Title: MRI results

Posts.Content: mjim, welcome, sorry you have to be here. Well the good news is, Gleason 6 is not a very aggressive cancer. In fact, many Drs will recommend Active Surviellance rather than surgery or radiation, with a G6. Although, the fact that you had positive samples from both sides of the prostate might disqualify you from some AS programs. Question: Did you investigate other options besides surgery? I dont want to put a monkey wrench in your plan, and keep in mind, I'm a surgery guy, and was succesfully (so far) treated, with no long lasting side effects. But i think its really important to look at all options before cutting. Also did you ask a lot of questions about the experience and results of your surgeon? Robotic? Open? How many surgeries under his belt (my opinion is you want at least 1000, some say 300). Whats his % of positive margins, what % of his patients regain full continence, full erectile functions. The reality is that most urologists surgeons, and they will recommend surgery. But there are many other options (brachy (seeds or HDR), sbrt (Cyberknife cousin), etc. Even if you want surgery, you should explore them. If you do this you will be more confident in your final decision. There is no rush with a G6. Although keep in mind that 30% of surgery cases have their Gleason score upgraded on final pathology after surgery (i was, and thats why i chose surgery, i wanted to know the real pathology). There are two books you should read, "Surviving Prostate Cancer" by Dr Patrick Walsh, and Invasion of the Prostate Snatchers" by Dr Mark Scholz. The first is written by a world reknowned surgeon, and the second by a Dr who is a big proponent of not overtreating, and doing AS where it makes sense. If you read both books it will give you not only a good education, but both points of view, and it will help you make good decisions I hope i have not clouded your thought process and your decisiveness, i am hoping to just be sure you have thought this through, and done your due dilligence.

Posts.Title: Can anyone advise me

Posts.Content: On another forum there is a robust discussion about test sensitivity, and it was mentioned by one poster that his Dr told him that lately, they have seen a lot of guys coming back wh were formerly undetectable, with.1 readings, specifically from Quest Diagnostics. In the posters caw, I think he said he came back with .1, then tested at Labcorp, and it came back undetectable. I'm curious if guys here have either experienced this or heard anything about it. Obviously there are variations from lab to lab. But uPSA fluctuations between <.01 and .1 is more than noise. I'm concerned about this, because I had my 9 month blood draw today at Quest labs, and will now be on edge for a week, waiting for results. If it comes back detectable, let alone .1, I'll likely fall down and break my skull

Posts.Title: I am in the zero club!!!!!

Posts.Content: mjim, welcome, sorry you have to be here. Well the good news is, Gleason 6 is not a very aggressive cancer. In fact, many Drs will recommend Active Surviellance rather than surgery or radiation, with a G6. Although, the fact that you had positive samples from both sides of the prostate might disqualify you from some AS programs. Question: Did you investigate other options besides surgery? I dont want to put a monkey wrench in your plan, and keep in mind, I'm a surgery guy, and was succesfully (so far) treated, with no long lasting side effects. But i think its really important to look at all options before cutting. Also did you ask a lot of questions about the experience and results of your surgeon? Robotic? Open? How many surgeries under his belt (my opinion is you want at least 1000, some say 300). Whats his % of positive margins, what % of his patients regain full continence, full erectile functions. The reality is that most urologists surgeons, and they will recommend surgery. But there are many other options (brachy (seeds or HDR), sbrt (Cyberknife cousin), etc. Even if you want surgery, you should explore them. If you do this you will be more confident in your final decision. There is no rush with a G6. Although keep in mind that 30% of surgery cases have their Gleason score upgraded on final pathology after surgery (i was, and thats why i chose surgery, i wanted to know the real pathology). There are two books you should read, "Surviving Prostate Cancer" by Dr Patrick Walsh, and Invasion of the Prostate Snatchers" by Dr Mark Scholz. The first is written by a world reknowned surgeon, and the second by a Dr who is a big proponent of not overtreating, and doing AS where it makes sense. If you read both books it will give you not only a good education, but both points of view, and it will help you make good decisions I hope i have not clouded your thought process and your decisiveness, i am hoping to just be sure you have thought this through, and done your due dilligence.

Posts.Title: Walking/Exercise Post Surgery

Posts.Content: Well, my biopsy was done this morning, and it was not even close to as bad as i expected. The Uro saw i was really nervous (and looped from the Xanax) and i told him i had a low pain threshold and had heard some horror stories. And i asked him if he could just make sure to wait until the lidocaine really kicked in before getting into his shoot-em-up with the gun, it would be appreciated. He was really good. Very careful, went in slow as promised, and i really felt no pain at all, only, as someone here said, a little annoyance. So thank God thats over. I have a little of my sanity back, even though still out of it from the Xanax. I think i can stay relaxed until early next week, as I get closer to getting the results. Doc is out next week, so i asked him to call me with results rather than make an appointment and having to wait two weeks. I asked his assistant to email me when the results come in, and give me an idea of when i will get the call. I would hate to be sitting at lunch with a client and get a call from the doc telling me i have cancer. From the Biopsy itself, he said my prostate was 33 grms, (i think its grams), higher than the "normal" 20 gms, but normally bigger for my age. So i am hoping that could be the reason for the PSA rise. Also he said that there was nothing abnormal that he saw in the ultrasound, and re-iterated that my DRE last week was totally normal. So i am cautiously optimistic. Interesting point: last week he did the DRE before sending me for psa bloodwork, and it jumped to 2.7 (from 2.2 a week earler). I know it might be attributed to different lab, and normal fluctiations, but i also asked him today if it could be a result of the DRE being done prior to the PSA. His response surprised me - he said that they don;t really believe, like many do, that PSA is elevated if done after a DRE. From all I've read here, i would scratch my head. But this place is one of the top 5 urology hospitals in the U.S. And the doc has great credentials, is published, does a lot of research etc. Wierd. Anyway, nothing to do now but wait a week or 10 days.
Posts.Title: Biopsy Done - whew!!

Posts.Content: one more thing - a question - re psa Density - Am i correct that PSA density is your PSA reading divided by the size? If so, my psa of 2.2 (ignoring the 2.7) divided by size of 33grms means i have a density of .06. Does anyone know if thats correct, and if so, if thats good or bad in terms of potential diagnosis?

Posts.Content: There was a recent, i believe, large, study, that showed benefit to starting Salvage Radiation Therapy, when PSA hits .03, rather than the traidtional .2, or .1 that some Uro's are now using. This applies, according to the study, when the surgical pathology is more aggressive, i.e. ECE present. https://prostatecancerinfolink.net/2...d-saves-lives/

Posts.Title: Biopsy Done - whew!!

Posts.Content: When he says hard 7, he is referring to the (4+3), which means it was Gleason 7, made up of a majority of grade 4 cells, with grade 3 (the indolent kind) being anywhere from 5-49% of the core. This is, as opposed to a Gleason 7 (3+4) which tends to be less aggressive, as the majority of cells in that core would have been grade 3, less aggressive. In either case, stay positive, because you were not a gleason 8, 9 or 10, which are way more aggressive. What you want to know is after surgery and after examinging the entire prostate, are you still G7 (4+3) OR were you upgraded to a higher gleason, which happens about 30% of the time (i was upgraded), or were you downgraded to a G6 which happens less frequently but does happen (and would be fantastic news) And as others have said, were your margins negative was there any evidence of escape from the prostate capsule, was there any lymph node involvement, seminal vesicle involvement. Also did the surgeon leave the nerve bundles (controlling ED) intact, or did he have to take part or all of them. Keep in mind that he most important thing aside from Gleason score, is negative margins, i think even more important than escape from the prostate. You could have cells that have escaped from the prostate, but still have negative margins and that would be good.

Posts.Title: Questions to ask surgeon at pathology report

Posts.Content: I don't know if Cancered is a word, but i mean, I'm burnt out from thinking about this. This last round of seeing the RO with a new PSA and discussing the actual probability of needing treatment, has really gotten to me. Pretty much the first thing i think about in the morning, the last thing i think about in the evening, and the only thing i read about in between. I'm really sick of it. I'm not complaining about my situation, a lot of guys here have it way worse than me, and even with a probable recurrence, i know i am in a decent position. Its just taking a mental toll on me. Maybe its a cumulative effe ct. Never sick a day in my life, then... Nov 2014 PC DX Jan 15 RALP June 15 Cardiac Cath 2 stents CT Heart Scan, Heavy Coronary Artery Plaque Sept 16 Wife rushed to ER, couldn't breath, DX Cancer 3 months chemo major surgery 3 more months chem Jan 17 - BCR begins March 17 - Daughter gets married, great guy - YAY something good Dec 17 - great guy son in law has surgery, high likelyhood of Thyroid cancer - thank God benign, still it was traumatic June 18 - daughter had traumatic event (she's ok thank God but i dont wanna talk about it. I think i have Medical PTSD. I need to find a way to rip it out of my brain at least for a while. Not healthy. I have a fitbit. It tracks a lot of things, including heartbeat, which i have tested, its very accurate. My resting HR is usually around 50-54, Since my visit with the Rad Onc on Tuesday, its risen to 60. The graph is amazing to look at (the app creates a graph, no, I'm not charting it. Not good for my already shitty health. Just blowing off some steam. Thanks for letting me do it.

Johns Hopkins second opinion, G6, G6, G6 Surgery with Dr Ash Tewari Jan 6, 2015 Post surgical pathology, stage T2c, bilateral disease, upstaged to G7(3+4) 5% of Prostate involved in Tumor. Posts.Title: MRI results

Posts.Content: AMri results, then visit with surgeon for results... One lesion noted, same place as one of the three biopsy cores, surgeon says it was consistent as to location, it may be a G6 as biopsy evaluation said, or may be higher. No evidence of extra capsular extension, seminal vehicle or lymph node involvement Pretty much made my decision, I'm doing surgery. Will keep my follow up appointment with RO next week for his assesment on MRI, But unless he says something that blows me away I'm going to surgery, scheduled for January 6. Wish it was tomorrow.

Posts.Title: New battle to commence

Posts.Content: Ernest, sorry to see your PSA jumping around like that. I'm in a "similar, but not quite the same" boat. Surgery January 2015, by Tewari, rock star surgeon at my Sinai in NYC. Undetectable at <.02 until the 2 year mark when I hit .02 (no <). Five months later, May 2015, .033 (different lab). Next test coming up in a few weeks. Like your surgeon mine said he's not worried. I told him if it was his prostate cancer I wouldn't be worried either. He said they do nothing until it hits .1, at which time he would do imaging, which I don't understand because at .1 most conventional imaging won't show anything. I took it upon myself to go and see Dr. Zelefsky , vice chair of radiation oncologyat MSKCC , and really well known and respected for PC. He told me that at this point he would not call it a probable recover expect a possible tou he told me that at this point he would not call it a probable recurrence only a POSSIBLE recurrence. Said he is not inclined to wait for some magic number, like .1, he would treat as soon as a clear trend was evident. There have been numerous studies showing that earlier Salvage radiation treatment successful when surgery fails If I were in your shoes, I would start testing more frequently and if it keeps rising, hit it. Regarding your second question, I wouldn't depend on my surgeon for ADT. ID want that decision made by a medical oncologist, or in the case of add as an adjunct to Salvage radiation, I'd depend on the radiation oncologist. Let's hope neither of us ever identifies a clear upward trend. I truly hope your PSA drops at the next test if it doesn't I'd start considering treatment. Keep us posted

Posts.Title: Cancered Out

Posts.Content: Mitch, as you know, about 30% of patients treated with surgery are upgraded (as I was). It stands to reason the more biopsies you have the more total cores looked t, so the odds do go down somewhat. But of course you can never be sure (you can never be sure.....the curse of all types of cancer) I believe I recall in one of our conversations that you had decided no more biopsies if your PSA remained more or less stable. If I'm correct, is there something that's making you change your thoughts on that?

Posts.Title: Metastatic prostate cancer

Posts.Content: Another, you make an excellent point. When I lost my "<" and went from <.02 to .02, my Dr said "I'm not worried at this point". Guess what. I wouldn't worry if it was HIS prostate either. I would hve rather heard "this may or may not be a precursor to BCR. If it turns out to be the latter, here's what might happen/here are your options. I think also, a part of the problem, at least for the guys who had surgery, is the Dr. who does the PSA and then naturally, has the discussion (or non discussion) with you, is a surgeon. Not an MO, or RO. If I see my next test or two continue to trend up, or it gets to .04, m not waiting for .1 or .2. I'm not asking my surgeon what happens next. I'm headed to the best RO I can find to at least discuss, then I'm contacting an MO that specializes in PC for guidance. It's all on us, we need to decide what should prompt action. Not the Drs. At lest up to a point

Posts.Title: 2 more days before surgery

Posts.Content: Well, my biopsy was done this morning, and it was not even close to as bad as i expected. The Uro saw i was really nervous (and looped from the Xanax) and i told him i had a low pain threshold and had heard some horror stories. And i asked him if he could just make sure to wait until the lidocaine really kicked in before getting into his shoot-em-up with the gun, it would be appreciated. He was really good. Very careful, went in slow as promised, and i really felt no pain at all, only, as someone here said, a little annoyance. So thank God thats over. I have a little of my sanity back, even though still out of it from the Xanax. I think i can stay relaxed until early next week, as I get closer to getting the results. Doc is out next week, so i asked him to call me with results rather than make an appointment and having to wait two weeks. I asked his assistant to email me when the results come in, and give me an idea of when i will get the call. I would hate to be sitting at lunch with a client and get a call from the doc telling me i have cancer. From the Biopsy itself, he said my prostate was 33 grms, (i think its grams), higher than the "normal" 20 gms, but normally bigger for my age. So i am hoping that could be the reason for the PSA rise. Also he said that there was nothing abnormal that he saw in the ultrasound, and re-iterated that my DRE last week was totally normal. So i am cautiously optimistic. Interesting point: last week he did the DRE before sending me for psa bloodwork, and it jumped to 2.7 (from 2.2 a week earler). I know it might be attributed to different lab, and normal fluctiations, but i also asked him today if it could be a result of the DRE being done prior to the PSA. His response surprised me - he said that they don;t really believe, like many do, that PSA is elevated if done after a DRE. From all I've read here, i would scratch my head. But this place is one of the top 5 urology hospitals in the U.S. And the doc has great credentials, is published, does a lot of research etc. Wierd. Anyway, nothing to do now but wait a week or 10 days.

Posts.Title: Active Surveillance Cancer Upgrade Question

Posts.Content: Thanks everyone for the hopeful comments, and for the warm welcome back. Intellectually I know that it could very well be a statistical anamoly. Emotionally though, as I'm sure everyone here knows, it's a killer of a thing to anticipate. It could go either way as we all know. The question is what was the last result 6 months ago? Was the true number .001? Or was it .019. I can't know that because the assay only measures to anything .02 or higher, thus the result <.02. If the true number was .001, I've got a problem. If it was .019, then a move to .020 is insignificant for sure. Then if it's positive again, and turns out it's a Recurrence, how do I know when it recurred. Might have been w months ago. Do we assume it was 2 years, since the test was done 2 years post RALP? Or could it have started soon fire my last test 6bmonths ago? Unknowable. The NP when she called with the result 3. Weeks ago told me they still consider it undetectable. But the fact is, it was measurable. I was told they don't really worry bout it until it hits .1. If in fact this is a recurrence, I don't plan on waiting that long. If it gets to .05, maybe .04, I'm off to see the nuke specialist. Which, from what I understand has a lower chance of working, when you had positive margins. So you can see, my head, which had been fairly com up until a day or two, is spinning. @ron, Chuck, I her you on the uPSA vs STANDARD PSA. But I think once you start with uPSA, it's hard to go back. And I would want to know sooner, if it's creeping up. @Micheal - my first few tests were done at Quest, and were all <.02. Then I had. 3 month test come back at 3.8 (no typo) which was an error that the Senior VP of oncology testing could not figure out how it happened, (I had a phone call with him because I was pissed) and I lost confidence in their process no started testing at my DRs (Tewari) hospital lab , mt Sinai in NY. The first two of those tests came back at 0.00, that's how they report it. Then the next two came back at <.02. I scrutinized those reports and found that the two 0.00's were a different assay than the last two. Now, the .02 reading without the <, was done on the same assay as the last two <02's. So I don't think it's the assay. I guess I'll know more tomorrow, seeing the Dr at 11am, but will likely get a phone call with the results by 9:30-9:45. I'll report back Thanks again.

Posts.Title: I'm back, with less than great news

Posts.Content: I've been way from here for a while, preoccupied with other family health issues. If it's not one thing, it's another. Like Brandon's dad, I am facing a possible issue, not yet sure though. RALP JAN 2015, (3+4), negative margins and begtive ECE. uPSA post RALP has consistently been <.02. Until 3 weeks go t my 2 year test, when it came back at .02. Nurse practitioner called me with results NS told me it's still considered undetectable. But clearly, it was measurable, unlike previous tests. They suggested retest at my Drs appointment which is scheduled for this Friday. I am going in tomorrow for the blood draw so he has the results when I see him. I know it could be a blip. Or maybe not. Shitting bricks tonight. Ken

Posts.Title: 19 months post surgery, 1 year since finished SRT, what is up with this?

Posts.Content: Tony welcome to the forum. You’ve got persistent PSA meaning, after surgery, it never went to undetectable. In addition a 3 month rise from .03 to .12 is pretty fast velocity. I would retest PSA to make sure the .12 is not lab error. Once you rule that out, I think you should get started with SRT as soon as feasible. But I’m not a doctor. Or even one of the more knowledgeable guys here. Did the Dr mention hormone therapy with the SRT?

Posts.Title: RP done, post op PSA concern - urgent advise needed

Posts.Content: OTS, this is a personal decision. But my opinion is that 3 hours is a long drive to do each day each way. To me it would be undoable. Even 3 hours round trip would be a stretch. Don’t forget, the last couple of weeks you may be fatigued. And I don’t recall but if you are doing HT, even tougher. I am planning on doing an hour commute each way, which I anticipate to be a grind, but I’ll take public transportation, and probably do it only w-4 days a week, stay at a friends apartment the other two days. If you can afford the most comfortable option, I’d look for a hotel, maybe an extended stay place, like Residence Inn by Marriott. In fact, ask the hospital you get treated at, they may have some options for out of town patients, or a deal for patient discounts with local hotels.

Posts.Title: Logistics & Planning for 9-weeks treatment far from home

Posts.Content: The first thing you should do IMO, is ask that the slides be sent for a second opinion at Johns Hopkins, Dr Jonathan Epstein, who is a foremost prostate cancer specific pathologist. if you got downgraded to G6 it might make active surviellance much more attractive. Reading prostate slides is very subjective, and should be done by a prostate expert. Most local pathologists read many different types of slides. Even if they specialize in Genoutory pathology, they look at prostate, bladder, kidney, ovarian, etc.

Posts.Title: RP done, post op PSA concern - urgent advise needed

Posts.Content: Tony, most doctors recommend Hormone Therapy IN CONJUNCTION WITH SRT these days, especially with g7 (4+3) or greater. But with favorable intermediate risk of g7(3+4), and a PSA thatbis still relatively low, you can probably avoid HT for now. Just my opinion, like I said I’m not a doc. Qualifier....my RO at MSKCC said with my current PSA at .07, he would be comfortable with me not doing HT with SRT. But if I waited until my PSA got to .1, he would be “much less comfortable”. (I too, am g7(3+4) That’s his opinion, and while he’s a top RO, there is no black and white answer, it’s all a judgement call.

Posts.Title: RP done, post op PSA concern - urgent advise needed

Posts.Content: Run away from this oncologist as fast as you camps, he is incompetent. First of all, in telling you there are no side effects from HT and radiation, he is lying. Period. Second of all, the point of "Watchful waiting" is to not let it get this far in the first place. He should have commended further investigation with an MRI and fusion guided biopsy followed by possible treatment at the first sign of PSA on the move. This is why the call it Active Surviellance now, rather than watchful waiting. The operative word is ACTIVE. I can't help but asking, so I apologize, but are you sure you got the whole, real story for your uncle, and he is not misinterpreting what the Dr is telling him? It's quite unbelievable that a Dr would put someone on active Surviellance for three years, wit till PSA gets to 33, then say no side effects from HT and Radiation. Sorry to be so direct

Posts.Title: Life Expectancy Expected To Rise To 80 By 2030

Posts.Content: Sorry about your diagnosis Mike. But as Highlander said, there's plenty of hope. As far as different Drs , different systems, you will get a referral from the urologist to an oncologist, but you don't have to take it. You can see anyone you want. Try to be sure that whatever oncologist you see, has plenty of experience with aggressive prostate cancer. And don't be railroaded into one treatment or bother. Do your own research, be your own advocate. Find a Dr you trust and are comfortable with. Don't just go with the flow

Posts.Title: Just got diagnosis

Posts.Content: It was called to my attention, that i never posted my results which i got last week. How i forgot to do so is beyond me, i guess i was so preoccupied with my cardiac issues and other things i was dealing with, my head just wasnt on straight. So my 6 month post surgery PSA came back at <.02. AGAIN. Now i can breathe for another 3 months. If i get that same result 2 more times, in October and January, they will tell me to not come back for 6 months. Keeping my fingers crossed. That would be sweet

Posts.Title: PSA Results all good

Posts.Content: Thanks everyone for the hopeful comments, and for the warm welcome back. Intellectually I know that it could very well be a statistical anamoly. Emotionally though, as I'm sure everyone here knows, it's a killer of a thing to anticipate. It could go either way as we all know. The question is what was the last result 6 months ago? Was the true number .001? Or was it .019. I can't know that because the assay only measures to anything .02 or higher, thus the result <.02. If the true number was .001, I've got a problem. If it was .019, then a move to .020 is insignificant for sure. Then if it's positive again, and turns out it's a Recurrence, how do I know when it recurred. Might have been w months ago. Do we assume it was 2 years, since the test was done 2 years post RALP? Or could it have started soon fire my last test 6bmonths ago? Unknowable. The NP when she called with the result 3. Weeks ago told me they still consider it undetectable. But the fact is, it was measurable. I was told they don't really worry bout it until it hits .1. If in fact this is a recurrence, I don't plan on waiting that long. If it gets to .05, maybe .04, I'm off to see the nuke specialist. Which, from what I understand has a lower chance of working, when you had positive margins. So you can see, my head, which had been fairly com up until a day or two, is spinning. @ron, Chuck, I her you on the uPSA vs STANDARD PSA. But I think once you start with uPSA, it's hard to go back. And I would want to know sooner, if it's creeping up. @Micheal - my first few tests were done at Quest, and were all <.02. Then I had. 3 month test come back at 3.8 (no typo) which was an error that the Senior VP of oncology testing could not figure out how it happened, (I had a phone call with him because I was pissed) and I lost confidence in their process no started testing at my DRs (Tewari) hospital lab , mt Sinai in NY. The first two of those tests came back at 0.00, that's how they report it. Then the next two came back at <.02. I scrutinized those reports and found that the two 0.00's were a different assay than the last two. Now, the .02 reading without the <, was done on the same assay as the last two <02's. So I don't think it's the assay. I guess I'll know more tomorrow, seeing the Dr at 11am, but will likely get a phone call with the results by 9:30-9:45. I'll report back Thanks again.

Posts.Title: I'm back, with less than great news

Posts.Content: Brad, I have no doubt that it was lab error. It happens. Happened to me. I went to Quest for my 9 month post op PSA and it came back 3.88, just 3 months after my 6 month test which was 0.00! My Dr took another blood sample and had it tested at his hospital lab, and it ca,e back 0.00. When Quest retested my same blood it came back <.02. AND THEY HAD NO EXPLANATION, THEY JUST COULDNT TELL ME WHAT HAPPENED BECAUSE THEY DIDNT KNOW!! It shouldn't happen. But it does. But in any case, congratulations great relief for you.

Posts.Title: Time for some good news.

Posts.Content: Trinity, tough call. Unfortunately i dont have experience so no suggestions. I do think i would have a tough time doing rad if PSA was undetectable. On the other hand, with a G9 positive margin, i guess it makes sense. I think the most important thing you can do is find the most experienced, well reputed, RO you can find to do the job, assuming you go ahead with it. Also consider consulting with a medical oncologist. Suggestion - Prostate Oncology Associates in Marina Del Rey California. I did a phone consult with them. They get all yoru records, and then do a one hour phone call for $600. Drs Scholz (wrote the book "invasion of the Prostate Snatchers", Dr Turner, and Dr Lam, all have great reps and all they do is prostate cancer.

Posts.Title: Surgery Results

Posts.Content: I am 38000 feet up, on my way home from a 10 day trip to Baton Rouge, Orlando, and Lake Worth, Florida, all for different reasons. While I was gone, I didn't spend as much time on this forum, the other PC forum I'm on, or the ovarian cancer forum I'm on. Not completely off the forums, but much less, mostly because I was very busy. I have to say, it was a great respite. I thought less about cancer. Which was nice, because lately it seems like cancer has occupied my thoughts more than any other topic. Which truly sucks. Anyone else feel this way? Anyway, my respite is about to end. I'll be back at work on Monday, and on Friday I have an appointment with my urologist. Which means -on Tuesday, Wednesday or Thursday, (haven't decided yet) I'll go for my blood draw for PSA. January was 2 years since surgery, and up till then I was <.02. But in January, then again in February I lost the <, and I was .02 both times. So this 3 month test is a big one for me, and I'm starting to sweat. On top of that, my wife is having a CT Scan on Friday, 1st one since finishing chemo for ovarian cncer, 5 weeks ago. She won't get the results for 10 days, when she sees the Dr. But I'll get my results the next day. So I don't know if I should have the blood draw 1, 2 or 3 days before the appointment. The only reason I'm c0nsidering Tuesday is because I have to be in Manhattan that day for business, and it would save me a Trip. But if I do it Tuesday, I will get the results Wednesday, and if it's higher (showing a trend) then I have to wait 2 days to see the Dr and have him talk me off the ledge. What to do, what to do. Just venting, thanks for listening. I really really don't want to recur.😰 (call me Captain Obvious)🙄

Posts.Title: Sweating Bullets

Posts.Content: Not much to add, just wanted to say welcome. Re the blood in urine - i had clots on and off for about 6 weeks. I was told it could last up to 8 weeks, and is a normal part of healing, nothing to be concerned about as long as its not heavy blood. He'll see more of it when he is active, less when he is sitting or lying down and not moving around.

Posts.Content: I have read that the shrinkage can be due to the shortening of the urethra when it is reattached to the bladder, thereby pulling in the penis. Not shore how accurate that is. I would be leery of any supplement that claims to affect my dick in any way. Especially in view of the fact that it's unregulated. Who knows if it contains a substance that can promote Cancer

Posts.Title: Just got diagnosis

Posts.Content: I've been way from here for a while, preoccupied with other family health issues. If it's not one thing, it's another. Like Brandon's dad, I am facing a possible issue, not yet sure though. RALP JAN 2015, (3+4), negative margins and begtive ECE. uPSA post RALP has consistently been <.02. Until 3 weeks go t my 2 year test, when it came back at .02. Nurse practitioner called me with results NS told me it's still considered undetectable. But clearly, it was measurable, unlike previous tests. They suggested retest at my Drs appointment which is scheduled for this Friday. I am going in tomorrow for the blood draw so he has the results when I see him. I know it could be a blip. Or maybe not. Shitting bricks tonight. Ken

Posts.Title: DDay

Posts.Content: Everything that Another said, x 1000. I try to follow the principles he laid out. Not always easy. For me the toughest is limited dairy , no added sugar, and daily exercise. But i try. And if you are going to supplement, make sure 1. you purchase well known, reputable brands like Solgar, Life Extension, etc. Although that too is no guarantee. There will never be large randomized control studies of vitamins and cancer, because its not profitable for the drug companies to fund them, and its too expensive for the supplement industry to do so (not that you would want them to).

Posts.Title: Early Salvage Radiation

Posts.Content: Hello Guys, its been a while. To those of you who have been here a while, its good (sort of) to be back, although not for the reasons Im here. So it looks like I may very well be headed for radiation treatments. And its been recommended I do so early. Im at .06 as of March, just to make it easy, Im going to cut and paste the post I put up on another forum, with the background, for the guys here that are new enough to not know my backstory....any comments are welcome and appreciated. At the reco of a friend/member here, I met today with the chair of RAd Onc at Cleveland Clinic in Florida. It was a long meeting, and very informative. The short version is.... He recommends treating soon (to review, I was undetectable until the 2 year post op mark, then .02, .033, .033, .046, 060, see signature below) he cited this study... /jamanetwork.com/journals/jamaoncology/article-abstract/2670381?redirect=true A multi institutional study with n=1566, it showed an advantage to treating below .1, vs treating .1 - .5. The entire cohort was adverse pathology. While I had negative final margins, the RO felt that because my frozen section intraoperative margin was positive, and at the apex, my negative final margin was questionable, and he placed a high probability on the PSA coming from cells left in the prostate bed, thus a relatively high probability of a good result. He said if I wanted to wait a few months he didnt think it would put me at increased risk. He didnt put too much weight into my low Decipher score, saying I could be one of the 3% that has recurrence, nor did he put much weight in the oncoDx Grid report that predicted poor response to SRT, saying there was not enough data to validate it yet, too small a sample. I also asked him what he thinks might happen if I decided to do nothing. His response, a 50% chance that 10 years from now I would be living a happy life with no issues related to PC. And a 50% chance that Id have some serious problems in 10 years. I dont like those odds. He said with their machine, Varian Edge, I think, the chance of permanent side effects was less than 5% (but I should expect transient side effects) I am meeting with Dr Zelefsky, RO at MSKCC, mid June. I will have one more PSA before that meeting. I am inclined to look fir one more increased PSA after the Zelefsky meeting, then taking action, although that also depends on what the pre-Zelefsky PSA shows. Ive pretty much tossed aside my Surgeons advice to do nothing until/unless i get to .2. I wish their was a black and white answer, but there apparently is not. So the beat goes on. One thing I did not ask, is whether Medicare would approve early Salvage . Anybody know the answer from experience?

Posts.Content: I've been way from here for a while, preoccupied with other family health issues. If it's not one thing, it's another. Like Brandon's dad, I am facing a possible issue, not yet sure though. RALP JAN 2015, (3+4), negative margins and begtive ECE. uPSA post RALP has consistently been <.02. Until 3 weeks go t my 2 year test, when it came back at .02. Nurse practitioner called me with results NS told me it's still considered undetectable. But clearly, it was measurable, unlike previous tests. They suggested retest at my Drs appointment which is scheduled for this Friday. I am going in tomorrow for the blood draw so he has the results when I see him. I know it could be a blip. Or maybe not. Shitting bricks tonight. Ken

Posts.Title: I'm back, with less than great news

Posts.Content: Chuck, i could be wrong, apologies if thats the case. But my understanding is that after RP surgery, they consider a BCR/Bio Chemical Recurrence, to be a rise to .1, followed by a second reading at that number or higher. After radiation, it would be a rise from nadir, followed by 2 consecutive rises after that. To Thewife - your husband is lucky to have you as his advocate. I AGREE with you that waiting 6 months is too long. If i were you i would ask him what the number is that he uses to signal BCR, and at what point he would recommend SRT. And i would also insist on a PSA retake sooner than 6 months. In fact, i would be asking for a retake in 2 months, 3 max. Also, there have been studies done that have shown in certain situations, the max benefit from SRT comes if its started earler, as early as PSA of .03. I do not recall 100%, but i think that was a study done specifically on G8-10 patients, so if thats the case, it may not apply. Good luck, please keep us posted

Posts.Title: New here - H has rising PSA following surgery

Posts.Content: Everyone is different and every experience is different, I am 7 weeks out from RALP. I have been fully continent (meaning no pads, but just a squirt here and there, mostly stress related, not enough to need to wear anything). BUT.... Tonight, lying in bed, watching TV, I fell asleep for about 40 minutes. Suddenly, I woke up, and realized that I was wet. VERY wet. Soaked thru my briefs and gym shorts. There was even a small wet spot in the blanket covering me. WTH? I had a strong urge to pee, and got up, was able to control it, then, when in the bathroom,took the longest pee I've taken since the catheter came out No idea where this came from, I guess I'm not really continent. Very frustrating, and scary. Anyone experience this?

Posts.Title: DDay

Posts.Content: Steve, so sorry for your horrible experience. To not treat, is a very personal decision. At age 81, I can definitely understand it. Not saying it would be my decision, but I get it. In fact there's a good chance that something else will do you in other than prostate cancer, which is usually a slow growing, highly treatable disease. Did you get the pathology report? What was your Gleason score/Grade? As far as biopsy, you've had an unfortunate experience to say the least, and a highly unusual one. What does the urologist say about it? I truly hope your symptoms resolve. Generally speaking, biopsy should be a fairly benign procedure, without such extreme consequences. And unfortunately, it's the only way to get a definitive diagnosis, so often, it's necessary. Wishing you best of luck, hope you recover from this and have many years left to enjoy life.

Posts.Title: Sweating Bullets

Posts.Content: You process the information that is relevant to go. And your case. There will be enough studies coming out and new ones to contradict each other. For me it was mindset. There is more to it than just the raw data. There was an argument to be made for me to do AS. But I'm not wired for it. So while I read a ton, all that was relevant yo me was an RO at MSKCC telling me that in my situation the cure rate was the same whether I did surgery or radiation. Get as educated as you can then Filter out what you don't need to know.

Posts.Title: Post RP

Posts.Content: Thanks Highlander, i appreciate the insight. I should clarify - when the doc said the DRE was normal (he actually used the word 'fine") i believe what he meant was (based on our conversation from the last visit) that there were no lumps and it was soft. I know that my prostate is somewhat enlarged (dont know how much) because i have been told that a couple of times over the last 10 years or so, but in the context of it being "normally enlarged for my age". Also, Highlander, no i have no urinary symptoms. I get up once at night, SOMETIMES, but i do dring a ton of water, even at night. I dont have dripping. My stream is not what i would consider weak, although i dont piss like a racehorse the way i did in my 30's. So I am pretty much asymptomatic. I am going to go ahead with the visit to Columbia - i might have mentioned in the previous post, i am seeing the Co-Director of the Dept of Urology - just to be complete. But i think i have decided that i after seeing him, unless he surprises me by telling me something different, i am going to have the biopsy. I am too nervous about it. I actually had to take a xanax tonight, so i don't want to live like this for three more months, or even six weeks. In addition to which i dowloaded the Dr. Patrick Walsh book and read the chapter on PSA and DRE screening, and he seems to indicate that i am clearly biopsy material. Curious - i mentioned also in a previous post, when i asked my current doc about pain management he seemed rather flip about it, he said its no big deal, he just gives " a little lydocaine around the area of the prostate" , and when asked said he doesnt numb the area prior to the lydocaine injection. No gel either. Is that standard? Should i be looking for something different? I don't have a great tolerance level for pain. Thanks again, in advance to everyone. I can't say you guys are calming me down, but you have been a big help.

Posts.Title: PSA Rising, Need Guidance

Posts.Content: Went to Urologist today, PSA continues to rise - facts and numbers as follows: Age - just turned 62 Father had Prostate Cancer PSA Levels: 2009 - .7 2010 - 1.1 2011 - did not take April 2012 - 1.7 (or 1.6, not clear) Nov 2012 - 2.2 Got the 2.2 results today. Doc did digital rectal exam, prostate felt normal. Gave me choice - biopsy now, or wait 3 months. Told me, while you can never be sure, he feels 3 months wait would not present any real risks. I asked what he would do if it was him - he said he would do the biopsy, and he has, in a similar situation. Said the threshold at my age is 3.5, but rising level, with family history is cause for concern. I found an online calculator that showed the velocity is .37, not sure of the exact dates i put in but they weren't far off. I've read that there is controversy about how important velocity is. I told the doc i would come back in three months for retake but i dont know if i am doing the right thing I am in NY area, i hear Columbia Presbyterian has high reputation docs for this. Should i 1. do the biopsy 2. wait the three months and retake PSA 3. retake PSA in a month or two (doc didn't date the scrip) 3. get a second opinion immediately Also, do any docs put you to sleep for the biopsy? I've heard it is pretty painful. Very nervous, any guidance would be really appreciated.

Posts.Title: DDay

Posts.Content: Thanks for all the responses. Much appreciated. @Featherboy - the doc i am working with is the urologist. My primary care doc, who is a cardiologist, said i should do the biopsy, but i'm ignoring him on this one, he's the type that if i show up at his office with a cold, he sends me for a brain scan. Update - i called the urologist back, and asked him some questions (below with his responses) . I got the questions from readin this forum, and he said they were great questions, all the right one's, so thank you. i asked 1. should we do free psa, psa3, before doing a biopsy. His response was he generally does those tests when the PSA is above 4. Since my PSA is 2.2, he thinks the results wouldn't be useful 2. What about CIPRO? - His response was that he uses CIPRO alot, but its more likely to be an infection, when there is a sudden spike, as opposed to my situation which has been trending up over a few years, slowly 3. Would doing a biopsy with what might be such an apparently very early stage situation increase the chances of false negative? He said it wouldn't 4. does he use ultrasound to guide the biopsy - he said yes 5. what does he do about pain management - he said it wasn't really necessary, he just uses a little lydocaine around the prostate. I followed up with a question about gel to numb the area before the lydocaine injection, he said he doesnt use it , there is not that much pain frmo the lydocaine injection. He said regarding teh cipro, even though my situation was not typical of an infection it was worth a try (why didnt he try it before i brought it up?) So he gave me a prescription and said to retake in a month. I said ok. Last thing i told him was that he shouldn't be surprised if i request the records because i would go for a second opinion before i do anything invasive (like a biopsy). He was totally cool with that (as he should be, it wouldn't matter to me if he wasnt) So that leads me to my next move. I contacted a Doc who was recommended to me at Columbia Presbyterian, Dr DeCastro, for a second opinion, i am going to see him next Friday. Maybe I am wrong, but it bothers me that the doc i am seeing is a one doc practice in a small local office. He was recommended to me by my Primary Care Doc,but you know how that goes, they are all buddies. So i have no way of knowing who is good, but i figure at Columbia, they are well known in Urology, i think on a par with Hopkins, and why not consult with the best. So we'll see. I will be pretty nervous until this is resolved one way or the other, even though i know that if it turns out to be a problem, it is in all likelyhood very early and curable. I can't even imagine having an "i have cancer" conversation with my 29 - 30 year old kids, no matter how good the prognosis. I think thats what scares me most. It will be a long week. Thanks for letting me vent 3.

Posts.Title: DDay

Posts.Content: Thanks for all the responses. Much appreciated. @Featherboy - the doc i am working with is the urologist. My primary care doc, who is a cardiologist, said i should do the biopsy, but i'm ignoring him on this one, he's the type that if i show up at his office with a cold, he sends me for a brain scan. Update - i called the urologist back, and asked him some questions (below with his responses) . I got the questions from readin this forum, and he said they were great questions, all the right one's, so thank you. i asked 1. should we do free psa, psa3, before doing a biopsy. His response was he generally does those tests when the PSA is above 4. Since my PSA is 2.2, he thinks the results wouldn't be useful 2. What about CIPRO? - His response was that he uses CIPRO alot, but its more likely to be an infection, when there is a sudden spike, as opposed to my situation which has been trending up over a few years, slowly 3. Would doing a biopsy with what might be such an apparently very early stage situation increase the chances of false negative? He said it wouldn't 4. does he use ultrasound to guide the biopsy - he said yes 5. what does he do about pain management - he said it wasn't really necessary, he just uses a little lydocaine around the prostate. I followed up with a question about gel to numb the area before the lydocaine injection, he said he doesnt use it , there is not that much pain frmo the lydocaine injection. He said regarding teh cipro, even though my situation was not typical of an infection it was worth a try (why didnt he try it before i brought it up?) So he gave me a prescription and said to retake in a month. I said ok. Last thing i told him was that he shouldn't be surprised if i request the records because i would go for a second opinion before i do anything invasive (like a biopsy). He was totally cool with that (as he should be, it wouldn't matter to me if he wasnt) So that leads me to my next move. I contacted a Doc who was recommended to me at Columbia Presbyterian, Dr DeCastro, for a second opinion, i am going to see him next Friday. Maybe I am wrong, but it bothers me that the doc i am seeing is a one doc practice in a small local office. He was recommended to me by my Primary Care Doc,but you know how that goes, they are all buddies. So i have no way of knowing who is good, but i figure at Columbia, they are well known in Urology, i think on a par with Hopkins, and why not consult with the best. So we'll see. I will be pretty nervous until this is resolved one way or the other, even though i know that if it turns out to be a problem, it is in all likelyhood very early and curable. I can't even imagine having an "i have cancer" conversation with my 29 - 30 year old kids, no matter how good the prognosis. I think thats what scares me most. It will be a long week. Thanks for letting me vent 3.

Posts.Content: Sorry for your diagnosis. But Gleason 6 is about as good , or maybe I should say, least bad, as it gets. You should def send your slides to dr Jonathan Epstein, at Johns Hopkins for 2nd opinion, he is the worlds recognized expert in prostate cancer pathology. Your Dr will know him, and you might be able to just ask your Drs office to arrange it. Otherwise, heres a link with info and instructions.... http://pathology.jhu.edu/department/...ondopinion.cfm Look at all options, surgery, and different types of radiation, SBRT (Cyberknife), LDR Brachytherapy (seeds), HDR Brachytherapy, even IG-IMRT. THEY WILL ALL LIKELY CURE YOU. ITS IMPORTANT TO SPEAK TO AN EXPERT IN EACH OF THESE METHODOLOGIES. They will all favor their own. Get educated then make up your own mind. You should have an open mind to Active Surveillance. But if you are not wired for it, totally understandable. Genomic testing might make you more comfortable with it. Or less. Walshs book is an excellent start to your education. You are in a good position. Stay calm, learn and you have plenty of time to decide. There is no wrong decision here.

Posts.Title: My One-Year Post-RP Visit

Posts.Content: Chuck, i could be wrong, apologies if thats the case. But my understanding is that after RP surgery, they consider a BCR/Bio Chemical Recurrence, to be a rise to .1, followed by a second reading at that number or higher. After radiation, it would be a rise from nadir, followed by 2 consecutive rises after that. To Thewife - your husband is lucky to have you as his advocate. I AGREE with you that waiting 6 months is too long. If i were you i would ask him what the number is that he uses to signal BCR, and at what point he would recommend SRT. And i would also insist on a PSA retake sooner than 6 months. In fact, i would be asking for a retake in 2 months, 3 max. Also, there have been studies done that have shown in certain situations, the max benefit from SRT comes if its started earler, as early as PSA of .03. I do not recall 100%, but i think that was a study done specifically on G8-10 patients, so if thats the case, it may not apply. Good luck, please keep us posted

Posts.Title: Back from RALRP

Posts.Content: Tony, most doctors recommend Hormone Therapy IN CONJUNCTION WITH SRT these days, especially with g7 (4+3) or greater. But with favorable intermediate risk of g7(3+4), and a PSA thatbis still relatively low, you can probably avoid HT for now. Just my opinion, like I said I’m not a doc. Qualifier....my RO at MSKCC said with my current PSA at .07, he would be comfortable with me not doing HT with SRT. But if I waited until my PSA got to .1, he would be “much less comfortable”. (I too, am g7(3+4) That’s his opinion, and while he’s a top RO, there is no black and white answer, it’s all a judgement call.

Posts.Title: Post Surgery, Perineurial Invasion Present

Posts.Content: Carol, to answer your question from a different angle, and only giving my viewpoint - yes , make plans. When you stop,mooing that, it's almost like giving up. I know it's easier for me to say as I'm not in your/Steves position. But think about it. Making plans for good things gives a person hope. And something to look forward to. I think that has an effect, sometimes even o tourse of the disease (obviously we have no way of knowing but attitude is important) And especially for your daughters wedding. It's something he will so look forward to, I know that as a father. If something comes up, and he can't make it, you'll deal with it at the time.

Posts.Title: DDay

Posts.Content: Brave horn thanks. Note: my 3+5 was downgraded to 3+3 on second opinion from Epatein at Johns Hopkins (who I also spoke with by phone and emphatically insisted that it was 3+3. Also the 3+3 was reconfirmed on third opinion by memorial Sloan Kettering Pathology. So I know I have reason to be optimistic. Still this is so freakin hard, especially these final days leading up to surgery, as many here know. Thanks for letting me vent

Posts.Content: Michael, the plastic bag technique is used with Robotic surgery as well as open. The prostate is enclosed inside the bag, and removed through the incision just above the navel. That is why, that particular incision is a bit larger than the others.

Posts.Title: A few more days until surgery

Posts.Content: Tony welcome to the forum. You’ve got persistent PSA meaning, after surgery, it never went to undetectable. In addition a 3 month rise from .03 to .12 is pretty fast velocity. I would retest PSA to make sure the .12 is not lab error. Once you rule that out, I think you should get started with SRT as soon as feasible. But I’m not a doctor. Or even one of the more knowledgeable guys here. Did the Dr mention hormone therapy with the SRT?

Posts.Title: RP done, post op PSA concern - urgent advise needed

Posts.Content: Tony, most doctors recommend Hormone Therapy IN CONJUNCTION WITH SRT these days, especially with g7 (4+3) or greater. But with favorable intermediate risk of g7(3+4), and a PSA thatbis still relatively low, you can probably avoid HT for now. Just my opinion, like I said I’m not a doc. Qualifier....my RO at MSKCC said with my current PSA at .07, he would be comfortable with me not doing HT with SRT. But if I waited until my PSA got to .1, he would be “much less comfortable”. (I too, am g7(3+4) That’s his opinion, and while he’s a top RO, there is no black and white answer, it’s all a judgement call.

Posts.Title: 12 Hours to go....

Posts.Content: Dave, yes, you hve to try to focus on going forward. I think you would be wise to see the RO and get his take. I read a study, can’t recall where, that showed Surgeons hve. Tendency to recommend SRT much later than RO’s. I’m guessing it’s becuase RO’s tend to read more about the latest data pointing to the benefits of Starting SRT earlier. I think I mentioned in your previous thread, I’ve seen one RO who recommended I start SRT now, or soon, and my PSA is at .06. And I’m seeing another RO who after seeing my last two psa’s, .046 and .06, had his secretary call me and say he wants to see me to discuss treatment. Meanwhile my surgeon, well known and world reknowned, tells me to wait till .2, then we’ll do imaging. So it’s a quandary, but my gut tells me that we both should put more weight in what the ro’s Say. This sure does suck. But it is what it is. We aren’t gonna die from this crap.worst case, it makes our life miserable for a while. But we soldier on

Posts.Title: 12 Hours to go....

Posts.Content: Sabertex, welcome to the other side. Re the BM, I think you can be a little,patient, say one more day. I went to Day 4, was passing gas but no BM, like you. On day 4 I asked my wife to go out and buy some prune juice. I had one 8 ounce glass on an empty stomach. About an hour later, it was bombs away, like the 4th of July. Might have happened anyway, but I think the it was the prune juice , working it’s magic. Tasted disgusting, but well worth it lol. Also, when you do go, hold a pillow against your stomach, to protect yourself from working too hard.

Posts.Title: 3 Days To Go

Posts.Content: Stuntmole, seems all pretty normal for 10 days past surgery. Nothing alarming here. U will learn to automatically Kegel at the right times, like getting out of bed for example, to prevent leaks. It will become an automatic reflex, no thinking involved. It will just take time. Also, don't expect improvement to be linear. It will happen, with two steps forward one step back. Yesterday for example, I had my first 24 hour (ending yesterday morning) leak free period. But today, I weighed my pad this morning and had a leakage over 24 hours of .3 ounces. So don't get discouraged, it will all get amazingly better over time.

Posts.Title: Questions on post RALP Incontinence Recovery

Posts.Content: Stuntmole, one of the most frustrating parts of recovery is the urinary leakage, at least for me.but it gets better. Everything you describe, sounds normal, including the burning while peeling . The day I got the catheter out, I remember having yo walk up,and down the halls after drinking water, so they could see me pee on my own before letting me go home. I remember walking back and forth fro about 3 hours, then I sat down for a few minutes as my legs needed a rest. When I got up, I noticed the chair was soaking wet. After feeling my sweatpants, I realizedthey were soaked. I would keep doing the Kegels. I started 4 times a day, each time was one set of 10 reps, holding 10 seconds, followed by 10 seconds f rest. I'm finally seeing progress, no,leaking In tHE LAST 36 hours, and last night I slept almost 6 hours without waking up to pee. That was the first time I went more than 3 hours of straight sleep since the surgery. So my point is, I went through the same frustatrayions as you are, but if you are diligent about Kegels, you will likely do well.

Posts.Title: Questions on post RALP Incontinence Recovery

Posts.Content: Samie, lots of good advice above. Especially from those who told you in one way or another that all is not lost. Has he had an MRI? A 3 Tesla Multiparametric MRI will show with 95% accuracy, whether the cancer has left the prostate capsule. I think that is what you should be looking to find out. If it hasnt its clearly curable with surgery. Even if it has, it might be. But if its contained, its a strong case for surgery. Also, consider sending the biopsy slides for a second opinion to either Dr Jonathan Epstein at Johns Hopkins or David Bostwick at Bostwick Laboratories. Both are experts in prostate pathology, as opposed to most local pathologists who look at all kinds of slides. It is not unusual to have a gleason score changed on second opinion, reading those slides is very subjective. If you were to be downgraded to a gleason 6 (3+3) it would change everything. Of course the PSA of 39 is troubling. But its not the end all. It could be partially attributed to infection or inflammation of the prostate.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by mstevens7878 I've had 2 prostatectomies, the last about a year ago. I am 64, and after the second one really had to rely on ED drugs completely. I did experience negative side effects at first (flushed face, back/leg soreness, headaches, dry mouth, stuffy nose) but most of the time even a half dose would seem as effective and really cut down on the side effects. I'm not making alot of money right now, so I have been ordering generic versions from this site http://goo.gl/oNqHkh, my insurance that covers everything else will not cover ED meds at all (I am prescribed to both Cialis & Viagra) and this pharmacy ships to me, and is way cheaper. The drugs are in the same amounts and seem to work exactly the same. Has anyone here had any experience with the "generic" versions that are available? How on earth did you have TWO prostatectomies?

Posts.Title: Did husband's doctor make a big mistake?

Posts.Content: Marve, it is very unfortunate that this is the way things are in Estonia. For what you and your dad are going through, your doctor owes it to you (and all of his patients, to give you a good explanation so that you can at least understand. Like you said, this is not just "the next thing, it's your dad, and his life, and his quality of life. If you have any possibility at all, of pushing them to talk more, I would do it if I were you. If you can, ask for another doctor for a second opinion on radiation. And pay attention to what Fairwind said above, it's important. Whatever progress your dad has made in side effects, pee and erectile function, will probably be frozen by the radiation, and he won't make more progress, unless he waits. So maybe a question to ask is " how important is it to have the radiation NOW? Can we at least wait 3 or 6 months

Posts.Title: How good can an ultrasensitive PSA test be?

Posts.Content: Stuntmole, one of the most frustrating parts of recovery is the urinary leakage, at least for me.but it gets better. Everything you describe, sounds normal, including the burning while peeling . The day I got the catheter out, I remember having yo walk up,and down the halls after drinking water, so they could see me pee on my own before letting me go home. I remember walking back and forth fro about 3 hours, then I sat down for a few minutes as my legs needed a rest. When I got up, I noticed the chair was soaking wet. After feeling my sweatpants, I realizedthey were soaked. I would keep doing the Kegels. I started 4 times a day, each time was one set of 10 reps, holding 10 seconds, followed by 10 seconds f rest. I'm finally seeing progress, no,leaking In tHE LAST 36 hours, and last night I slept almost 6 hours without waking up to pee. That was the first time I went more than 3 hours of straight sleep since the surgery. So my point is, I went through the same frustatrayions as you are, but if you are diligent about Kegels, you will likely do well.

Posts.Title: Questions on post RALP Incontinence Recovery

Posts.Content: Welcome to the place that nobody wants to be, but some of us need to. First thing I'd recommend is get a second pinion on your pathology. Tell your urologists office that you want the slides sent to Dr JOnatjan Epstein at Johns Hopkins, or Davd Bostwick at Bostick Labs, for second opinion. They will do it, they get this request all the time from knowledgeable patients who are wanting to be their own best advocate. My GLeason was G8, then downgraded on second and third opinion to G6, and this changed everything Second, on what basis is your urologist recommending radiation therapy? Is that what he does? And on what basis is he saying you have a 40% chance that the Cancer is not organ confined? Not saying he is wrong, but I'd be curious, with a 5.9 PSA (not crazy high) Third, with radiation, you will have more ejaculate than with surgery (with surgery you will have none, and a 60-80% chance of return of sexual function (erection good enough for penetration) , with radiation I have been told (with BRachy/seeds) it would be 65% without drugs, and 80-85% with EDdrugs. But be aware that you will produce LESS ejaculate than before. Also, with Surgery, side effects tend to come early and improve over time, while with radiation they tend to be milder, and eventually disappear, but over a period of years, may return. You should visit with more than one surgeon, and more than one radiation oncologist. Educate yourself, then, make the decision that you. Feel most comfortable with. If a second opinion downgrades you to G6 you might even be able to consider active surveillance. Aside from that, both surgery and radiation work well, in most cases of locally confined disease. Good luck

Posts.Title: new member and trying to decide on surgery vs. radiation

Posts.Content: Stuntmole, seems all pretty normal for 10 days past surgery. Nothing alarming here. U will learn to automatically Kegel at the right times, like getting out of bed for example, to prevent leaks. It will become an automatic reflex, no thinking involved. It will just take time. Also, don't expect improvement to be linear. It will happen, with two steps forward one step back. Yesterday for example, I had my first 24 hour (ending yesterday morning) leak free period. But today, I weighed my pad this morning and had a leakage over 24 hours of .3 ounces. So don't get discouraged, it will all get amazingly better over time.

My GLeason was G8, then downgraded on second and third opinion to G6, and this changed everything Second, on what basis is your urologist recommending radiation therapy? Is that what he does? And on what basis is he saying you have a 40% chance that the Cancer is not organ confined? Not saying he is wrong, but I'd be curious, with a 5.9 PSA (not crazy high) Third, with radiation, you will have more ejaculate than with surgery (with surgery you will have none, and a 60-80% chance of return of sexual function (erection good enough for penetration) , with radiation I have been told (with BRachy/seeds) it would be 65% without drugs, and 80-85% with EDdrugs. But be aware that you will produce LESS ejaculate than before. Also, with Surgery, side effects tend to come early and improve over time, while with radiation they tend to be milder, and eventually disappear, but over a period of years, may return. You should visit with more than one surgeon, and more than one radiation oncologist. Educate yourself, then, make the decision that you. Feel most comfortable with. If a second opinion downgrades you to G6 you might even be able to consider active surveillance. Aside from that, both surgery and radiation work well, in most cases of locally confined disease. Good luck

Posts.Title: HAPPY thanksgiving - Lots to be Thankful For

Posts.Content: Last year, on Thanksgiving Day, before my guests arrived for the Holiday, I had to sit down with my daughter and tell her I had cancer. That was a hard conversation. Fast forward a year later, and like the title says, I've got a lot yo be thankful for. SO FAR seemingly successful surgery with minimal if any side effects, not to mention a test happy Primary Care Doc, whose tests found a life threatening Blockage in my main artery. What a year. So I just want to thank the guys here for the help I got in my darkest moments. Especially Chuck. I hope I can continue to repay it by helping other guys who show up here with a similar dilemma. Enjoy your turkey!

Posts.Title: Surgery at Hopkins - Post Surgical Interactions?

Posts.Content: So after having a cardiac catheterization 2 months ago with 2 stents inserted, to clear blockage sq, I'm having another one this morning. Had a very slight tightness in my throat when I run, after about a minute, that goes away when I slow to a walk. Honestly I'm not sure if it's real, or in my head, because I am so hyper aware of every little sensation since the stents were inserted in June. In fact, it's so slight, that I told the Dr if I wasn't looking for it, I wouldn't even notice it. But I had an echo stress test yesterday, and while the pictures were ok, the EKG showed abnormalities, same as before my stents were out in. So the doctor wants to be cautious and make sure everything is ok. I am seriously so done with this crap, it's really getting old. Thanks for letting me rant

Posts.Title: Here we go again

Posts.Content: Thanks all, for your responses, all very helpful, and Otago - thank you very useful, I appreciate the information. So i got home an hour ago, very uneventful. They found nothing. He told me that the stents were in place and working just the way we want them to, and they found nothing significant that needed to be stented. I asked, in that case, how should we approach the fact that i did have a positive echo stress test. He told me that the positive aspect of the stress test were not that significant, so just dont worry about it. I know that about 30% of stress tests are false positives. Also it was only the EKG that was abnormal, the images looked very good. So hopefully thats the end of it and i can move on. I'll talk with my cardiologist later today or tomorrow. Otago, you've given me some great questions to ask the cardiologist, expecially about whether to exercess through what appears to be stable angina (or my defective brain, not sure which. So now i get to lay around all day and ask my wife to make me lunch, do this, get me that. And actually get away with it, without hearing "go f yourself, do it yourself? LOL Thanks again to all, for the support.

Posts.Content: Thanks Derk, i appreciate it. I am not going anywhere, i like the people on this board (and the other one i found) and feel like i have really gotten help here, so if i can hang around and occasionally post something that helps someone else who might be a few steps behind me, i'd like to do that. Regarding the subject at hand, HI Grade PIN, i think i have sort of convinced myself that there is a high probability that over the next few years, i will be diagnosed and become a full fledged member of the club. Maybe I'm wrong, hope so, but from the reading i have been doing, it almost seems like a forgone conclusion. I guess its good that they found pin in only one core out of 12 (actually i think its was 14), but still, its HGPIN. Time will tell. Sometimes i wonder if its really a good thing, all these "advances" they make in diagnosis and identifying precursors, etc. Its like gene testing in breast cancer - do you really want to know?

Posts.Title: Could My Husband Have Prostate Cancer?

Posts.Content: John, welcome. I had surgery as my primary treatment. And most of us have a bias towards whatever treatment we chose. With that caveat, I'll say I'm not sorry. Uneventful, full recovery, no incontinence, and with Cialis no issues with turning little John into Big John. Hve you looked at SBRT (AKA Cyberknife)? It's got a very good 10 year track record now, I think IMRT for primary is old school, and what's more common these days is SBRT and HDR Brachytherapy, which leads me to my next question. You mentioned brachytherapy, but didn't differentiate between HDR and LDR. HDR is the newer and I think more state of the art form. Rectestosterone, I'm no expert, but I think there's a lot of scientific evidence that supplements don't promote PC growth. It's counterintuitive, I know, but that's what I read. Good luck and keep us posted

Posts.Title: New Member of the "0" Club!!!!

Posts.Content: Thanks Newporter, Dave, appreciate the responses. I have to admit this issue kept me up last night. I guess i just have to adjust my mindset, and remember that it doesnt always lead to PC, and if it does it can take many years. Hey, if i can get to 70 before being diagnosed (I'm age 62 now) , then maybe i can get away with no treatments. If anyone else here now or in the future is looking for info on PIN, as i am, note that i found a couple of pages of good information in very simple terms, in Dr Walshs book (page 179), along with a link to FAQs on Prostate Pathology, including on PIN. the link is..... http://adasp.org/FAQs/03-prostate.htm Hope it helps someone.
Posts.Title: HI Grade PIN

Posts.Content: DP, i have to say i find it odd, that a physician, who has followed many Prostate Cancer patients, would come to an internet forum for advice from a group of laymen With that said, there is always possibility of a lab error, as you probably know. I had 3 consecutive undetectable PSAs after surgery with very favorable pathology and similar results on the MSKCC Nomogram as your dads. And then my fourth PSA test came back at 3.88!!!!! I had it retested at another lab, it came back undetectable, and the first lab then confirmed that after retesting the same blood they too got an undetectable. So yes, its possible that its a lab error, get a retest.

Posts.Title: Urgent, panicked

Posts.Content: 88, Generally speaking, Prostate Cancer in its early stage, even if you've had it for a few years (it grows VERY slowly in most cases) does not present with pain in the testicles or anywhere else, for that matter. As far as i know, and have seen, in talking with many PC patients.

Posts.Title: Prostate problems for 40 years - new symptoms, cancer questions

Posts.Content: I think the nomograms are fairly accurate, they are based on actual data, actual experience of actual patients. However two things to keep in mind One, they are somewhat of a lagging indicator, so fir example if a nomograms is based on 10,000 patient experiences diagnosed between 2006 thru 2016, you have many patients diagnosed 8-9-10 years ago. No doubt as patients diagnosed today, the experience is better. Second, the nomograms are statistics. And statistics matter to a large group. It's like our friend Jim would tell you, if you sit at the blackjack table or stand at the craps table, the longer you play the truer the odds.sane thing holds for the nomograms. The larger the sample the truer the results. You are a cohort of 1. So the stats may tell us our chances individually, but they don't mean as much. Good luck with your surgery.

Posts.Title: Newly Diagnosed with PC

Posts.Content: JMorris All good advice above. I'm just 12 days past surgery, so it's still fresh in my mind. So I'll add what I can without being repetitive... First couple of days, maybe three, will be tough. Butvthen you will start to see big improvements each day for a week or two Assuming you are doin robotic, you will have gas pains in your chest shoulders back and neck, this is gas they pump in you to open up the area and give them more room to work. The only way to get rid of this a is to walk. So walk as much as you can every day. Try to walk within a few hours of getting out of recovery room. They will, push you to do that. Go with it. GasX and tums might help a bit too. The catheter is annoying, but not painful. But the day they take the catheter out, is a day that you will want to be declared as a national holiday, you will feel like q new man. To give you an idea of how quickly things will progress, I am 12 days past surgery and only 3 days past getting the catheter out. I walked three miles in an hour yesterday. I'm 64. Good luck, and please, when it's over come back and keep us posted. There is a lot of support for you here if you want it. See you on the other side.

Posts.Title: HI Grade PIN

Posts.Content: Sounds like you've got a good marriage. I don't know you from a hole in the wall, but I'm guessing if you offered to "set her free" she would laugh in your face, then smack you down. Suggestion... talk to a professional, it might help. Getting any kind of cancer diagnosis, even a relatively treatable, and even curable one, is devastating , it takes time to process. And the thought of side effects would be upsetting to anyone. I'm no expert, but it sounds to me like you could use some professional help sorting out your feelings.

Posts.Title: 3 years.....

Posts.Content: So i finally go to speak with the Uro - first conversation since the biopsy (from my other thread you may know i got the good news that results were negative for cancer via email from the nurse). He told me that 1 sample (i think he took 14, at least thats how many of those little sample containers they wheeled in for the biopsy along with the tools) showed Hi Grade PIN. He explained that it used to be accepted that this was a precursor or hi predictor of future PC diagnosis, but that it is generally not so much universally accepted any more and they (he) believe that it is not necessarily a precursor. But he also said that there are doctors who will disagree. He suggested i not wait a year, retake PSA in 6 months. Well, that was definitive! Any thoughts?
Posts.Title: HI Grade PIN

Posts.Content: Not sure about that someone else may chime in. Often, if a urologist suspects infection as the cause of a PSA rise, they will put you on a course of Cipro, or other antibiotic, then retake PSA before doing a biopsy. But I suspect that your urologist skip that step due to the nodules Please stay focused on this fact: even if the news is bad you're not going to be in big trouble. It will be a bump in the road because PC is a slow-growing cancer compared to other types of cancers and most Prostate cancers are slow growing indolent cancers that don't spread to distant sites But let's hope your case but the biopsy shows no cancer
