Posts.Title: Could My Husband Have Prostate Cancer?

Posts.Content: Ian, I had a biopsy two years ago that was negative for PC but AHOWED one core out of 14 with hi grade pin. Dr said it was of no concern and just continue to test every six months which I dis. My PSA kept rising, but slowly. After nine months when my PSA went from 2.7 to 3.1 in only 6 months, I asked about a biopsy he said no because he was not concerned because the rate of rise was not fast enough. In early November I had another biopsy and if was positive, 3 cores, all G6 thankfully If I had to do if all over again, I would have pushed a little harder for the 2nd biopsy six months ago, and if the dr still wouldn't do it, I would have come back for another biopsy in three months instead of waiting the six months. If I were in your shoes, with a PSA of 8.9 I would retest very three months and insist on a repeat biopsy in a year. Unless the doc shows you on the path report that you've got a very large Prostate and has VERY good reason to not assume the Psa being that high is not attributable to BPH or some other benign issue. Hope this provides you with some perspective. HGPIN is known to not always, but OFTEN, turn into Cancer

Posts.Title: What's the % chance of PC

Posts.Content: Pretty much what lance peace said, the combination of that high a PSA and the nodules palpable on the DRE aren't a great sign. Still hope for the best while YIU know its a possibility that the news won't be ideal. I'd say prepare for the worst, but the fact is, I don't think most people can be prepared for that call Still, it's possible it's an infection. My doc told me to call him in a wek for results, I knew it should take less than a week. And in fact he called me 3 business days later with the bad news . I think if it was good news he would have waited for me to call him. So each day that goes by without them calling you, is possibly something positive to hang on to. Keeping fingers tightly crossed that you get a negative biopsy result and disappear from here. If it's positive, come back here and ask a lot of questions, and start doing your research. Don't just listen to the Drs.

Posts.Title: The one year mark

Posts.Content: @Chuck, thanks for taking a stab at it. Your educated guess is what i am hoping to hear, but i can't seem to find anything on it when i do a google search, other than the general comment that fPSA is most helpful with total psa above 4. @Otago - thanks to you as well. You have a great attitude, i wish i could be as logical, unfortunately its never been in my nature to not assume the worst. I do try to change that but...... My dads PC was diagnosed in his late 60;s. Unfortunately, he was already ill from other issues, i.e. kidney, heart bypass, and mental issues that arose as a result of his hear bypass (dementia). So he was treated with hormone therapy (i believe, it was injections, his wife was overseeing it, and kept me informed, sorry to this day that i was not more proactive about being involved). They worked for a couple of years, but by then he was already in a nursing home, and over a period of two years or so, deteriorated generally, and passed. I never knew his Gleason score. I was a shmuck (NY word for idiot) When it was first recommended that i get a biopsy, it was recommended by my local Uro, and my PSA was 2.2, but had risen ever time it was taken over a multi year period, so despite the low absolute number and a negative DRE, it seemed to make sense. Nevertheless, i felt that if i was going to go that route, and do anything invasive, i wanted a top Doc doing the procedure and a good lab checking the samples. So thats when i went to Columbia Presbyterian for a second opinion before doing the biopsy. They are highly ranked in many areas including Urology. THAT Doc also said that a biopsy was a good idea in view of the steadily rising trend. And he did another PSA, that was the one two weeks later. I didnt realize until i got home, that he took the blood AFTER the DRE, because i was such a mental wreck. So yes, i do not place much importance on THAT 2.8 reading. But the next 2.8 reading was with my current (third URO) who is also a top guy, was with Columbia until Feb 2012 when he became Chairman of Uro at Winthrop, a large Long Island Hospital. (he still teaches at Columbia) So thats the entire story, sorry i realize you said you read my past posts. In any case, i wish i could find something that substantiates that the fPSA was not something to worry about with a 2.8 Total PSA. BTW, this last doc, in April, who i am going to see again in a couple weeks, also did a PCA3, which came in at 13, (under 25 is ok, as i understand it)

Posts.Title: Free PSA question

Posts.Content: Not sure about that someone else may chime in. Often, if a urologist suspects infection as the cause of a PSA rise, they will put you on a course of Cipro, or other antibiotic, then retake PSA before doing a biopsy. But I suspect that your urologist skip that step due to the nodules Please stay focused on this fact: even if the news is bad you're not going to be in big trouble. It will be a bump in the road because PC is a slow-growing cancer compared to other types of cancers and most Prostate cancers are slow growing indolent cancers that don't spread to distant sites But let's hope your case but the biopsy shows no cancer

Posts.Title: Recurrence after Surgery - Now what?

Posts.Content: MM, you've read enough on this forum and I'm sure elsewhere, to know that while this is scary stuff, it's definitely manageable, and highly likely to be curable. The T1c is great, that means no abnormalities felt on the DRE of the prostate. uC from what I hear is a great place for this, and you'll be in great hands. We all know your head is swimming now, because none of us will ever forget how we were, the day we got the news and the weeks that followed. But your gonna be fine, and a year from now, (less actually), you will likely look back at this as a bump in the road. One thing - get your slides sent to Epstein or Bostwick for a second opinion. Keep us posted, we've all got your back.

Posts.Title: To Wine or not to Wine

Posts.Content: Thanks everyone for the hopeful comments, and for the warm welcome back. Intellectually I know that it could very well be a statistical anamoly. Emotionally though, as I'm sure everyone here knows, it's a killer of a thing to anticipate. It could go either way as we all know. The question is what was the last result 6 months ago? Was the true number .001? Or was it .019. I can't know that because the assay only measures to anything .02 or higher, thus the result <.02. If the true number was .001, I've got a problem. If it was .019, then a move to .020 is insignificant for sure. Then if it's positive again, and turns out it's a Recurrence, how do I know when it recurred. Might have been w months ago. Do we assume it was 2 years, since the test was done 2 years post RALP? Or could it have started soon fire my last test 6bmonths ago? Unknowable. The NP when she called with the result 3. Weeks ago told me they still consider it undetectable. But the fact is, it was measurable. I was told they don't really worry bout it until it hits .1. If in fact this is a recurrence, I don't plan on waiting that long. If it gets to .05, maybe .04, I'm off to see the nuke specialist. Which, from what I understand has a lower chance of working, when you had positive margins. So you can see, my head, which had been fairly com up until a day or two, is spinning. @ron, Chuck, I her you on the uPSA vs STANDARD PSA. But I think once you start with uPSA, it's hard to go back. And I would want to know sooner, if it's creeping up. @Micheal - my first few tests were done at Quest, and were all <.02. Then I had. 3 month test come back at 3.8 (no typo) which was an error that the Senior VP of oncology testing could not figure out how it happened, (I had a phone call with him because I was pissed) and I lost confidence in their process no started testing at my DRs (Tewari) hospital lab , mt Sinai in NY. The first two of those tests came back at 0.00, that's how they report it. Then the next two came back at <.02. I scrutinized those reports and found that the two 0.00's were a different assay than the last two. Now, the .02 reading without the <, was done on the same assay as the last two <02's. So I don't think it's the assay. I guess I'll know more tomorrow, seeing the Dr at 11am, but will likely get a phone call with the results by 9:30-9:45. I'll report back Thanks again.

Posts.Title: I'm back, with less than great news

Posts.Content: JLukas, you are a good son. I am, your dads age, 64, and I had surgery with Ash Tewari 2 weeks ago tomorrow. I would highly recommend him, and you may hear the same from another member soon NYCGman. I also used Jonathan Epstein at Johns Hopkins for 2nd opinion on the pathology slides, you should do it. As far as a radiation oncologist, one of the more well known in Nyc is dr Zelefsky, at MSKCC. HE specializes in Brachytherapy, which is radioactive seeds, but I'm sure he can talk to you about other types of radiation. I consulted with Dr Gewanter at MSKCC, AT THEIR Long Island Facility. Great professional, good man. Be aware, that before Dr ZELEFSKY will see you, he will require your slides, the pathology report, the discs from your dads bone scan and CT scan and you will have to have (your father I mean) a 3Tesla multiparametricMRI metric MRI done. (This is also done by Dr Tewari , required by him before surgery to help him plan. ) The MRI cannot be done for 6-7 weeks after biopsy, or it will be inaccurate. What I did was, I immediately scheduled the surgery with dr Tewari at my first visit. It can't be done for at least 6-7 weeks after biopsy. I used that time to explore the other options. And I did the MRI at Mount SiNai, with prescription from Dr Tewari, and had a copy sent to dr Gewanter, the RO at MSKCC. THIS WAY, I DIDNT LOSE ANY TIME. Have your dad explore ALL options. I am a surgery guy, others would rather do radiation. The both have their upside and downside. You need to learn a lot, and make an informed decision. radiation Oncologists will tell you do radiation and surgeons will be biased towards surgery. Dr. Tewari at my first visit, encouraged me to consult with a radiation oncologist as well before making up my mind. If you have other questions and want to PM me for my email address I will be happy to try to help. Know one thing though - this is not a death sentence. When we are first diagnosed most of us are in a fog. But as we educate ourselves, we learn that this disease is curable, and for the minority of unlucky ones who cannot be cured, there is a lot that can be done to hold this beast at bay for many years, even decades. And your dads PSA would seem to indicate good chance that he has early stage/curable disease Last thing - the suggestion to buy and read dr Patrick Walshs book is a good one. Almost a must. Get the third edition, it's the most recent, you can buy or download it on amazon. You are not alone we are here and anxious to help.

Posts.Title: Im scared for my father - today his results came back and he has pc

Posts.Content: John, welcome. I had surgery as my primary treatment. And most of us have a bias towards whatever treatment we chose. With that caveat, I'll say I'm not sorry. Uneventful, full recovery, no incontinence, and with Cialis no issues with turning little John into Big John. Hve you looked at SBRT (AKA Cyberknife)? It's got a very good 10 year track record now, I think IMRT for primary is old school, and what's more common these days is SBRT and HDR Brachytherapy, which leads me to my next question. You mentioned brachytherapy, but didn't differentiate between HDR and LDR. HDR is the newer and I think more state of the art form. Rectestosterone, I'm no expert, but I think there's a lot of scientific evidence that supplements don't promote PC growth. It's counterintuitive, I know, but that's what I read. Good luck and keep us posted

Posts.Content: Lukas, 2 weeks post surgery I am doing fine. Still some leaking but improving, had an erection when I woke up this morning, but that's unusual, it can take a long time for many, everyone is different, some don't get it back. No real pain, just less stamina which will resolve with Time. I would schedule an appointment with Tewari, after you've had your bone andCT scans, although ithe scans are highly likely to be negative. Contact an RO as well. Take a breath, relax, it will all work out

Posts.Content: Everything that Another said, x 1000. I try to follow the principles he laid out. Not always easy. For me the toughest is limited dairy , no added sugar, and daily exercise. But i try. And if you are going to supplement, make sure 1. you purchase well known, reputable brands like Solgar, Life Extension, etc. Although that too is no guarantee. There will never be large randomized control studies of vitamins and cancer, because its not profitable for the drug companies to fund them, and its too expensive for the supplement industry to do so (not that you would want them to).
Posts.Title: How do you prevent cancer from returning, vitamins?

Posts.Content: Trinity, i sent you a PM in response to your PM. I'll add to it here but just want to note that everyone here has confirmed what i said in my PM, that you need to address this, and need treatment, pending a second opinion on the slides, which you should get on immediately. I assume you are in the NY area based on who you said you are seeing in your PM. Based on that, you have plenty of good people to consult with. I would recommend my surgeon, (as I'm sure most everybody would, LOL) Dr Ash Tewari, in Manhattan. He's done over 6000 Robotic Prostatectomies. I specifically asked him if he does the entire surgery. He told me, that his assistants (Drs) position the arms of the robot, but he is the only one that ever touches the controls. Also, Dr James Eastham has a very good rep at MSKCC, i believe he does mostly open. Others will mention Samadi, i met with him, and thought he was pompous, he denegrated my urologist, Dr Aaron Katz, who does have a good rep, so i would never go near him, Just my opinion. You should also explore radiation - seeds (brachy), SBRT (Cyberknife) and external Beam radiation. I met with Dr Gewanter, who is at MSKCC on Long Island (on the campus of Mercy Hospital, but no affilaition). He was terrific. He is Cheif of radiation Oncology at MSKCC, LONG ISLAND DIVISION. He does not do Brachy, if you went that way, he would refer you to the manhattan LOCATION. Dr Zelefsky, who does Brach at MSKCC in Manhattan, is one of the best in the country. Of course, Dr Jon Haas, does Cyberknife at Winthrop. Back to surgery, if you prefer to see someone on Long Island, i would meet with Dr Felix Badillo. I know two people who had him do surgery and both were very happy. I met with him, nice man. I just wanted Tewari. Badillo is Chief of Urology at Saint Francis. Most important - you need to learn all you can about all the different options available to you. Everyone has different values, i, like most people had my priorities of cure, contincence and erectile function in that order. As i told my surgeon. At age 65, i piss 7 times a day, i have sex 7 times a year (exaggerating to make a point) so just make sure i am continent. Tewaris results are 97% fully continent within one year - his definition of continent (important question to ask) is no pads. Like i said, learn as much as possible, be your own advocate. If you look hard enough you might find a doctor that tells you what you want to hear, that AS is ok. (although maybe not, with a G8 )BUT You need treatment if in fact it is an 8. Sorry to ramble, but i wanted to give you as much help as possible. Again, I'm not a medical professional, just a guy who had his prostate taken out and is very happy with the result, and more knowledgeable for the experience. Good luck and keep us posted, and keep in touch

Posts.Title: Another newbie...decided on surgery

Posts.Content: Wilde, good luck man. The fear of God comes as one of the main side effects of a PSA Test, we all love with that. So vent away, it’s good to do that. Hopefully that < reappears or at least you get another .05. Should you get a rise, I would wait for one more rise, then consider acting. My Uro also recommended waiting till .2. But I’m starting treatment this week, at .08 Anyway, we all have different situations, and different personalities and different pathologies. If your PSA stays low but stable it’s good and you don’t have to do anything. Good luck, we are looking forward to a good report,

Posts.Title: Finally on Day+1

Posts.Content: Lukas, 2 weeks post surgery I am doing fine. Still some leaking but improving, had an erection when I woke up this morning, but that's unusual, it can take a long time for many, everyone is different, some don't get it back. No real pain, just less stamina which will resolve with Time. I would schedule an appointment with Tewari, after you've had your bone andCT scans, although ithe scans are highly likely to be negative. Contact an RO as well. Take a breath, relax, it will all work out

Posts.Title: Im scared for my father - today his results came back and he has pc

Posts.Content: JLukas, you are a good son. I am, your dads age, 64, and I had surgery with Ash Tewari 2 weeks ago tomorrow. I would highly recommend him, and you may hear the same from another member soon NYCGman. I also used Jonathan Epstein at Johns Hopkins for 2nd opinion on the pathology slides, you should do it. As far as a radiation oncologist, one of the more well known in Nyc is dr Zelefsky, at MSKCC. HE specializes in Brachytherapy, which is radioactive seeds, but I'm sure he can talk to you about other types of radiation. I consulted with Dr Gewanter at MSKCC, AT THEIR Long Island Facility. Great professional, good man. Be aware, that before Dr ZELEFSKY will see you, he will require your slides, the pathology report, the discs from your dads bone scan and CT scan and you will have to have (your father I mean) a 3Tesla multiparametricMRI metric MRI done. (This is also done by Dr Tewari , required by him before surgery to help him plan. ) The MRI cannot be done for 6-7 weeks after biopsy, or it will be inaccurate. What I did was, I immediately scheduled the surgery with dr Tewari at my first visit. It can't be done for at least 6-7 weeks after biopsy. I used that time to explore the other options. And I did the MRI at Mount SiNai, with prescription from Dr Tewari, and had a copy sent to dr Gewanter, the RO at MSKCC. THIS WAY, I DIDNT LOSE ANY TIME. Have your dad explore ALL options. I am a surgery guy, others would rather do radiation. The both have their upside and downside. You need to learn a lot, and make an informed decision. radiation Oncologists will tell you do radiation and surgeons will be biased towards surgery. Dr. Tewari at my first visit, encouraged me to consult with a radiation oncologist as well before making up my mind. If you have other questions and want to PM me for my email address I will be happy to try to help. Know one thing though - this is not a death sentence. When we are first diagnosed most of us are in a fog. But as we educate ourselves, we learn that this disease is curable, and for the minority of unlucky ones who cannot be cured, there is a lot that can be done to hold this beast at bay for many years, even decades. And your dads PSA would seem to indicate good chance that he has early stage/curable disease Last thing - the suggestion to buy and read dr Patrick Walshs book is a good one. Almost a must. Get the third edition, it's the most recent, you can buy or download it on amazon. You are not alone we are here and anxious to help.

Posts.Title: PSA Results - I'm in a Panic

Posts.Content: After being undetectable since surgery, including my last test 3 months ago, my 9 month post op PSA came back from Quest, at 3.38 (no typo, 3.3. Needless to say I am besides myself. Ingot the results online and have an appointment tomorrow at the surgeons office but not with the Dr., I am supposed to meet with his director of Wellness, who does the nutrition, and other holistic stuff. He said I didn't need to see him this visit . And I said, right, unless the PSA comes back detectable. He responded by telling me "with your surgical pathology, it's not going to happen. So here I am looking 7 times to make sure I wasn't seeing things, at a 3.38. I called the office spoke to the PA, she said it's likely a mistake. Said to retest when I come in tomorrow, and they'd have the results Monday. But I didn't want to wait the weekend, in this mental state, so I asked if I could drive into the city (about an hour, and get the blood draw tonight, which I did. I'll have results tomorrow. My surgical pathology was (3+4), negative margins (1 positive intra operative margin so he cut more and got a negative final margin. No ECE, SV-, 9 lymph nodes all negative. So how can this happen. It's high probability it was an error by the lab. But doesn't make sense how do you make such an error? I called the lab and asked them to check and make sure I was given my results and not someone else's. They did so and confirmed it was mine. They said the blood tube is checked carefully so there cannot be a mixup in the blood, and when the girl drew my blood at the Quest Center, she put the label on the tube, and showed it to me with m name and had me initial . Even of it was a mistake, and someone entered 3.38, but should have been .338, that's a huge jump from <.02 3 months ago. I'm confused scared and in a panic

Posts.Title: I went public with my diagnosis

Posts.Content: Thanks Michael. I did call Quest and asked questions. They checked and confirmed that the numbers posted on my account were in fact my numbers. And when I asked if it's possible that tubes of blood were mixed up, she said highly unlikely, as the tubes are meticulously identified at every step of the process. Also when they took the blood, at the local center, she showed me the tube right after taking my blood and asked me for confirmation that my name, etc w was correct. I asked her if there was any change in the testing assay method and she didn't even know what that meant, she also told me that the normal range was below 4, so it's not a result that should be questioned. At that point I corrected her and pointed out that under 4 is for someone with a. Prostate, and that the test ordered for me was a post prostatectomy test. But I realized that the person. Spoke to was an idiot. If this turns out to be an error, and I'm undetectable, trust me, the CEO is getting a letter from me via FedEx, not that it will matter. I just hope I get that opportunity. Hey,mlogically. Know it's an error in all likelihood. But emotionally I can't help but be a wreck. Even if the number is .338, rather than 3.38, that would be a huge jump in three months. Posts.Title: PSA Results - I'm in a Panic

Posts.Content: Thanks Michael. I did call Quest and asked questions. They checked and confirmed that the numbers posted on my account were in fact my numbers. And when I asked if it's possible that tubes of blood were mixed up, she said highly unlikely, as the tubes are meticulously identified at every step of the process. Also when they took the blood, at the local center, she showed me the tube right after taking my blood and asked me for confirmation that my name, etc w was correct. I asked her if there was any change in the testing assay method and she didn't even know what that meant, she also told me that the normal range was below 4, so it's not a result that should be questioned. At that point I corrected her and pointed out that under 4 is for someone with a. Prostate, and that the test ordered for me was a post prostatectomy test. But I realized that the person. Spoke to was an idiot. If this turns out to be an error, and I'm undetectable, trust me, the CEO is getting a letter from me via FedEx, not that it will matter. I just hope I get that opportunity. Posts.Title: PSA After Surgery - Hopkins

Posts.Content: JLukas, you are a good son. I am, your dads age, 64, and I had surgery with Ash Tewari 2 weeks ago tomorrow. I would highly recommend him, and you may hear the same from another member soon NYCGman. I also used Jonathan Epstein at Johns Hopkins for 2nd opinion on the pathology slides, you should do it. As far as a radiation oncologist, one of the more well known in Nyc is dr Zelefsky, at MSKCC. HE specializes in Brachytherapy, which is radioactive seeds, but I'm sure he can talk to you about other types of radiation. I consulted with Dr Gewanter at MSKCC, AT THEIR Long Island Facility. Great professional, good man. Be aware, that before Dr ZELEFSKY will see you, he will require your slides, the pathology report, the discs from your dads bone scan and CT scan and you will have to have (your father I mean) a 3Tesla multiparametricMRI metric MRI done. (This is also done by Dr Tewari , required by him before surgery to help him plan. ) The MRI cannot be done for 6-7 weeks after biopsy, or it will be inaccurate. What I did was, I immediately scheduled the surgery with dr Tewari at my first visit. It can't be done for at least 6-7 weeks after biopsy. I used that time to explore the other options. And I did the MRI at Mount SiNai, with prescription from Dr Tewari, and had a copy sent to dr Gewanter, the RO at MSKCC. THIS WAY, I DIDNT LOSE ANY TIME. Have your dad explore ALL options. I am a surgery guy, others would rather do radiation. The both have their upside and downside. You need to learn a lot, and make an informed decision. radiation Oncologists will tell you do radiation and surgeons will be biased towards surgery. Dr. Tewari at my first visit, encouraged me to consult with a radiation oncologist as well before making up my mind. If you have other questions and want to PM me for my email address I will be happy to try to help. Know one thing though - this is not a death sentence. When we are first diagnosed most of us are in a fog. But as we educate ourselves, we learn that this disease is curable, and for the minority of unlucky ones who cannot be cured, there is a lot that can be done to hold this beast at bay for many years, even decades. And your dads PSA would seem to indicate good chance that he has early stage/curable disease Last thing - the suggestion to buy and read dr Patrick Walshs book is a good one. Almost a must. Get the third edition, it's the most recent, you can buy or download it on amazon. You are not alone we are here and anxious to help.

Posts.Title: How many military vets are here?

Posts.Content: Tink, 1. Yes most doctors do the biopsy with the patient fully awake. They usually give local anesthetic, a shot of lidocaine to numb the prostate. It's usually not really painful, just a series of spring-loaded pin pricks. I took a couple of xanax before my biopsies, but that was it. 2. They take tiny samples from different areas of the prostate, not from other organs. 3. He will be sore for a couple if days, there will probably be some blood in his urine, usually for a couple of days. And he will have bloody semen which can last weeks. (Sorry, as his daughter/son, you Probably don't want to know that part ) 4. It takes a few days, sometimes up to a week, although that's unusual. Some doctors will call with the results, others will make an appointment at the time of biopsy, to give you the results about a week later. 5. If it's positive, a lot depends on the information in the biopsy. What is the Gleason score, or grade (aggressiveness), what is the volume % in each core, how many cores taken and how many positive. Etc. generally, a second opinion should be had on the slides, because it is subjective and you want a trained eye evaluating it. Most people use dr Jonathan Epstein at Johns Hopkins. He's the recognized expert in prostate pathology Then you will,need to learn about the different treatments, and make a decision. That's a long discussion, for a different time. If his cancer is advanced and aggressive though, he will probably have hormone therapy to start. If he chooses surgery, he is in the hands of a prostate surgeon/urologist If he chooses radiation he is in the hands of a radiation oncologist If he needs systemic treatment such as hormone therapy and/or chemo, he should see a medical oncologist with a focus on prostate cancer. Take cues from his urologist when he gets the results, but don't just listen to what he says without questioning and getting other opinions, Get a copy of the pathology report, and come back here with the details, you'll get lots of help on next steps.

Posts.Title: Biopsy...then what?

Posts.Content: Steve, sorry you are in this mental state, which will lead to you not getting treatment. Do you hve children? Grandchildren? Are they worth fighting for ? Aren't they a reason to live? If you don't hve children, surely you have friends, or other reasons to get up in the morning. My mom, who would be 90 today, when she was in the late stages of breast cancer, said to me " where there's life, there's hope." There are so many treatments today, and new ones coming every day. The hormone shot will make you feel lethargic, from what I've read. Fight it. Find the strength to go for a walk, maybe a couple times a day. It's likely, that if you fight, something else will get you, not prostate cancer. Good luck

Posts.Title: Hi Guys

Posts.Content: Had my 3 month follow up with my Surgeon today. This was the first time I had a chance to speak/meet with him directly, since the surgery, so I got to ask all my questions It was a great meeting. My one concern was the upgrade from G6 to g7 (3+4). He told me with negative margins and everything, I should be celebrating. He said that of all his patients with the same pathology as me, less than 5% have needed further treatment, and he's never lost one. (whew, that's a relief) So all good. He also told me my follow ups would be every 3 months for the first year, then we go to every 6 months. That was good news, because I had thought it would be 3 month visits for 2 years. I told him I was so happy I chose surgery, and that I chose him as my surgeon, and I meant it. I walked out of there, feeling more confident about the future than I have since this whole shitstorm started.

Posts.Content: Sorry about your diagnosis Mike. But as Highlander said, there's plenty of hope. As far as different Drs , different systems, you will get a referral from the urologist to an oncologist, but you don't have to take it. You can see anyone you want. Try to be sure that whatever oncologist you see, has plenty of experience with aggressive prostate cancer. And don't be railroaded into one treatment or bother. Do your own research, be your own advocate. Find a Dr you trust and are comfortable with. Don't just go with the flow

Posts.Content: The first thing you should do IMO, is ask that the slides be sent for a second opinion at Johns Hopkins, Dr Jonathan Epstein, who is a foremost prostate cancer specific pathologist. if you got downgraded to G6 it might make active surviellance much more attractive. Reading prostate slides is very subjective, and should be done by a prostate expert. Most local pathologists read many different types of slides. Even if they specialize in Genoutory pathology, they look at prostate, bladder, kidney, ovarian, etc.

Posts.Title: Second PSA-test after surgery..

Posts.Content: Thanks Michael. I did call Quest and asked questions. They checked and confirmed that the numbers posted on my account were in fact my numbers. And when I asked if it's possible that tubes of blood were mixed up, she said highly unlikely, as the tubes are meticulously identified at every step of the process. Also when they took the blood, at the local center, she showed me the tube right after taking my blood and asked me for confirmation that my name, etc w was correct. I asked her if there was any change in the testing assay method and she didn't even know what that meant, she also told me that the normal range was below 4, so it's not a result that should be questioned. At that point I corrected her and pointed out that under 4 is for someone with a. Prostate, and that the test ordered for me was a post prostatectomy test. But I realized that the person. Spoke to was an idiot. If this turns out to be an error, and I'm undetectable, trust me, the CEO is getting a letter from me via FedEx, not that it will matter. I just hope I get that opportunity. Hey,mlogically. Know it's an error in all likelihood. But emotionally I can't help but be a wreck. Even if the number is .338, rather than 3.38, that would be a huge jump in three months. The Xanax is kicking in (I hate taking that) so I guess I'll get through the night, then going yo Dr first thing in the AM PS, Iremember posting about problems with Quest, but never saw or heard of anything like this

Posts.Title: Dr. Epstein @ John Hopkin's

Posts.Content: I have been away in the Wilderness, literally. I dont remember if i mentioned this upcoming trip, but i spent 3 days in Vancouver, a beautiful, and hip city, 8 days cruising Alaska, which was amazing, and then a 2 night stay in Seattle, another great place. Got back last night. While i did have internet access, i made it a point not to log on, i just felt i needed a rest. Between my RALP in January, and the stents and Coronary Artery disease in June, i was just worn out. So i tuned out. I have to say, this was the most timely vacation I've ever taken. I found myself not thinking about cancer (or heart disease) for days at a time, which was a new experience for me. I also found some perspective on life, i believe. I know that i will still be a lunatic if something else goes wrong. But for now, i feel more relaxed about things than i have in a long time. My reason for posting this, is for the new guys. I've noticed in the two weeks i am back, that a lot of new guys have shown up here, and while i dont like to have to welcome them to our reluctant brotherhood, its good for the forum, because we help them and they hopefully get through treatment and help the next group. So my message to the new guys, is there is life after PC, and a really good life. Stay positive, none of us want to be here but we are and there is a lot of life ahead of us to enjoy. Time heals. Take your time to be upset when newly diagnosed, its totally normal. Then get treatment, kick some ass, and take a long vacation. Stay positive

Posts.Title: Life Goes On - Off Topic but not really

Posts.Content: Now that I've had the test, I did what I typically do, surfed the internet looking for data on the validity and utility of this fairly new genomic test. What it's done for me, having come back with a low risk score, if 37, is made me a bit less anxious about a VERY small rise in PSA. And also I think I might be less ggressive about looking at SRT at say .05, if I ever get there, vs the traditional, or as my Uro referred to it, "gold standard" for SRT, of .1. It seems also that this is a terrific tool for determining whether AS is a good idea after a biopsy that indicates low or intermediate risk cancer. Here's an article that I think is worth reading, for anyone struggling with a related issue. it's a discussion of a compendium of studies on the value of the test. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4859922/

Posts.Title: Cellulitis

Posts.Content: Everyone is different and every experience is different, I am 7 weeks out from RALP. I have been fully continent (meaning no pads, but just a squirt here and there, mostly stress related, not enough to need to wear anything). BUT.... Tonight, lying in bed, watching TV, I fell asleep for about 40 minutes. Suddenly, I woke up, and realized that I was wet. VERY wet. Soaked thru my briefs and gym shorts. There was even a small wet spot in the blanket covering me. WTH? I had a strong urge to pee, and got up, was able to control it, then, when in the bathroom,took the longest pee I've taken since the catheter came out No idea where this came from, I guess I'm not really continent. Very frustrating, and scary. Anyone experience this?

Posts.Title: Incontinence Exp

Posts.Content: Tony, most doctors recommend Hormone Therapy IN CONJUNCTION WITH SRT these days, especially with g7 (4+3) or greater. But with favorable intermediate risk of g7(3+4), and a PSA thatbis still relatively low, you can probably avoid HT for now. Just my opinion, like I said I’m not a doc. Qualifier....my RO at MSKCC said with my current PSA at .07, he would be comfortable with me not doing HT with SRT. But if I waited until my PSA got to .1, he would be “much less comfortable”. (I too, am g7(3+4) That’s his opinion, and while he’s a top RO, there is no black and white answer, it’s all a judgement call.

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by mstevens7878 I've had 2 prostatectomies, the last about a year ago. I am 64, and after the second one really had to rely on ED drugs completely. I did experience negative side effects at first (flushed face, back/leg soreness, headaches, dry mouth, stuffy nose) but most of the time even a half dose would seem as effective and really cut down on the side effects. I'm not making alot of money right now, so I have been ordering generic versions from this site http://goo.gl/oNqHkh, my insurance that covers everything else will not cover ED meds at all (I am prescribed to both Cialis & Viagra) and this pharmacy ships to me, and is way cheaper. The drugs are in the same amounts and seem to work exactly the same. Has anyone here had any experience with the "generic" versions that are available? How on earth did you have TWO prostatectomies?

Posts.Title: Cialis and Viagra ??

Posts.Content: From ASA's first link, this is very impressive... 'At five years following SBRT, 97 percent of patients were free from prostate cancer progression. In low-risk patients, the cancer control rates was superior to historical controls. Specifically in the low-risk group, the five-year RFS rate was 97.3 percent, which is superior to the 93 percent historical comparison DFS control rate (p = 0.014). Actuarial five-year OS was 95.6 percent for the entire cohort. Actuarial five-year nadir+2 RFS was 97.1 percent for all patients, representing 97.3 percent of low-risk and 97.1 of intermediate-risk patients. Actuarial five-year ASTRO RFS was 92.3 percent and 91.3 percent for low- and intermediate-risk groups, respectively. Fewer than two percent of all patients experienced serious side effects in the five years following SBRT. Five grade three GU side effects were reported in four of the 309 study participants. There were no reported grade four or five toxicities nor any grade three GI toxicities. Between half and two-thirds of patients experienced less serious side effects, with rates of 53 and 59 percent for grade one GU and GI toxicities and rates of 35 and 10 percent for grade two GU and GI toxicities, respectively. These side effects were usually temporary." Also, Chuck, I may be wrong, but I believe that cyberknife aka SBRT, is not focal, it hits the entire prostate and small amount of surrounding tissue, but is precise enough to avoid most of the healthy non prostatic tissue and areas lie bladder, urethra, etc Also, here's data on, I believe 8 year results with SBRT (aka Cyberknife )��. Don't discount it. One more thing....actually 2....and I don't want to make you nervous, but stuff you need to know... First, my understanding is that 3T MRI is good at picking up higher grade lesions, but not so good at picking up g6. So maybe there is something. But more aggressive lurking Second, the part in the MRI report about the lesion "abutting the capsule", gives me pause. It might mean you re at risk for extra capsular extension sooner rather than later. I'm no doctor , not even an expert Lynn, so none feel free to correct nothing I said tht might be wrong

Posts.Title: Biopsy Done - whew!!

Posts.Content: I am 38000 feet up, on my way home from a 10 day trip to Baton Rouge, Orlando, and Lake Worth, Florida, all for different reasons. While I was gone, I didn't spend as much time on this forum, the other PC forum I'm on, or the ovarian cancer forum I'm on. Not completely off the forums, but much less, mostly because I was very busy. I have to say, it was a great respite. I thought less about cancer. Which was nice, because lately it seems like cancer has occupied my thoughts more than any other topic. Which truly sucks. Anyone else feel this way? Anyway, my respite is about to end. I'll be back at work on Monday, and on Friday I have an appointment with my urologist. Which means -on Tuesday, Wednesday or Thursday, (haven't decided yet) I'll go for my blood draw for PSA. January was 2 years since surgery, and up till then I was <.02. But in January, then again in February I lost the <, and I was .02 both times. So this 3 month test is a big one for me, and I'm starting to sweat. On top of that, my wife is having a CT Scan on Friday, 1st one since finishing chemo for ovarian cncer, 5 weeks ago. She won't get the results for 10 days, when she sees the Dr. But I'll get my results the next day. So I don't know if I should have the blood draw 1, 2 or 3 days before the appointment. The only reason I'm c0nsidering Tuesday is because I have to be in Manhattan that day for business, and it would save me a Trip. But if I do it Tuesday, I will get the results Wednesday, and if it's higher (showing a trend) then I have to wait 2 days to see the Dr and have him talk me off the ledge. What to do, what to do. Just venting, thanks for listening. I really really don't want to recur.😰 (call me Captain Obvious)🙄

Posts.Title: And On It Goes

Posts.Content: You process the information that is relevant to go. And your case. There will be enough studies coming out and new ones to contradict each other. For me it was mindset. There is more to it than just the raw data. There was an argument to be made for me to do AS. But I'm not wired for it. So while I read a ton, all that was relevant yo me was an RO at MSKCC telling me that in my situation the cure rate was the same whether I did surgery or radiation. Get as educated as you can then Filter out what you don't need to know.

Posts.Title: Still in the Zero Club

Posts.Content: I read those studies yesterday I believe they came out of the ASCO meetings. This is something that is common sense, to an extent. For me, it makes sense but is a problem. I love my cheese, and other dairy products. I do try to , and am mostly successful at keeping it to low fat. What's tough and weird though, is that we were always taught that we needed our daiiries. Example:,I enjoy a Fage zero fat Greek yogurt with fruit on occasion. We always thought that yogurt was good for you. And here we are being told that yogurt is not good. Not sure it apples to the fat free though. I I think I recall that reading it was originally though it was the fat in yogurt that was bad for PC, then I read that it was found that the calcium is what's bad. I have managed to cut back on red meat, but I do enjoy a good steak, only occasionally There have also been studies showing that vitamin D is important and needs to be kept at optimum levels. Then I read that there is a correlation between high Vit D and BCR. THE DIET THING IS ALL SO CONFUSING

Posts.Title: Prostate Biopsy 46 yrs old 4.8 PSA

Posts.Content: Chuck, i could be wrong, apologies if thats the case. But my understanding is that after RP surgery, they consider a BCR/Bio Chemical Recurrence, to be a rise to .1, followed by a second reading at that number or higher. After radiation, it would be a rise from nadir, followed by 2 consecutive rises after that. To Thewife - your husband is lucky to have you as his advocate. I AGREE with you that waiting 6 months is too long. If i were you i would ask him what the number is that he uses to signal BCR, and at what point he would recommend SRT. And i would also insist on a PSA retake sooner than 6 months. In fact, i would be asking for a retake in 2 months, 3 max. Also, there have been studies done that have shown in certain situations, the max benefit from SRT comes if its started earler, as early as PSA of .03. I do not recall 100%, but i think that was a study done specifically on G8-10 patients, so if thats the case, it may not apply. Good luck, please keep us posted

Posts.Title: DDay

Posts.Content: DP, i have to say i find it odd, that a physician, who has followed many Prostate Cancer patients, would come to an internet forum for advice from a group of laymen With that said, there is always possibility of a lab error, as you probably know. I had 3 consecutive undetectable PSAs after surgery with very favorable pathology and similar results on the MSKCC Nomogram as your dads. And then my fourth PSA test came back at 3.88!!!!! I had it retested at another lab, it came back undetectable, and the first lab then confirmed that after retesting the same blood they too got an undetectable. So yes, its possible that its a lab error, get a retest.

Posts.Content: Everyone is different and every experience is different, I am 7 weeks out from RALP. I have been fully continent (meaning no pads, but just a squirt here and there, mostly stress related, not enough to need to wear anything). BUT.... Tonight, lying in bed, watching TV, I fell asleep for about 40 minutes. Suddenly, I woke up, and realized that I was wet. VERY wet. Soaked thru my briefs and gym shorts. There was even a small wet spot in the blanket covering me. WTH? I had a strong urge to pee, and got up, was able to control it, then, when in the bathroom,took the longest pee I've taken since the catheter came out No idea where this came from, I guess I'm not really continent. Very frustrating, and scary. Anyone experience this?

Posts.Title: Biopsy Done - whew!!

Posts.Content: Hello Guys, its been a while. To those of you who have been here a while, its good (sort of) to be back, although not for the reasons Im here. So it looks like I may very well be headed for radiation treatments. And its been recommended I do so early. Im at .06 as of March, just to make it easy, Im going to cut and paste the post I put up on another forum, with the background, for the guys here that are new enough to not know my backstory....any comments are welcome and appreciated. At the reco of a friend/member here, I met today with the chair of RAd Onc at Cleveland Clinic in Florida. It was a long meeting, and very informative. The short version is.... He recommends treating soon (to review, I was undetectable until the 2 year post op mark, then .02, .033, .033, .046, 060, see signature below) he cited this study... /jamanetwork.com/journals/jamaoncology/article-abstract/2670381?redirect=true A multi institutional study with n=1566, it showed an advantage to treating below .1, vs treating .1 - .5. The entire cohort was adverse pathology. While I had negative final margins, the RO felt that because my frozen section intraoperative margin was positive, and at the apex, my negative final margin was questionable, and he placed a high probability on the PSA coming from cells left in the prostate bed, thus a relatively high probability of a good result. He said if I wanted to wait a few months he didnt think it would put me at increased risk. He didnt put too much weight into my low Decipher score, saying I could be one of the 3% that has recurrence, nor did he put much weight in the oncoDx Grid report that predicted poor response to SRT, saying there was not enough data to validate it yet, too small a sample. I also asked him what he thinks might happen if I decided to do nothing. His response, a 50% chance that 10 years from now I would be living a happy life with no issues related to PC. And a 50% chance that Id have some serious problems in 10 years. I dont like those odds. He said with their machine, Varian Edge, I think, the chance of permanent side effects was less than 5% (but I should expect transient side effects) I am meeting with Dr Zelefsky, RO at MSKCC, mid June. I will have one more PSA before that meeting. I am inclined to look fir one more increased PSA after the Zelefsky meeting, then taking action, although that also depends on what the pre-Zelefsky PSA shows. Ive pretty much tossed aside my Surgeons advice to do nothing until/unless i get to .2. I wish their was a black and white answer, but there apparently is not. So the beat goes on. One thing I did not ask, is whether Medicare would approve early Salvage . Anybody know the answer from experience?

Posts.Title: Back from RALRP

Posts.Content: Sorry for your diagnosis. But Gleason 6 is about as good , or maybe I should say, least bad, as it gets. You should def send your slides to dr Jonathan Epstein, at Johns Hopkins for 2nd opinion, he is the worlds recognized expert in prostate cancer pathology. Your Dr will know him, and you might be able to just ask your Drs office to arrange it. Otherwise, heres a link with info and instructions.... http://pathology.jhu.edu/department/...ondopinion.cfm Look at all options, surgery, and different types of radiation, SBRT (Cyberknife), LDR Brachytherapy (seeds), HDR Brachytherapy, even IG-IMRT. THEY WILL ALL LIKELY CURE YOU. ITS IMPORTANT TO SPEAK TO AN EXPERT IN EACH OF THESE METHODOLOGIES. They will all favor their own. Get educated then make up your own mind. You should have an open mind to Active Surveillance. But if you are not wired for it, totally understandable. Genomic testing might make you more comfortable with it. Or less. Walshs book is an excellent start to your education. You are in a good position. Stay calm, learn and you have plenty of time to decide. There is no wrong decision here.

Posts.Title: New to the Forum

Posts.Content: Thanks everyone for the hopeful comments, and for the warm welcome back. Intellectually I know that it could very well be a statistical anamoly. Emotionally though, as I'm sure everyone here knows, it's a killer of a thing to anticipate. It could go either way as we all know. The question is what was the last result 6 months ago? Was the true number .001? Or was it .019. I can't know that because the assay only measures to anything .02 or higher, thus the result <.02. If the true number was .001, I've got a problem. If it was .019, then a move to .020 is insignificant for sure. Then if it's positive again, and turns out it's a Recurrence, how do I know when it recurred. Might have been w months ago. Do we assume it was 2 years, since the test was done 2 years post RALP? Or could it have started soon fire my last test 6bmonths ago? Unknowable. The NP when she called with the result 3. Weeks ago told me they still consider it undetectable. But the fact is, it was measurable. I was told they don't really worry bout it until it hits .1. If in fact this is a recurrence, I don't plan on waiting that long. If it gets to .05, maybe .04, I'm off to see the nuke specialist. Which, from what I understand has a lower chance of working, when you had positive margins. So you can see, my head, which had been fairly com up until a day or two, is spinning. @ron, Chuck, I her you on the uPSA vs STANDARD PSA. But I think once you start with uPSA, it's hard to go back. And I would want to know sooner, if it's creeping up. @Micheal - my first few tests were done at Quest, and were all <.02. Then I had. 3 month test come back at 3.8 (no typo) which was an error that the Senior VP of oncology testing could not figure out how it happened, (I had a phone call with him because I was pissed) and I lost confidence in their process no started testing at my DRs (Tewari) hospital lab , mt Sinai in NY. The first two of those tests came back at 0.00, that's how they report it. Then the next two came back at <.02. I scrutinized those reports and found that the two 0.00's were a different assay than the last two. Now, the .02 reading without the <, was done on the same assay as the last two <02's. So I don't think it's the assay. I guess I'll know more tomorrow, seeing the Dr at 11am, but will likely get a phone call with the results by 9:30-9:45. I'll report back Thanks again.

Posts.Title: 1 Year Anniversary of Surgery & Thoughts

Posts.Content: Thanks for all the responses. Much appreciated. @Featherboy - the doc i am working with is the urologist. My primary care doc, who is a cardiologist, said i should do the biopsy, but i'm ignoring him on this one, he's the type that if i show up at his office with a cold, he sends me for a brain scan. Update - i called the urologist back, and asked him some questions (below with his responses) . I got the questions from readin this forum, and he said they were great questions, all the right one's, so thank you. i asked 1. should we do free psa, psa3, before doing a biopsy. His response was he generally does those tests when the PSA is above 4. Since my PSA is 2.2, he thinks the results wouldn't be useful 2. What about CIPRO? - His response was that he uses CIPRO alot, but its more likely to be an infection, when there is a sudden spike, as opposed to my situation which has been trending up over a few years, slowly 3. Would doing a biopsy with what might be such an apparently very early stage situation increase the chances of false negative? He said it wouldn't 4. does he use ultrasound to guide the biopsy - he said yes 5. what does he do about pain management - he said it wasn't really necessary, he just uses a little lydocaine around the prostate. I followed up with a question about gel to numb the area before the lydocaine injection, he said he doesnt use it , there is not that much pain frmo the lydocaine injection. He said regarding teh cipro, even though my situation was not typical of an infection it was worth a try (why didnt he try it before i brought it up?) So he gave me a prescription and said to retake in a month. I said ok. Last thing i told him was that he shouldn't be surprised if i request the records because i would go for a second opinion before i do anything invasive (like a biopsy). He was totally cool with that (as he should be, it wouldn't matter to me if he wasnt) So that leads me to my next move. I contacted a Doc who was recommended to me at Columbia Presbyterian, Dr DeCastro, for a second opinion, i am going to see him next Friday. Maybe I am wrong, but it bothers me that the doc i am seeing is a one doc practice in a small local office. He was recommended to me by my Primary Care Doc,but you know how that goes, they are all buddies. So i have no way of knowing who is good, but i figure at Columbia, they are well known in Urology, i think on a par with Hopkins, and why not consult with the best. So we'll see. I will be pretty nervous until this is resolved one way or the other, even though i know that if it turns out to be a problem, it is in all likelyhood very early and curable. I can't even imagine having an "i have cancer" conversation with my 29 - 30 year old kids, no matter how good the prognosis. I think thats what scares me most. It will be a long week. Thanks for letting me vent 3.
Posts.Title: PSA Rising, Need Guidance

Posts.Content: Went to Urologist today, PSA continues to rise - facts and numbers as follows: Age - just turned 62 Father had Prostate Cancer PSA Levels: 2009 - .7 2010 - 1.1 2011 - did not take April 2012 - 1.7 (or 1.6, not clear) Nov 2012 - 2.2 Got the 2.2 results today. Doc did digital rectal exam, prostate felt normal. Gave me choice - biopsy now, or wait 3 months. Told me, while you can never be sure, he feels 3 months wait would not present any real risks. I asked what he would do if it was him - he said he would do the biopsy, and he has, in a similar situation. Said the threshold at my age is 3.5, but rising level, with family history is cause for concern. I found an online calculator that showed the velocity is .37, not sure of the exact dates i put in but they weren't far off. I've read that there is controversy about how important velocity is. I told the doc i would come back in three months for retake but i dont know if i am doing the right thing I am in NY area, i hear Columbia Presbyterian has high reputation docs for this. Should i 1. do the biopsy 2. wait the three months and retake PSA 3. retake PSA in a month or two (doc didn't date the scrip) 3. get a second opinion immediately Also, do any docs put you to sleep for the biopsy? I've heard it is pretty painful. Very nervous, any guidance would be really appreciated.

Posts.Content: I've been way from here for a while, preoccupied with other family health issues. If it's not one thing, it's another. Like Brandon's dad, I am facing a possible issue, not yet sure though. RALP JAN 2015, (3+4), negative margins and begtive ECE. uPSA post RALP has consistently been <.02. Until 3 weeks go t my 2 year test, when it came back at .02. Nurse practitioner called me with results NS told me it's still considered undetectable. But clearly, it was measurable, unlike previous tests. They suggested retest at my Drs appointment which is scheduled for this Friday. I am going in tomorrow for the blood draw so he has the results when I see him. I know it could be a blip. Or maybe not. Shitting bricks tonight. Ken

Posts.Title: The Prostate has left the building.

Posts.Content: Depends on the doc. My first will be at 6 weeks post surgery, the second will be 6 weeks after that. I think after that I go to 3 months, not sure. Honestly, if I had a PSA rise at 6 weeks I wouldn't do anything anyway, too soon after surgery to have SRT, so I don't know what the sense is. I wonder if the DRs that do the first one at 6 weeks post op are doing it more for their own research. But I'll do whatever my surgeon says, he's a rock star, so I'm not about to debate the usefulness of that first PSA.

Posts.Title: One year Result, no man's land follow up.

Posts.Content: Trinity, i sent you a PM in response to your PM. I'll add to it here but just want to note that everyone here has confirmed what i said in my PM, that you need to address this, and need treatment, pending a second opinion on the slides, which you should get on immediately. I assume you are in the NY area based on who you said you are seeing in your PM. Based on that, you have plenty of good people to consult with. I would recommend my surgeon, (as I'm sure most everybody would, LOL) Dr Ash Tewari, in Manhattan. He's done over 6000 Robotic Prostatectomies. I specifically asked him if he does the entire surgery. He told me, that his assistants (Drs) position the arms of the robot, but he is the only one that ever touches the controls. Also, Dr James Eastham has a very good rep at MSKCC, i believe he does mostly open. Others will mention Samadi, i met with him, and thought he was pompous, he denegrated my urologist, Dr Aaron Katz, who does have a good rep, so i would never go near him, Just my opinion. You should also explore radiation - seeds (brachy), SBRT (Cyberknife) and external Beam radiation. I met with Dr Gewanter, who is at MSKCC on Long Island (on the campus of Mercy Hospital, but no affilaition). He was terrific. He is Cheif of radiation Oncology at MSKCC, LONG ISLAND DIVISION. He does not do Brachy, if you went that way, he would refer you to the manhattan LOCATION. Dr Zelefsky, who does Brach at MSKCC in Manhattan, is one of the best in the country. Of course, Dr Jon Haas, does Cyberknife at Winthrop. Back to surgery, if you prefer to see someone on Long Island, i would meet with Dr Felix Badillo. I know two people who had him do surgery and both were very happy. I met with him, nice man. I just wanted Tewari. Badillo is Chief of Urology at Saint Francis. Most important - you need to learn all you can about all the different options available to you. Everyone has different values, i, like most people had my priorities of cure, contincence and erectile function in that order. As i told my surgeon. At age 65, i piss 7 times a day, i have sex 7 times a year (exaggerating to make a point) so just make sure i am continent. Tewaris results are 97% fully continent within one year - his definition of continent (important question to ask) is no pads. Like i said, learn as much as possible, be your own advocate. If you look hard enough you might find a doctor that tells you what you want to hear, that AS is ok. (although maybe not, with a G8 )BUT You need treatment if in fact it is an 8. Sorry to ramble, but i wanted to give you as much help as possible. Again, I'm not a medical professional, just a guy who had his prostate taken out and is very happy with the result, and more knowledgeable for the experience. Good luck and keep us posted, and keep in touch

Posts.Title: 12 Hours to go....

Posts.Content: Thanks for all the responses. Much appreciated. @Featherboy - the doc i am working with is the urologist. My primary care doc, who is a cardiologist, said i should do the biopsy, but i'm ignoring him on this one, he's the type that if i show up at his office with a cold, he sends me for a brain scan. Update - i called the urologist back, and asked him some questions (below with his responses) . I got the questions from readin this forum, and he said they were great questions, all the right one's, so thank you. i asked 1. should we do free psa, psa3, before doing a biopsy. His response was he generally does those tests when the PSA is above 4. Since my PSA is 2.2, he thinks the results wouldn't be useful 2. What about CIPRO? - His response was that he uses CIPRO alot, but its more likely to be an infection, when there is a sudden spike, as opposed to my situation which has been trending up over a few years, slowly 3. Would doing a biopsy with what might be such an apparently very early stage situation increase the chances of false negative? He said it wouldn't 4. does he use ultrasound to guide the biopsy - he said yes 5. what does he do about pain management - he said it wasn't really necessary, he just uses a little lydocaine around the prostate. I followed up with a question about gel to numb the area before the lydocaine injection, he said he doesnt use it , there is not that much pain frmo the lydocaine injection. He said regarding teh cipro, even though my situation was not typical of an infection it was worth a try (why didnt he try it before i brought it up?) So he gave me a prescription and said to retake in a month. I said ok. Last thing i told him was that he shouldn't be surprised if i request the records because i would go for a second opinion before i do anything invasive (like a biopsy). He was totally cool with that (as he should be, it wouldn't matter to me if he wasnt) So that leads me to my next move. I contacted a Doc who was recommended to me at Columbia Presbyterian, Dr DeCastro, for a second opinion, i am going to see him next Friday. Maybe I am wrong, but it bothers me that the doc i am seeing is a one doc practice in a small local office. He was recommended to me by my Primary Care Doc,but you know how that goes, they are all buddies. So i have no way of knowing who is good, but i figure at Columbia, they are well known in Urology, i think on a par with Hopkins, and why not consult with the best. So we'll see. I will be pretty nervous until this is resolved one way or the other, even though i know that if it turns out to be a problem, it is in all likelyhood very early and curable. I can't even imagine having an "i have cancer" conversation with my 29 - 30 year old kids, no matter how good the prognosis. I think thats what scares me most. It will be a long week. Thanks for letting me vent 3.
Posts.Title: PSA Rising, Need Guidance

Posts.Content: Went to Urologist today, PSA continues to rise - facts and numbers as follows: Age - just turned 62 Father had Prostate Cancer PSA Levels: 2009 - .7 2010 - 1.1 2011 - did not take April 2012 - 1.7 (or 1.6, not clear) Nov 2012 - 2.2 Got the 2.2 results today. Doc did digital rectal exam, prostate felt normal. Gave me choice - biopsy now, or wait 3 months. Told me, while you can never be sure, he feels 3 months wait would not present any real risks. I asked what he would do if it was him - he said he would do the biopsy, and he has, in a similar situation. Said the threshold at my age is 3.5, but rising level, with family history is cause for concern. I found an online calculator that showed the velocity is .37, not sure of the exact dates i put in but they weren't far off. I've read that there is controversy about how important velocity is. I told the doc i would come back in three months for retake but i dont know if i am doing the right thing I am in NY area, i hear Columbia Presbyterian has high reputation docs for this. Should i 1. do the biopsy 2. wait the three months and retake PSA 3. retake PSA in a month or two (doc didn't date the scrip) 3. get a second opinion immediately Also, do any docs put you to sleep for the biopsy? I've heard it is pretty painful. Very nervous, any guidance would be really appreciated.
Posts.Title: PSA Rising, Need Guidance

Posts.Content: I get such different takes on the pain level. Half the people i have talked to agree with you Featherboy. The other half tell me its really difficult.
Posts.Title: PSA Rising, Need Guidance

Posts.Content: Thanks Highlander, i appreciate the insight. I should clarify - when the doc said the DRE was normal (he actually used the word 'fine") i believe what he meant was (based on our conversation from the last visit) that there were no lumps and it was soft. I know that my prostate is somewhat enlarged (dont know how much) because i have been told that a couple of times over the last 10 years or so, but in the context of it being "normally enlarged for my age". Also, Highlander, no i have no urinary symptoms. I get up once at night, SOMETIMES, but i do dring a ton of water, even at night. I dont have dripping. My stream is not what i would consider weak, although i dont piss like a racehorse the way i did in my 30's. So I am pretty much asymptomatic. I am going to go ahead with the visit to Columbia - i might have mentioned in the previous post, i am seeing the Co-Director of the Dept of Urology - just to be complete. But i think i have decided that i after seeing him, unless he surprises me by telling me something different, i am going to have the biopsy. I am too nervous about it. I actually had to take a xanax tonight, so i don't want to live like this for three more months, or even six weeks. In addition to which i dowloaded the Dr. Patrick Walsh book and read the chapter on PSA and DRE screening, and he seems to indicate that i am clearly biopsy material. Curious - i mentioned also in a previous post, when i asked my current doc about pain management he seemed rather flip about it, he said its no big deal, he just gives " a little lydocaine around the area of the prostate" , and when asked said he doesnt numb the area prior to the lydocaine injection. No gel either. Is that standard? Should i be looking for something different? I don't have a great tolerance level for pain. Thanks again, in advance to everyone. I can't say you guys are calming me down, but you have been a big help.
Posts.Title: PSA Rising, Need Guidance

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by Flkjr Well that sucks, Gunny!!! And not only for you but the rest of us, too! Everyone with stats like yours (me included) just got a little less comfortable with their own situation. Keep us abreast of your situation and good luck!!! Fran ^^^^^This It's amazing to me how I see so many guys here and on the other forum I frequent, with G7(3+4) negative margins, no ECE, no "nuttin", who end up with BCR. My surgeon to,d me at my 3 month post up visit that less than 5 % of his patients with those (my) stats need any further treatment. And yet I see so many guys like you, Gunny, who end up with BCR. At least the scans were negative. Keep us posted on the ROs comments.

Posts.Title: Psa post robotic prostate removal

Posts.Content: Dave, yes, you hve to try to focus on going forward. I think you would be wise to see the RO and get his take. I read a study, can’t recall where, that showed Surgeons hve. Tendency to recommend SRT much later than RO’s. I’m guessing it’s becuase RO’s tend to read more about the latest data pointing to the benefits of Starting SRT earlier. I think I mentioned in your previous thread, I’ve seen one RO who recommended I start SRT now, or soon, and my PSA is at .06. And I’m seeing another RO who after seeing my last two psa’s, .046 and .06, had his secretary call me and say he wants to see me to discuss treatment. Meanwhile my surgeon, well known and world reknowned, tells me to wait till .2, then we’ll do imaging. So it’s a quandary, but my gut tells me that we both should put more weight in what the ro’s Say. This sure does suck. But it is what it is. We aren’t gonna die from this crap.worst case, it makes our life miserable for a while. But we soldier on

Posts.Title: Surgeons at Johns Hopkins

Posts.Content: I think the book you mention does a good service in that it does provide a different perspective vs the Patrick Walsh book which so many read. It’s important that newly diagnosed men be aware of the possibility of Overtreatment. I read both books and chose surgery. I’d rather be overtreated than undertreated (that alone would probably make for an interesting thread). And I’m not a big fan of AS despite the studies showing how well it works. But that’s me. I do think the task force reco’s Cost lives.

Posts.Title: Surgeons at Johns Hopkins

Posts.Content: Sorry about your diagnosis Mike. But as Highlander said, there's plenty of hope. As far as different Drs , different systems, you will get a referral from the urologist to an oncologist, but you don't have to take it. You can see anyone you want. Try to be sure that whatever oncologist you see, has plenty of experience with aggressive prostate cancer. And don't be railroaded into one treatment or bother. Do your own research, be your own advocate. Find a Dr you trust and are comfortable with. Don't just go with the flow

Posts.Title: Ridiculous squirting-problem

Posts.Content: Thanks all, for your responses, all very helpful, and Otago - thank you very useful, I appreciate the information. So i got home an hour ago, very uneventful. They found nothing. He told me that the stents were in place and working just the way we want them to, and they found nothing significant that needed to be stented. I asked, in that case, how should we approach the fact that i did have a positive echo stress test. He told me that the positive aspect of the stress test were not that significant, so just dont worry about it. I know that about 30% of stress tests are false positives. Also it was only the EKG that was abnormal, the images looked very good. So hopefully thats the end of it and i can move on. I'll talk with my cardiologist later today or tomorrow. Otago, you've given me some great questions to ask the cardiologist, expecially about whether to exercess through what appears to be stable angina (or my defective brain, not sure which. So now i get to lay around all day and ask my wife to make me lunch, do this, get me that. And actually get away with it, without hearing "go f yourself, do it yourself? LOL Thanks again to all, for the support.

Everyone with stats like yours (me included) just got a little less comfortable with their own situation. Keep us abreast of your situation and good luck!!! Fran ^^^^^This It's amazing to me how I see so many guys here and on the other forum I frequent, with G7(3+4) negative margins, no ECE, no "nuttin", who end up with BCR. My surgeon to,d me at my 3 month post up visit that less than 5 % of his patients with those (my) stats need any further treatment. And yet I see so many guys like you, Gunny, who end up with BCR. At least the scans were negative. Keep us posted on the ROs comments.

Posts.Title: Sweating Bullets

Posts.Content: I am 38000 feet up, on my way home from a 10 day trip to Baton Rouge, Orlando, and Lake Worth, Florida, all for different reasons. While I was gone, I didn't spend as much time on this forum, the other PC forum I'm on, or the ovarian cancer forum I'm on. Not completely off the forums, but much less, mostly because I was very busy. I have to say, it was a great respite. I thought less about cancer. Which was nice, because lately it seems like cancer has occupied my thoughts more than any other topic. Which truly sucks. Anyone else feel this way? Anyway, my respite is about to end. I'll be back at work on Monday, and on Friday I have an appointment with my urologist. Which means -on Tuesday, Wednesday or Thursday, (haven't decided yet) I'll go for my blood draw for PSA. January was 2 years since surgery, and up till then I was <.02. But in January, then again in February I lost the <, and I was .02 both times. So this 3 month test is a big one for me, and I'm starting to sweat. On top of that, my wife is having a CT Scan on Friday, 1st one since finishing chemo for ovarian cncer, 5 weeks ago. She won't get the results for 10 days, when she sees the Dr. But I'll get my results the next day. So I don't know if I should have the blood draw 1, 2 or 3 days before the appointment. The only reason I'm c0nsidering Tuesday is because I have to be in Manhattan that day for business, and it would save me a Trip. But if I do it Tuesday, I will get the results Wednesday, and if it's higher (showing a trend) then I have to wait 2 days to see the Dr and have him talk me off the ledge. What to do, what to do. Just venting, thanks for listening. I really really don't want to recur.😰 (call me Captain Obvious)🙄

Posts.Title: 3 Days To Go

Posts.Content: Red, as Highlander indicated, a PSA of 140 is certainly an indicator of a probable problem. And treatment won't be fun. But prostate cancer today, can be treated as a chronic disease for many years, even decades. I know of one brother who was diagnosed 11 years ago with a PSA of 3200 and bone Mets all over the place. Today his PSA is undetectable, and he is living large. Here is a link to his blog, he is n inspiration.... http://toddseals63.blogspot.com . He was 42 when diagnosed. It's a shock. Take a breath. Get educated. Your husband will be around to annoy you for many years. Good luck, stick around, and keep us posted.

Posts.Title: Beginning of new journey

Posts.Content: Your Cancer is low to intermediate risk . Keep in mind that you will need to keep an eye on your Psa as your Dr has surely told you after surgery. But if it was confined to the Prostate when taken out, the odds are better than 90% that it won't return. If you do get some rise in PSA after surgery , yes, you will need radiation. That should zap it. If it comes back after that, it's far from goodbye. There are all kinds of different Hormone Therapies, chmotherapy etc that can keep things under control for many years, even decades.

Posts.Title: So im ready for the surgery

Posts.Content: Dave, yes, you hve to try to focus on going forward. I think you would be wise to see the RO and get his take. I read a study, can’t recall where, that showed Surgeons hve. Tendency to recommend SRT much later than RO’s. I’m guessing it’s becuase RO’s tend to read more about the latest data pointing to the benefits of Starting SRT earlier. I think I mentioned in your previous thread, I’ve seen one RO who recommended I start SRT now, or soon, and my PSA is at .06. And I’m seeing another RO who after seeing my last two psa’s, .046 and .06, had his secretary call me and say he wants to see me to discuss treatment. Meanwhile my surgeon, well known and world reknowned, tells me to wait till .2, then we’ll do imaging. So it’s a quandary, but my gut tells me that we both should put more weight in what the ro’s Say. This sure does suck. But it is what it is. We aren’t gonna die from this crap.worst case, it makes our life miserable for a while. But we soldier on

Posts.Content: Welcome to the forum. You’ve gotten good advice above, not much to add, except to emphasize that you should get that second opinion on your pathology. And get it from the gold standard, Dr Jonathan Epstein at Johns Hopkins. Here’s a link http://pathology.jhu.edu/department/...ondopinion.cfm

Posts.Title: 12 Hours to go....

Posts.Content: Samie, lots of good advice above. Especially from those who told you in one way or another that all is not lost. Has he had an MRI? A 3 Tesla Multiparametric MRI will show with 95% accuracy, whether the cancer has left the prostate capsule. I think that is what you should be looking to find out. If it hasnt its clearly curable with surgery. Even if it has, it might be. But if its contained, its a strong case for surgery. Also, consider sending the biopsy slides for a second opinion to either Dr Jonathan Epstein at Johns Hopkins or David Bostwick at Bostwick Laboratories. Both are experts in prostate pathology, as opposed to most local pathologists who look at all kinds of slides. It is not unusual to have a gleason score changed on second opinion, reading those slides is very subjective. If you were to be downgraded to a gleason 6 (3+3) it would change everything. Of course the PSA of 39 is troubling. But its not the end all. It could be partially attributed to infection or inflammation of the prostate.

Posts.Title: 61 yo husband newly diagnosed with high risk prostrate cancer

Posts.Content: Stuntmole, one of the most frustrating parts of recovery is the urinary leakage, at least for me.but it gets better. Everything you describe, sounds normal, including the burning while peeling . The day I got the catheter out, I remember having yo walk up,and down the halls after drinking water, so they could see me pee on my own before letting me go home. I remember walking back and forth fro about 3 hours, then I sat down for a few minutes as my legs needed a rest. When I got up, I noticed the chair was soaking wet. After feeling my sweatpants, I realizedthey were soaked. I would keep doing the Kegels. I started 4 times a day, each time was one set of 10 reps, holding 10 seconds, followed by 10 seconds f rest. I'm finally seeing progress, no,leaking In tHE LAST 36 hours, and last night I slept almost 6 hours without waking up to pee. That was the first time I went more than 3 hours of straight sleep since the surgery. So my point is, I went through the same frustatrayions as you are, but if you are diligent about Kegels, you will likely do well.

Posts.Title: Questions on post RALP Incontinence Recovery

Posts.Content: Last year, on Thanksgiving Day, before my guests arrived for the Holiday, I had to sit down with my daughter and tell her I had cancer. That was a hard conversation. Fast forward a year later, and like the title says, I've got a lot yo be thankful for. SO FAR seemingly successful surgery with minimal if any side effects, not to mention a test happy Primary Care Doc, whose tests found a life threatening Blockage in my main artery. What a year. So I just want to thank the guys here for the help I got in my darkest moments. Especially Chuck. I hope I can continue to repay it by helping other guys who show up here with a similar dilemma. Enjoy your turkey!
