Posts.Title: Questions on post RALP Incontinence Recovery

Posts.Content: I think the book you mention does a good service in that it does provide a different perspective vs the Patrick Walsh book which so many read. It’s important that newly diagnosed men be aware of the possibility of Overtreatment. I read both books and chose surgery. I’d rather be overtreated than undertreated (that alone would probably make for an interesting thread). And I’m not a big fan of AS despite the studies showing how well it works. But that’s me. I do think the task force reco’s Cost lives.

Posts.Title: 61 yo husband newly diagnosed with high risk prostrate cancer

Posts.Content: Sounds like you've got a good marriage. I don't know you from a hole in the wall, but I'm guessing if you offered to "set her free" she would laugh in your face, then smack you down. Suggestion... talk to a professional, it might help. Getting any kind of cancer diagnosis, even a relatively treatable, and even curable one, is devastating , it takes time to process. And the thought of side effects would be upsetting to anyone. I'm no expert, but it sounds to me like you could use some professional help sorting out your feelings.

Posts.Title: Newly Diagnosed - Way too much information to process

Posts.Content: Your Cancer is low to intermediate risk . Keep in mind that you will need to keep an eye on your Psa as your Dr has surely told you after surgery. But if it was confined to the Prostate when taken out, the odds are better than 90% that it won't return. If you do get some rise in PSA after surgery , yes, you will need radiation. That should zap it. If it comes back after that, it's far from goodbye. There are all kinds of different Hormone Therapies, chmotherapy etc that can keep things under control for many years, even decades.

Posts.Title: My Cousin has Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: Red, as Highlander indicated, a PSA of 140 is certainly an indicator of a probable problem. And treatment won't be fun. But prostate cancer today, can be treated as a chronic disease for many years, even decades. I know of one brother who was diagnosed 11 years ago with a PSA of 3200 and bone Mets all over the place. Today his PSA is undetectable, and he is living large. Here is a link to his blog, he is n inspiration.... http://toddseals63.blogspot.com . He was 42 when diagnosed. It's a shock. Take a breath. Get educated. Your husband will be around to annoy you for many years. Good luck, stick around, and keep us posted.

Posts.Content: Sabertex, welcome to the other side. Re the BM, I think you can be a little,patient, say one more day. I went to Day 4, was passing gas but no BM, like you. On day 4 I asked my wife to go out and buy some prune juice. I had one 8 ounce glass on an empty stomach. About an hour later, it was bombs away, like the 4th of July. Might have happened anyway, but I think the it was the prune juice , working it’s magic. Tasted disgusting, but well worth it lol. Also, when you do go, hold a pillow against your stomach, to protect yourself from working too hard.

Posts.Title: DDay

Posts.Content: MM, you've read enough on this forum and I'm sure elsewhere, to know that while this is scary stuff, it's definitely manageable, and highly likely to be curable. The T1c is great, that means no abnormalities felt on the DRE of the prostate. uC from what I hear is a great place for this, and you'll be in great hands. We all know your head is swimming now, because none of us will ever forget how we were, the day we got the news and the weeks that followed. But your gonna be fine, and a year from now, (less actually), you will likely look back at this as a bump in the road. One thing - get your slides sent to Epstein or Bostwick for a second opinion. Keep us posted, we've all got your back.

Posts.Title: Here we go again...

Posts.Content: John, welcome. I had surgery as my primary treatment. And most of us have a bias towards whatever treatment we chose. With that caveat, I'll say I'm not sorry. Uneventful, full recovery, no incontinence, and with Cialis no issues with turning little John into Big John. Hve you looked at SBRT (AKA Cyberknife)? It's got a very good 10 year track record now, I think IMRT for primary is old school, and what's more common these days is SBRT and HDR Brachytherapy, which leads me to my next question. You mentioned brachytherapy, but didn't differentiate between HDR and LDR. HDR is the newer and I think more state of the art form. Rectestosterone, I'm no expert, but I think there's a lot of scientific evidence that supplements don't promote PC growth. It's counterintuitive, I know, but that's what I read. Good luck and keep us posted

Posts.Title: Good Luck Highlander

Posts.Content: Stuntmole, seems all pretty normal for 10 days past surgery. Nothing alarming here. U will learn to automatically Kegel at the right times, like getting out of bed for example, to prevent leaks. It will become an automatic reflex, no thinking involved. It will just take time. Also, don't expect improvement to be linear. It will happen, with two steps forward one step back. Yesterday for example, I had my first 24 hour (ending yesterday morning) leak free period. But today, I weighed my pad this morning and had a leakage over 24 hours of .3 ounces. So don't get discouraged, it will all get amazingly better over time.

Posts.Title: One day after surgery.

Posts.Content: Samie, lots of good advice above. Especially from those who told you in one way or another that all is not lost. Has he had an MRI? A 3 Tesla Multiparametric MRI will show with 95% accuracy, whether the cancer has left the prostate capsule. I think that is what you should be looking to find out. If it hasnt its clearly curable with surgery. Even if it has, it might be. But if its contained, its a strong case for surgery. Also, consider sending the biopsy slides for a second opinion to either Dr Jonathan Epstein at Johns Hopkins or David Bostwick at Bostwick Laboratories. Both are experts in prostate pathology, as opposed to most local pathologists who look at all kinds of slides. It is not unusual to have a gleason score changed on second opinion, reading those slides is very subjective. If you were to be downgraded to a gleason 6 (3+3) it would change everything. Of course the PSA of 39 is troubling. But its not the end all. It could be partially attributed to infection or inflammation of the prostate.

Posts.Title: 61 yo husband newly diagnosed with high risk prostrate cancer

Posts.Content: Your Cancer is low to intermediate risk . Keep in mind that you will need to keep an eye on your Psa as your Dr has surely told you after surgery. But if it was confined to the Prostate when taken out, the odds are better than 90% that it won't return. If you do get some rise in PSA after surgery , yes, you will need radiation. That should zap it. If it comes back after that, it's far from goodbye. There are all kinds of different Hormone Therapies, chmotherapy etc that can keep things under control for many years, even decades.

Posts.Title: Meeting with the URO next Friday for TX options

Posts.Content: So after having a cardiac catheterization 2 months ago with 2 stents inserted, to clear blockage sq, I'm having another one this morning. Had a very slight tightness in my throat when I run, after about a minute, that goes away when I slow to a walk. Honestly I'm not sure if it's real, or in my head, because I am so hyper aware of every little sensation since the stents were inserted in June. In fact, it's so slight, that I told the Dr if I wasn't looking for it, I wouldn't even notice it. But I had an echo stress test yesterday, and while the pictures were ok, the EKG showed abnormalities, same as before my stents were out in. So the doctor wants to be cautious and make sure everything is ok. I am seriously so done with this crap, it's really getting old. Thanks for letting me rant

Posts.Title: Here we go again

Posts.Content: Everything i have read, says that a fPSA test is not useful if the PSA is under 4.1. So if my total PSA is 2.8, and my fPSA is 11, (which i know is not a good number), what does that mean, does anyone know? This was the situation last April, and i am due to go back for retest in the next couple of weeks. The fPSA # is making me nervous, but if my PSA is below 4, does that make it meaningless? And if its not useful with PSA under 4.1, why would a Uro order the test, knowing that total psa is under 4.1?

Posts.Title: Free PSA question

Posts.Content: Thanks all, for your responses, all very helpful, and Otago - thank you very useful, I appreciate the information. So i got home an hour ago, very uneventful. They found nothing. He told me that the stents were in place and working just the way we want them to, and they found nothing significant that needed to be stented. I asked, in that case, how should we approach the fact that i did have a positive echo stress test. He told me that the positive aspect of the stress test were not that significant, so just dont worry about it. I know that about 30% of stress tests are false positives. Also it was only the EKG that was abnormal, the images looked very good. So hopefully thats the end of it and i can move on. I'll talk with my cardiologist later today or tomorrow. Otago, you've given me some great questions to ask the cardiologist, expecially about whether to exercess through what appears to be stable angina (or my defective brain, not sure which. So now i get to lay around all day and ask my wife to make me lunch, do this, get me that. And actually get away with it, without hearing "go f yourself, do it yourself? LOL Thanks again to all, for the support.

Posts.Title: Surgery at Hopkins - Post Surgical Interactions?

Posts.Content: Hey Chris - never thought i would say this - but don't worry about the biopsy. I had mine a week ago today, and for a week leading up to it, i was mentally upside down. I was so scared that it would be painful, etc. But as it turned out, just like many guys here told me, it was very much not painful. It was uncomfortable but not painful. Take a couple of xanax on the way to the procedure, have someone drive you, and you will be fine. Still waiting for my results, btw, i am going to call them tomorrow.

Posts.Title: Reluctant new member questions, including second opinion on biopsy and stage of PC

Posts.Content: Welcome to the place that nobody wants to be, but some of us need to. First thing I'd recommend is get a second pinion on your pathology. Tell your urologists office that you want the slides sent to Dr JOnatjan Epstein at Johns Hopkins, or Davd Bostwick at Bostick Labs, for second opinion. They will do it, they get this request all the time from knowledgeable patients who are wanting to be their own best advocate. My GLeason was G8, then downgraded on second and third opinion to G6, and this changed everything Second, on what basis is your urologist recommending radiation therapy? Is that what he does? And on what basis is he saying you have a 40% chance that the Cancer is not organ confined? Not saying he is wrong, but I'd be curious, with a 5.9 PSA (not crazy high) Third, with radiation, you will have more ejaculate than with surgery (with surgery you will have none, and a 60-80% chance of return of sexual function (erection good enough for penetration) , with radiation I have been told (with BRachy/seeds) it would be 65% without drugs, and 80-85% with EDdrugs. But be aware that you will produce LESS ejaculate than before. Also, with Surgery, side effects tend to come early and improve over time, while with radiation they tend to be milder, and eventually disappear, but over a period of years, may return. You should visit with more than one surgeon, and more than one radiation oncologist. Educate yourself, then, make the decision that you. Feel most comfortable with. If a second opinion downgrades you to G6 you might even be able to consider active surveillance. Aside from that, both surgery and radiation work well, in most cases of locally confined disease. Good luck

Posts.Title: Metastatic Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: Goatts, it's certainly high volume Cancer, but it's G7 which is intermediate risk. The fact that it's on one side is a "favorable finding" to use the words Tha Dr Epstein at Johns Hopkins used in talking to me. So I think you just have to get the scans done, and see what the Dr. says. But again, with high volume cores consistently, and a PSA of 38, be prepared for the possibility that it has escaped. Not the result you wanted, but even if it's escaped or metastasize, the chances are high it can be controlled for many years, even decades, and youll die of something else.

Posts.Title: PSA 38, Biopsy Shows Gleason 7

Posts.Content: KY, Sorry you find yourself in this predicament. First off, i agree with Highlander, especially in view of the fact that your prostate is normal size, that with a PSA of 30, treating the cancer would be a "best practice" for lack of a better way of putting it. Incontinence, permanently, is a very small possibility, maybe 3%. Sexual side effects, more of a possibility. This is a very personal decision. At age 56, i know what i would do. If you were 66 and the doc said probably 10 years without symptoms, then maybe i would consider doing nothing with your state of mind. You are lucky to have a wife that stands by you, we all are, so thats a plus. Like i said, its really personal decision, that only you can make. And if being here just venting helps, then by all means, vent away.

Posts.Title: Newly Diagnosed - Way too much information to process

Posts.Content: Pretty much what lance peace said, the combination of that high a PSA and the nodules palpable on the DRE aren't a great sign. Still hope for the best while YIU know its a possibility that the news won't be ideal. I'd say prepare for the worst, but the fact is, I don't think most people can be prepared for that call Still, it's possible it's an infection. My doc told me to call him in a wek for results, I knew it should take less than a week. And in fact he called me 3 business days later with the bad news . I think if it was good news he would have waited for me to call him. So each day that goes by without them calling you, is possibly something positive to hang on to. Keeping fingers tightly crossed that you get a negative biopsy result and disappear from here. If it's positive, come back here and ask a lot of questions, and start doing your research. Don't just listen to the Drs.

Posts.Title: What's the % chance of PC

Posts.Content: Ian, I had a biopsy two years ago that was negative for PC but AHOWED one core out of 14 with hi grade pin. Dr said it was of no concern and just continue to test every six months which I dis. My PSA kept rising, but slowly. After nine months when my PSA went from 2.7 to 3.1 in only 6 months, I asked about a biopsy he said no because he was not concerned because the rate of rise was not fast enough. In early November I had another biopsy and if was positive, 3 cores, all G6 thankfully If I had to do if all over again, I would have pushed a little harder for the 2nd biopsy six months ago, and if the dr still wouldn't do it, I would have come back for another biopsy in three months instead of waiting the six months. If I were in your shoes, with a PSA of 8.9 I would retest very three months and insist on a repeat biopsy in a year. Unless the doc shows you on the path report that you've got a very large Prostate and has VERY good reason to not assume the Psa being that high is not attributable to BPH or some other benign issue. Hope this provides you with some perspective. HGPIN is known to not always, but OFTEN, turn into Cancer

Posts.Title: One year on Lupron

Posts.Content: MM, you've read enough on this forum and I'm sure elsewhere, to know that while this is scary stuff, it's definitely manageable, and highly likely to be curable. The T1c is great, that means no abnormalities felt on the DRE of the prostate. uC from what I hear is a great place for this, and you'll be in great hands. We all know your head is swimming now, because none of us will ever forget how we were, the day we got the news and the weeks that followed. But your gonna be fine, and a year from now, (less actually), you will likely look back at this as a bump in the road. One thing - get your slides sent to Epstein or Bostwick for a second opinion. Keep us posted, we've all got your back.

Posts.Title: Dr. Aaron Katz, New York?

Posts.Content: John, welcome. I had surgery as my primary treatment. And most of us have a bias towards whatever treatment we chose. With that caveat, I'll say I'm not sorry. Uneventful, full recovery, no incontinence, and with Cialis no issues with turning little John into Big John. Hve you looked at SBRT (AKA Cyberknife)? It's got a very good 10 year track record now, I think IMRT for primary is old school, and what's more common these days is SBRT and HDR Brachytherapy, which leads me to my next question. You mentioned brachytherapy, but didn't differentiate between HDR and LDR. HDR is the newer and I think more state of the art form. Rectestosterone, I'm no expert, but I think there's a lot of scientific evidence that supplements don't promote PC growth. It's counterintuitive, I know, but that's what I read. Good luck and keep us posted

Posts.Title: Stomach bloating after surgery....

Posts.Content: JMorris All good advice above. I'm just 12 days past surgery, so it's still fresh in my mind. So I'll add what I can without being repetitive... First couple of days, maybe three, will be tough. Butvthen you will start to see big improvements each day for a week or two Assuming you are doin robotic, you will have gas pains in your chest shoulders back and neck, this is gas they pump in you to open up the area and give them more room to work. The only way to get rid of this a is to walk. So walk as much as you can every day. Try to walk within a few hours of getting out of recovery room. They will, push you to do that. Go with it. GasX and tums might help a bit too. The catheter is annoying, but not painful. But the day they take the catheter out, is a day that you will want to be declared as a national holiday, you will feel like q new man. To give you an idea of how quickly things will progress, I am 12 days past surgery and only 3 days past getting the catheter out. I walked three miles in an hour yesterday. I'm 64. Good luck, and please, when it's over come back and keep us posted. There is a lot of support for you here if you want it. See you on the other side.

Posts.Title: Meeting with the URO next Friday for TX options

Posts.Content: MM, you've read enough on this forum and I'm sure elsewhere, to know that while this is scary stuff, it's definitely manageable, and highly likely to be curable. The T1c is great, that means no abnormalities felt on the DRE of the prostate. uC from what I hear is a great place for this, and you'll be in great hands. We all know your head is swimming now, because none of us will ever forget how we were, the day we got the news and the weeks that followed. But your gonna be fine, and a year from now, (less actually), you will likely look back at this as a bump in the road. One thing - get your slides sent to Epstein or Bostwick for a second opinion. Keep us posted, we've all got your back.

Posts.Title: I never get used to it...(PSA-test-angst)

Posts.Content: I have been away in the Wilderness, literally. I dont remember if i mentioned this upcoming trip, but i spent 3 days in Vancouver, a beautiful, and hip city, 8 days cruising Alaska, which was amazing, and then a 2 night stay in Seattle, another great place. Got back last night. While i did have internet access, i made it a point not to log on, i just felt i needed a rest. Between my RALP in January, and the stents and Coronary Artery disease in June, i was just worn out. So i tuned out. I have to say, this was the most timely vacation I've ever taken. I found myself not thinking about cancer (or heart disease) for days at a time, which was a new experience for me. I also found some perspective on life, i believe. I know that i will still be a lunatic if something else goes wrong. But for now, i feel more relaxed about things than i have in a long time. My reason for posting this, is for the new guys. I've noticed in the two weeks i am back, that a lot of new guys have shown up here, and while i dont like to have to welcome them to our reluctant brotherhood, its good for the forum, because we help them and they hopefully get through treatment and help the next group. So my message to the new guys, is there is life after PC, and a really good life. Stay positive, none of us want to be here but we are and there is a lot of life ahead of us to enjoy. Time heals. Take your time to be upset when newly diagnosed, its totally normal. Then get treatment, kick some ass, and take a long vacation. Stay positive

Posts.Title: PSA Results - I'm in a Panic

Posts.Content: After being undetectable since surgery, including my last test 3 months ago, my 9 month post op PSA came back from Quest, at 3.38 (no typo, 3.3. Needless to say I am besides myself. Ingot the results online and have an appointment tomorrow at the surgeons office but not with the Dr., I am supposed to meet with his director of Wellness, who does the nutrition, and other holistic stuff. He said I didn't need to see him this visit . And I said, right, unless the PSA comes back detectable. He responded by telling me "with your surgical pathology, it's not going to happen. So here I am looking 7 times to make sure I wasn't seeing things, at a 3.38. I called the office spoke to the PA, she said it's likely a mistake. Said to retest when I come in tomorrow, and they'd have the results Monday. But I didn't want to wait the weekend, in this mental state, so I asked if I could drive into the city (about an hour, and get the blood draw tonight, which I did. I'll have results tomorrow. My surgical pathology was (3+4), negative margins (1 positive intra operative margin so he cut more and got a negative final margin. No ECE, SV-, 9 lymph nodes all negative. So how can this happen. It's high probability it was an error by the lab. But doesn't make sense how do you make such an error? I called the lab and asked them to check and make sure I was given my results and not someone else's. They did so and confirmed it was mine. They said the blood tube is checked carefully so there cannot be a mixup in the blood, and when the girl drew my blood at the Quest Center, she put the label on the tube, and showed it to me with m name and had me initial . Even of it was a mistake, and someone entered 3.38, but should have been .338, that's a huge jump from <.02 3 months ago. I'm confused scared and in a panic

Posts.Title: PSA Results - I'm in a Panic

Posts.Content: John, welcome. I had surgery as my primary treatment. And most of us have a bias towards whatever treatment we chose. With that caveat, I'll say I'm not sorry. Uneventful, full recovery, no incontinence, and with Cialis no issues with turning little John into Big John. Hve you looked at SBRT (AKA Cyberknife)? It's got a very good 10 year track record now, I think IMRT for primary is old school, and what's more common these days is SBRT and HDR Brachytherapy, which leads me to my next question. You mentioned brachytherapy, but didn't differentiate between HDR and LDR. HDR is the newer and I think more state of the art form. Rectestosterone, I'm no expert, but I think there's a lot of scientific evidence that supplements don't promote PC growth. It's counterintuitive, I know, but that's what I read. Good luck and keep us posted

Posts.Title: A little learning is a dangerous thing . . .

Posts.Content: I don't know of any research which has DEFINITIVELY, in peer reviewed studies, shown any foods to be good, or bad, for PC, either prevention wise, or after diagnosis. In fact, part of the diet conversation has always been, eliminate red meat, and here is your dad, a vegan, with an advanced case of PC. With that said, from my readings, and conversations with various Drs and Nutritionists, my understanding is that there is very strong evidence that dairy products are not good for Prostate Cancer, and also egg yolks. Something about choline in egg yolks, and calcium in dairy, so even fat free dairy is believed to be something that should be limited. Also, I've read that a heart healthy diet is synonymous with a prostate healthy diet. So no enriched wheat, only whole wheat, whole grains, high protein, low fat, etc. Also, cruciferous vegetables are thought to be good, i.e. broccoli, cauliflower, brussel sprouts. I follow the above, but loosely, I'm not going to stop living life based on theories. Again, these are things that have been thought to have strong links, both positive and negative, but none of this to my knowledge, has been proven in peer reviewed studies.

Posts.Title: I never get used to it...(PSA-test-angst)

Posts.Content: Thanks Michael. I did call Quest and asked questions. They checked and confirmed that the numbers posted on my account were in fact my numbers. And when I asked if it's possible that tubes of blood were mixed up, she said highly unlikely, as the tubes are meticulously identified at every step of the process. Also when they took the blood, at the local center, she showed me the tube right after taking my blood and asked me for confirmation that my name, etc w was correct. I asked her if there was any change in the testing assay method and she didn't even know what that meant, she also told me that the normal range was below 4, so it's not a result that should be questioned. At that point I corrected her and pointed out that under 4 is for someone with a. Prostate, and that the test ordered for me was a post prostatectomy test. But I realized that the person. Spoke to was an idiot. If this turns out to be an error, and I'm undetectable, trust me, the CEO is getting a letter from me via FedEx, not that it will matter. I just hope I get that opportunity. Hey,mlogically. Know it's an error in all likelihood. But emotionally I can't help but be a wreck. Even if the number is .338, rather than 3.38, that would be a huge jump in three months. The Xanax is kicking in (I hate taking that) so I guess I'll get through the night, then going yo Dr first thing in the AM PS, Iremember posting about problems with Quest, but never saw or heard of anything like this

Posts.Title: Metastatic Prostate Cancer

Posts.Content: After being undetectable since surgery, including my last test 3 months ago, my 9 month post op PSA came back from Quest, at 3.38 (no typo, 3.3. Needless to say I am besides myself. Ingot the results online and have an appointment tomorrow at the surgeons office but not with the Dr., I am supposed to meet with his director of Wellness, who does the nutrition, and other holistic stuff. He said I didn't need to see him this visit . And I said, right, unless the PSA comes back detectable. He responded by telling me "with your surgical pathology, it's not going to happen. So here I am looking 7 times to make sure I wasn't seeing things, at a 3.38. I called the office spoke to the PA, she said it's likely a mistake. Said to retest when I come in tomorrow, and they'd have the results Monday. But I didn't want to wait the weekend, in this mental state, so I asked if I could drive into the city (about an hour, and get the blood draw tonight, which I did. I'll have results tomorrow. My surgical pathology was (3+4), negative margins (1 positive intra operative margin so he cut more and got a negative final margin. No ECE, SV-, 9 lymph nodes all negative. So how can this happen. It's high probability it was an error by the lab. But doesn't make sense how do you make such an error? I called the lab and asked them to check and make sure I was given my results and not someone else's. They did so and confirmed it was mine. They said the blood tube is checked carefully so there cannot be a mixup in the blood, and when the girl drew my blood at the Quest Center, she put the label on the tube, and showed it to me with m name and had me initial . Even of it was a mistake, and someone entered 3.38, but should have been .338, that's a huge jump from <.02 3 months ago. I'm confused scared and in a panic

Posts.Content: JMorris All good advice above. I'm just 12 days past surgery, so it's still fresh in my mind. So I'll add what I can without being repetitive... First couple of days, maybe three, will be tough. Butvthen you will start to see big improvements each day for a week or two Assuming you are doin robotic, you will have gas pains in your chest shoulders back and neck, this is gas they pump in you to open up the area and give them more room to work. The only way to get rid of this a is to walk. So walk as much as you can every day. Try to walk within a few hours of getting out of recovery room. They will, push you to do that. Go with it. GasX and tums might help a bit too. The catheter is annoying, but not painful. But the day they take the catheter out, is a day that you will want to be declared as a national holiday, you will feel like q new man. To give you an idea of how quickly things will progress, I am 12 days past surgery and only 3 days past getting the catheter out. I walked three miles in an hour yesterday. I'm 64. Good luck, and please, when it's over come back and keep us posted. There is a lot of support for you here if you want it. See you on the other side.

Posts.Title: please welcome me to the club

Posts.Content: Had my 3 month follow up with my Surgeon today. This was the first time I had a chance to speak/meet with him directly, since the surgery, so I got to ask all my questions It was a great meeting. My one concern was the upgrade from G6 to g7 (3+4). He told me with negative margins and everything, I should be celebrating. He said that of all his patients with the same pathology as me, less than 5% have needed further treatment, and he's never lost one. (whew, that's a relief) So all good. He also told me my follow ups would be every 3 months for the first year, then we go to every 6 months. That was good news, because I had thought it would be 3 month visits for 2 years. I told him I was so happy I chose surgery, and that I chose him as my surgeon, and I meant it. I walked out of there, feeling more confident about the future than I have since this whole shitstorm started.

Posts.Content: So it looks like you had 2 positive cores. They only took 8 cores? Officially you are low intermediate risk, with the 3+4. But with 40% grade 4 in that core, I agree, about not doing AS, although some others may disagree. With your PSA still way below 10, I assume, you’ve got some time. And you’ve got all options open to you, I think you’ll be told that your chance of cure is high, and about equal no matter what treatment you choose.

Posts.Title: Follow up with Surgeon

Posts.Content: I don't know of any research which has DEFINITIVELY, in peer reviewed studies, shown any foods to be good, or bad, for PC, either prevention wise, or after diagnosis. In fact, part of the diet conversation has always been, eliminate red meat, and here is your dad, a vegan, with an advanced case of PC. With that said, from my readings, and conversations with various Drs and Nutritionists, my understanding is that there is very strong evidence that dairy products are not good for Prostate Cancer, and also egg yolks. Something about choline in egg yolks, and calcium in dairy, so even fat free dairy is believed to be something that should be limited. Also, I've read that a heart healthy diet is synonymous with a prostate healthy diet. So no enriched wheat, only whole wheat, whole grains, high protein, low fat, etc. Also, cruciferous vegetables are thought to be good, i.e. broccoli, cauliflower, brussel sprouts. I follow the above, but loosely, I'm not going to stop living life based on theories. Again, these are things that have been thought to have strong links, both positive and negative, but none of this to my knowledge, has been proven in peer reviewed studies.

Posts.Title: A Return to Continence

Posts.Content: From m y experience, Dollar, its totally normal. Sitting in the docs office after removing the catheter, when they were waiting for me to void before letting me leave, i didnt even realize i was leaking, then after about an hour and a half, i reaized not only was my depends brief wet, my sweatpants were soaked. It will change, just do your kegels, do a lot of walking, and over time you will see. Last night at 5 months post op, i slept 8 straight hours without waking up to pee for the first time. When i woke up my bladder felt like it was about to burst, but i was dry. Immediately after surgery, i couldnt go more than 2 1/2 or 3 hours. Also, you will find later on especially, as you recover, that you will piss like a water canon. And even though your bladder feels really really full, it will take you not more than 15 seconds to empty it. Good luck with your recovery

Posts.Content: Lukas, 2 weeks post surgery I am doing fine. Still some leaking but improving, had an erection when I woke up this morning, but that's unusual, it can take a long time for many, everyone is different, some don't get it back. No real pain, just less stamina which will resolve with Time. I would schedule an appointment with Tewari, after you've had your bone andCT scans, although ithe scans are highly likely to be negative. Contact an RO as well. Take a breath, relax, it will all work out

Posts.Title: Im scared for my father - today his results came back and he has pc

Posts.Content: JLukas, you are a good son. I am, your dads age, 64, and I had surgery with Ash Tewari 2 weeks ago tomorrow. I would highly recommend him, and you may hear the same from another member soon NYCGman. I also used Jonathan Epstein at Johns Hopkins for 2nd opinion on the pathology slides, you should do it. As far as a radiation oncologist, one of the more well known in Nyc is dr Zelefsky, at MSKCC. HE specializes in Brachytherapy, which is radioactive seeds, but I'm sure he can talk to you about other types of radiation. I consulted with Dr Gewanter at MSKCC, AT THEIR Long Island Facility. Great professional, good man. Be aware, that before Dr ZELEFSKY will see you, he will require your slides, the pathology report, the discs from your dads bone scan and CT scan and you will have to have (your father I mean) a 3Tesla multiparametricMRI metric MRI done. (This is also done by Dr Tewari , required by him before surgery to help him plan. ) The MRI cannot be done for 6-7 weeks after biopsy, or it will be inaccurate. What I did was, I immediately scheduled the surgery with dr Tewari at my first visit. It can't be done for at least 6-7 weeks after biopsy. I used that time to explore the other options. And I did the MRI at Mount SiNai, with prescription from Dr Tewari, and had a copy sent to dr Gewanter, the RO at MSKCC. THIS WAY, I DIDNT LOSE ANY TIME. Have your dad explore ALL options. I am a surgery guy, others would rather do radiation. The both have their upside and downside. You need to learn a lot, and make an informed decision. radiation Oncologists will tell you do radiation and surgeons will be biased towards surgery. Dr. Tewari at my first visit, encouraged me to consult with a radiation oncologist as well before making up my mind. If you have other questions and want to PM me for my email address I will be happy to try to help. Know one thing though - this is not a death sentence. When we are first diagnosed most of us are in a fog. But as we educate ourselves, we learn that this disease is curable, and for the minority of unlucky ones who cannot be cured, there is a lot that can be done to hold this beast at bay for many years, even decades. And your dads PSA would seem to indicate good chance that he has early stage/curable disease Last thing - the suggestion to buy and read dr Patrick Walshs book is a good one. Almost a must. Get the third edition, it's the most recent, you can buy or download it on amazon. You are not alone we are here and anxious to help.

Posts.Title: Im scared for my father - today his results came back and he has pc

Posts.Content: After being undetectable since surgery, including my last test 3 months ago, my 9 month post op PSA came back from Quest, at 3.38 (no typo, 3.3. Needless to say I am besides myself. Ingot the results online and have an appointment tomorrow at the surgeons office but not with the Dr., I am supposed to meet with his director of Wellness, who does the nutrition, and other holistic stuff. He said I didn't need to see him this visit . And I said, right, unless the PSA comes back detectable. He responded by telling me "with your surgical pathology, it's not going to happen. So here I am looking 7 times to make sure I wasn't seeing things, at a 3.38. I called the office spoke to the PA, she said it's likely a mistake. Said to retest when I come in tomorrow, and they'd have the results Monday. But I didn't want to wait the weekend, in this mental state, so I asked if I could drive into the city (about an hour, and get the blood draw tonight, which I did. I'll have results tomorrow. My surgical pathology was (3+4), negative margins (1 positive intra operative margin so he cut more and got a negative final margin. No ECE, SV-, 9 lymph nodes all negative. So how can this happen. It's high probability it was an error by the lab. But doesn't make sense how do you make such an error? I called the lab and asked them to check and make sure I was given my results and not someone else's. They did so and confirmed it was mine. They said the blood tube is checked carefully so there cannot be a mixup in the blood, and when the girl drew my blood at the Quest Center, she put the label on the tube, and showed it to me with m name and had me initial . Even of it was a mistake, and someone entered 3.38, but should have been .338, that's a huge jump from <.02 3 months ago. I'm confused scared and in a panic

Posts.Title: PSA Results - I'm in a Panic

Posts.Content: Thanks Michael. I did call Quest and asked questions. They checked and confirmed that the numbers posted on my account were in fact my numbers. And when I asked if it's possible that tubes of blood were mixed up, she said highly unlikely, as the tubes are meticulously identified at every step of the process. Also when they took the blood, at the local center, she showed me the tube right after taking my blood and asked me for confirmation that my name, etc w was correct. I asked her if there was any change in the testing assay method and she didn't even know what that meant, she also told me that the normal range was below 4, so it's not a result that should be questioned. At that point I corrected her and pointed out that under 4 is for someone with a. Prostate, and that the test ordered for me was a post prostatectomy test. But I realized that the person. Spoke to was an idiot. If this turns out to be an error, and I'm undetectable, trust me, the CEO is getting a letter from me via FedEx, not that it will matter. I just hope I get that opportunity. Hey,mlogically. Know it's an error in all likelihood. But emotionally I can't help but be a wreck. Even if the number is .338, rather than 3.38, that would be a huge jump in three months. The Xanax is kicking in (I hate taking that) so I guess I'll get through the night, then going yo Dr first thing in the AM PS, Iremember posting about problems with Quest, but never saw or heard of anything like this

Posts.Content: Lukas, 2 weeks post surgery I am doing fine. Still some leaking but improving, had an erection when I woke up this morning, but that's unusual, it can take a long time for many, everyone is different, some don't get it back. No real pain, just less stamina which will resolve with Time. I would schedule an appointment with Tewari, after you've had your bone andCT scans, although ithe scans are highly likely to be negative. Contact an RO as well. Take a breath, relax, it will all work out

Posts.Title: PSA Results - I'm in a Panic

Posts.Content: John, welcome. I had surgery as my primary treatment. And most of us have a bias towards whatever treatment we chose. With that caveat, I'll say I'm not sorry. Uneventful, full recovery, no incontinence, and with Cialis no issues with turning little John into Big John. Hve you looked at SBRT (AKA Cyberknife)? It's got a very good 10 year track record now, I think IMRT for primary is old school, and what's more common these days is SBRT and HDR Brachytherapy, which leads me to my next question. You mentioned brachytherapy, but didn't differentiate between HDR and LDR. HDR is the newer and I think more state of the art form. Rectestosterone, I'm no expert, but I think there's a lot of scientific evidence that supplements don't promote PC growth. It's counterintuitive, I know, but that's what I read. Good luck and keep us posted

Posts.Title: A little learning is a dangerous thing . . .

Posts.Content: Davis, from everything I've seen, I think it is a fallacy that PC in younger guys is more aggressive. Hope that helps. Try not to anticipate, it won't help, won't "prepare" you, just in case, and won't change the outcome. Hopefully you are just passing thru here, but let us know how the biopsy results look,if you need to stick around and join the club, you'll get plenty of education and support here from us guys that have been thru it and went on to live normal lives.

Posts.Title: PSA Results - I'm in a Panic

Posts.Content: I don't know of any research which has DEFINITIVELY, in peer reviewed studies, shown any foods to be good, or bad, for PC, either prevention wise, or after diagnosis. In fact, part of the diet conversation has always been, eliminate red meat, and here is your dad, a vegan, with an advanced case of PC. With that said, from my readings, and conversations with various Drs and Nutritionists, my understanding is that there is very strong evidence that dairy products are not good for Prostate Cancer, and also egg yolks. Something about choline in egg yolks, and calcium in dairy, so even fat free dairy is believed to be something that should be limited. Also, I've read that a heart healthy diet is synonymous with a prostate healthy diet. So no enriched wheat, only whole wheat, whole grains, high protein, low fat, etc. Also, cruciferous vegetables are thought to be good, i.e. broccoli, cauliflower, brussel sprouts. I follow the above, but loosely, I'm not going to stop living life based on theories. Again, these are things that have been thought to have strong links, both positive and negative, but none of this to my knowledge, has been proven in peer reviewed studies.

So no enriched wheat, only whole wheat, whole grains, high protein, low fat, etc. Also, cruciferous vegetables are thought to be good, i.e. broccoli, cauliflower, brussel sprouts. I follow the above, but loosely, I'm not going to stop living life based on theories. Again, these are things that have been thought to have strong links, both positive and negative, but none of this to my knowledge, has been proven in peer reviewed studies.

Posts.Title: Diet changes / diet recommendations for advanced prostate cancer

Posts.Content: JLukas, you are a good son. I am, your dads age, 64, and I had surgery with Ash Tewari 2 weeks ago tomorrow. I would highly recommend him, and you may hear the same from another member soon NYCGman. I also used Jonathan Epstein at Johns Hopkins for 2nd opinion on the pathology slides, you should do it. As far as a radiation oncologist, one of the more well known in Nyc is dr Zelefsky, at MSKCC. HE specializes in Brachytherapy, which is radioactive seeds, but I'm sure he can talk to you about other types of radiation. I consulted with Dr Gewanter at MSKCC, AT THEIR Long Island Facility. Great professional, good man. Be aware, that before Dr ZELEFSKY will see you, he will require your slides, the pathology report, the discs from your dads bone scan and CT scan and you will have to have (your father I mean) a 3Tesla multiparametricMRI metric MRI done. (This is also done by Dr Tewari , required by him before surgery to help him plan. ) The MRI cannot be done for 6-7 weeks after biopsy, or it will be inaccurate. What I did was, I immediately scheduled the surgery with dr Tewari at my first visit. It can't be done for at least 6-7 weeks after biopsy. I used that time to explore the other options. And I did the MRI at Mount SiNai, with prescription from Dr Tewari, and had a copy sent to dr Gewanter, the RO at MSKCC. THIS WAY, I DIDNT LOSE ANY TIME. Have your dad explore ALL options. I am a surgery guy, others would rather do radiation. The both have their upside and downside. You need to learn a lot, and make an informed decision. radiation Oncologists will tell you do radiation and surgeons will be biased towards surgery. Dr. Tewari at my first visit, encouraged me to consult with a radiation oncologist as well before making up my mind. If you have other questions and want to PM me for my email address I will be happy to try to help. Know one thing though - this is not a death sentence. When we are first diagnosed most of us are in a fog. But as we educate ourselves, we learn that this disease is curable, and for the minority of unlucky ones who cannot be cured, there is a lot that can be done to hold this beast at bay for many years, even decades. And your dads PSA would seem to indicate good chance that he has early stage/curable disease Last thing - the suggestion to buy and read dr Patrick Walshs book is a good one. Almost a must. Get the third edition, it's the most recent, you can buy or download it on amazon. You are not alone we are here and anxious to help.

Posts.Title: With apologies....

Posts.Content: Thanks for the response Rob. You make some good points With that said, I already know so much, that for my stage, I'm not sure what's left to learn (sure , there's always something more to learn, but you get my drift, I'm "learned up". I'm not even sure what I'm looking for sometimes when I start to do searches on the internet. I think what I'm describing, and thanks for helping me identify it, is "obsession" I think I'm too obsessed and that's what's unhealthy. Btw, you hit on another thing I obsess about....my plan is to spend Winters at my new home in Florida which I just purchased two months ago. And I obsess about the possibility that Health issues may I interfere with that plan. Then I say, well I can always get treatment in Florida. But I don't think the quality of care in Florida is up to the quality of care I get in NYC. So I obsess about that too.

Posts.Title: With apologies....

Posts.Content: Lukas, 2 weeks post surgery I am doing fine. Still some leaking but improving, had an erection when I woke up this morning, but that's unusual, it can take a long time for many, everyone is different, some don't get it back. No real pain, just less stamina which will resolve with Time. I would schedule an appointment with Tewari, after you've had your bone andCT scans, although ithe scans are highly likely to be negative. Contact an RO as well. Take a breath, relax, it will all work out

Posts.Title: Concerned Prostate Wife

Posts.Content: Pom, .65, followed by .94 is unfortunately pretty strong evidence of biochemical recurrence. Conventional thinking is that after surgery, .2 is where they start talking about salvage radiation or other treatments. I don't know how that is different after HIFU! It probably is. Studies have shown that on average, there is an 8 year spread between first biochemical recurrence and actual symptoms of spread.

Posts.Title: Zero Club status still intact

Posts.Content: Logic, for me to tell you to relax is pointless, it won't happen unless you find a way to make it happen. Once I made the decision i was more relaxed till a day or two before the surgery. You chose a great dr try to just keep in mind that you chose him for a reason and have faith that he will cure you. Regarding your cincerns, I think every doc has a different opinion. Dr John Mulhall, at MSKCC is an acknowledged expert in ED, and works with PC patients in that area. I know of at least one guy who is being treated by him, and started seeing him BEFORE his surgery. I believe he said that Mullhall recommends taking Viagra or Cialis or whatever, before surgery. Others don't agree. But Mullhall is an expert. He wrote a book on sex after PC, which you can buy on Amazon http://http://www.amazon.com/Saving-Your-Sex-Life-Prostate/dp/0980064961/ref=sr_1_2?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1423745518&sr=1-2&keywords=Dr+john+Mulhall I didn't start taking Cialis until 2 weeks after surgery. And was getting erections almost immediately. And the other day I tried an experiment and stopped taking the Cialis for two days, and after 50 hours, of no Cialis, I was able to get a good solid erection. Everyone is different. But try to be optimistic. Regarding continence, as others have said, everyone is different. And also, docs have different opinions about Kegels before surgery. My Surgeon, Dr Tewari, recommended that I do them, which I did. And his nurse, after surgery, told me it would help me regain confidence faster. I did4 sets a day of 10 reps, and still am. Believe it or not, if you have a smart phone, there are apps that remind you at whatever time intervals you set and then guide you thru the reps. I am 5 weeks post surgery, and am leaking about .2-.3 ounces a day, not a big deal, just annoying. I expected (maybe like you?) that incontinence means pissing all over yourself like an old man in a nursing home. That's not what it is. The first day or two I was leaking heavily, like7 ounces in a 24 hour period. After that it improved fast. Btw, I have a friend who had surgery 4 years ago. He did NOT do Kegels before surgery, and when they took the catheter out, he was 100% continent within a day. So everyone is different Like someone said above, spend time with those important to you, think in terms of you are getting closer to being Cancer free and getting on with your life. And if possible, have as much sex as possible. I hope you can find some peace , I know it's not easy, but trust that this mental mess and all of the head trash in your mind is temporary. Now that you've sxheduled the surgery, there is light at the end of the tunnel.

Posts.Title: Starting to get nervous: two pre-surgery questions

Posts.Content: I don't know of any research which has DEFINITIVELY, in peer reviewed studies, shown any foods to be good, or bad, for PC, either prevention wise, or after diagnosis. In fact, part of the diet conversation has always been, eliminate red meat, and here is your dad, a vegan, with an advanced case of PC. With that said, from my readings, and conversations with various Drs and Nutritionists, my understanding is that there is very strong evidence that dairy products are not good for Prostate Cancer, and also egg yolks. Something about choline in egg yolks, and calcium in dairy, so even fat free dairy is believed to be something that should be limited. Also, I've read that a heart healthy diet is synonymous with a prostate healthy diet. So no enriched wheat, only whole wheat, whole grains, high protein, low fat, etc. Also, cruciferous vegetables are thought to be good, i.e. broccoli, cauliflower, brussel sprouts. I follow the above, but loosely, I'm not going to stop living life based on theories. Again, these are things that have been thought to have strong links, both positive and negative, but none of this to my knowledge, has been proven in peer reviewed studies.

Posts.Title: Im scared for my father - today his results came back and he has pc

Posts.Content: From m y experience, Dollar, its totally normal. Sitting in the docs office after removing the catheter, when they were waiting for me to void before letting me leave, i didnt even realize i was leaking, then after about an hour and a half, i reaized not only was my depends brief wet, my sweatpants were soaked. It will change, just do your kegels, do a lot of walking, and over time you will see. Last night at 5 months post op, i slept 8 straight hours without waking up to pee for the first time. When i woke up my bladder felt like it was about to burst, but i was dry. Immediately after surgery, i couldnt go more than 2 1/2 or 3 hours. Also, you will find later on especially, as you recover, that you will piss like a water canon. And even though your bladder feels really really full, it will take you not more than 15 seconds to empty it. Good luck with your recovery

Posts.Title: Newbie from Ottawa

Posts.Content: Logic, for me to tell you to relax is pointless, it won't happen unless you find a way to make it happen. Once I made the decision i was more relaxed till a day or two before the surgery. You chose a great dr try to just keep in mind that you chose him for a reason and have faith that he will cure you. Regarding your cincerns, I think every doc has a different opinion. Dr John Mulhall, at MSKCC is an acknowledged expert in ED, and works with PC patients in that area. I know of at least one guy who is being treated by him, and started seeing him BEFORE his surgery. I believe he said that Mullhall recommends taking Viagra or Cialis or whatever, before surgery. Others don't agree. But Mullhall is an expert. He wrote a book on sex after PC, which you can buy on Amazon http://http://www.amazon.com/Saving-Your-Sex-Life-Prostate/dp/0980064961/ref=sr_1_2?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1423745518&sr=1-2&keywords=Dr+john+Mulhall I didn't start taking Cialis until 2 weeks after surgery. And was getting erections almost immediately. And the other day I tried an experiment and stopped taking the Cialis for two days, and after 50 hours, of no Cialis, I was able to get a good solid erection. Everyone is different. But try to be optimistic. Regarding continence, as others have said, everyone is different. And also, docs have different opinions about Kegels before surgery. My Surgeon, Dr Tewari, recommended that I do them, which I did. And his nurse, after surgery, told me it would help me regain confidence faster. I did4 sets a day of 10 reps, and still am. Believe it or not, if you have a smart phone, there are apps that remind you at whatever time intervals you set and then guide you thru the reps. I expected (maybe like you?) that incontinence means pissing all over yourself like an old man in a nursing home. That's not what it is. The first day or two I was leaking heavily, like7 ounces in a 24 hour period. After that it improved fast. Btw, I have a friend who had surgery 4 years ago. He did NOT do Kegels before surgery, and when they took the catheter out, he was 100% continent within a day. So everyone is different Like someone said above, spend time with those important to you, think in terms of you are getting closer to being Cancer free and getting on with your life. And if possible, have as much sex as possible. I hope you can find some peace , I know it's not easy, but trust that this mental mess and all of the head trash in your mind is temporary. Now that you've sxheduled the surgery, there is light at the end of the tunnel.

Posts.Content: JPhils post is good advice and reminded me of what I left out if mine. Do what you can to get in shape. I remember someone here mentioned they had some weight issues and was out of shape, I don't recall if it was you logic. But it doesn't matter, just do what you can. Walk or run a lot, eat right, do some exercises for your core. For 5 weeks before my surgery, I walked 3-4 miles a day, most days. I ate healthy, and I did planks and crunches every day to strengthen my abs. I believe it helped my recovery. You should try to give yourself every edge that you can. Like a soldier going to war.

Posts.Title: Post-RALP Catheter Removal

Posts.Content: @MichaelF - Since you had RALP 3 + years ago, can i ask, for how long did you see improvement? Did your progress stop at say 1 year, 2 years? I'm fully continent, but as i said, i get the ghost squirts, even 9 months out, and i do get up some nights to pee. Also, on occasion, i would say maybe 3 times since my fully continent state began, about 6 wweeks after surgery, i have found myself waking up to find i peed myself. Not all over the place, on the bed, etc, but the underwear is wet in a decent size spot, once the whole front, but more often, maybe the size of a dollar bill, or a bit less. I think it happens mostly when i have drank a lot of water before going to bed and am very tired to begin with. Its not the end of the world, but psychologically, it upsets me.

Posts.Title: Im scared for my father - today his results came back and he has pc

Posts.Content: JLukas, you are a good son. I am, your dads age, 64, and I had surgery with Ash Tewari 2 weeks ago tomorrow. I would highly recommend him, and you may hear the same from another member soon NYCGman. I also used Jonathan Epstein at Johns Hopkins for 2nd opinion on the pathology slides, you should do it. As far as a radiation oncologist, one of the more well known in Nyc is dr Zelefsky, at MSKCC. HE specializes in Brachytherapy, which is radioactive seeds, but I'm sure he can talk to you about other types of radiation. I consulted with Dr Gewanter at MSKCC, AT THEIR Long Island Facility. Great professional, good man. Be aware, that before Dr ZELEFSKY will see you, he will require your slides, the pathology report, the discs from your dads bone scan and CT scan and you will have to have (your father I mean) a 3Tesla multiparametricMRI metric MRI done. (This is also done by Dr Tewari , required by him before surgery to help him plan. ) The MRI cannot be done for 6-7 weeks after biopsy, or it will be inaccurate. What I did was, I immediately scheduled the surgery with dr Tewari at my first visit. It can't be done for at least 6-7 weeks after biopsy. I used that time to explore the other options. And I did the MRI at Mount SiNai, with prescription from Dr Tewari, and had a copy sent to dr Gewanter, the RO at MSKCC. THIS WAY, I DIDNT LOSE ANY TIME. Have your dad explore ALL options. I am a surgery guy, others would rather do radiation. The both have their upside and downside. You need to learn a lot, and make an informed decision. radiation Oncologists will tell you do radiation and surgeons will be biased towards surgery. Dr. Tewari at my first visit, encouraged me to consult with a radiation oncologist as well before making up my mind. If you have other questions and want to PM me for my email address I will be happy to try to help. Know one thing though - this is not a death sentence. When we are first diagnosed most of us are in a fog. But as we educate ourselves, we learn that this disease is curable, and for the minority of unlucky ones who cannot be cured, there is a lot that can be done to hold this beast at bay for many years, even decades. And your dads PSA would seem to indicate good chance that he has early stage/curable disease Last thing - the suggestion to buy and read dr Patrick Walshs book is a good one. Almost a must. Get the third edition, it's the most recent, you can buy or download it on amazon. You are not alone we are here and anxious to help.

Posts.Title: With apologies....

Posts.Content: Apologies to the guys and gals here who are on the "other forum"... I'm. Opting and pasting this for the folks who are not on that forum. I posted it there, and thought it was worth getting a discussion going here to for the benefit of the guys who frequent this forum only (and me ). So it's about what seems to have become my "life's work.... I'm not referring to my work as a Financial Planner, I'm referring to what seems to have become my life's work, life as a senior citizen with health issues. And I'm not even sure if this is a rant, or a question. But I'm curious to know if I'm in the majority or minority, I.e. How others manage things. Between my prostate Cancer which has been in the rear view mirror, but might be pulling up alongside me now, and my coronary artery disease, which will always be in front of me, and family members health issues, I find myself totally preoccupied with all matters health. Diet, exercise, supplements, dr appointments, and the inevitable "worry". I manage to have a good time with my friends, and manage to focus on work when I'm in the office, or with a client. But health I always there. I constantly wonder if I'm doing the right things diet wise, supplement wise. And uncertainty about the future is always in the back, sometimes in the front, of my mind. When I am not at work, or out with friends,I'm reading a health book, or searching the internet for studies, or on a forum. I thought of taking a long vacation from ALL the health related forums I'm on, but I don't want to. Which is bad. I take Zoloft, it helps, I do biofeedback breathing exercises, I think it helps. I try mindfulness. But the bottom line is that health has become, in some sense, my life's work. I fear this is unhealthy, and will only make things worse in the long term. Not to mention all the time I spend on it that I could be doing other things (stupid mindless things like watching replays of Seinfeld, or useful things like learning to be a good photographer) Maybe I'm wrong, but I'm guessing I'm not the only one here in this mindset. Especially guys with more advanced cases than mine. Maybe this would be a useful discussion for others. I think if it was "just" prostate cancer (forgive me), it would be easier. But combined with heart disease, and other family issues I'm dealing with, it's hard to get away from it. Thoughts?

Posts.Title: With apologies....

Posts.Content: Thanks for the response Rob. You make some good points With that said, I already know so much, that for my stage, I'm not sure what's left to learn (sure , there's always something more to learn, but you get my drift, I'm "learned up". I'm not even sure what I'm looking for sometimes when I start to do searches on the internet. I think what I'm describing, and thanks for helping me identify it, is "obsession" I think I'm too obsessed and that's what's unhealthy. Btw, you hit on another thing I obsess about....my plan is to spend Winters at my new home in Florida which I just purchased two months ago. And I obsess about the possibility that Health issues may I interfere with that plan. Then I say, well I can always get treatment in Florida. But I don't think the quality of care in Florida is up to the quality of care I get in NYC. So I obsess about that too.

Posts.Content: I've read accounts of men who have had terrible back and leg pain when on Cialis and have had to go off it. Luckily for me, i experienced no side effects at all, with the exception of the possibilty that these palpatations i've been getting were from the Cialis. (but i dont think so). On another note, i have been off Cialis for 10 days, and was able to have sex last night with no problem. So thats encouraging, but i am still hoping when this cardiac thing is figured out and over, i can go back on it.

Posts.Title: Cialis Effects

Posts.Content: Allen, My surgeon has dictated that he wants me to continue on Cialis for the time being because it will continue to promote blood flow to the area, separate from the erectile function issue. That's his protocol Now if my cardiac issue prevents that, then according to his NO they will recommend injections, trimix I guess. At that point I'll have to make a decision, which will probably be to say no. I really don't want to be sticking needles in my junk. And I think it puts me at higher risk for peyronies. But if I can take the cialis after the cardiac thing is resolved, why not

Be aware, that before Dr ZELEFSKY will see you, he will require your slides, the pathology report, the discs from your dads bone scan and CT scan and you will have to have (your father I mean) a 3Tesla multiparametricMRI metric MRI done. (This is also done by Dr Tewari , required by him before surgery to help him plan. ) The MRI cannot be done for 6-7 weeks after biopsy, or it will be inaccurate. What I did was, I immediately scheduled the surgery with dr Tewari at my first visit. It can't be done for at least 6-7 weeks after biopsy. I used that time to explore the other options. And I did the MRI at Mount SiNai, with prescription from Dr Tewari, and had a copy sent to dr Gewanter, the RO at MSKCC. THIS WAY, I DIDNT LOSE ANY TIME. Have your dad explore ALL options. I am a surgery guy, others would rather do radiation. The both have their upside and downside. You need to learn a lot, and make an informed decision. radiation Oncologists will tell you do radiation and surgeons will be biased towards surgery. Dr. Tewari at my first visit, encouraged me to consult with a radiation oncologist as well before making up my mind. If you have other questions and want to PM me for my email address I will be happy to try to help. Know one thing though - this is not a death sentence. When we are first diagnosed most of us are in a fog. But as we educate ourselves, we learn that this disease is curable, and for the minority of unlucky ones who cannot be cured, there is a lot that can be done to hold this beast at bay for many years, even decades. And your dads PSA would seem to indicate good chance that he has early stage/curable disease Last thing - the suggestion to buy and read dr Patrick Walshs book is a good one. Almost a must. Get the third edition, it's the most recent, you can buy or download it on amazon. You are not alone we are here and anxious to help.

Posts.Title: Now a Gleason 9

Posts.Content: Gorhad, 1. you think turning 50 is "dreaded"? Dude, I'm 66, i'd give my left nut, or my prostate, to be 50.....oh, wait.... 2. biopsy is no a big deal most of the time. I took a xanax before i left the house, another one in the car, and a third one when i got to the Drs office. I was very looped. And it was not bad. Second biopsy i only took one xanax an hour before. easy peasy. 3. Be ready after the biopsy to piss some blood, lasts a day or two, up to a week. And be expecting that your gism will be blood red at first, then slowly turn brownish then in a few weeks back to normal 4. the fact that your PSA jumped so much in a short time, combined with the fact that the DRE was painful, leads me to think Prostatitis. Maybe ask for a round of Cipro before proceeding to biopsy? If that brings the PSA down to a much lower range, then its likely an infection. Good luck. Breathe

Posts.Title: Post op pathology back today...

Posts.Content: Apologies to the guys and gals here who are on the "other forum"... I'm. Opting and pasting this for the folks who are not on that forum. I posted it there, and thought it was worth getting a discussion going here to for the benefit of the guys who frequent this forum only (and me ). So it's about what seems to have become my "life's work.... I'm not referring to my work as a Financial Planner, I'm referring to what seems to have become my life's work, life as a senior citizen with health issues. And I'm not even sure if this is a rant, or a question. But I'm curious to know if I'm in the majority or minority, I.e. How others manage things. Between my prostate Cancer which has been in the rear view mirror, but might be pulling up alongside me now, and my coronary artery disease, which will always be in front of me, and family members health issues, I find myself totally preoccupied with all matters health. Diet, exercise, supplements, dr appointments, and the inevitable "worry". I manage to have a good time with my friends, and manage to focus on work when I'm in the office, or with a client. But health I always there. I constantly wonder if I'm doing the right things diet wise, supplement wise. And uncertainty about the future is always in the back, sometimes in the front, of my mind. When I am not at work, or out with friends,I'm reading a health book, or searching the internet for studies, or on a forum. I thought of taking a long vacation from ALL the health related forums I'm on, but I don't want to. Which is bad. I take Zoloft, it helps, I do biofeedback breathing exercises, I think it helps. I try mindfulness. But the bottom line is that health has become, in some sense, my life's work. I fear this is unhealthy, and will only make things worse in the long term. Not to mention all the time I spend on it that I could be doing other things (stupid mindless things like watching replays of Seinfeld, or useful things like learning to be a good photographer) Maybe I'm wrong, but I'm guessing I'm not the only one here in this mindset. Especially guys with more advanced cases than mine. Maybe this would be a useful discussion for others. I think if it was "just" prostate cancer (forgive me), it would be easier. But combined with heart disease, and other family issues I'm dealing with, it's hard to get away from it. Thoughts?

Posts.Title: Concerned Partner

Posts.Content: RTS, you said... "I just can’t see how with my pathology report that cancer could have gotten out of my prostate." I asked my surgeon the exact same question. His answer was just.... "it can certainly happen. Anything is possible with Prostate Cancer" and i was a g7(3+4) but with low Decipher. Regarding the Decipher Grid Report - i pointed out to my RO that the Grid Report states a low chance that Salvage Radiation would work (i dont recall the exact words)> He responded that its just investigational (as Chuck pointed out) and its not considered actionable science at this point. Regarding the benign prostate tissue question, its very doubtful, with a psa of .25 that benign tissue is causing the increase. .025, maybe, not .25 This sucks, sorry you are going through it, i am as well, although my psa is still lower, at .068 (next PSA blood draw this week). So i feel your pain. We just have to deal with it, and hope that we can move on after treatment. I keep saying lots of guys here have gone through it and come out the other end to enjoy life. So i can too.

Posts.Title: Post-RALP Catheter Removal

Posts.Content: JimBow, welcome to the forum, and our "reluctant brotherhood". It tends to be a bit quiet here on the weekends, some replies will trickle in, but by early in the week, you'll have way more, and alot from folks more knowledgeable than i am. Just remember, the most important thing is to do your own research, we can relate our experiences and give our opinions, although none of us, as far as i know, are doctors, and even if we were, we may not know all the specifics of your case. First of all, slow down, take a deep breath, your world is not going to come to an end, it will just change. I can tell you from my personal experience, that its really not nearly as bad as we all expect, when we get the diagnosis and our minds start running wild. I was in your position, exactly a year ago, having been diagnosed in November of 2014, with my biopsy showing a Gleason 6. However after surgery my pathology was changed to a G7(3+4). So i guess the first question that would be worth knowing is, were you a 3+4 or a 4+3? One is low intermediate risk, the other is high intermediate risk. There is a clear difference. But the good news is, you are not an 8 9 or one of the rare G10s. Those are the very aggressive tumors. . As i said, i was exactly where you were a year ago, and had my surgery January 6th, 2015. In March i was back to work (desk job). In May i was playing golf (i could have played months earlier if the weather allowed). In July i wennt on a two week trip to Vancouver and Alaska. November i ran a 5K with my daughter (to benefit Prostate Cancer Awareness). And in December, i flew to Aruba for 9 days in the sun. SO ALL IS NOT LOST, YOUR LIFE WILL BE FULL OF HAPPINESS AGAIN, AFTER YOU GET THROUGH THIS. Yes, there are guys who have ongoing problems. But the majority move on and live their full lives as before. PC is a very slow growing cancer in the vast majority of cases. Good on ya that you bought Walshs book. Its a great primer for newly diagnosed guys. Make sure you have the 3rd edition. But even some of that is outdated, as it was published in 2012 and things are moving fast in PC treatement world (for the better). For my money, surgery is probably the right thing for you, just based on your age. But you should look at the various forms of radiation as well. SBRT (Cyberknife), IMRT, IGRT, LDR and HDR Brachy (seeds). They've all gotten great results with low and intermediate risk guys, if the cancer has not escaped the prostate capsule. And with your relatively low PSA, combined with the fact that you had cancer showing only on one side, and a negative DRE, the chances of no escape, are pretty high. In fact, if there was escape, radiation would probably be the better choice, because radiation cooks not only the prostate, but surrounding tissue. There is a reason i think its important to explore all options. You get only one shot at CHOOSING the best treatment. If you look at all the possibilites, and are educated about them, the side effects of each, the results of each, etc, you will choose the right one for YOU (everyone is different) with CONFIDENCE AND YOU WON'T LOOK BACK. And once you do that you will feel so much better. And you won't look back. Remember, most Urologists are surgeons, and many if not most surgeons will recommend surgery. Radiation Oncologists will recommend radiation. Not because they don't have you best interest at heart. But because they have a natural bias. They believe in what they do, or they wouldn't be doing it. So its up to you to decide on whats best for YOU. The phase you are in now, understanding, educating, and deciding, is probably the hardest part of this journey. Which brings me to 3TmultiParametric MRI. You should ask for one. It will tell you with about 90-95% certainty whether there has been any escape from the capsule. If there has, it might affect your treatment choice. The other thing you should do, that might affect your treatment choice, is get a second opinion on the pathology. Have the slides sent to either Jonathan Epstein at Johns Hopkins, or David Bostwick and Bostwick Labs. Your Doctor gets this request all the time from newly diagnosed guys that are educating themselves about the disease, and should know where to send them. If not, just google Johns Hopkins Second Opinion Service Prostate, and it will take you to the instructions. They charge $250, its usually not covered by insurance but its worth it. And Dr Epstein will get on the phone with you after the results are in, if you have questions. The reason this is important, is that these two guys ,Epstein and Bostwick, are the acknowldged experts in Prostate Cell Pathology. And reading prostate slides is a very subjective thing. Most local pathologists generally read all kinds of slides, so before reading yours, they might have read a breast or colon slide. Epstein (and Bostwick) read only Prostate Slides. When i asked my surgeon, if i could take Espteins second opinion to the bank, his response was "Epstein IS the bank". My Biopsy was originally diagnosed at Gleason 8 (3+5). UGH!!! Epstein downgraded it to a G6 (3+3). As i mentioned after surgery, when they looked at the entire prostate, they found G6, but also found some g7(3+4). The biopsy samples only about 1/1000th of the prostate, so it can often miss something. Thats why in about 30% of cases, post surgical pathology changes the Gleason score. Don't worry about hormone therapy right now, it may well not be necessary. Especially if your Gleason is a 7(3+4) Regarding surgery, you want a surgeon who is highly experienced, having done at least 300 surgeries, according to research, but for margin of safety i wanted at least 1000. Arbitrary number i know. The surgeon i chose, Dr Ash Tewari, in NYC, hadover 6000 under his belt. Everyone has a different experience. For me, the surgery wasnt so bad, and i was fully continent after 5 weeks, and experienced no Erectile Dysfunction. I took Cialis for about 10 mnths, but am off it now, no need. Enough for now. 1. calm down 2. read the book 3. speak to many Practitioners in the various treatment options until you find the one you are comfortable with. 4. Slay the beast 5. Remember you aren't alone, we are all with you, we've all gone through it, survived, and thrived in most cases. Good luck , stick around, keep us posted along the way, and ask alot of questions of both us and your doctors.

Posts.Title: Surgery behind me now

Posts.Content: Larry, I never heard of "within the margins" in a pathology report. Maybe someone else would chime in. I would want to know 1. We're the margins negative for Cancer 2. We're lymph nodes taken and were they positive or negative 3. We're the seminal vesicles positive or negative 4. Did the Cancer escape from the capsule 5. What was the final GLeason score. (About 30% of cases are upgraded on surgical pathology) Those are the main and most important issues. I'd also want to know what % of the tumor was involved by tumor, was there PErineural invasion (in post surgical pathology, most specimens will show this, but it's less important according to most experts, than if there was PNI in the biopsy), was the disease bi lateral or found on one side only It would help us to give you better answers if you posted your info in a signature block, I.e. Age, biopsy results, etc.

Posts.Title: After surgery,now what

Posts.Content: RTS, you said... "I just can’t see how with my pathology report that cancer could have gotten out of my prostate." I asked my surgeon the exact same question. His answer was just.... "it can certainly happen. Anything is possible with Prostate Cancer" and i was a g7(3+4) but with low Decipher. Regarding the Decipher Grid Report - i pointed out to my RO that the Grid Report states a low chance that Salvage Radiation would work (i dont recall the exact words)> He responded that its just investigational (as Chuck pointed out) and its not considered actionable science at this point. Regarding the benign prostate tissue question, its very doubtful, with a psa of .25 that benign tissue is causing the increase. .025, maybe, not .25 This sucks, sorry you are going through it, i am as well, although my psa is still lower, at .068 (next PSA blood draw this week). So i feel your pain. We just have to deal with it, and hope that we can move on after treatment. I keep saying lots of guys here have gone through it and come out the other end to enjoy life. So i can too.

Posts.Title: Now I'm Getting A Little Nervous!

Posts.Content: Thanks for the response Rob. You make some good points With that said, I already know so much, that for my stage, I'm not sure what's left to learn (sure , there's always something more to learn, but you get my drift, I'm "learned up". I'm not even sure what I'm looking for sometimes when I start to do searches on the internet. I think what I'm describing, and thanks for helping me identify it, is "obsession" I think I'm too obsessed and that's what's unhealthy. Btw, you hit on another thing I obsess about....my plan is to spend Winters at my new home in Florida which I just purchased two months ago. And I obsess about the possibility that Health issues may I interfere with that plan. Then I say, well I can always get treatment in Florida. But I don't think the quality of care in Florida is up to the quality of care I get in NYC. So I obsess about that too.
