Posts.Title: Considering delaying biopsy. Thoughts, opinons welcome.

Posts.Content: As documented in another thread, i had a "positive" echo stress test and my PCP, who is a Board Certified Cardiologist as well, took me off Cialis. Up to that point i have had no ED problems since RALP. The other day, after having gone 5 days with no Cialis, i engaged in "doing the deed" and still had no problem at all. So does this mean i no longer need to be on Cialis (putting the heart issue aside), or is it still too soon to tell? My Uro's NP, whom i called when this development occurred last week, said that being off Cialis for a few weeks wont hurt, but that they do like to keep patients on it longer term for a while, to promote blood flow. And she further said, that if i cannot go back on it in a few weeks or a month, they would suggest injections/Trimix, which i REALLY REALLY REALLY want nothing to do with, if i can avoid it. So just curious if anyone has any thoughts on 1. being able to "do it" after 5 days with no ED Meds means I'm home free, and 2. is it really important to do the injections if i am getting full erections at will, with no meds, 5 months post RP

Posts.Title: Considering delaying biopsy. Thoughts, opinons welcome.

Posts.Content: Gorhad, 1. you think turning 50 is "dreaded"? Dude, I'm 66, i'd give my left nut, or my prostate, to be 50.....oh, wait.... 2. biopsy is no a big deal most of the time. I took a xanax before i left the house, another one in the car, and a third one when i got to the Drs office. I was very looped. And it was not bad. Second biopsy i only took one xanax an hour before. easy peasy. 3. Be ready after the biopsy to piss some blood, lasts a day or two, up to a week. And be expecting that your gism will be blood red at first, then slowly turn brownish then in a few weeks back to normal 4. the fact that your PSA jumped so much in a short time, combined with the fact that the DRE was painful, leads me to think Prostatitis. Maybe ask for a round of Cipro before proceeding to biopsy? If that brings the PSA down to a much lower range, then its likely an infection. Good luck. Breathe

Posts.Content: On the surface I agree with the others, from your path report alone, you are a poster boy for Active Surviellance. The one question I would have is what about the Pirads 4? My understanding is that MP-MRI is good at detecting high grade cancer, but not so good at detecting low grade/G6. So yes, ask about that P-4.

Posts.Title: What Should i Expect

Posts.Content: Gorhad, 1. you think turning 50 is "dreaded"? Dude, I'm 66, i'd give my left nut, or my prostate, to be 50.....oh, wait.... 2. biopsy is no a big deal most of the time. I took a xanax before i left the house, another one in the car, and a third one when i got to the Drs office. I was very looped. And it was not bad. Second biopsy i only took one xanax an hour before. easy peasy. 3. Be ready after the biopsy to piss some blood, lasts a day or two, up to a week. And be expecting that your gism will be blood red at first, then slowly turn brownish then in a few weeks back to normal 4. the fact that your PSA jumped so much in a short time, combined with the fact that the DRE was painful, leads me to think Prostatitis. Maybe ask for a round of Cipro before proceeding to biopsy? If that brings the PSA down to a much lower range, then its likely an infection. Good luck. Breathe

Posts.Content: DD, you are describing the same thing I am experiencing, 9 months out, and I was thinking about it the other day. I too sometimes feel a squirt, but there is none. And sometimes I piss like a water canon and other times it's not a weak stream but not especially strong either. And there are a few occasions where I feel like I haven't fully emptied. The only difference for me is at night I rarely wake more than once a night. And sometimes I sleep 7 hours without waking. I find that to be dependent on whether I drink a lot of water after 8PM or so. These issues are things I am going to discuss with my surgeon in Jamuary at my one year follow up

Posts.Title: Plumbing issues

Posts.Content: Apologies to the guys and gals here who are on the "other forum"... I'm. Opting and pasting this for the folks who are not on that forum. I posted it there, and thought it was worth getting a discussion going here to for the benefit of the guys who frequent this forum only (and me ). So it's about what seems to have become my "life's work.... I'm not referring to my work as a Financial Planner, I'm referring to what seems to have become my life's work, life as a senior citizen with health issues. And I'm not even sure if this is a rant, or a question. But I'm curious to know if I'm in the majority or minority, I.e. How others manage things. Between my prostate Cancer which has been in the rear view mirror, but might be pulling up alongside me now, and my coronary artery disease, which will always be in front of me, and family members health issues, I find myself totally preoccupied with all matters health. Diet, exercise, supplements, dr appointments, and the inevitable "worry". I manage to have a good time with my friends, and manage to focus on work when I'm in the office, or with a client. But health I always there. I constantly wonder if I'm doing the right things diet wise, supplement wise. And uncertainty about the future is always in the back, sometimes in the front, of my mind. When I am not at work, or out with friends,I'm reading a health book, or searching the internet for studies, or on a forum. I thought of taking a long vacation from ALL the health related forums I'm on, but I don't want to. Which is bad. I take Zoloft, it helps, I do biofeedback breathing exercises, I think it helps. I try mindfulness. But the bottom line is that health has become, in some sense, my life's work. I fear this is unhealthy, and will only make things worse in the long term. Not to mention all the time I spend on it that I could be doing other things (stupid mindless things like watching replays of Seinfeld, or useful things like learning to be a good photographer) Maybe I'm wrong, but I'm guessing I'm not the only one here in this mindset. Especially guys with more advanced cases than mine. Maybe this would be a useful discussion for others. I think if it was "just" prostate cancer (forgive me), it would be easier. But combined with heart disease, and other family issues I'm dealing with, it's hard to get away from it. Thoughts?

Posts.Title: With apologies....

Posts.Content: @MichaelF - Since you had RALP 3 + years ago, can i ask, for how long did you see improvement? Did your progress stop at say 1 year, 2 years? I'm fully continent, but as i said, i get the ghost squirts, even 9 months out, and i do get up some nights to pee. Also, on occasion, i would say maybe 3 times since my fully continent state began, about 6 wweeks after surgery, i have found myself waking up to find i peed myself. Not all over the place, on the bed, etc, but the underwear is wet in a decent size spot, once the whole front, but more often, maybe the size of a dollar bill, or a bit less. I think it happens mostly when i have drank a lot of water before going to bed and am very tired to begin with. Its not the end of the world, but psychologically, it upsets me.

Posts.Title: Plumbing issues

Posts.Content: JimBow, welcome to the forum, and our "reluctant brotherhood". It tends to be a bit quiet here on the weekends, some replies will trickle in, but by early in the week, you'll have way more, and alot from folks more knowledgeable than i am. Just remember, the most important thing is to do your own research, we can relate our experiences and give our opinions, although none of us, as far as i know, are doctors, and even if we were, we may not know all the specifics of your case. First of all, slow down, take a deep breath, your world is not going to come to an end, it will just change. I can tell you from my personal experience, that its really not nearly as bad as we all expect, when we get the diagnosis and our minds start running wild. I was in your position, exactly a year ago, having been diagnosed in November of 2014, with my biopsy showing a Gleason 6. However after surgery my pathology was changed to a G7(3+4). So i guess the first question that would be worth knowing is, were you a 3+4 or a 4+3? One is low intermediate risk, the other is high intermediate risk. There is a clear difference. But the good news is, you are not an 8 9 or one of the rare G10s. Those are the very aggressive tumors. . As i said, i was exactly where you were a year ago, and had my surgery January 6th, 2015. In March i was back to work (desk job). In May i was playing golf (i could have played months earlier if the weather allowed). In July i wennt on a two week trip to Vancouver and Alaska. November i ran a 5K with my daughter (to benefit Prostate Cancer Awareness). And in December, i flew to Aruba for 9 days in the sun. SO ALL IS NOT LOST, YOUR LIFE WILL BE FULL OF HAPPINESS AGAIN, AFTER YOU GET THROUGH THIS. Yes, there are guys who have ongoing problems. But the majority move on and live their full lives as before. PC is a very slow growing cancer in the vast majority of cases. Good on ya that you bought Walshs book. Its a great primer for newly diagnosed guys. Make sure you have the 3rd edition. But even some of that is outdated, as it was published in 2012 and things are moving fast in PC treatement world (for the better). For my money, surgery is probably the right thing for you, just based on your age. But you should look at the various forms of radiation as well. SBRT (Cyberknife), IMRT, IGRT, LDR and HDR Brachy (seeds). They've all gotten great results with low and intermediate risk guys, if the cancer has not escaped the prostate capsule. And with your relatively low PSA, combined with the fact that you had cancer showing only on one side, and a negative DRE, the chances of no escape, are pretty high. In fact, if there was escape, radiation would probably be the better choice, because radiation cooks not only the prostate, but surrounding tissue. There is a reason i think its important to explore all options. You get only one shot at CHOOSING the best treatment. If you look at all the possibilites, and are educated about them, the side effects of each, the results of each, etc, you will choose the right one for YOU (everyone is different) with CONFIDENCE AND YOU WON'T LOOK BACK. And once you do that you will feel so much better. And you won't look back. Remember, most Urologists are surgeons, and many if not most surgeons will recommend surgery. Radiation Oncologists will recommend radiation. Not because they don't have you best interest at heart. But because they have a natural bias. They believe in what they do, or they wouldn't be doing it. So its up to you to decide on whats best for YOU. The phase you are in now, understanding, educating, and deciding, is probably the hardest part of this journey. Which brings me to 3TmultiParametric MRI. You should ask for one. It will tell you with about 90-95% certainty whether there has been any escape from the capsule. If there has, it might affect your treatment choice. The other thing you should do, that might affect your treatment choice, is get a second opinion on the pathology. Have the slides sent to either Jonathan Epstein at Johns Hopkins, or David Bostwick and Bostwick Labs. Your Doctor gets this request all the time from newly diagnosed guys that are educating themselves about the disease, and should know where to send them. If not, just google Johns Hopkins Second Opinion Service Prostate, and it will take you to the instructions. They charge $250, its usually not covered by insurance but its worth it. And Dr Epstein will get on the phone with you after the results are in, if you have questions. The reason this is important, is that these two guys ,Epstein and Bostwick, are the acknowldged experts in Prostate Cell Pathology. And reading prostate slides is a very subjective thing. Most local pathologists generally read all kinds of slides, so before reading yours, they might have read a breast or colon slide. Epstein (and Bostwick) read only Prostate Slides. When i asked my surgeon, if i could take Espteins second opinion to the bank, his response was "Epstein IS the bank". My Biopsy was originally diagnosed at Gleason 8 (3+5). UGH!!! Epstein downgraded it to a G6 (3+3). As i mentioned after surgery, when they looked at the entire prostate, they found G6, but also found some g7(3+4). The biopsy samples only about 1/1000th of the prostate, so it can often miss something. Thats why in about 30% of cases, post surgical pathology changes the Gleason score. Don't worry about hormone therapy right now, it may well not be necessary. Especially if your Gleason is a 7(3+4) Regarding surgery, you want a surgeon who is highly experienced, having done at least 300 surgeries, according to research, but for margin of safety i wanted at least 1000. Arbitrary number i know. The surgeon i chose, Dr Ash Tewari, in NYC, hadover 6000 under his belt. Everyone has a different experience. For me, the surgery wasnt so bad, and i was fully continent after 5 weeks, and experienced no Erectile Dysfunction. I took Cialis for about 10 mnths, but am off it now, no need. Enough for now. 1. calm down 2. read the book 3. speak to many Practitioners in the various treatment options until you find the one you are comfortable with. 4. Slay the beast 5. Remember you aren't alone, we are all with you, we've all gone through it, survived, and thrived in most cases. Good luck , stick around, keep us posted along the way, and ask alot of questions of both us and your doctors.

Posts.Title: Just got diagnosed

Posts.Content: Brownie I think one more thing needs to be added here. The moral of this story is, you really need to be your own patient advocate. Nobody cares about you as much as you and your family . It's particularly important with prostate cancer, where there are so many treatments to choose from in most cases and also in most cases they will all cure you, particularly if your Gleason six diagnosis holds. Educate yourself do a lot of reading learn about the disease asked the doctors for guidance, make your own educated decisions, and then have a doctors execute on your decisions . Best of luck and please keep us posted

Posts.Title: Pc 101

Posts.Content: You need to find different Doctors, IMHO. FIrst, G6 is usually indolent, meaning you could have no treatment, NS stay on active surveillance. But active surveillance does not mean a PSA every six months. You should be monitored on a regular basis in a structured program with PSA tested every three months, annual biopsies etc. Second, it's very curious to me that your PSA would be as high as it is with G6 and only 2 cores positive. You might have some prostatitis going on in there in addition to the cancerous cells . Third, be aware but in about 30% of cases, for those who choose to go the surgery route ( not recommending for or against surgery ) The Gleason score is upgraded, to a more serious grade . On the other hand if you had something higher than a G6 the MRI a(I assume it was a 3T multi parametric MRI) usually will pick it up. In short, I don't think it's time to panic, but I do think you need to find a top doctor Who specializes in prostate cancer knows what he's doing. The only thing that any of your doctor said that make sense to me, is that in large lymph nodes should be investigated . The fact that the only way you found out about that is by reading the report, speaks volumes to how little you're attending doctor cares. I'd be furious.

Posts.Title: Just got diagnosed

Posts.Content: Pom, .65, followed by .94 is unfortunately pretty strong evidence of biochemical recurrence. Conventional thinking is that after surgery, .2 is where they start talking about salvage radiation or other treatments. I don't know how that is different after HIFU! It probably is. Studies have shown that on average, there is an 8 year spread between first biochemical recurrence and actual symptoms of spread.

I was in your position, exactly a year ago, having been diagnosed in November of 2014, with my biopsy showing a Gleason 6. However after surgery my pathology was changed to a G7(3+4). So i guess the first question that would be worth knowing is, were you a 3+4 or a 4+3? One is low intermediate risk, the other is high intermediate risk. There is a clear difference. But the good news is, you are not an 8 9 or one of the rare G10s. Those are the very aggressive tumors. . As i said, i was exactly where you were a year ago, and had my surgery January 6th, 2015. In March i was back to work (desk job). In May i was playing golf (i could have played months earlier if the weather allowed). In July i wennt on a two week trip to Vancouver and Alaska. November i ran a 5K with my daughter (to benefit Prostate Cancer Awareness). And in December, i flew to Aruba for 9 days in the sun. SO ALL IS NOT LOST, YOUR LIFE WILL BE FULL OF HAPPINESS AGAIN, AFTER YOU GET THROUGH THIS. Yes, there are guys who have ongoing problems. But the majority move on and live their full lives as before. PC is a very slow growing cancer in the vast majority of cases. Good on ya that you bought Walshs book. Its a great primer for newly diagnosed guys. Make sure you have the 3rd edition. But even some of that is outdated, as it was published in 2012 and things are moving fast in PC treatement world (for the better). For my money, surgery is probably the right thing for you, just based on your age. But you should look at the various forms of radiation as well. SBRT (Cyberknife), IMRT, IGRT, LDR and HDR Brachy (seeds). They've all gotten great results with low and intermediate risk guys, if the cancer has not escaped the prostate capsule. And with your relatively low PSA, combined with the fact that you had cancer showing only on one side, and a negative DRE, the chances of no escape, are pretty high. In fact, if there was escape, radiation would probably be the better choice, because radiation cooks not only the prostate, but surrounding tissue. There is a reason i think its important to explore all options. You get only one shot at CHOOSING the best treatment. If you look at all the possibilites, and are educated about them, the side effects of each, the results of each, etc, you will choose the right one for YOU (everyone is different) with CONFIDENCE AND YOU WON'T LOOK BACK. And once you do that you will feel so much better. And you won't look back. Remember, most Urologists are surgeons, and many if not most surgeons will recommend surgery. Radiation Oncologists will recommend radiation. Not because they don't have you best interest at heart. But because they have a natural bias. They believe in what they do, or they wouldn't be doing it. So its up to you to decide on whats best for YOU. The phase you are in now, understanding, educating, and deciding, is probably the hardest part of this journey. Which brings me to 3TmultiParametric MRI. You should ask for one. It will tell you with about 90-95% certainty whether there has been any escape from the capsule. If there has, it might affect your treatment choice. The other thing you should do, that might affect your treatment choice, is get a second opinion on the pathology. Have the slides sent to either Jonathan Epstein at Johns Hopkins, or David Bostwick and Bostwick Labs. Your Doctor gets this request all the time from newly diagnosed guys that are educating themselves about the disease, and should know where to send them. If not, just google Johns Hopkins Second Opinion Service Prostate, and it will take you to the instructions. They charge $250, its usually not covered by insurance but its worth it. And Dr Epstein will get on the phone with you after the results are in, if you have questions. The reason this is important, is that these two guys ,Epstein and Bostwick, are the acknowldged experts in Prostate Cell Pathology. And reading prostate slides is a very subjective thing. Most local pathologists generally read all kinds of slides, so before reading yours, they might have read a breast or colon slide. Epstein (and Bostwick) read only Prostate Slides. When i asked my surgeon, if i could take Espteins second opinion to the bank, his response was "Epstein IS the bank". My Biopsy was originally diagnosed at Gleason 8 (3+5). UGH!!! Epstein downgraded it to a G6 (3+3). As i mentioned after surgery, when they looked at the entire prostate, they found G6, but also found some g7(3+4). The biopsy samples only about 1/1000th of the prostate, so it can often miss something. Thats why in about 30% of cases, post surgical pathology changes the Gleason score. Don't worry about hormone therapy right now, it may well not be necessary. Especially if your Gleason is a 7(3+4) Regarding surgery, you want a surgeon who is highly experienced, having done at least 300 surgeries, according to research, but for margin of safety i wanted at least 1000. Arbitrary number i know. The surgeon i chose, Dr Ash Tewari, in NYC, hadover 6000 under his belt. Everyone has a different experience. For me, the surgery wasnt so bad, and i was fully continent after 5 weeks, and experienced no Erectile Dysfunction. I took Cialis for about 10 mnths, but am off it now, no need. Enough for now. 1. calm down 2. read the book 3. speak to many Practitioners in the various treatment options until you find the one you are comfortable with. 4. Slay the beast 5. Remember you aren't alone, we are all with you, we've all gone through it, survived, and thrived in most cases. Good luck , stick around, keep us posted along the way, and ask alot of questions of both us and your doctors.

Posts.Title: Just got diagnosed

Posts.Content: Jen, welcome to the forum, really sorry you guys need to be here, especially at such a young age. I can't answer the bladder question, not familiar. Regarding the Prostate Cancer, thats a lot of cancer. But all is not lost and its likely highly treatable and maybe even curable. The fact that his PSA is under 20, suggests that its unlikely that bone mets will be detected. ... 1. have the slides sent to Dr Jonathan Epstein at Johns Hopkins for a second opinion. Reading these slides is very subjective and you want someone eyeballing the slides that is an expert at Prostate cells specifically, not a local pathologist who looks at all kinds of slides. The reason to get the second opinion, is not to confirm that there is cancer, with that many cores positive, there most definitely is. But it could be that the G7s get downgraded to G6, or upgraded to G8, which might change treatment options. 2. get and read Dr Patrick Walshs book "surviving Prostate Cancer". Make sure its the third edition. It will give you an excellent understanding of the disease and things you need to think about and ask your doctors. And its an easy read. 3. Consider asking that an MRI be done on the prostate. 3 TESLA Multiparametric MRI to be specific. This test is 95% accurate at determining whether the cancer has left the prostate. 4. make sure you explore ALL options available to you. Not just surgery, not just radiation. Thats enough for now, others will surely chime in soon. A couple of suggestions

Posts.Title: husband just diagnosed

Posts.Content: Sorry your dad is having all these issues. A DRE prior to blood draw, and especially two DRE's, can and will raise PSA, but it won't raise a normal PSA into "the hundreds". I'd assume a catheter can raise PSA Significantly, although I've never read about that.. but I doubt into the 100's. An enlarged prostate and /or prostatitis, can raise PSA, but not into the 100's. But I'm thinking, wondering, I suppose all these things taken together, could possibly raise PSA by a lot. Maybe into the 100'a, I don't know. The only definitive diagnosis for Prostate Cancer is a biopsy . But your dad should try to eliminate all other possibilities first. If his doc indeed did do a DRE PRIOR to PSA blood draw, I would be looking for another doc, any urologist knows that's not good practice.

Posts.Title: PSA in 100's

Posts.Content: Gorhad, 1. you think turning 50 is "dreaded"? Dude, I'm 66, i'd give my left nut, or my prostate, to be 50.....oh, wait.... 2. biopsy is no a big deal most of the time. I took a xanax before i left the house, another one in the car, and a third one when i got to the Drs office. I was very looped. And it was not bad. Second biopsy i only took one xanax an hour before. easy peasy. 3. Be ready after the biopsy to piss some blood, lasts a day or two, up to a week. And be expecting that your gism will be blood red at first, then slowly turn brownish then in a few weeks back to normal 4. the fact that your PSA jumped so much in a short time, combined with the fact that the DRE was painful, leads me to think Prostatitis. Maybe ask for a round of Cipro before proceeding to biopsy? If that brings the PSA down to a much lower range, then its likely an infection. Good luck. Breathe

Posts.Title: What Should i Expect

Posts.Content: DD, you are describing the same thing I am experiencing, 9 months out, and I was thinking about it the other day. I too sometimes feel a squirt, but there is none. And sometimes I piss like a water canon and other times it's not a weak stream but not especially strong either. And there are a few occasions where I feel like I haven't fully emptied. The only difference for me is at night I rarely wake more than once a night. And sometimes I sleep 7 hours without waking. I find that to be dependent on whether I drink a lot of water after 8PM or so. These issues are things I am going to discuss with my surgeon in Jamuary at my one year follow up

Posts.Title: What Should i Expect

Posts.Content: RTS, you said... "I just can’t see how with my pathology report that cancer could have gotten out of my prostate." I asked my surgeon the exact same question. His answer was just.... "it can certainly happen. Anything is possible with Prostate Cancer" and i was a g7(3+4) but with low Decipher. Regarding the Decipher Grid Report - i pointed out to my RO that the Grid Report states a low chance that Salvage Radiation would work (i dont recall the exact words)> He responded that its just investigational (as Chuck pointed out) and its not considered actionable science at this point. Regarding the benign prostate tissue question, its very doubtful, with a psa of .25 that benign tissue is causing the increase. .025, maybe, not .25 This sucks, sorry you are going through it, i am as well, although my psa is still lower, at .068 (next PSA blood draw this week). So i feel your pain. We just have to deal with it, and hope that we can move on after treatment. I keep saying lots of guys here have gone through it and come out the other end to enjoy life. So i can too.

Posts.Title: husband just diagnosed

Posts.Content: On the surface I agree with the others, from your path report alone, you are a poster boy for Active Surviellance. The one question I would have is what about the Pirads 4? My understanding is that MP-MRI is good at detecting high grade cancer, but not so good at detecting low grade/G6. So yes, ask about that P-4.

Posts.Title: Ugh, but not overly concerned

Posts.Content: Gorhad, 1. you think turning 50 is "dreaded"? Dude, I'm 66, i'd give my left nut, or my prostate, to be 50.....oh, wait.... 2. biopsy is no a big deal most of the time. I took a xanax before i left the house, another one in the car, and a third one when i got to the Drs office. I was very looped. And it was not bad. Second biopsy i only took one xanax an hour before. easy peasy. 3. Be ready after the biopsy to piss some blood, lasts a day or two, up to a week. And be expecting that your gism will be blood red at first, then slowly turn brownish then in a few weeks back to normal 4. the fact that your PSA jumped so much in a short time, combined with the fact that the DRE was painful, leads me to think Prostatitis. Maybe ask for a round of Cipro before proceeding to biopsy? If that brings the PSA down to a much lower range, then its likely an infection. Good luck. Breathe

Posts.Title: What Should i Expect

Posts.Content: Jen, welcome to the forum, really sorry you guys need to be here, especially at such a young age. I can't answer the bladder question, not familiar. Regarding the Prostate Cancer, thats a lot of cancer. But all is not lost and its likely highly treatable and maybe even curable. The fact that his PSA is under 20, suggests that its unlikely that bone mets will be detected. ... 1. have the slides sent to Dr Jonathan Epstein at Johns Hopkins for a second opinion. Reading these slides is very subjective and you want someone eyeballing the slides that is an expert at Prostate cells specifically, not a local pathologist who looks at all kinds of slides. The reason to get the second opinion, is not to confirm that there is cancer, with that many cores positive, there most definitely is. But it could be that the G7s get downgraded to G6, or upgraded to G8, which might change treatment options. 2. get and read Dr Patrick Walshs book "surviving Prostate Cancer". Make sure its the third edition. It will give you an excellent understanding of the disease and things you need to think about and ask your doctors. And its an easy read. 3. Consider asking that an MRI be done on the prostate. 3 TESLA Multiparametric MRI to be specific. This test is 95% accurate at determining whether the cancer has left the prostate. 4. make sure you explore ALL options available to you. Not just surgery, not just radiation. Thats enough for now, others will surely chime in soon. A couple of suggestions

Posts.Title: husband just diagnosed

Posts.Content: Hilander, you've gotten good advice. Its easy for us to tell you to relax, and just not get yourself crazy until you have a reason to. But we have all been there, and so we know to tell you that would be trite, not to mention useless. What was the history of your progression? Was it a sudden jump, of a slow steady rise over a period of years? If a sudden jump it could be an infection. PSA is not an indication of cancer, its an indication that something is inflaming the prostate, and that something could be a number of things. Also, did the urologist do a Free PSA before goign to biopsy? Hang in there, and stick around, hope you dont need the help after you get results, but if its the news you fear, we are here to help

Posts.Title: Probability?

Posts.Content: JimBow, welcome to the forum, and our "reluctant brotherhood". It tends to be a bit quiet here on the weekends, some replies will trickle in, but by early in the week, you'll have way more, and alot from folks more knowledgeable than i am. Just remember, the most important thing is to do your own research, we can relate our experiences and give our opinions, although none of us, as far as i know, are doctors, and even if we were, we may not know all the specifics of your case. First of all, slow down, take a deep breath, your world is not going to come to an end, it will just change. I can tell you from my personal experience, that its really not nearly as bad as we all expect, when we get the diagnosis and our minds start running wild. I was in your position, exactly a year ago, having been diagnosed in November of 2014, with my biopsy showing a Gleason 6. However after surgery my pathology was changed to a G7(3+4). So i guess the first question that would be worth knowing is, were you a 3+4 or a 4+3? One is low intermediate risk, the other is high intermediate risk. There is a clear difference. But the good news is, you are not an 8 9 or one of the rare G10s. Those are the very aggressive tumors. . As i said, i was exactly where you were a year ago, and had my surgery January 6th, 2015. In March i was back to work (desk job). In May i was playing golf (i could have played months earlier if the weather allowed). In July i wennt on a two week trip to Vancouver and Alaska. November i ran a 5K with my daughter (to benefit Prostate Cancer Awareness). And in December, i flew to Aruba for 9 days in the sun. SO ALL IS NOT LOST, YOUR LIFE WILL BE FULL OF HAPPINESS AGAIN, AFTER YOU GET THROUGH THIS. Yes, there are guys who have ongoing problems. But the majority move on and live their full lives as before. PC is a very slow growing cancer in the vast majority of cases. Good on ya that you bought Walshs book. Its a great primer for newly diagnosed guys. Make sure you have the 3rd edition. But even some of that is outdated, as it was published in 2012 and things are moving fast in PC treatement world (for the better). For my money, surgery is probably the right thing for you, just based on your age. But you should look at the various forms of radiation as well. SBRT (Cyberknife), IMRT, IGRT, LDR and HDR Brachy (seeds). They've all gotten great results with low and intermediate risk guys, if the cancer has not escaped the prostate capsule. And with your relatively low PSA, combined with the fact that you had cancer showing only on one side, and a negative DRE, the chances of no escape, are pretty high. In fact, if there was escape, radiation would probably be the better choice, because radiation cooks not only the prostate, but surrounding tissue. There is a reason i think its important to explore all options. You get only one shot at CHOOSING the best treatment. If you look at all the possibilites, and are educated about them, the side effects of each, the results of each, etc, you will choose the right one for YOU (everyone is different) with CONFIDENCE AND YOU WON'T LOOK BACK. And once you do that you will feel so much better. And you won't look back. Remember, most Urologists are surgeons, and many if not most surgeons will recommend surgery. Radiation Oncologists will recommend radiation. Not because they don't have you best interest at heart. But because they have a natural bias. They believe in what they do, or they wouldn't be doing it. So its up to you to decide on whats best for YOU. The phase you are in now, understanding, educating, and deciding, is probably the hardest part of this journey. Which brings me to 3TmultiParametric MRI. You should ask for one. It will tell you with about 90-95% certainty whether there has been any escape from the capsule. If there has, it might affect your treatment choice. The other thing you should do, that might affect your treatment choice, is get a second opinion on the pathology. Have the slides sent to either Jonathan Epstein at Johns Hopkins, or David Bostwick and Bostwick Labs. Your Doctor gets this request all the time from newly diagnosed guys that are educating themselves about the disease, and should know where to send them. If not, just google Johns Hopkins Second Opinion Service Prostate, and it will take you to the instructions. They charge $250, its usually not covered by insurance but its worth it. And Dr Epstein will get on the phone with you after the results are in, if you have questions. The reason this is important, is that these two guys ,Epstein and Bostwick, are the acknowldged experts in Prostate Cell Pathology. And reading prostate slides is a very subjective thing. Most local pathologists generally read all kinds of slides, so before reading yours, they might have read a breast or colon slide. Epstein (and Bostwick) read only Prostate Slides. When i asked my surgeon, if i could take Espteins second opinion to the bank, his response was "Epstein IS the bank". My Biopsy was originally diagnosed at Gleason 8 (3+5). UGH!!! Epstein downgraded it to a G6 (3+3). As i mentioned after surgery, when they looked at the entire prostate, they found G6, but also found some g7(3+4). The biopsy samples only about 1/1000th of the prostate, so it can often miss something. Thats why in about 30% of cases, post surgical pathology changes the Gleason score. Don't worry about hormone therapy right now, it may well not be necessary. Especially if your Gleason is a 7(3+4) Regarding surgery, you want a surgeon who is highly experienced, having done at least 300 surgeries, according to research, but for margin of safety i wanted at least 1000. Arbitrary number i know. The surgeon i chose, Dr Ash Tewari, in NYC, hadover 6000 under his belt. Everyone has a different experience. For me, the surgery wasnt so bad, and i was fully continent after 5 weeks, and experienced no Erectile Dysfunction. I took Cialis for about 10 mnths, but am off it now, no need. Enough for now. 1. calm down 2. read the book 3. speak to many Practitioners in the various treatment options until you find the one you are comfortable with. 4. Slay the beast 5. Remember you aren't alone, we are all with you, we've all gone through it, survived, and thrived in most cases. Good luck , stick around, keep us posted along the way, and ask alot of questions of both us and your doctors.

Posts.Title: Enlarged prostate with negative biopsy

Posts.Content: Logic, on the incontinence , you are spot on. I too,found that, I would have a great day, then at around 4-5pM the squirts would start, especially after a full day. It continued that way till about 2 1/2 months. At my 3 month visit to my surgeon, it was only a once in a while,squirt, every few days. He told me it would continue to improve for another few months. And now at 4 months, I've been squirt free for about two weeks now. So you are right on track to total normalcy. Thanks again for this thread, on behalf of all the new dudes.

Posts.Title: Update: 7 weeks out - progress

Posts.Content: Sorry your dad is having all these issues. A DRE prior to blood draw, and especially two DRE's, can and will raise PSA, but it won't raise a normal PSA into "the hundreds". I'd assume a catheter can raise PSA Significantly, although I've never read about that.. but I doubt into the 100's. An enlarged prostate and /or prostatitis, can raise PSA, but not into the 100's. But I'm thinking, wondering, I suppose all these things taken together, could possibly raise PSA by a lot. Maybe into the 100'a, I don't know. The only definitive diagnosis for Prostate Cancer is a biopsy . But your dad should try to eliminate all other possibilities first. If his doc indeed did do a DRE PRIOR to PSA blood draw, I would be looking for another doc, any urologist knows that's not good practice.

Posts.Title: Post op pathology back today...

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by brownie43 You stated you would be furious with the Dr. Well, it is the VA, and I forgot to mention that I am 73yrs. old. The first VA Urologist that I saw at the VA was a bit "put off" because I had a PSA in my labs., and said he would never order a PSA for anyone 70 or older but seeing as how someone else was ordering 'unnecessary lab work", he would do a DRE (enlarged but no bumps). Said if I came in dragging an oxygen bottle or such, he would not order more tests, etc. but I was a youthful 73, so lucky me. Anyway, he did order up another PSA and recommended a biopsy. Not sure how to get a second opinion at the VA, so will probably go to my Medicare PCP So once we turn 70, we don't need the same level,of care? Because we are gonna die soon anyway? Absurd. I'm 66. I've got health issues. I still plan to be around for a long time. And part of that plan is to monitor for issues that haven't shown up yet.

Posts.Title: Pc 101

Posts.Content: Brownie I think one more thing needs to be added here. The moral of this story is, you really need to be your own patient advocate. Nobody cares about you as much as you and your family . It's particularly important with prostate cancer, where there are so many treatments to choose from in most cases and also in most cases they will all cure you, particularly if your Gleason six diagnosis holds. Educate yourself do a lot of reading learn about the disease asked the doctors for guidance, make your own educated decisions, and then have a doctors execute on your decisions . Best of luck and please keep us posted

Posts.Title: Just got diagnosed

Posts.Content: JimBow, welcome to the forum, and our "reluctant brotherhood". It tends to be a bit quiet here on the weekends, some replies will trickle in, but by early in the week, you'll have way more, and alot from folks more knowledgeable than i am. Just remember, the most important thing is to do your own research, we can relate our experiences and give our opinions, although none of us, as far as i know, are doctors, and even if we were, we may not know all the specifics of your case. First of all, slow down, take a deep breath, your world is not going to come to an end, it will just change. I can tell you from my personal experience, that its really not nearly as bad as we all expect, when we get the diagnosis and our minds start running wild. I was in your position, exactly a year ago, having been diagnosed in November of 2014, with my biopsy showing a Gleason 6. However after surgery my pathology was changed to a G7(3+4). So i guess the first question that would be worth knowing is, were you a 3+4 or a 4+3? One is low intermediate risk, the other is high intermediate risk. There is a clear difference. But the good news is, you are not an 8 9 or one of the rare G10s. Those are the very aggressive tumors. . As i said, i was exactly where you were a year ago, and had my surgery January 6th, 2015. In March i was back to work (desk job). In May i was playing golf (i could have played months earlier if the weather allowed). In July i wennt on a two week trip to Vancouver and Alaska. November i ran a 5K with my daughter (to benefit Prostate Cancer Awareness). And in December, i flew to Aruba for 9 days in the sun. SO ALL IS NOT LOST, YOUR LIFE WILL BE FULL OF HAPPINESS AGAIN, AFTER YOU GET THROUGH THIS. Yes, there are guys who have ongoing problems. But the majority move on and live their full lives as before. PC is a very slow growing cancer in the vast majority of cases. Good on ya that you bought Walshs book. Its a great primer for newly diagnosed guys. Make sure you have the 3rd edition. But even some of that is outdated, as it was published in 2012 and things are moving fast in PC treatement world (for the better). For my money, surgery is probably the right thing for you, just based on your age. But you should look at the various forms of radiation as well. SBRT (Cyberknife), IMRT, IGRT, LDR and HDR Brachy (seeds). They've all gotten great results with low and intermediate risk guys, if the cancer has not escaped the prostate capsule. And with your relatively low PSA, combined with the fact that you had cancer showing only on one side, and a negative DRE, the chances of no escape, are pretty high. In fact, if there was escape, radiation would probably be the better choice, because radiation cooks not only the prostate, but surrounding tissue. There is a reason i think its important to explore all options. You get only one shot at CHOOSING the best treatment. If you look at all the possibilites, and are educated about them, the side effects of each, the results of each, etc, you will choose the right one for YOU (everyone is different) with CONFIDENCE AND YOU WON'T LOOK BACK. And once you do that you will feel so much better. And you won't look back. Remember, most Urologists are surgeons, and many if not most surgeons will recommend surgery. Radiation Oncologists will recommend radiation. Not because they don't have you best interest at heart. But because they have a natural bias. They believe in what they do, or they wouldn't be doing it. So its up to you to decide on whats best for YOU. The phase you are in now, understanding, educating, and deciding, is probably the hardest part of this journey. Which brings me to 3TmultiParametric MRI. You should ask for one. It will tell you with about 90-95% certainty whether there has been any escape from the capsule. If there has, it might affect your treatment choice. The other thing you should do, that might affect your treatment choice, is get a second opinion on the pathology. Have the slides sent to either Jonathan Epstein at Johns Hopkins, or David Bostwick and Bostwick Labs. Your Doctor gets this request all the time from newly diagnosed guys that are educating themselves about the disease, and should know where to send them. If not, just google Johns Hopkins Second Opinion Service Prostate, and it will take you to the instructions. They charge $250, its usually not covered by insurance but its worth it. And Dr Epstein will get on the phone with you after the results are in, if you have questions. The reason this is important, is that these two guys ,Epstein and Bostwick, are the acknowldged experts in Prostate Cell Pathology. And reading prostate slides is a very subjective thing. Most local pathologists generally read all kinds of slides, so before reading yours, they might have read a breast or colon slide. Epstein (and Bostwick) read only Prostate Slides. When i asked my surgeon, if i could take Espteins second opinion to the bank, his response was "Epstein IS the bank". My Biopsy was originally diagnosed at Gleason 8 (3+5). UGH!!! Epstein downgraded it to a G6 (3+3). As i mentioned after surgery, when they looked at the entire prostate, they found G6, but also found some g7(3+4). The biopsy samples only about 1/1000th of the prostate, so it can often miss something. Thats why in about 30% of cases, post surgical pathology changes the Gleason score. Don't worry about hormone therapy right now, it may well not be necessary. Especially if your Gleason is a 7(3+4) Regarding surgery, you want a surgeon who is highly experienced, having done at least 300 surgeries, according to research, but for margin of safety i wanted at least 1000. Arbitrary number i know. The surgeon i chose, Dr Ash Tewari, in NYC, hadover 6000 under his belt. Everyone has a different experience. For me, the surgery wasnt so bad, and i was fully continent after 5 weeks, and experienced no Erectile Dysfunction. I took Cialis for about 10 mnths, but am off it now, no need. Enough for now. 1. calm down 2. read the book 3. speak to many Practitioners in the various treatment options until you find the one you are comfortable with. 4. Slay the beast 5. Remember you aren't alone, we are all with you, we've all gone through it, survived, and thrived in most cases. Good luck , stick around, keep us posted along the way, and ask alot of questions of both us and your doctors.

Posts.Title: Just got diagnosed

Posts.Content: Jen, welcome to the forum, really sorry you guys need to be here, especially at such a young age. I can't answer the bladder question, not familiar. Regarding the Prostate Cancer, thats a lot of cancer. But all is not lost and its likely highly treatable and maybe even curable. The fact that his PSA is under 20, suggests that its unlikely that bone mets will be detected. ... 1. have the slides sent to Dr Jonathan Epstein at Johns Hopkins for a second opinion. Reading these slides is very subjective and you want someone eyeballing the slides that is an expert at Prostate cells specifically, not a local pathologist who looks at all kinds of slides. The reason to get the second opinion, is not to confirm that there is cancer, with that many cores positive, there most definitely is. But it could be that the G7s get downgraded to G6, or upgraded to G8, which might change treatment options. 2. get and read Dr Patrick Walshs book "surviving Prostate Cancer". Make sure its the third edition. It will give you an excellent understanding of the disease and things you need to think about and ask your doctors. And its an easy read. 3. Consider asking that an MRI be done on the prostate. 3 TESLA Multiparametric MRI to be specific. This test is 95% accurate at determining whether the cancer has left the prostate. 4. make sure you explore ALL options available to you. Not just surgery, not just radiation. Thats enough for now, others will surely chime in soon. A couple of suggestions

Posts.Title: a simple thanks

Posts.Content: Hilander, you've gotten good advice. Its easy for us to tell you to relax, and just not get yourself crazy until you have a reason to. But we have all been there, and so we know to tell you that would be trite, not to mention useless. What was the history of your progression? Was it a sudden jump, of a slow steady rise over a period of years? If a sudden jump it could be an infection. PSA is not an indication of cancer, its an indication that something is inflaming the prostate, and that something could be a number of things. Also, did the urologist do a Free PSA before goign to biopsy? Hang in there, and stick around, hope you dont need the help after you get results, but if its the news you fear, we are here to help

Posts.Title: Concerned Partner

Posts.Content: Gorhad, 1. you think turning 50 is "dreaded"? Dude, I'm 66, i'd give my left nut, or my prostate, to be 50.....oh, wait.... 2. biopsy is no a big deal most of the time. I took a xanax before i left the house, another one in the car, and a third one when i got to the Drs office. I was very looped. And it was not bad. Second biopsy i only took one xanax an hour before. easy peasy. 3. Be ready after the biopsy to piss some blood, lasts a day or two, up to a week. And be expecting that your gism will be blood red at first, then slowly turn brownish then in a few weeks back to normal 4. the fact that your PSA jumped so much in a short time, combined with the fact that the DRE was painful, leads me to think Prostatitis. Maybe ask for a round of Cipro before proceeding to biopsy? If that brings the PSA down to a much lower range, then its likely an infection. Good luck. Breathe

Posts.Title: What Should i Expect

Posts.Content: Dave, your thinking, and your mindset mirror mine. You said... "I will never know if I over treated, but I sure as heck would know if I undertreated and would question why I didn't do more earlier so I didn't have to be on ADT the rest of my life." and that is exacty what i was thinking. I didnt want to be kicking myself if i waited till .02 and then recurred after SRT. So i pulled the trigger, but not until giving it much thought. Every situation is different, and every person is wired differently, so everybody needs to make their own decision, based on how they feel not only test wise, but mentally Good luck, i know first hand that being in nowhere land, the uncertainty can be tortous

Posts.Content: Mark, looking at your final pathology, I see you are a G7(4+3), and what jumped out t me was 90% grade 4. While it’s great that margins were clean and tumor was contained in the capsule, if it where me, I’d want a more sensitive test. Be happy with the result for now, but go to labcorp for the next regularly scheduled test. If you start getting a rise, you’ll know sooner if it means anything. Of course, with that, c0mes more stress. Let’s hope it never becomes an issue.

Posts.Title: Got My 6-week post RALP first test - not sure what it means...

Posts.Content: Jen, welcome to the forum, really sorry you guys need to be here, especially at such a young age. I can't answer the bladder question, not familiar. Regarding the Prostate Cancer, thats a lot of cancer. But all is not lost and its likely highly treatable and maybe even curable. The fact that his PSA is under 20, suggests that its unlikely that bone mets will be detected. ... 1. have the slides sent to Dr Jonathan Epstein at Johns Hopkins for a second opinion. Reading these slides is very subjective and you want someone eyeballing the slides that is an expert at Prostate cells specifically, not a local pathologist who looks at all kinds of slides. The reason to get the second opinion, is not to confirm that there is cancer, with that many cores positive, there most definitely is. But it could be that the G7s get downgraded to G6, or upgraded to G8, which might change treatment options. 2. get and read Dr Patrick Walshs book "surviving Prostate Cancer". Make sure its the third edition. It will give you an excellent understanding of the disease and things you need to think about and ask your doctors. And its an easy read. 3. Consider asking that an MRI be done on the prostate. 3 TESLA Multiparametric MRI to be specific. This test is 95% accurate at determining whether the cancer has left the prostate. 4. make sure you explore ALL options available to you. Not just surgery, not just radiation. Thats enough for now, others will surely chime in soon. A couple of suggestions

Posts.Content: Great report. While it would be better to hve negative margins, it is very good news tht the positive margin was a grade 3. Low likelihood of it developing into something. Good sign that he's able to stop and start urine stream. I was able to as well, and by week 5 , I was going without pads. Expect recovervto full continence to not be linear. Posts.Title: Update and Final Pathology

Posts.Content: MM, with your G9, EPE and Positive Margins, i would probably err on the side of caution and get ART as soon as possible. Try to wait until you are healed and fully continent, from what I've read, any progress you make in continence, and i think ED, will be stopped in its tracks - not reversed, but not get any better - once you have RT So its a tough call. Listen, as I've told you, i have a friend whose dad had epe with G9, 15 years ago, and never had RT, PSA stayed at zero for about 13 years. I guess its a very personal choice - do you want to take the risk, in hopes you get lucky? If you wait, i would ask for very close monitoring of PSA, and jump on any rise (2 in a row)

Posts.Title: Diagnosed Today

Posts.Content: Mike , welcome to active forum participation, glad to have you here, sharing your experience so that others can benefit. It sounds like you are on a very typical NON LINEAR track to full continence. Setbacks are a normal part of the game, that you will likely eventually win with full continence. I also weighed my pads like Wilde, to measure my progress. I'm 9 months out of surgery now and what I would call full continence. I a, writing this, while wearing my very comfortable boxers, the thought of which brings me great joy! �� I remember at my 3 month Follow up, I was pretty much full continent but with an occasional leak. The surgeon told me I will continue to improve, for many months. And it was true, I did. I now pretty much only leak when I grab my wife's ass, or let my bladder get really full. Last night I slept 7 1/2 hours without getting up to pee. You'll get there, it just takes time.nice work so far. Btw I still do kegels 3-4 X a day

Posts.Title: Thrilled to be in the "Zero Club"!

Posts.Content: Mike , welcome to active forum participation, glad to have you here, sharing your experience so that others can benefit. It sounds like you are on a very typical NON LINEAR track to full continence. Setbacks are a normal part of the game, that you will likely eventually win with full continence. I also weighed my pads like Wilde, to measure my progress. I'm 9 months out of surgery now and what I would call full continence. I a, writing this, while wearing my very comfortable boxers, the thought of which brings me great joy! �� I remember at my 3 month Follow up, I was pretty much full continent but with an occasional leak. The surgeon told me I will continue to improve, for many months. And it was true, I did. I now pretty much only leak when I grab my wife's ass, or let my bladder get really full. Last night I slept 7 1/2 hours without getting up to pee. You'll get there, it just takes time.nice work so far. Btw I still do kegels 3-4 X a day

Posts.Title: Hi -- any "active surveillors" out there?

Posts.Content: Great report. While it would be better to hve negative margins, it is very good news tht the positive margin was a grade 3. Low likelihood of it developing into something. Good sign that he's able to stop and start urine stream. I was able to as well, and by week 5 , I was going without pads. Expect recovervto full continence to not be linear. It will be 2 good days, one pad day. I weighed my pads and kept a journal of how much I leaked each day. That lowed me to see the progress week to week. Good luck with the recovery

Posts.Title: It's all perspective

Posts.Content: MB, WELCOME, I Hope you are just passing through. To paraphrase Jim, "from another guy who has "CHRONIC ANXIETY"! By that I mean, I get how you feel, I always think of and dwell on the worst. It's a terrible affliction, and sounds like where you are at right now. Only natural. But please stop. You are NOWHERE NEAR A CANCER DIAGNOSIS. Good on ya for taking it upon yourself to make an appointment with a urologist. In my laymans opinion, I think that's the next step. If I were in your shoes, I would cancel the ultrasound for now. If in fact the nodule turns out to be cancer, youlL have plenty of time to get things stuck up your poop. Until then, the less invasion of your privates, the better. Let the Uro determine if you need an ultrasound alone, or a biopsy. If it's biopsy, then you'll have the ultrasound as part of it. What value is there in knowing the size of Your prostate thru ultrasound (which is an estimate anyway). A good urologist can tell in general terms if your prostate is enlarged. Also, when your Dr does the PSA, ASK HIM to order A FREE PSA as well, it can be performed on the same blood, and will give the Uro more info. And tell your Dr you are going to a Uro. It's your health, and if he is offended that you took input into your own hands, then it says a lot about the Dr. Not in a good way. But I'm sure he'll be fine with it Good luck and please keep us posted. You're not alone.

Posts.Title: Update: 7 weeks out - progress

Posts.Content: Logic, on the incontinence , you are spot on. I too,found that, I would have a great day, then at around 4-5pM the squirts would start, especially after a full day. It continued that way till about 2 1/2 months. At my 3 month visit to my surgeon, it was only a once in a while,squirt, every few days. He told me it would continue to improve for another few months. And now at 4 months, I've been squirt free for about two weeks now. So you are right on track to total normalcy. Thanks again for this thread, on behalf of all the new dudes.

Posts.Title: Four year anniversary.

Posts.Content: Thanks for the link, Djin. From that link, this is particularly striking....... BCR after RP As mentioned, not all patients with BCR after RP will develop clinical failure; indeed, published reports suggest that an estimated 24–34% of men who develop BCR will experience clinically evident recurrence (i.e., metastatic disease) within 15 years of surgery [21, 23]. Furthermore, it has been estimated that 2–6% of men who experience BCR after RP may die from PCa [21, 23]. So only 24-34% of men with BCR will develop mets ? Am I interpreting tht correctly?

Posts.Title: Doctor found nodule during DRE, my first ever, no PSA record.. long history of UTI

Posts.Content: You need to find different Doctors, IMHO. FIrst, G6 is usually indolent, meaning you could have no treatment, NS stay on active surveillance. But active surveillance does not mean a PSA every six months. You should be monitored on a regular basis in a structured program with PSA tested every three months, annual biopsies etc. Second, it's very curious to me that your PSA would be as high as it is with G6 and only 2 cores positive. You might have some prostatitis going on in there in addition to the cancerous cells . Third, be aware but in about 30% of cases, for those who choose to go the surgery route ( not recommending for or against surgery ) The Gleason score is upgraded, to a more serious grade . On the other hand if you had something higher than a G6 the MRI a(I assume it was a 3T multi parametric MRI) usually will pick it up. In short, I don't think it's time to panic, but I do think you need to find a top doctor Who specializes in prostate cancer knows what he's doing. The only thing that any of your doctor said that make sense to me, is that in large lymph nodes should be investigated . The fact that the only way you found out about that is by reading the report, speaks volumes to how little you're attending doctor cares. I'd be furious.

Posts.Title: Pc 101

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by brownie43 You stated you would be furious with the Dr. Well, it is the VA, and I forgot to mention that I am 73yrs. old. The first VA Urologist that I saw at the VA was a bit "put off" because I had a PSA in my labs., and said he would never order a PSA for anyone 70 or older but seeing as how someone else was ordering 'unnecessary lab work", he would do a DRE (enlarged but no bumps). Said if I came in dragging an oxygen bottle or such, he would not order more tests, etc. but I was a youthful 73, so lucky me. Anyway, he did order up another PSA and recommended a biopsy. Not sure how to get a second opinion at the VA, so will probably go to my Medicare PCP So once we turn 70, we don't need the same level,of care? Because we are gonna die soon anyway? Absurd. I'm 66. I've got health issues. I still plan to be around for a long time. And part of that plan is to monitor for issues that haven't shown up yet.

Posts.Title: Pc 101

Posts.Content: There have been studies done showing that early SRT at PSA .03 shows better long term survival. For sure its a Rick and a hard place because you can't really know with certainty if the cancer is in the prostate bed or elsewhere, in which case you've done SRT for no good reason. Here is an article you might be interested regarding this issue with less aggressive pathology... http://prostatecancerinfolink.net/20...mical-relapse/ And here is an article on the topic. That addresses more aggressive pathology http://prostatecancerinfolink.net/20...ation-therapy/ Hope it helps. It's a tough decision.

Posts.Title: Losing my Mind

Posts.Content: Jlynn, welcome, and sorry, you had to show up here. First of all, we've all been in your (husbands shoes). So we know, easy for us to tell you to calm down, not so easy to do. But there are reasons for you to do so, With your husbands PSA of 4.6, and a Gleason score of G7(3+4) , which is the less aggressive Goeason 7, it's highly likely that you have caught this early, that it's contained within the prostate capsule, and that you have a number of options all of which will have a high chance of CURING your husbands cancer. The thing with Prostate cancer is, in many cases, there is no one treatment that is better than the others. surgeons (urologists are usually surgeons ) will say surgery is your best option. radiation Oncologists will tell you that (the form of ) radiation that they practice is the best course. In some cases, you might be told to practice active surveillance, which is a structured program of regular testing, with preset parameters that might call for action, but no other treatment until and unless those parameters are met. All confusing I know, but the point is, you have to get educated about your options, and be your own advocate. So, 3 suggestions, no 4. 1. Take a deep breath, it's going to be ok. 2. Have your husbands slides sent to an expert in Prostate Pathology for a second opinion. The two acknowledged experts in the U.s. Are Jonathan Epstein at Johns Hopkins, and David Bostwick at Bostwick labs. This is not a big deal, you can go to their websites and get the paperwork, or you can just tell your urologists office that you want the slides sent to Epstein or Bostwick, as I did. They've likely done this before and will know what you are talking about. The reason you want to do this, is that local pathologists usually look at many types of slides, breast, colon, prostate, etc. and Prostate Gleason scoring is a very subjective process, so you want an expert opinion because it could ,are a difference in treatment 3. Go to Amazon and Buy his book, http://www.amazon.com/s/ref=nb_sb_no...+Patrick+Walsh make sure it's the third edition. It's the best education you'll get, and it's easy reading. Seriously, it's going to be ok. Oh one more thing. As far as your husbands concern about side effects, yes with surgery it happens. But it's highly likely in today's world, that he will be fully continent in short order. And over time, will regain his full erectile function. That may take longer but especially at his young age, it will probably happen Also (sorry, I'm rambling) if I wasn't clear... It's important that you explore ALL options. Surgery, radiation in all its forms (seeds(Brachytherapy), cyberknife (SBRT) Etc., Active Surviellance (you might be a candidate especially if the second opinion downgrades you to G6) even if you guys are set on surgery, if you do your own due diligence before making a final decision, you will be more likely to not look back with regret no matter how things turn out.

Posts.Title: Prostate Cancer Reading List.

Posts.Content: One week to the day i was diagnosed, with G6 x 2 and one G8, 3 DAYS FROM Receiving second opinion from Johns Hopkins saying 3 G6 (the G8 was an unusual 3+5, he called it a 3+3 saying the premise the pathologist used to call it a 5 is wrong and invalid) I am so confused and depressed. I know G6 is spelled C-U-R-E. But what if there is something else there that was missed? 2 years ago i had a biopsy that was negative but showed hi grade pin in one core on LEFT side. This biopsy showed all the cancer on the RIGHT side. What if there is G8, OR G9 on the left that was missed? I have seen one rock star surgeon, and am seeing the other one (nyc, you know who they are, probaly) this week. Of course, they rec surgery. Seeing my Uro for the first time on Wednesday. He will rec Cyberknife because thats what his hospital does. Every one has an agenda I made an appt with surgeon at MSKCC, they told me no agenda, if surgery is not my best option, then he will tell me. But he can't see me until Mid Dec. EVERY DAY THAT GOES BY I AM AFRAID I AM AT MORE RISK OF ESCAPING THE CAPSULE. Trying to see a RO at MSKCC, wont even give me an appt until they get the reports (easy) scans (easy), slides (still at Hopkins) and a TE Parametric MRI which they say i ccant have until end December because it needs to be 7-8 weeks after biopsy. More time lost. And how is it that i get to see two rock star surgeons who have done over 5000 robotic surgeries each, within days, but i cant see anyone at MSKCC for over a month? How does that work? I'm so confused, scared and depressed. Logicallty i know, i have time. But still.

Posts.Title: Incontinence Progress

Posts.Content: First, slow down. Don’t put the cart before the horse. It far from a forgone conclusion that you have prostate cancer. And even further from fact that you have AGGRESSIVE PC. In fact, the most aggressive forms of prostate cancer, Gleason 9 and 10, sometimes put out very little PSA. You’re right, that’s a big jump. But more often than not, a jump like that is indicative of Prostatitis, or infection/inflammation of the prostate that usually resolves on its own. Still it’s a high PSA for your age, so yeah further testing probably makes sense. But I wouldn’t rush to biopsy. I would ask for a PHI test (stands for Prostate Health Index). It’s a combination of PSA, free PSA and a few other tests that taken together are a better indication than PSA alone that a biopsy is warranted. And ask for a referral to a urologist. This is beyond the scope of most GP’s Like I said, slow down, one step At a time. Even the more aggressive prostate cancers don’t grow very fast. Good luck and keep us posted.

Posts.Title: PSA INCREASE 2.8 in one year. Doc not alarmed.

Posts.Content: I had a PCA3 urine test done last week and i came back at 13, nurse said 25 is the cutoff so it was very good result. I am trying to understand what this all means, in light of my FreePSA being 11 (i know, bad) and my Total PSA being 2.8, but on a slow steady rise from .7 about 4-5 years ago. One biopsy, two months ago, negative for PCa, positive for high grade PIN in one core out of 14, showed some BPH, with prostate size 38 cc's. Age 62. All negative DRE's Doc said to come back in 4 months for follow up and retest PSA. He wanted an MRI as well (my first visit with this doc) but insurance denied it. Thats when he changed the follow up from 6 months to 4, and it was before he got the Pca3 results. Any ideas how important and indicative of the future the Pca3 is?

Posts.Title: Provenge?

Posts.Content: Wilde, you had your surgery the day after I did. You are only 5 months out. I was lucky in the ED department. I think you will be too. It will just take a little longer. Most men have to wait 6-24 months to get back to full continence. Sure , some men never get it back. But younger men have a better shot at it, that's why I think you will be one of the lucky ones. In the meantime, talk to your surgeon, there are many things that can be done to move the process along And. Try to think about all the things you have to be than,full for. Like zero PSA, a loving wife who sounds like she gets it, and cares for you unconditionally. Every day is a gift man. Take it, try to stay positive.

Posts.Title: Alternative Medicine?

Posts.Content: Not only do they have an opinion, but they are right. In My Opinion, LOL After my first (negative) biopsy, my Uro ordered an MRI. It was declined. I knew a lot less at the time, but I told him, if he thought it was really important, I’d pay out of pocket. He said nah, just see me in 3 m0nths for another PSA and Dre. Two years later, my next biopsy came back positive. Just anecdotal, but I often think, if the insurance co (non Medicare at the time) had approved the mri, maybe I wouldn’t be in the position I’m in now. And maybe the insurance co would have saved themselves the cost of 40 fractions of ig/imrt and 6 months of Firmagon. Freakin dopes.

Posts.Content: Ron, not much to add, besides whats already been said. Just want to say welcome, and good luck with your meeting. If you do choose surgery, I can comment that for me at least, with a top surgeon, after the first couple of weeks I healed rapidly. There is a new normal, but its not too much different than the old normal, and certainly will not interfere with my QOL. But you do sound like a good candidate for AS. I would make a note to ask if there are other diagnostic tests, i.e. 3tesla Multiparametric MRI, or others, that might have a good chance of finding anything more sinister than G6 lurking, or hopefully, increase the chance that that's all there is, and hopefully reconfirm that you are a good candidate for AS

Posts.Title: Provenge?

Posts.Content: First, slow down. Don’t put the cart before the horse. It far from a forgone conclusion that you have prostate cancer. And even further from fact that you have AGGRESSIVE PC. In fact, the most aggressive forms of prostate cancer, Gleason 9 and 10, sometimes put out very little PSA. You’re right, that’s a big jump. But more often than not, a jump like that is indicative of Prostatitis, or infection/inflammation of the prostate that usually resolves on its own. Still it’s a high PSA for your age, so yeah further testing probably makes sense. But I wouldn’t rush to biopsy. I would ask for a PHI test (stands for Prostate Health Index). It’s a combination of PSA, free PSA and a few other tests that taken together are a better indication than PSA alone that a biopsy is warranted. And ask for a referral to a urologist. This is beyond the scope of most GP’s Like I said, slow down, one step At a time. Even the more aggressive prostate cancers don’t grow very fast. Good luck and keep us posted.

Posts.Title: Observation, Statistics, Coincidences?

Posts.Content: Jim, i think the problem he is with, and that i am sure i would grapple with in his situation, is that there is no way to know for sure, if the PSA rise is a result of cancer cells in the Prostate Bed. So its entirely possible, to have SRT to the prostate bed, and not solve the problem. A big risk to take, for sure. And the rock and the hard place comes in because you have to ask yourself, as you did, "well, since i don't know for sure that i a attacking the cancer cells by nuking the prostate bed, and i decide to wait until its detectable on a Choline scan, i risk the possiblity of it being in the prostate bed now, and by the time its detectable elsewhere, its, well.... elsewhere, i've given it a chance to escape. So its a very personal choice. Chuck is right, most Drs will wait till they see .1, even .2. In fact, my surgeons PA told me right after the surgery, that if ever there was a rise they would not be concerned until it hit .1 at which time they would do imaging to try to find the source. But who knows what the right answer is. A connundrum, for sure.

Posts.Content: Wilde, you had your surgery the day after I did. You are only 5 months out. I was lucky in the ED department. I think you will be too. It will just take a little longer. Most men have to wait 6-24 months to get back to full continence. Sure , some men never get it back. But younger men have a better shot at it, that's why I think you will be one of the lucky ones. In the meantime, talk to your surgeon, there are many things that can be done to move the process along And. Try to think about all the things you have to be than,full for. Like zero PSA, a loving wife who sounds like she gets it, and cares for you unconditionally. Every day is a gift man. Take it, try to stay positive.

Posts.Title: Salvage Radiation I hope a good question?

Posts.Content: Bad68rs, up until my PC diagnosis, I'd never been sick a day in my life. I had surgery, was sort of depressed afterwards, although the surgery seemed to have gone well with good pathology, no complications, and none of the dreaded side effects. After about 5-6bmonths, I started to feel good, and was more or less over the psychological effects of having to face my own mortality. I was 65, so older than you, but trust me, it doesn't make it easier. 7 months after surgery, I. Feeling great... then....BOOM!!!....routine physical, bad ekg, bad echostress, bad nuclear stress, bad Ct heart scan all in one day. The next day I was in the cardiac catch lab having 2 stents inserted.WTF? I was told I have coronary artery disease and a heavy plaque load. Very depressed, for a long while. And I became obsessed with my health , diet, etc. you would think that's good, but it's not I got over it and started enjoying life again. A year and a half later, my wife gets diagnosed with ovarian cancer. So I'm asking myself again, WTF? What a horrible 3 years. Why does God hate me? What did I do wrong? But I know it doesn't work that way. Shit happens. I didn't take care of myself all my life as you did, (aside from the alcohol, and congrats on kicking it btw)I started when I got my PCP diagnosis. So maybe unlike you, I did it to myself, who knows. Maybe it's just genetic. Can't control it, can't change it. I don't know what branch bundle block is, I hope it's something treatable. But whatever it is, I hope you learn to live in the moment, and enjoy each day without obsessing over it all the way I do. It's a matter of QOL. Keep taking good care of yourself, and squeeze all the juice out of every day. Because every day is a day you won't get back.

Posts.Title: DX Last Week.....

Posts.Content: Jlynn, welcome, and sorry, you had to show up here. First of all, we've all been in your (husbands shoes). So we know, easy for us to tell you to calm down, not so easy to do. But there are reasons for you to do so, With your husbands PSA of 4.6, and a Gleason score of G7(3+4) , which is the less aggressive Goeason 7, it's highly likely that you have caught this early, that it's contained within the prostate capsule, and that you have a number of options all of which will have a high chance of CURING your husbands cancer. The thing with Prostate cancer is, in many cases, there is no one treatment that is better than the others. surgeons (urologists are usually surgeons ) will say surgery is your best option. radiation Oncologists will tell you that (the form of ) radiation that they practice is the best course. In some cases, you might be told to practice active surveillance, which is a structured program of regular testing, with preset parameters that might call for action, but no other treatment until and unless those parameters are met. All confusing I know, but the point is, you have to get educated about your options, and be your own advocate. So, 3 suggestions, no 4. 1. Take a deep breath, it's going to be ok. 2. Have your husbands slides sent to an expert in Prostate Pathology for a second opinion. The two acknowledged experts in the U.s. Are Jonathan Epstein at Johns Hopkins, and David Bostwick at Bostwick labs. This is not a big deal, you can go to their websites and get the paperwork, or you can just tell your urologists office that you want the slides sent to Epstein or Bostwick, as I did. They've likely done this before and will know what you are talking about. The reason you want to do this, is that local pathologists usually look at many types of slides, breast, colon, prostate, etc. and Prostate Gleason scoring is a very subjective process, so you want an expert opinion because it could ,are a difference in treatment 3. Go to Amazon and Buy his book, http://www.amazon.com/s/ref=nb_sb_no...+Patrick+Walsh make sure it's the third edition. It's the best education you'll get, and it's easy reading. Seriously, it's going to be ok. Oh one more thing. As far as your husbands concern about side effects, yes with surgery it happens. But it's highly likely in today's world, that he will be fully continent in short order. And over time, will regain his full erectile function. That may take longer but especially at his young age, it will probably happen Also (sorry, I'm rambling) if I wasn't clear... It's important that you explore ALL options. Surgery, radiation in all its forms (seeds(Brachytherapy), cyberknife (SBRT) Etc., Active Surviellance (you might be a candidate especially if the second opinion downgrades you to G6) even if you guys are set on surgery, if you do your own due diligence before making a final decision, you will be more likely to not look back with regret no matter how things turn out.
