Posts.Content: Jlynn, welcome, and sorry, you had to show up here. First of all, we've all been in your (husbands shoes). So we know, easy for us to tell you to calm down, not so easy to do. But there are reasons for you to do so, With your husbands PSA of 4.6, and a Gleason score of G7(3+4) , which is the less aggressive Goeason 7, it's highly likely that you have caught this early, that it's contained within the prostate capsule, and that you have a number of options all of which will have a high chance of CURING your husbands cancer. The thing with Prostate cancer is, in many cases, there is no one treatment that is better than the others. surgeons (urologists are usually surgeons ) will say surgery is your best option. radiation Oncologists will tell you that (the form of ) radiation that they practice is the best course. In some cases, you might be told to practice active surveillance, which is a structured program of regular testing, with preset parameters that might call for action, but no other treatment until and unless those parameters are met. All confusing I know, but the point is, you have to get educated about your options, and be your own advocate. So, 3 suggestions, no 4. 1. Take a deep breath, it's going to be ok. 2. Have your husbands slides sent to an expert in Prostate Pathology for a second opinion. The two acknowledged experts in the U.s. Are Jonathan Epstein at Johns Hopkins, and David Bostwick at Bostwick labs. This is not a big deal, you can go to their websites and get the paperwork, or you can just tell your urologists office that you want the slides sent to Epstein or Bostwick, as I did. Posts.Title: 55 yr old husband just diagnosed with PC

Posts.Content: Wilde, you had your surgery the day after I did. You are only 5 months out. I was lucky in the ED department. I think you will be too. It will just take a little longer. Most men have to wait 6-24 months to get back to full continence. Sure , some men never get it back. But younger men have a better shot at it, that's why I think you will be one of the lucky ones. In the meantime, talk to your surgeon, there are many things that can be done to move the process along And. Try to think about all the things you have to be than,full for. Like zero PSA, a loving wife who sounds like she gets it, and cares for you unconditionally. Every day is a gift man. Take it, try to stay positive.

Posts.Title: How do You cope?

Posts.Content: Bad68rs, up until my PC diagnosis, I'd never been sick a day in my life. I had surgery, was sort of depressed afterwards, although the surgery seemed to have gone well with good pathology, no complications, and none of the dreaded side effects. After about 5-6bmonths, I started to feel good, and was more or less over the psychological effects of having to face my own mortality. I was 65, so older than you, but trust me, it doesn't make it easier. 7 months after surgery, I. Feeling great... then....BOOM!!!....routine physical, bad ekg, bad echostress, bad nuclear stress, bad Ct heart scan all in one day. The next day I was in the cardiac catch lab having 2 stents inserted.WTF? I was told I have coronary artery disease and a heavy plaque load. Very depressed, for a long while. And I became obsessed with my health , diet, etc. you would think that's good, but it's not I got over it and started enjoying life again. A year and a half later, my wife gets diagnosed with ovarian cancer. So I'm asking myself again, WTF? What a horrible 3 years. Why does God hate me? What did I do wrong? But I know it doesn't work that way. Shit happens. I didn't take care of myself all my life as you did, (aside from the alcohol, and congrats on kicking it btw)I started when I got my PCP diagnosis. So maybe unlike you, I did it to myself, who knows. Maybe it's just genetic. Can't control it, can't change it. I don't know what branch bundle block is, I hope it's something treatable. But whatever it is, I hope you learn to live in the moment, and enjoy each day without obsessing over it all the way I do. It's a matter of QOL. Keep taking good care of yourself, and squeeze all the juice out of every day. Because every day is a day you won't get back.

Posts.Content: Ron, not much to add, besides whats already been said. Just want to say welcome, and good luck with your meeting. If you do choose surgery, I can comment that for me at least, with a top surgeon, after the first couple of weeks I healed rapidly. I would make a note to ask if there are other diagnostic tests, i.e. 3tesla Multiparametric MRI, or others, that might have a good chance of finding anything more sinister than G6 lurking, or hopefully, increase the chance that that's all there is, and hopefully reconfirm that you are a good candidate for AS

Posts.Title: How long after the drips started???

Posts.Content: Amazing how many G7(3+4), which is considered low intermediate risk, with negative margins no EPE, end up recurring. I too was g7(3+4), negative margins, 5% of prostate involved, and 5% grade 4 cells. t2b, and 3 1/2 years out of RALP my PSA has been slowly rising and is now .068. One more rise in PSA (end of this month), and I will do SRT. But no HT. So FWIW, I think with g7(3+4) no Ht necessary. I did however have one RO tell me that if I wait till PSA hits .1, he would strongly advise HT. Another RO tells me my Gleason score dictates no hot, but I should treat soon. So I say saben, get to an RO, maybe 2, and get there thoughts, but take action soon.

Posts.Title: Prostate Cancer Recurrence - PSA rising after Prostate Surgery - next steps?

Posts.Content: I would get a second opinion on the biopsy. If the 3+4 is really a 4+4 or a 3+3, you want to know, it might affect treatment choice. Its easy to do. Tell your urologist that you want the slides sent to Dr Jonathan Epstein at Johns Hopkins. Do not take no for an answer. They have gotten this request before and should know exactly what to do. Just in case, here is a link... http://pathology.jhu.edu/department/...ondopinion.cfm. You could also use David Bostwick at Bostwick labs. My experience with Epstein was excellent. They were quick, responsive, and Dr Epstein himself got on the phone and spoke with me. ( AND I would never have even attempted to speak with him, if i had not been told by someone here that he speaks with patients). In the meantime, educate yourself on all options. With 70% of one core being cancerous and being stage 2A, you are probably not a great candidate for Active Surviellance, but look at surgery, and all the various types of radiation. What does your Urologist mean when he says Dr Kaul is a superstar? How many surgeries has he done? Does he do open or robotic? What is his record of positive margins? These are all questions you should ask. You have a right to know. Trust your doctors, but verify. Dont take anyones word for anything. Prostate Cancer is big business. The vast majority of Drs have their clients best interest at heart, but they all have their natural biases. Be your own advocate

Posts.Title: 43 year old small spike psa

Posts.Content: You don’t say when your last PSA, the 6.6 result was. If it was in the last year or 18m9nths, it’s possible, even probable that it’s prostatitis. Or BPH or both. PSA is not a test for cancer, it’s a test that tells you if there is something going on with the prostate. Typically, from my experience at least, but also from what I’ve read here and elsewhere, PC will cause a slow but steady rising trend in PSA over time, a spike like this is often in fact, Prostatitis.

Posts.Content: The cure rates for surgery and radiation can be the same, it depends on the skill of the surgeon or radiation oncologist, as well as your dads prognosis. What do you mean when you say he has a "possible" malignancy? I assume if treatment has been recommended, he has had a biopsy that was positive for cancer? I think its reasonable to say that at age 78, surgery may not be the best option, depending partly on his general health. It would be helpful if you could post his stats from the biopsy report . At his age, if it is low grade, low volume cancer, he might be a candidate for Active Surveillance which means no treatment for now, just periodic blood tests and possible annual biopsies.

Posts.Title: Rising PSA after RP

Posts.Content: I would get a second opinion on the biopsy. If the 3+4 is really a 4+4 or a 3+3, you want to know, it might affect treatment choice. Its easy to do. Tell your urologist that you want the slides sent to Dr Jonathan Epstein at Johns Hopkins. Do not take no for an answer. They have gotten this request before and should know exactly what to do. Just in case, here is a link... http://pathology.jhu.edu/department/...ondopinion.cfm. You could also use David Bostwick at Bostwick labs. My experience with Epstein was excellent. They were quick, responsive, and Dr Epstein himself got on the phone and spoke with me. ( AND I would never have even attempted to speak with him, if i had not been told by someone here that he speaks with patients). In the meantime, educate yourself on all options. With 70% of one core being cancerous and being stage 2A, you are probably not a great candidate for Active Surviellance, but look at surgery, and all the various types of radiation. What does your Urologist mean when he says Dr Kaul is a superstar? How many surgeries has he done? Does he do open or robotic? What is his record of positive margins? These are all questions you should ask. You have a right to know. Trust your doctors, but verify. Dont take anyones word for anything. Prostate Cancer is big business. The vast majority of Drs have their clients best interest at heart, but they all have their natural biases. Be your own advocate

Posts.Title: Just learned my biopsy was positive

Posts.Content: Tim, first thing i will tell you, have the slides sent for a second opinion by a pathologist specializing in Prostate Cancer. I sent mine to Dr Epstein at Johns Hopkins, there is also David Bostwick at Bostwick Labs. I'm sure there are others. My original path was G6 and G8, but epstein dowgraded in his opinion to G6/G6. The other docs (surgeons and urologist) that i spoke with said i an take Epsteins opinion as gospel (pending surgerial pathology) of ourse Advantages of surgery are you can always have radiation afterwards if there is still PSA, but its much harder to have surgery after radiation. Also, and this is important - 40% of PC gleason scores get upgraded after surgery (some get downgraded) and surgery is the only real way to know exactly what you are dealing with. Beause the pathologist looks at the entire prostate that was removed as opposed to 12 tiny tissue sample. From what i have been reading in my research, Radiation brings similar results, but with fwer side effects. although i have read that you can have more side effects later in future years. But i have not yet met with an RO. Meeting with one next week. In my mind i am doing surgery. Unless the RO says something that blows me away. Lots to think about. But think about this. Even a worst case scenario, you get primary treatment and in 2 years, say, your PSA starts to rise. AVERAGE life expectancy from PSA rise is over 13 years. There is a guy on another forum that was diagnosed with a psa of 3200 no typo. Bone mets all over his body. That was in 2006. He is still doing well, with the beast under control. Try not to panic. I did, and still do sometimes. But slowly as you educate yourself, you will realize that you will be around for a long time. This is not late stage breast cancer. PC is not lethal as many other cancers are, at least in the short and intermediate years.

Posts.Title: Appreciation to Yale Radiation

Posts.Content: One week to the day i was diagnosed, with G6 x 2 and one G8, 3 DAYS FROM Receiving second opinion from Johns Hopkins saying 3 G6 (the G8 was an unusual 3+5, he called it a 3+3 saying the premise the pathologist used to call it a 5 is wrong and invalid) I am so confused and depressed. I know G6 is spelled C-U-R-E. But what if there is something else there that was missed? 2 years ago i had a biopsy that was negative but showed hi grade pin in one core on LEFT side. This biopsy showed all the cancer on the RIGHT side. What if there is G8, OR G9 on the left that was missed? I have seen one rock star surgeon, and am seeing the other one (nyc, you know who they are, probaly) this week. Of course, they rec surgery. Seeing my Uro for the first time on Wednesday. He will rec Cyberknife because thats what his hospital does. Every one has an agenda I made an appt with surgeon at MSKCC, they told me no agenda, if surgery is not my best option, then he will tell me. But he can't see me until Mid Dec. EVERY DAY THAT GOES BY I AM AFRAID I AM AT MORE RISK OF ESCAPING THE CAPSULE. Trying to see a RO at MSKCC, wont even give me an appt until they get the reports (easy) scans (easy), slides (still at Hopkins) and a TE Parametric MRI which they say i ccant have until end December because it needs to be 7-8 weeks after biopsy. More time lost. And how is it that i get to see two rock star surgeons who have done over 5000 robotic surgeries each, within days, but i cant see anyone at MSKCC for over a month? How does that work? I'm so confused, scared and depressed. Logicallty i know, i have time. But still.

Posts.Title: Losing my Mind

Posts.Content: Jlynn, welcome, and sorry, you had to show up here. First of all, we've all been in your (husbands shoes). So we know, easy for us to tell you to calm down, not so easy to do. But there are reasons for you to do so, With your husbands PSA of 4.6, and a Gleason score of G7(3+4) , which is the less aggressive Goeason 7, it's highly likely that you have caught this early, that it's contained within the prostate capsule, and that you have a number of options all of which will have a high chance of CURING your husbands cancer. The thing with Prostate cancer is, in many cases, there is no one treatment that is better than the others. surgeons (urologists are usually surgeons ) will say surgery is your best option. radiation Oncologists will tell you that (the form of ) radiation that they practice is the best course. In some cases, you might be told to practice active surveillance, which is a structured program of regular testing, with preset parameters that might call for action, but no other treatment until and unless those parameters are met. All confusing I know, but the point is, you have to get educated about your options, and be your own advocate. So, 3 suggestions, no 4. 1. Take a deep breath, it's going to be ok. 2. Have your husbands slides sent to an expert in Prostate Pathology for a second opinion. The two acknowledged experts in the U.s. Are Jonathan Epstein at Johns Hopkins, and David Bostwick at Bostwick labs. This is not a big deal, you can go to their websites and get the paperwork, or you can just tell your urologists office that you want the slides sent to Epstein or Bostwick, as I did. They've likely done this before and will know what you are talking about. The reason you want to do this, is that local pathologists usually look at many types of slides, breast, colon, prostate, etc. and Prostate Gleason scoring is a very subjective process, so you want an expert opinion because it could ,are a difference in treatment 3. Go to Amazon and Buy his book, http://www.amazon.com/s/ref=nb_sb_no...+Patrick+Walsh make sure it's the third edition. It's the best education you'll get, and it's easy reading. Seriously, it's going to be ok. Oh one more thing. As far as your husbands concern about side effects, yes with surgery it happens. But it's highly likely in today's world, that he will be fully continent in short order. And over time, will regain his full erectile function. That may take longer but especially at his young age, it will probably happen Also (sorry, I'm rambling) if I wasn't clear... It's important that you explore ALL options. Surgery, radiation in all its forms (seeds(Brachytherapy), cyberknife (SBRT) Etc., Active Surviellance (you might be a candidate especially if the second opinion downgrades you to G6) even if you guys are set on surgery, if you do your own due diligence before making a final decision, you will be more likely to not look back with regret no matter how things turn out.

Posts.Title: 55 yr old husband just diagnosed with PC

Posts.Content: I'm not on any HT, only treatment i have had was RALP in January. So cannot speak to that. I can say, i have never been much on resistance training, but try to at least do cardio somewhat regularly. I find since my diagnosis last November, 2014, i have been way more active. I started by walking 4 miles almost every day, and doing planks and crunches about 5 days a week, for the 5 weeks before my surgery, and i believe it helped in my recovery. Once i was past surgery, i got on the treadmill as quickly as possible, doing about 1.5 miles a day even with the catheter still in. I've worked up to 3-4 miles a day and still do it regularly. I've been cleared for a while to do some lifting, and while i havent ever been much of on weights, i intend to start, as i have noticed muscle loss, at least in my arms, which i dont like, although i guess it comes with age.

Posts.Title: Working out - post treatment thoughts, experience, etc

Posts.Content: So yesterday, after meeting again with my Urologist, and separately, with. medical Oncologist, in his office, I made a decision to move forward with SRT + ADT. The Medical Oncologist agreed that from a medical perspective I was not jumping the gun, and that I would eventually need treatment, and that it’s better to do it now, while everything looked non-aggressive. My urologist also said I should treat. But when I pressed him, he said his treatment recommendation was based on me as a person, and if he was meeting me for the first time, and justvlooking at my chart, without knowing me, he would recommend that I wait until .2 (my last PSA had been .082). We had a long discussion, and I asked him if he would do one more PSA, even though my last one, .082, was only 18 days ago. I got the results this morning, it was .078. While the blood draw was in my Drs office, and previous blood draws were at a local labcorp office, the lab AND assay was the same, labcorp in Raritan NJ and Roche ECLIA. I’m thinking this is JUST TEST TO TEST VARIATION, and doesn’t mean much. I know there was a thread about it somewhere, and a study I think in Djin subforum but I couldn’t find it. But if I round these two tests off, they are both .08. The good news is that when I got the .082, it was only 6bweeks after a .068 result, and it broke a very constant trend of a .01 rise every three months, very linear. That made me nervous. This new result gets me right back into the linear trend, and I am not worried that things are getting more aggressive. So nothing changes, I’m going to upload these results to the MSK patient portal and just comment, to the RO, that if this changes anything in your recommendation, let me know, but if not, I plan to be there Wednesday for my first Firmagon shot. As far as I’m concerned, I’m done researching, satisfied that I’ve done what I can, and making the exact right decision at the exact right time.

Posts.Title: Just had the Prostate Ultrasound and Biopsy

Posts.Content: I would get a second opinion on the biopsy. If the 3+4 is really a 4+4 or a 3+3, you want to know, it might affect treatment choice. Its easy to do. Tell your urologist that you want the slides sent to Dr Jonathan Epstein at Johns Hopkins. Do not take no for an answer. They have gotten this request before and should know exactly what to do. Just in case, here is a link... http://pathology.jhu.edu/department/...ondopinion.cfm. You could also use David Bostwick at Bostwick labs. My experience with Epstein was excellent. They were quick, responsive, and Dr Epstein himself got on the phone and spoke with me. ( AND I would never have even attempted to speak with him, if i had not been told by someone here that he speaks with patients). In the meantime, educate yourself on all options. With 70% of one core being cancerous and being stage 2A, you are probably not a great candidate for Active Surviellance, but look at surgery, and all the various types of radiation. What does your Urologist mean when he says Dr Kaul is a superstar? How many surgeries has he done? Does he do open or robotic? What is his record of positive margins? These are all questions you should ask. You have a right to know. Trust your doctors, but verify. Dont take anyones word for anything. Prostate Cancer is big business. The vast majority of Drs have their clients best interest at heart, but they all have their natural biases. Be your own advocate

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by RobLee That's the correct attitude Ken. I was looking for your first post of the day, as I knew you had the panel meetings yesterday. And I'm glad to hear that you're jumping in full throttle (if I may mix metaphors). I too caught the .02 typo mentioned by Djin, but knew what you meant. So now is the time to STOP SWEATING the details, just keep your head up and move forward. Here's hoping to see a smooth descent to zero... and stay there! Thanks Rob. Aboutvthat panel meeting... so I getvthere, and they put me in a room, just me and a young Medical Oncologist, whom I never heard of before. I asked what happened to my meeting with Drs Stock, Oh, and Cheetam? He said something about it being August and hard to get them all together. I was out of my mind pissed off I wanted to put my fist in his mouth (not that it was his fault). But amazingly, I bit my tongue and just said, ok. I mentoned it to Tewari when I met with him afterwards, his response was hmmm....thats never happened before Anyway, the med onc , who did seem to know his stuff, and who said he works closely with dr stock, the rad onc, recommended to treat. Tewari repeated his recommendation to treat. I pushed him this time though and asked him if you didnt know me personally, if you were meeting me for the first time, and just looking at my chart, would your rec be the same, he said no, Id tell you to wait. But part of my job is to care for the whole patient, not the disease, and I think if you waited youd be constantly preoccupied with worry. To me, thats a good doctor.

Posts.Title: GREAT pathology report (and a few minor setbacks, but who cares!)

Posts.Content: To the original poster - i dont think the comments about colonic mucosa or squamous mucosa are cause for concern, especially considering they have the word "benign" in front of them. Also, he may not have actually missed the prostate on that side, he may have caught some colon cells on the way in to the prostate. I used google to find info and came across an article in the Harvard Medical School Harvard Medical Publication. I don't think the forum rules permit posting links, please correct me if i am wrong. But you can google "Harvard" and "Understanding Your Pathology Report" and it will probably take you to the article. In any case, i am cutting and pasting this section below, which is relevant to your question..... "Don’t be alarmed if you see mention of rectal or colonic tissue. Small fragments of bowel lining (colonic mucosa) are common in needle core biopsy specimens since the needle has to poke through this tissue to get to the prostate." Also, regarding Squamous Mucosa, I couldn't find anything as it relates to colon or prostate cells but i did find something related to other types of cells, like Esophagus. Apparently squamous is just a type of cell in the lining of an organ. See below, which i found in another article: "2. What does "squamous mucosa" mean? The lining of the esophagus is known as the "mucosa." Most of the esophagus is lined by squamous cells, similar to those seen on the surface of the skin. I hope this puts your mind at ease, as it relates to these two issues, i know what its like to be at a loss for understanding something like this. Which is probably why the envelope was sealed.

And keep focused on the fact that your dada is now in a better place, with no suffering , pain or anguish. Godspeed.

Posts.Title: Tumor Load

Posts.Content: Welcome football. I’m a die hard NY Jets fan, so take everything I say with a grain of salt.. Do you know if all of those psa’s In your history we’re done at the same lab, with the same Assay/method? PSa generally does not drop from 7.3 to 6.7 to 6.1. It is usually a slow steady rise. But if the tests are from different labs, they can’t be compared to identify a trend. So you might want to find that out. As chuck said, there is some belief that diet has a lot to do with PC. But no confirmed evidential proof. So I wouldn’t hang my hat on that if I were you.

Posts.Title: Sudden Blood in Urine Post-Surgery

Posts.Content: My first thought is that if your Uro never heard of the c-11 scan, then he's not up on current advances and isn't the right guy. But you've already figured that out. So discount what he said. Prostatectomy after radiation can be a mess. It can be done but it's very difficult and must be done by someone who specializes in salvage surgery. And the side effects are worse than after Prostatectomy for primary treatment. I may have missed it, but am I to understand that your radiation was primary treatment? If so, I think it's too soon to assume failure. I'm not an expert in this area, I'm sure others more knowledgeable, will chime in soon, so stay tuned. And good luck.

Posts.Title: Sudden Blood in Urine Post-Surgery

Posts.Content: With apologies to those whove already seen this on another forum, there are some really knowledgeable folks here that are not there, so Im copying and pasting with a few minor edits. So, in the face of a rising PSA, i am going to make a final decision about going ahead with SRT with or without Hormone Therapy after one more PSA which i will do the end of this month. My current PSA is .068 as of a month ago. For background, i had negative margins, however, my surgeon does a intra operative frozen section which is looked at by pathology, which showed a positive margin, leading to the surgeon to do further resection, to obtain final negative margins. I saw two prominent Radiation Oncologists who both advised that i should be treated now, saying that they felt 80% sure that the negative final margin actually did contain some cancer cells that were missed and wasnt really negative My surgeon thinks i should wait and do scans if i reach .2, which he says may never happen. So I recently asked that the slides be relooked at, and that i be informed what % of pattern 4 cells there was in the g7(3+4) which was the "dominant tumor" (1.1 cm) AND also what the gleason was at the positive margin in the frozen section, before the surgeon obtained negative final margins. Today i got the results as follows: The tumor shows approximately 5% of a Gleason pattern 4, with the remaining 95% pattern 3 And this: While the final margins are negative, the involved apical margin (part A (which was the frozen section)) showed Gleason pattern 3 at the margin So now, this new information gives me pause, and i am not so sure whether i should do SRT at such a low PSA. I do know that if I do SRT, I am now heavily leaning toward NOT adding Hormone Therapy to the mix. Any thoughts would be welcome. I feel like Im in never never land, I know there is no clear answer.

Posts.Title: Like a bad rash, Im back

Posts.Content: Hope everyone here Is doing well. I thought Id update as I havent been here for a while... Just finished week 5 of SRT, and am in the middle of month 3 of a 6 month course of ADT. Regarding the radiation, with 3 weeks to go, no side effects to date other than being very tired but I think thats as much a function of getting up at 4-4:15 every morning to go into Manhattan for treatment, then working an almost full day. Other than that, no issues. One problem Ive had, only the last two days, is that even though I empty my bowels each morning at 5:30-6am, I start to feel a little gassy just before I get called in for treatment, and indeed, the last two days, right after treatment, when I go to empty my bladder, I have another (not insignificant) bowel movement, I cant let that continue, lest I end up with damage, so Ill start today, increasing the Metamucil and colace, frM 2 to 3 x a day. Also Ill eliminate salads for lunch, and eat less at night. I hope that works Other than that, no bleeding, no diarrhea, no urinary frequency, so thus far, Im blessed, I know its the last few weeks though, that this stuff starts. As far as ADT, I started on Firmagon, had 2none month shots, both give me a pretty bad reaction at the injection sight. So my RO switched me to Lupron, and it was so much easier. In the two + months that my T has been at castrate levels (5 - 6), the only SE Ive had is the hot flashes, and they are annoying but not unbearable. Other than that, nothing. No insomnia, fatigue, depression, more emotion, or any if the other side effects. When I started treatment my PSA was .08. The two monthly tests since I started have both been undetectable. But MSKCC tests only down to <.05, so I guess it could be anywhere from 0.000 to 0.049. But I know its probably closer to 0.00 and its because of the Lupron. 3 more weeks of treatment and one more Lupron shot, which will be a 3 month shot. Then I just wait, until T starts to rise, and hopefully PSA stays down. Hope this helps someone who may be about to start salvage treatment, and is concerned about side effects. Its really not bad as it sounds, for most men.

Posts.Title: Like a bad rash, Im back

Posts.Content: Of the PC forums I’ve been on, this one has always been one of not THE most user-friendly and supportive forums I’ve been on. I’ve always considered it the more “warm and fuzzy” forum, of all of them. With that said, I think every forum evolves to its own biases. I do think this forum has a slight bias towards surgery, just as I think “the other” major forum, has a bias towards Radiation. But I don’t think anyone here intended to criticize the OP’s treatment choice. Least of all, Chuck. No forum is perfect, we should all accept that. But all ‘the forums I’ve been on, ESPECIALLY and including this one, are populated by a core group of guys who are active and are present to both be supportive and get support. That’s my two cents

Posts.Title: Cialis and Heart

Posts.Content: I posted this on another forum, apologies to some of you who may have seen it, but i am looking for answers so just pasting it here too.... So now i have a new problem. Has anyone ever experienced heart issues that turned out to be related to Cialis? I went to my longtime PCP today for a checkup, first since the surgery. My bloodwork was all perfect, (i did the bloods in advance of the appointment). Cholesterol was 136. Triglycerides 148, down from 300 in December, he did about 30 other tests, all normal, so i was feeling good going in. But i mentioned to him that i was having what felt like palpatations on occasion. He did an EKG, which showed an "extra heart beat". which i guess, is an arrythmia. So he did an echo cardiogram, which was normal. Then an echo stress test, which was "positive" whatever the f that means. He told me to stop the Cialis immediately, and he put me on a beta blocker, wants me back a week from Monday (i'm going away on vacation next week). He said, depending on what happens between now and then, he will possibly send me for a CT Angiogram to look for blockages. These palpatations started soon after my surgery, which is why i thought it might be related to the Cialis. But i called my surgeon and spoke with his NP, she said she had never seen a heart problem caused by Cialis. Said if i have to stay off it, they would probably recommend injections, whcih i really dont want. So now, i have PSA Anxiety (next test, one month), a probable limp dick, AND heart issues. I'm ready to shoot myself in the mouth. Seriously depressing. Just when i was starting to feel safe. I think my life expectancy has gone down dramatically

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by RobLee That's the correct attitude Ken. I was looking for your first post of the day, as I knew you had the panel meetings yesterday. And I'm glad to hear that you're jumping in full throttle (if I may mix metaphors). I too caught the .02 typo mentioned by Djin, but knew what you meant. So now is the time to STOP SWEATING the details, just keep your head up and move forward. Here's hoping to see a smooth descent to zero... and stay there! Thanks Rob. Aboutvthat panel meeting... so I getvthere, and they put me in a room, just me and a young Medical Oncologist, whom I never heard of before. I asked what happened to my meeting with Drs Stock, Oh, and Cheetam? He said something about it being August and hard to get them all together. I was out of my mind pissed off I wanted to put my fist in his mouth (not that it was his fault). But amazingly, I bit my tongue and just said, ok. I mentoned it to Tewari when I met with him afterwards, his response was hmmm....thats never happened before Anyway, the med onc , who did seem to know his stuff, and who said he works closely with dr stock, the rad onc, recommended to treat. Tewari repeated his recommendation to treat. I pushed him this time though and asked him if you didnt know me personally, if you were meeting me for the first time, and just looking at my chart, would your rec be the same, he said no, Id tell you to wait. But part of my job is to care for the whole patient, not the disease, and I think if you waited youd be constantly preoccupied with worry. To me, thats a good doctor.

Posts.Title: Decision made, and PSA result

Posts.Content: So yesterday, after meeting again with my Urologist, and separately, with. medical Oncologist, in his office, I made a decision to move forward with SRT + ADT. The Medical Oncologist agreed that from a medical perspective I was not jumping the gun, and that I would eventually need treatment, and that it’s better to do it now, while everything looked non-aggressive. My urologist also said I should treat. But when I pressed him, he said his treatment recommendation was based on me as a person, and if he was meeting me for the first time, and justvlooking at my chart, without knowing me, he would recommend that I wait until .2 (my last PSA had been .082). We had a long discussion, and I asked him if he would do one more PSA, even though my last one, .082, was only 18 days ago. I got the results this morning, it was .078. While the blood draw was in my Drs office, and previous blood draws were at a local labcorp office, the lab AND assay was the same, labcorp in Raritan NJ and Roche ECLIA. I’m thinking this is JUST TEST TO TEST VARIATION, and doesn’t mean much. I know there was a thread about it somewhere, and a study I think in Djin subforum but I couldn’t find it. But if I round these two tests off, they are both .08. The good news is that when I got the .082, it was only 6bweeks after a .068 result, and it broke a very constant trend of a .01 rise every three months, very linear. That made me nervous. This new result gets me right back into the linear trend, and I am not worried that things are getting more aggressive. So nothing changes, I’m going to upload these results to the MSK patient portal and just comment, to the RO, that if this changes anything in your recommendation, let me know, but if not, I plan to be there Wednesday for my first Firmagon shot. As far as I’m concerned, I’m done researching, satisfied that I’ve done what I can, and making the exact right decision at the exact right time.

Posts.Content: To the original poster - i dont think the comments about colonic mucosa or squamous mucosa are cause for concern, especially considering they have the word "benign" in front of them. Also, he may not have actually missed the prostate on that side, he may have caught some colon cells on the way in to the prostate. I used google to find info and came across an article in the Harvard Medical School Harvard Medical Publication. I don't think the forum rules permit posting links, please correct me if i am wrong. But you can google "Harvard" and "Understanding Your Pathology Report" and it will probably take you to the article. In any case, i am cutting and pasting this section below, which is relevant to your question..... "Don’t be alarmed if you see mention of rectal or colonic tissue. Small fragments of bowel lining (colonic mucosa) are common in needle core biopsy specimens since the needle has to poke through this tissue to get to the prostate." Also, regarding Squamous Mucosa, I couldn't find anything as it relates to colon or prostate cells but i did find something related to other types of cells, like Esophagus. Apparently squamous is just a type of cell in the lining of an organ. See below, which i found in another article: "2. What does "squamous mucosa" mean? The lining of the esophagus is known as the "mucosa." Most of the esophagus is lined by squamous cells, similar to those seen on the surface of the skin. I hope this puts your mind at ease, as it relates to these two issues, i know what its like to be at a loss for understanding something like this. Which is probably why the envelope was sealed.
Posts.Title: Prostate Patholosist report>>>>

Posts.Content: I have a question that may seem ridiculous, but it's an issue that's bothering me, despite assurances from one member here who is very knowledgeable (to whom I apologize in advance). The question is probably Bourne out of plain old fashioned nervousness, but here's the story.... As you can see from my stats, my biopsy was 3 weeks ago and results were 3 of 12 cores positive, [email protected]%, [email protected]% and [email protected]%. The G8 is in the right apex and all three positive cores are on one the right side (mid, base, and apex). PSA at time of biopsy was 4.3, up from 3.1 6 months earlier. I immediately requested the slides be sent to Johns Hopkins for. A second opinion. I got results from them, which I discussed with Dr Jon Epstein by phone, which reduced the G6 to a G8 @80%, so now 3/12 cores positive all G6. The 80% is driving me crazy.Dr Epstein said it didn't mean anything. My Urologist who did the biopsy, also fairly high profile, said it was "concerning" that one of the positive cores was 80%. And I read an interview in the Harvard Medical Newsletter (or whatever it's called), that said it is often just a matter of where the needle hit the tumor (Bulls eye vs glancing the side) which is what I was told by a knowledgeable member here. So I am getting different opinions. So first question, any thoughts on this ? Second related question. - I looked at the path report, and added up the total length of all the cores, then looked at the positive cores, their sizes and % of core cancerous. Then I did the calculation of what % of all tissue taken was cancerous (all tissue being both positive and negative cores) and I came up with a result that of all the tissue taken, 6.6% of the total tissue was cancerous. So my question is, aside from the fact that I am being OCD and crazy, is this calculation meaningful? I have been so vigilant, with regular testing over the last 5 years, a biopsy two years ago that was negative except for one core of high grade PIN, and PSA tests every six months for the last two years, and I am fearful that despite the care I took, I got it late, not early enough for full cure.

Posts.Content: Welcome football. I’m a die hard NY Jets fan, so take everything I say with a grain of salt.. Do you know if all of those psa’s In your history we’re done at the same lab, with the same Assay/method? PSa generally does not drop from 7.3 to 6.7 to 6.1. It is usually a slow steady rise. But if the tests are from different labs, they can’t be compared to identify a trend. So you might want to find that out. As chuck said, there is some belief that diet has a lot to do with PC. But no confirmed evidential proof. So I wouldn’t hang my hat on that if I were you.

Posts.Title: PSA. up again time to pull the trigger

Posts.Content: Does Gleason score and detailed pathology matter once the cancer is in the bones? Yes, and no, yes, it could determine how quickly it will might spread, but no, because there is nothing you can do to change it, and I don't THINK it would affect or rather, inform, treatment. Will we only know how responsive the cancer is to the hormone therapy by doing blood tests every so many months? you may also be able to tell, or maybe, get a feeling, based on whether his symptoms improve. But the Drs will go by the PSA Will the level at which his psa drops to have some bearing to his overall survival? i don't think so, but maybe someone else will chime in. I think what's more important is how long he remains respinsive to hormone therapy, and other treatments that follow once he becomes resistant (which could be years) The oncologist mentioned zytiga w Lupron (stampede) or chemo in the next couple of months. Is it better to do the chemo early? It really depends on his individual case. I think standard of care is HT alone at first, then chemo when HT stops working. But I also think recent studies have shown that chemo with HT helps the HT be more effective. He is seeig a top oncologist at the Cleveland clinic whom we haven't seen since being first diagnosed. I'd ask these questions of him if I could. Thx so much your dad is in good hands at CC, you should have confidence in his doc. A suggestion.... why not ask your dad to sign off in you being able to speak to his doc, get information, etc. if he and your mom are not informed, it's hard for them to be their own advocate, which is really important. You being on the forum, helps you help them. You should ask for copies of all his reports, biosy, imaging, PSA history, etc. keep them ina binder. Just a suggestion. Others may come up with different answers to your question, I'm not an expert in advanced cases (and NONE OF US ARE MEDICAL PROFESSIONALS). But I'm sure you are anxious for some responses to your post, so I wanted to respond as best as I could What I can tell you, is that even with G9, there are many treatments available. When one stops working, there are many others. Most often, advanced PC today is treated as a chronic disease. It's not a Death sentence. Your dad has a fight ahead of him. But it's highly likely that he'll be around for many years. Hang in there, Good luck and keep us posted

Posts.Title: Two Years Post Robotic - Life Gets Better

Posts.Content: Of the PC forums I’ve been on, this one has always been one of not THE most user-friendly and supportive forums I’ve been on. I’ve always considered it the more “warm and fuzzy” forum, of all of them. With that said, I think every forum evolves to its own biases. I do think this forum has a slight bias towards surgery, just as I think “the other” major forum, has a bias towards Radiation. But I don’t think anyone here intended to criticize the OP’s treatment choice. Least of all, Chuck. No forum is perfect, we should all accept that. But all ‘the forums I’ve been on, ESPECIALLY and including this one, are populated by a core group of guys who are active and are present to both be supportive and get support. That’s my two cents

Posts.Title: Cialis and Heart

Posts.Content: I posted this on another forum, apologies to some of you who may have seen it, but i am looking for answers so just pasting it here too.... So now i have a new problem. Has anyone ever experienced heart issues that turned out to be related to Cialis? I went to my longtime PCP today for a checkup, first since the surgery. My bloodwork was all perfect, (i did the bloods in advance of the appointment). Cholesterol was 136. Triglycerides 148, down from 300 in December, he did about 30 other tests, all normal, so i was feeling good going in. But i mentioned to him that i was having what felt like palpatations on occasion. He did an EKG, which showed an "extra heart beat". which i guess, is an arrythmia. So he did an echo cardiogram, which was normal. Then an echo stress test, which was "positive" whatever the f that means. He told me to stop the Cialis immediately, and he put me on a beta blocker, wants me back a week from Monday (i'm going away on vacation next week). He said, depending on what happens between now and then, he will possibly send me for a CT Angiogram to look for blockages. These palpatations started soon after my surgery, which is why i thought it might be related to the Cialis. But i called my surgeon and spoke with his NP, she said she had never seen a heart problem caused by Cialis. Said if i have to stay off it, they would probably recommend injections, whcih i really dont want. So now, i have PSA Anxiety (next test, one month), a probable limp dick, AND heart issues. I'm ready to shoot myself in the mouth. Seriously depressing. Just when i was starting to feel safe. I think my life expectancy has gone down dramatically

Posts.Title: Pathology Report seems OK or maybe not so OK

Posts.Content: With apologies to those whove already seen this on another forum, there are some really knowledgeable folks here that are not there, so Im copying and pasting with a few minor edits. So, in the face of a rising PSA, i am going to make a final decision about going ahead with SRT with or without Hormone Therapy after one more PSA which i will do the end of this month. My current PSA is .068 as of a month ago. For background, i had negative margins, however, my surgeon does a intra operative frozen section which is looked at by pathology, which showed a positive margin, leading to the surgeon to do further resection, to obtain final negative margins. I saw two prominent Radiation Oncologists who both advised that i should be treated now, saying that they felt 80% sure that the negative final margin actually did contain some cancer cells that were missed and wasnt really negative My surgeon thinks i should wait and do scans if i reach .2, which he says may never happen. So I recently asked that the slides be relooked at, and that i be informed what % of pattern 4 cells there was in the g7(3+4) which was the "dominant tumor" (1.1 cm) AND also what the gleason was at the positive margin in the frozen section, before the surgeon obtained negative final margins. Today i got the results as follows: The tumor shows approximately 5% of a Gleason pattern 4, with the remaining 95% pattern 3 And this: While the final margins are negative, the involved apical margin (part A (which was the frozen section)) showed Gleason pattern 3 at the margin So now, this new information gives me pause, and i am not so sure whether i should do SRT at such a low PSA. I do know that if I do SRT, I am now heavily leaning toward NOT adding Hormone Therapy to the mix. Any thoughts would be welcome. I feel like Im in never never land, I know there is no clear answer.

Posts.Title: SRT? Or No SRT. More Data From My Surgery 3 + years Ago

Posts.Content: With apologies to those whove already seen this on another forum, there are some really knowledgeable folks here that are not there, so Im copying and pasting with a few minor edits. So, in the face of a rising PSA, i am going to make a final decision about going ahead with SRT with or without Hormone Therapy after one more PSA which i will do the end of this month. My current PSA is .068 as of a month ago. For background, i had negative margins, however, my surgeon does a intra operative frozen section which is looked at by pathology, which showed a positive margin, leading to the surgeon to do further resection, to obtain final negative margins. I saw two prominent Radiation Oncologists who both advised that i should be treated now, saying that they felt 80% sure that the negative final margin actually did contain some cancer cells that were missed and wasnt really negative My surgeon thinks i should wait and do scans if i reach .2, which he says may never happen. So I recently asked that the slides be relooked at, and that i be informed what % of pattern 4 cells there was in the g7(3+4) which was the "dominant tumor" (1.1 cm) AND also what the gleason was at the positive margin in the frozen section, before the surgeon obtained negative final margins. Today i got the results as follows: The tumor shows approximately 5% of a Gleason pattern 4, with the remaining 95% pattern 3 And this: While the final margins are negative, the involved apical margin (part A (which was the frozen section)) showed Gleason pattern 3 at the margin So now, this new information gives me pause, and i am not so sure whether i should do SRT at such a low PSA. I do know that if I do SRT, I am now heavily leaning toward NOT adding Hormone Therapy to the mix. Any thoughts would be welcome. I feel like Im in never never land, I know there is no clear answer.

Posts.Title: SRT? Or No SRT. More Data From My Surgery 3 + years Ago

Posts.Content: Hope everyone here Is doing well. I thought Id update as I havent been here for a while... Just finished week 5 of SRT, and am in the middle of month 3 of a 6 month course of ADT. Regarding the radiation, with 3 weeks to go, no side effects to date other than being very tired but I think thats as much a function of getting up at 4-4:15 every morning to go into Manhattan for treatment, then working an almost full day. Other than that, no issues. One problem Ive had, only the last two days, is that even though I empty my bowels each morning at 5:30-6am, I start to feel a little gassy just before I get called in for treatment, and indeed, the last two days, right after treatment, when I go to empty my bladder, I have another (not insignificant) bowel movement, I cant let that continue, lest I end up with damage, so Ill start today, increasing the Metamucil and colace, frM 2 to 3 x a day. Also Ill eliminate salads for lunch, and eat less at night. I hope that works Other than that, no bleeding, no diarrhea, no urinary frequency, so thus far, Im blessed, I know its the last few weeks though, that this stuff starts. As far as ADT, I started on Firmagon, had 2none month shots, both give me a pretty bad reaction at the injection sight. So my RO switched me to Lupron, and it was so much easier. In the two + months that my T has been at castrate levels (5 - 6), the only SE Ive had is the hot flashes, and they are annoying but not unbearable. Other than that, nothing. No insomnia, fatigue, depression, more emotion, or any if the other side effects. When I started treatment my PSA was .08. The two monthly tests since I started have both been undetectable. But MSKCC tests only down to <.05, so I guess it could be anywhere from 0.000 to 0.049. But I know its probably closer to 0.00 and its because of the Lupron. 3 more weeks of treatment and one more Lupron shot, which will be a 3 month shot. Then I just wait, until T starts to rise, and hopefully PSA stays down. Hope this helps someone who may be about to start salvage treatment, and is concerned about side effects. Its really not bad as it sounds, for most men.

Posts.Title: Update on SRT + ADT

Posts.Content: I posted this on another forum, apologies to some of you who may have seen it, but i am looking for answers so just pasting it here too.... So now i have a new problem. Has anyone ever experienced heart issues that turned out to be related to Cialis? I went to my longtime PCP today for a checkup, first since the surgery. My bloodwork was all perfect, (i did the bloods in advance of the appointment). Cholesterol was 136. Triglycerides 148, down from 300 in December, he did about 30 other tests, all normal, so i was feeling good going in. But i mentioned to him that i was having what felt like palpatations on occasion. He did an EKG, which showed an "extra heart beat". which i guess, is an arrythmia. So he did an echo cardiogram, which was normal. Then an echo stress test, which was "positive" whatever the f that means. He told me to stop the Cialis immediately, and he put me on a beta blocker, wants me back a week from Monday (i'm going away on vacation next week). He said, depending on what happens between now and then, he will possibly send me for a CT Angiogram to look for blockages. These palpatations started soon after my surgery, which is why i thought it might be related to the Cialis. But i called my surgeon and spoke with his NP, she said she had never seen a heart problem caused by Cialis. Said if i have to stay off it, they would probably recommend injections, whcih i really dont want. So now, i have PSA Anxiety (next test, one month), a probable limp dick, AND heart issues. I'm ready to shoot myself in the mouth. Seriously depressing. Just when i was starting to feel safe. I think my life expectancy has gone down dramatically

I really think the Dr will tell me that with 5% grade 4vcells, I don’t need HT. BUT IF THEY TELL ME DIFFERENT, I will listen to them. I AM tempted to do HT, in the spirit if throwing everything at it to get. Cure. But I recall reading that studies show HT imparts a significant advantage only in advanced or high Gleason situations.
Posts.Signature: Diagnosed at age 64 (in November, 2014), PSA 4.3 Nov 2014 BX 3 of 12 cores positive original pathology G6 10%, G6 20%, G8 (3+5), 70%. Posts.Content: PSA came back at .082 Based on the past rate of rise. I was expecting something between .072 and .074. So Im a bit concerned. Six weeks ago, at my last blood draw it was .068, and 2 1/2 months before that it was .060. But whatever, seems to me that its time to treat. RO told me at .068 that he would be comfortable treating me without ADT if I prefer, but if it gets to .1, he would be much less comfortable. So I dont want to wait. Seeing the surgeon tomorrow, probably my last visit with him. IM WONDERING if the increased rate of rise means anything at this point.

Posts.Title: PSA. up again time to pull the trigger

Posts.Content: With apologies to those whove already seen this on another forum, there are some really knowledgeable folks here that are not there, so Im copying and pasting with a few minor edits. So, in the face of a rising PSA, i am going to make a final decision about going ahead with SRT with or without Hormone Therapy after one more PSA which i will do the end of this month. My current PSA is .068 as of a month ago. For background, i had negative margins, however, my surgeon does a intra operative frozen section which is looked at by pathology, which showed a positive margin, leading to the surgeon to do further resection, to obtain final negative margins. I saw two prominent Radiation Oncologists who both advised that i should be treated now, saying that they felt 80% sure that the negative final margin actually did contain some cancer cells that were missed and wasnt really negative My surgeon thinks i should wait and do scans if i reach .2, which he says may never happen. So I recently asked that the slides be relooked at, and that i be informed what % of pattern 4 cells there was in the g7(3+4) which was the "dominant tumor" (1.1 cm) AND also what the gleason was at the positive margin in the frozen section, before the surgeon obtained negative final margins. Today i got the results as follows: The tumor shows approximately 5% of a Gleason pattern 4, with the remaining 95% pattern 3 And this: While the final margins are negative, the involved apical margin (part A (which was the frozen section)) showed Gleason pattern 3 at the margin So now, this new information gives me pause, and i am not so sure whether i should do SRT at such a low PSA. I do know that if I do SRT, I am now heavily leaning toward NOT adding Hormone Therapy to the mix. Any thoughts would be welcome. I feel like Im in never never land, I know there is no clear answer.

Posts.Title: Question on soreness after operation

Posts.Content: This sounds like just normal healing. I dont think that you can extrapolate that because you've recovered from surgery fast in the past you should recover fast from this one. This is total plumbinb rearrangement. I sat on a donut when in the car, and in my recliner, for about a month. With that said, if it really is concerning, then call your Dr. You know your body better than anyone (but maybe not,, after this surgery)

Posts.Title: Almost One Month After Da Vinci Procedure-Pain Question?

Posts.Content: Regarding Newporters comment on outcomes being the same, this is what I was told today in a consult with RO at MSKCC. It seems that for early stage, low GLeason , cure rates are similar, with less trauma to the body. Side effects are different but seem to be more tolerable than SE's of RP. On the other hand, with RP, you get certainty on final pathology, and quick drop in PSA. My opinion after today's consult and my own reading, is that early stage, low GLeason PC , you do equally well with either decision, and it comes down to individual priorities. I still have not decided. DOING A 3T MRI next week then, with results I will consult one more time with surgeon and RO, then make a decision without ever looking back, and no regrets. As far as AS, that's a whole different ball of wax.

Posts.Content: I posted this on another forum, apologies to some of you who may have seen it, but i am looking for answers so just pasting it here too.... So now i have a new problem. Has anyone ever experienced heart issues that turned out to be related to Cialis? I went to my longtime PCP today for a checkup, first since the surgery. My bloodwork was all perfect, (i did the bloods in advance of the appointment). Cholesterol was 136. Triglycerides 148, down from 300 in December, he did about 30 other tests, all normal, so i was feeling good going in. But i mentioned to him that i was having what felt like palpatations on occasion. He did an EKG, which showed an "extra heart beat". which i guess, is an arrythmia. So he did an echo cardiogram, which was normal. Then an echo stress test, which was "positive" whatever the f that means. He told me to stop the Cialis immediately, and he put me on a beta blocker, wants me back a week from Monday (i'm going away on vacation next week). He said, depending on what happens between now and then, he will possibly send me for a CT Angiogram to look for blockages. These palpatations started soon after my surgery, which is why i thought it might be related to the Cialis. But i called my surgeon and spoke with his NP, she said she had never seen a heart problem caused by Cialis. Said if i have to stay off it, they would probably recommend injections, whcih i really dont want. So now, i have PSA Anxiety (next test, one month), a probable limp dick, AND heart issues. I'm ready to shoot myself in the mouth. Seriously depressing. Just when i was starting to feel safe. I think my life expectancy has gone down dramatically

Posts.Content: PSA came back at .082 Based on the past rate of rise. I was expecting something between .072 and .074. So Im a bit concerned. Six weeks ago, at my last blood draw it was .068, and 2 1/2 months before that it was .060. But whatever, seems to me that its time to treat. RO told me at .068 that he would be comfortable treating me without ADT if I prefer, but if it gets to .1, he would be much less comfortable. So I dont want to wait. Seeing the surgeon tomorrow, probably my last visit with him. IM WONDERING if the increased rate of rise means anything at this point.

Posts.Title: Surgery Scheduled for January

Posts.Content: Regarding Newporters comment on outcomes being the same, this is what I was told today in a consult with RO at MSKCC. It seems that for early stage, low GLeason , cure rates are similar, with less trauma to the body. Side effects are different but seem to be more tolerable than SE's of RP. On the other hand, with RP, you get certainty on final pathology, and quick drop in PSA. My opinion after today's consult and my own reading, is that early stage, low GLeason PC , you do equally well with either decision, and it comes down to individual priorities. I still have not decided. DOING A 3T MRI next week then, with results I will consult one more time with surgeon and RO, then make a decision without ever looking back, and no regrets. As far as AS, that's a whole different ball of wax.
